n. a small pack suitable for one-day tramps

She took the backpack off, put the framepack on, staggered a little. The daypack she perched precariously on her shoulders, but she knew she'd need her hands free. (Dec 28, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B1)

GEE He will put his daypack on the grass.. (1992,Going West,43)

BURDON I ate the half grapefruit and a piece of muesli bar remaining from my day pack. (1996,Hunting for DOC,17)

n. (Rural) [hunting and mustering] a small pack, holding provisions for a day's work. (See hillbag)

HOLDEN Much of the boned-out meat and prime cuts were carried in his pikau, an improvised daypack. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,188)

dayth¶

n. date

McGILL That's 1922,' said Kelvin.See the dayth above the tunnel.' Dayth' fordate', just like my brother Michael and Dad saying fillum' forfilm'. It is the Irish way, quite common in Kiwiland. (1985,G'day Country,97)

db drag racing¶

n.

A sport has even grown out of the super stereo craze. Called db drag racing, competitors park their cars side by side with a microphone mounted on the front seat. On the starter's orders, competitors crank up their stereos to full volume via remote control. The loudest one wins. (Jan 19, 2000,Evening Post,21)

DC¶

abbr. Detention Centre. [(prisoners')]

I am writing you this from D.C. which is what we call it but it is really Detention Centre ... . Its[sic] good training here ... If you go to Borstal everyone has been in more trouble so Iwould not like to be there. (Sep 1982,Landfall,143/261)

NEWBOLD There were lots of screws, not only from the prison but from the DC as well. (1982,Big Huey, The,214)

HARRISON `A tattoo done in jail. Or borstal. Or D.C.' ... Detention centre. Or remand home. (1981,Quiet Earth, The,153)

DCM¶

abbr. get the D.C.M.,to get the sack; be fired (`Don't Come Monday'). [ca1972 Oct 25 I suppose I'll get the D.C.M. in the pay packet on Friday.]

Hori', [the boss] says,the D.C.M. means `Don't Come Monday' You're fired, got the bullet and sacked.' (Jun 1963,Home Life,2)

de facto¶

n. A common-law spouse, as opposed to a de jure, or legally married one; one who has a permanent, live-in relationship with a partner of the opposite sex outside marriage. [ca1950 Wellington]

WATSON Even if it was my de facto husband. (1965,Stand in the Rain,108)

Radicals are not race-conscious. To prove this, radical girls like to have a tame Polynesian boyfriend/de facto to show off to their friends. (Jun 7, 1972,Salient,16)

de facto: mistress (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

GLEN Each one of the girls was quietly living with her own fears for husband, boyfriend, de-facto, children's and parents. (1980,Bush in Our Yard,116)

n. [(transf.).]

KNIGHT Dalton had previously captained the All Blacks against the Springboks in 1981 when ... Mourie had been unavailable. Dalton believed this question implied his role in 1981 had been that of ade facto and he judged this to be demeaning of both himself and his team. (1986,Geriatrics, The,9)

adj. of the nature of a common-law marital relationship

BAXTER ... Sarah filled/ a hedge-gap in Duffy's life,/ perhaps more as a burnt child/ than as a de facto wife: (1966,Collected Poems,350,1979 ed.)

The words de facto' are Latin and meanin fact'. ... In common parlance, a de facto relationship has come to mean a relationship where a man and woman live together as husband and wife buthave never been lawfully married. (Aug 4, 1982,NZ Truth,16)

included ... are births which arise from parents living in a defacto relationship. (1982,NZ Almanac,173)

de facto ... 2 n. NZ & Austral. (also de facto wife or husband) person living with another as if married. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,194) [NOTES: [Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 291; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 125]]

A man was alleged ... to have used his former de facto wife's kitchen knife ... to stab to death her male friend ... (Apr 7, 1987,Dominion,6)

In evidence, Mr Hoey's de facto wife, Mrs Julia Hunt, said Vogel had seemed wasted' at the party. She assumed he hadpilled up.' (Jul 24, 1987,Evening Post,6)

Drummer stabs de facto wife. Sickness beneficiary dies of stab wounds. (Jun 1987,Landfall,162/121) [NOTES: (Johnston)]

KOEA His de facto wife has misbehaved atChristmas and has given him severalpieces of her mind and much else. (1992,Staying Home & Being Rotten,20)

3 adv.

GLEN We went on to discuss the common practice of trying out a relationship, living together de-facto as so many young people do today. (1980,Bush in Our Yard,146)

de-bottlenecking¶

n. the removal of a bottleneck

This so-called "de-bottlenecking" study could reveal opportunities to lift production by up to 20 per cent, the company said... He added the de-bottlenecking was necessary given the group's expectation that demand for fuel will expand about 2 per cent a year. (Apr 30, 2004,Dominion Post,C2)

de-Cullenisation¶

n.

In the Labour camp, the unpalatable option is whether Labour's decline can be halted by a spot of de-Cullenisation. (Jul 9, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

de-factoing¶

n. living in a non-marital relationship

Isn't it grand that amid all the de-factoings and the one-night-lie-downs ... and the cynicism and the cool, a fellow can still ... ask a girl to marry him? (Jun 5, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,10) [NOTES: (Brian Edwards)]

de-kutu¶

v. to delouse. See also kutu. [(nonce)]

NATUSCH March 29 was spent ... on the way to the Waimakariri kaika, ... A pretty girl sat de-kutuing the head of her handsome admirer, popping the proceeds into her mouth. (1978,Cruise of the Acheron,103)

de-lethalise¶

v.

Long before the fancy renovations were made to the Wellington terminal, measures should have been taken to de-lethalise these areas. (Jul 20, 2000,Evening Post,1)

de-rail¶

n. illicit raw spirits.

HYDE It was Maori country, which meant no licensed hotels, but plenty of sly grog - the good stuff down to [129] de-rail, denatured alcohol and meths. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,128,1970 ed.)

de-wooling paint¶

n.

MACDONALD Generally there has been little change in fellmongering practice since 1892. Skins are still cold-water washed in `dollies' or paddles, deburring machines are no longer used, but the de-wooling paint is applied on a moving conveyor instead of on the piled skins. (1957,Canterbury Frozen Meat Company,69)

dead¶

adj. in the sense `exact (likeness, etc.)' (See cut,ring,rink)

adj. applied to a horse which will be (or has been) scratched, pulled (i.e. not allowed to run its best), or otherwise interfered with, so as not to start in, or to lose a race; a horse which does not try to win.

SCOTT [If he backed it] ... the horse would be `dead' in that particular race, and would win the next time of trying. (1900,Colonial Turf,90)

McCALLUM This big joker say to me, Listen, mate, that horse has got no show. He is dead.' I say,He is not dead. I can see him now and he looks very much alive.' He then say, `I don't mean he is dead that way, but he is not a jigger. He is going to be hooked, pulled and run into the ground.' Ibid. 32 He won't start. ... Dad backed him last week and he told Mum he was dead. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,24)

dead as a moa¶

phr. long dead (See moa)

dead as Ned Kelly¶

phr. [ca1920 p.c. Sep 1979 middle-aged woman, De Brett Hotel, Wellington. This was a saying of her father and an old aunt first heard c1920. `I wouldn't be dead for quids,' said by somebody enjoying himself.]

MASTERS `Dead! Dead as Ned Kelly. Just shows what the wrong kind of boose [sic] can do to a man. ... ' (1960,Back-Country Tales,172)

dead baby¶

n. [(boarding-schoolboys') ca1930 (R. Mason) Girls' Boarding-school, Auckland: chocolate tapioca. -->ca1941 N.C.C. Small Wanganui Collegiate: brown sinker with chocolate sauce. -->ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silversteam: brown blancmange.]

dead bird¶

n. 1898 MORRIS Austral Eng. 115/2 Dead-bird, in Australia, a recent slang term,meaning `a certainty'. The metaphor is from pigeon-shooting, where the bird being let loose in front of a good shot is as good as dead.

Aroncel, a nice filly.. was considered to be a 'dead bird'. (Apr 12, 1890,NZ Observer,15)

dead block¶

1 n. (Rural) a hunting area no longer populated with wild deer or pigs.

SWAN Dead blocks are repopulated with pigs which he liberates. (1992,Grunter Hunters, The,34)

dead country¶

n. . [goldmining; cf kindly country]

I am informed that Copper was obtained in rising, if so they have gone through it diagonally as elsewhere and lost it, the back or roof shows nothing but dead country destitute of copper or lode formation. (Jan 31, 1885,Nelson Evening Mail,3)

In the Aroha Subdivision, as in other mining areas of the Hauraki Peninsula, a distinction between kindly' anddead' country is made by miners. ... Kindly' country for each locality is country in which lodes of that locality may carry valuable ore, whiledead' country is country in which the lodes become barren and small, or pinch out altogether. (1913,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.16 (NS) 98-9) [NOTES: (Henderson and Bartrum)]

This morning it was 12ft. from wall to wall, but of this great width some 3ft. or 4 ft. was dead country not worth crushing. (Oct 14, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,2)

n. [figurative, sports - mainly rugby]

Messenger, however, was near at hand and saved a score against his side by kicking out into dead country. (Aug 26, 1907,Evening Post,7)

The Blacks were now making the game very interesting for the home team, and the ball was scarcely in play again before they were once more at their throats and were within an ace of scoring, Fihelly just saving by kicking into dead country. (Aug 5, 1907,Wanganui Herald,3)

An interesting race between him and Bisley resulted in favour of the Nelson man, who kicked the oval to dead country. (Sep 16, 1907,Marlborough Express,7)

Manawhenua continued the pressure, and when Walden failed to kick the ball into the dead country Williams dived over to score. (Sep 7, 1931,Evening Post,14)

Hicks secured and kicked to dead country. (Aug 5, 1914,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

dead fly biscuit¶

n. a fly cemetery

LELAND Dead Fly Biscuit see FLY CEMETERY (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,41)

dead ground¶

n. [mining]

Colors of gold have been seen right up to th eend, and Mr Cartwright has every hope that the next stope coming along will show a corresponding improvement, and there is every prospect of the reef making again over the piece of dead ground, to which I referred om an ealier report. (Nov 1, 1897,Thames Star,3)

Six or seven feet of dead ground separates the branches. (Sep 30, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3)

The most important feature to record for the time, is the sinking of a winze from the surface of the Homeward Bound claim, on a leader through a block of ground which was considered nothing better than "dead ground;" but from the commencement of the winze good payable stuff has been obtained . . . (Dec 13, 1870,NZ Herald,2)

No. 11 stope has been carried through the dead ground at the break, and the men at the time of my visit were stripping the reef on the seaward side. (Nov 7, 1883,Thames Star,2)

n.

CRUMP Dead ground? Yeah, dead ground is the country in hollows and between ridges that you can't see when you're looking at something a long way off, like those mountains there. Distances are very deceptive in this sort of country. You can travel all day towards a landmark and never seem to get any closer. Then bang, you're suddenly there. Something to do with dead ground I suppose. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,76)

dead man's bread¶

n. [The Mansfield use evokes a child's perception of all berries are poisonous':tall berry bushes' suggest tutu - red would barely fit that; `white' suggests ?? cotoneaster; ed. Murry 1923 dated 1916. [R. Hyde ?Tutu; ?Black (Deadly) Nightshade; ?Hinau; ?Tawa mistaken for karaka: cf the following where R.H. mistakes ?karaka and tawa:]

HYDE Karaka berries, purple, fell and rotted to nothing if the birds didn't find them. Ibid. 126 There was a dark trail, ... and a stream came with edgings of fine malachite ferns, ... Purple berries lay fallen, rich as damsons but not as big, and good only for the fantails ... Ibid. xx But ours [sc. leaves of history], darker, might cry, `Where is Selwyn? Where is Rutherford? Where is Katherine, with weeds on her grave at Fontainebleau, when what she really wanted was the dark berry along our creeks? (Don't you remember? We call them Dead Man's Bread.) (1938,Godwits Fly, The,89,1970 ed.)

MANSFIELD We were at home again beside the stream/ Fringed with tall berry bushes, white and red./ Don't touch them: they are poisonous,' I said./ ... And as you stooped I saw the berries gleam./Don't you remember? We called them Dead man's Bread!' (1923,Poems (various authors),47) [NOTES: 1916 Mansfield in 1923 Poems 47(To L.H.B. (1894-1915)]

dead man's fingers¶

n.

Consider the Stinkhorn. The Fairy Club or the the Shaggy Parasol Mushroom. The Slippery Lizard Tuft, King Arthur's Cakes, the brain [sic] Mushroom or the Dead Man'sFingers. (Dec 10, 1988,Dominion,3) [NOTES: (David Hill)]

dead man's watch¶

n. [(? naut. sl., WW1)]

MILLER As I was on Dead Man's Watch [on the troopship] I stayed in bunk till dinnertime. (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,14) [NOTES: 1917 Feb 5 in 1939 Miller Camps, Tracks and Trenches 14]

dead marine¶

n. (informal) an empty pint (beer) bottle; very common in NZ for `empty liquor bottle' (esp. after a party) from the 1870s; see beer shell.

Complaints had been received by the DeadMarines Department. (Dec 1, 1920,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual 45)

It is Town Talk... That the abnormal weather caused a lot of seasickness among usually tough yachtsmen... Perhaps this accounts for the large numbers of dead marines that have been seen in the harbour lately. (Jan 6, 1912,NZ Free Lance,26)

A huge burial mound for `dead marines', as it consisted of empty bottles. (1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,7/99)

dead marine n. N.Z. & Austral. inf. an empty beer bottle. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,286) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

WARD The writer was told that some of the Government officials helped in the good work by throwing "dead marines," in the shape of beer and ink bottles, out of the windows into the sea. (1928,Early Wellington,454)

So what's a few dead marines between friends? (May 14, 2002,Evening Post,14)

BAXTER The dead marines rolled down the stairsor spun from the top windows to plop intothe salt sober harbour. (1967,Man on the Horse, The,138)

BENNETT A quart bottle of beer is a rigger, and a pint bottle is a marine: doubtless neither of these terms is peculiar to New Zealand, but they are rarely, if ever, heard in England. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

One back street especially was a little of smashed glass and discarded "dead marines." (Dec 8, 1917,NZ Truth,6)

There was the "suicide," "dead to theworld," surrounded by defunct "marines,"and clasping in his hand a corkscrew. (Feb 13, 1904,Free Lance,12)

dead meat ticket¶

n. an identity disc, cf. meat ticket

MILLER Our Dead Meat Tickets (identity discs) were issued ... (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,15)

dead muzzler¶

n. a wind opposed to a ship's course. [1933 ?Eaddy ?? -->1939]

BAINES Here we found three schooners wind-bound, for the breeze that had brought us along so famously was a `dead muzzler' for them. (1874,Edward Crewe,160)

dead needle¶

n. get the dead needle from (someone): to get the cold shoulder from. [Compare get the pricker.]

I got the dead needle [from a woman]. (1949,It Was So Late,COLE) [NOTES: (`Blues in the Night')]

dead out¶

adj. dead drunk [cf naut. dead oh]. [1980 citation belongs elsewhere (deal to?)]

Magistrate: How much whisky can a man drink?' Witness (a hotel proprietor):Oh, it varies very much. Some men are `dead out' after three nips, while others can drink two bottles a dayeasy.' (Apr 23, 1910,NZ Truth,252/1/6)

BERRY Jim twenty-eight looking forty-eight, and Ben forty-eight pretending twenty-eight. Jim talking of bread, grass, acid, boob, screws and dealing to people, while Ben spoke of money, marijuana, LSD, prison officers, and good hidings. (1980,First Offender,147)

dead possum syndrome¶

n.

Another common problem in emergencies is what he calls "dead possum syndrome"; people look at the thing they are trying to avoid hitting - so inevitably hitting it. (Oct 1, 2001,Dominion,3)

dead ring¶

n. the exact likeness of [(the dead ring of, also the dead spit of, the dead cut of) ca1938 Havelock schoolchildren]

"Aw, they were grand! One fellow was the dead ring of you. Man (reminiscently), they could pull some ugly faces." (May 12, 1909,Otago Witness,73)

BALLANTYNE Bob said they were the dead ring of Gil, especially Gilbert. (1948,Cunninghams, The,72,1976 ed.)

You are the dead ring of that chap [Jiggs] in the skit in the back of the `Evening Post.' (Nov 15, 1952,Evening Post,9)

McGILL dead ring exact likeness; eg David Ballantyne, The Cunninghams, 1948, writing of the sons: They were the dead ring of Gil.' NZA. Akadead ringer', also US. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,35)

The full-brother to Little Pointer is acting good. He is the dead ring of his relation. (Sep 9, 1922,NZ Truth,9)

dead spit¶

n. the exact likeness [(the dead spit of) the spitting image[OED2 spit sb?. 3 the very spit of 1825-1886; EDD gen. dial. and EDD. spit, esp. in phrs the very spit of in most Eng. dials except SW.]] (See dead ring)

He is well proportioned, and the dead spit of his daddy, with legs like bars of steel; a few black splodges through his golden coat indicate the Stockwell strain, as the Duke of Westminster's celebrated stud horse Bend Or is marked similarly. (Aug 3, 1893,Otago Witness,30)

"Excuse me, sir, but, barring the whisker, you are the dead spit of a man I knew once, professor." (Mar 15, 1898,Press, The,2)

A TRAMP That horse ... is the `dead spit' of the steeplechaser Orangeman. (1891,Casual Ramblings,91)

MANSFIELD She's not like you - takes after her father?' ...No, she don't; she's the dead spit of me. Any fool could see that.' (1912,Stories,112,(1984 Alpers) ed.)

SLATTER ... he belted my bare bottom and shouted you're like your parents no damn good you're the dead spit of your old man. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,231)

LELAND look the dead spit: `Beaut baby! Looks the dead spit of his dad!' JUST ALIKE. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,61)

Everybody present fairly shook with laughter when this estimable person, having been asked how she could tell that the defendant was father of the child, replied: "I saw it two months afterwards; it had thriven wonderful, and it exactly resembles Mr------------ (the defendant). It's the dead spit of him-as if it had been cut off with a knife and fork. .." (1885,Thames Star,2)

It is a wonderful thing to be instantly recognised as a personage. For instance, there is an old bean at Home who is the dead spit of Lloyd-George. (Dec 20, 1919,Observer (Auckland),10)

dead stick¶

n. [(marbles)]

SUTTON-SMITH It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such asRinger, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/770)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

dead sticks daisy¶

n.

Downstream, where the Ashburton and Rangitata burst through their gorges onto the Canterbury plains, willow, lupins, and broom are already choking the riverbeds, usurping the silvery native cushion plants and the 'dead sticks' daisies. (Aug 2002,Forest & Bird,305/29)

dead throating¶

v.

What self-respecting style queen would be seen dead throating a brown stubby? (Nov 11, 1999,Dominion,13)

dead wool¶

n. wool plucked from the skin of a sheep dead through natural causes.

1 n. (Rural) wool that has been sloughed off or plucked from a dead sheep [ of value when wool prices are high.]

All wool not taken from live sheep is called dead wool. (Nov 21, 1868,Otago Witness,16) [NOTES: useful descriptions in this article]

`Dead Wool,' removed from dead sheep, has little commercial value and is never an important item. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,710)

MARSH When did we start buying dead wool? ... The smell of dead wool goes off when it is plucked. (1945,Died in the Wool,15)

Dead Wool: Wool plucked from a dead sheep. May contain cellular debris from the skin known as scud. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

McKAY Baxter's duties, as recorded in the station journal kept by the manager Mr Charlie Harris, were with the sheep, drafting, and picking over crutchings and dead wool in the paddocks. (1990,James K. Baxter,86)

MACINTOSH To speak of selling three sacks of dead wool and buying a vacuum cleaner ... (1974,Never a Dull Moment,11)

LOUGHNAN When sloughed from a dead sheep, wool is not classed as cast but as dead wool. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,16)

MACNICOL & TROTTER It was a very bad winter and many sheep were lost. They retrieved the dead wool, scoured it, and sent some to the Dunedin Exhibition. They won first prize for the Scoured Dead Wool. (1987,I, Duncan from Skippers,13)

WATT I told her I would be taking all the men and two pack horses next day to pick up some dead wool and would try to dig the horse out of the slip at the same time because I thought my saddle was still on it. (1990,Wild Horses & Me,141)

dead work¶

n. Preparatory work unproductive of ore or gold. [goldmining; used elsewhere - nb OED]

The weekly battery returns appears small, but the crashing leaves a very respectable margin of profit, which helps materially to keep down the burden of the cost of the dead work now going on in the mine. (Aug 18, 1888,West Coast Times,4)

If it is satisfactory, as for instance when the supervisor is able to assure the executive that the miner is engaged on 'dead' work necessary to open up a promising claim, his subsidy is confirmed. (Jun 11, 1935,Evening Post,9)

... while its close proximity to the vein would obviate the necessity of much `dead work' before the vein was reached. (1910,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.11 (NS) 37) [NOTES: (Webb, Mt Radiant)]

MAY DEAD WORK: all preparatory work on a claim - sinking shafts, driving tunnels, constructing a race - before gold-saving commences. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1962 ed.)

Most of the dead work is finished, and all hands will be chiefly engaged procuring quartz. (Apr 6, 1881,West Coast Times,2)

Like other engineers, he was doing some dead work, but hoped in a few months to get a return for the present outlay. (Jul 22, 1897,Thames Star,4)

The last time the tunnel closed 78 shores were necessary to reopen the works, and it would require more dead work if the tunnel is closed now. (Feb 9, 1920,Northern Advocate,2)

This tunnel is merely preliminary dead work which has no connection with the finished job; but all the same is absolutely essential to enable the job to be done. (Jul 19, 1926,Auckland Star,8)

dead zone¶

n. area dubbed "low employment location"

For a "dead zone", Tinui seems remarkably alive and kicking. ... A year ago Sunday Star Times visited the tiny Wairarapa settlement not long after it was designated as one of 160 "low employment locations" (better known as dead zones or no-go areas) by Work and Income, meaning that people could not move there and receive a benefit. (Mar 6, 2005,Sunday Times (NZ),A15)

dead-head¶

n. a free-loader

It is not no uncommon experience.. tofind two-thirds of a railway carriagecomposed of "dead-heads". (Dec 22, 1938,NZ Observer,9)

dead-house¶

n.

COOPER The body was then taken back to the dead-house. (Dec 17, 1867,Digger's Diary,23,1978 ed.)

2 n. [(?mainly Northland gumfields)]

... when the heroes of a hundred drunks' are helplessly prone on the floor [of a Kaipara bar] ... a couple of stretcher men speedily whip away thedead drunk' off to an outbuilding in the rear ... known as the dead house', there to sleep off the effects of the debauch. On one Sunday, 18 bushmen and gumdiggers were lyingheads and tails' in the deadhouse ... (Jun 10, 1876,Weekend Herald) [NOTES: 1876 June 10 Weekly Herald in 1987 Scott Seven Lives on Salt River 52]

SATCHELL [To publican] Where is the guest?'In the dead-house ... We have to put him in there at times; he won't keep out of the bar.' [? Main or additional meaning: where dead bodies are kept;backblocks morgue] (1902,Land of the Lost,15)

Dead House: A rough room with bunks round it, which was kept by country publicans to put the dead drunks in. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15)

REED ... and the `deadhouse', at that time [c1900] a necessary abjunct to every country hotel, wherein the paralytic drunks were thrown, is now known only in history. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,121)

THOMAS [Northland] If he became drunk enough [in the gumfields hotel the White Pig] to be a danger to himself or to anyone else accommodation would be provided in the dead house. This institution ... was a small, strongly built shed with no windows. Auger holes provided light and ventilation. The door was locked outside by a strong hasp and padlock. (1970,Way Up North,34)

dead-Kiwi bounce¶

n.

The only way out is up, and hopefully not via a dead-Kiwi bounce. (Aug 26, 2000,Evening Post,20)

dead-sheep hole¶

n.

It was found near the farm's dead-sheep hole about 300 metres into the paddock. (Jan 19, 1999,Dominion,1)

deadbeat¶

n. a person down on his luck [aka dead-beat, dead beat]

MEREDITH A deadbeat appealed to the owner for a job, and wouldn't take no for an answer. (1875,West Coast Gold Rushes,156,1935 ed.)

SATCHELL This [gumfield] is the stamping-ground of the dead-beats of the World. (1902,Land of the Lost,18)

CRADDOCK Rabbiters are not in the highest class of New Zealand workmen - in fact, as a rule, they are men who cannot keep steady at any other work, and are rather aptly called `dead-beats.' (1904,Sport in NZ,10)

If a hungry `dead beat' tried to strike one of Booth's hash foundries for a bit of tucker before he had earned about four times its value ... (Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8/1/7)

dead a.- dead'beat n. a person down on his luck. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,3)

dead beat n. man down on his luck, stone broke; completely exhausted. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

He had the appearance of being a deadbeat, owing to his rather shabby attire.  (Aug 19, 1896,6) [NOTES: not certain that this is NZ source - Jan]

deader¶

n. a dead fish.

That much-moustachioed officer sternly ordered Brown to take the deaders [the rotten 'couta] to the end of the jetty and hurl them back into their native element. (Apr 1, 1911,NZ Truth,301/6/3)

deadheader¶

n. someone removing dead flower heads from flowering plants

...the only movement of any significance comes from the rose garden where teams of dead-headers, some from as far afield as Geraldine, move slowly like priests down the aisles of plants, bestowing the benediction of their secateurs on the dead and dying. (May 10, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

deadhouse¶

n.

The "deadhouse" is a familiar adjunct toa bush pub. (Sep 3, 1910,NZ Free Lance,13)

deadly¶

adj. very good

see [Aviemore Visitors' Book] Fantabulous (Oct 15, 1966,Dominion,3/1)

deadman¶

n. a post

Where it is difficult to obtain ground hold for fence strainer posts, such as in swamps or rocky hill country, fences may be strained with a 'deadman', and the strainer post should be cast ... (1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,61)

1 n. (Rural) [fencing] a post placed underground to enhance anchorage of a strainer post.

Where it is difficult to obtain ground hold for fence strainer posts, such as in swamps or rocky hill country, fences may be strained with a 'deadman' ... (1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,61)

RIDDOLLS This method of anchoring is known as the "deadman." (1958,Farm Engineering,418)

.. a cheaper and less laborious alternative would be to use a treated timber post (or half a post) in place of the concrete slab, burying it to act as a 'dead-man.' (Apr 11, 1968,NZ Farmer,17)

Posts: 400 No 1 2.7m round posts, 700 No 1 3.0m half-round posts, 200 deadmen. [dead-man] (Jun 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,02)

deadman's arm¶

n. a steamed pudding or currant roll.

Oh you [bush-felling] contractors in black singlets and bowyangs, fuelled onspuds and mutton and pumpkin and rice and spotted dog or deadman's arm and black billy tea: perfect toast sopping with butter and Cocky's Joy (treacle): come into our art galleries, onto our stamps, wrap within songs, ... (Feb 3, 1985,NZ Times,5)

deadset¶

adj. definite

Right now, only one deadset certainty has been on top of his game from the start of Super 12 - Crusaders flanker Reuben Thorne. (May 6, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B2)

deal bag¶

n.

Police found three lsd tablets and 23 grams of cannabis in a "deal bag" during a search of the premises. (Apr 6, 1999,Dominion,3)

deal to¶

v. give a hiding or bashing to; to beat up. [(mainly criminals')]

NEWBOLD `Policeman' were plentiful, and already one inmate who had been seen talking to the screws about the matchstick affair had been dealt to. Ibid. 248 DEAL TO (v) Assault, beat up, damage, destroy. (1982,Big Huey, The,121)

If you think you're gonna get your beans ... [sc. to get beaten up] well, you don't want to have it dealt to you. (Apr 7, 1983,Dominion,7)

The week after the incident, she had overheard Carrington say he had dealt to' somebody and had seen him move his fists and saypow, pow'. (Jun 21, 1983,Dominion,4)

Britt had learned that a group of Rastafarians at the party had `dealt to' Miss Edwards and her friend Kim McFarlane. (Mar 28, 1984,Dominion,7)

`There were eight of them watching us getting dealt to and they did nothing,' Ms Stirling said. (Sep 2, 1986,Dominion,1)

Michael Morris of Wellington, says the term "deal to" sounds strange to him as a New Zealand citizen returning after 22 years away. He says he hears New Zealanders but never British people saying "deal to" and much to his surprise has also seen it in print here. He quotes a Lloyd Jones short story saying "... and the intervening coastline looked to have been dealt to with a meat cleaver".... That said, "deal to is accepted by Oxford's Dictionary of NZ English with plenty of citation. (Sep 10, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

The couple should drop the case. If they didn't they would be "dealt to". (Jul 29, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

v. [(transf.)]

Rugby Commentator [on Canadian Team] Most of the team that dealt to Tonga are still with it. [On the Canadian rugby team which had defeated Tonga] (May 30, 1987,TV1)

deal-fish¶

n.

In shape, [the family Trachypteridae] are usually long, deep, and very much compressed and flattened on the sides, so much so that their local appellations always embody some idea of these peculiarities - such as ribband-fish, lath or deal fish, band fish or blade fish, and also oar-fish. (1881,TrNZI,13/196) [NOTES: (Clarke)]

The Oar-fish, 12 to 20 feet long, with a high, flame-tipped head-crest (the elongated fin rays) is probably the sea-serpent of repute. Its pelvic fins are narrow, elongated processes, hence the name Oar-fish. The Deal-fish is much smaller, but of the same type, but we know very little of the habits of either of them. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,198) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 198]

AYLING RIBBONFISH (Dealfish) Trachipterus trachypterus ...The ribbonfish is similar to the oarfish but is much smaller.. (1982,Collins Guide,189,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] dealfish 1069-81 DEALFISHES 1069-85 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

In May, two rare pygmy whales were stranded further north on Waitarere Beach, and in February, a two-metre-long deepsea dealfish with saucer-sized eyes and a retractable mouth spooked walkers on Waikanae Beach. (Nov 18, 2002,Dominion Post,A8)

dealing to¶

n. (informal) a beating

[the bouncer] descended, seized one of the chaps and hauled him away ... for a dealing to. (Oct 1985,Metro,24)

deaner¶

n. (See deener)

death cap mushroom¶

n.

The death cap mushroom - which can resemble a puffball in its early stages - was small and brown with a green or brown cap and white gills. (Jun 4, 2005,Dominion Post)

death lily¶

n. descriptive for arum lily

You'll notice that grazing animals tend to leave these arums, callas, zantedeschias, call them what you will, alone because their poisonous leaves taste nasty. Death lily is one name Wellington Regional Council says has been applied to them. (Jul 6, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,9)

debt-dodger¶

n. First Echelon volunteer; see also debt-evader, wife-beater. [usu. pl. (WW2)]

BRUNO (Foreword) Certain near-sober First Echelon wife-beaters and debt-dodgers (1944,Desert Daze)

BRUNO (1948,Maleesh George,84)

McGILL Debt Dodgers and Wife Beaters First Echelon, 2NZEF, WWII, used derisively even by the volunteers themselves; perhaps originating from media comment at the time, Jim Henderson speculates (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,35)

Sinclair & Harrex The troops left home in three 'Echelons'. The first went to Egypt. As eager volunteers, they were labelled 'the wife beaters and debt dodgers'. (1978,Looking Back,215)

debt-evader¶

n. [(WW2) usu. pl.] (See debt-dodger)

FULLARTON 'Truth' said last week ... that this First Echelon was made up of debt-evaders and wife-deserters and out-of-works. (1946,We Walked Alone,62)

deburring¶

n. (See also burr)

MACDONALD Generally there has been little change in fellmongering practice since 1892. Skins are still cold-water washed in `dolllies' or paddles, deburring machines are no longer used, but the de-wooling paint is applied on a moving conveyor instead of on the piled skins. (1957,Canterbury Frozen Meat Company,69)

decile¶

n.

In scenario one, he has the top income deciles losing most government health, education and housing services and the middle deciles losing somewhat less, while those on lower incomes are left untouched. (Apr 15, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

My mother was a city person, didn't want to go on a farm, married a lower decile, so we have very little communication with the farmpeople. (Aug 10, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

2 n.

Even before cutbacks, the government spends less on the 10th decile than any other - and this despite the fact that the average top-decile household has more people in it than any other decile. (Apr 15, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

I have worked in low and high decile, rural and urban, and single sex and co-educational schools. (Jun 1999,North & South,16)

One of Don Brash's strongest areas of objection to "race-based funding" is decile funding, a way of helping the poorest schools that was introduced by National in the mid-1990s. (Feb 8, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C2)

Many lower decile schools have all but emptied out as parents shift their children to 'better' (read higher decile) schools. (Nov 5, 1999,NZ Education Review,7)

However, Mr McCully said the taxi bill was "clearly the result of decile funding"... Under the Education Ministry's decile scheme, schools from the lowest-ranked income areas - ranked decile 1A - get about $330 a year per pupil of special funding aimed at increasing educational achievement. Schools in the richest areas - decile 10 - get nothing. (Apr 3, 2002,Dominion,14)

She acknowledged that the wealthy decile 10 school had better resources than many. (May 16, 2001,Evening Post,3)

deck¶

n. a wooden platform outside a house [The word deck is given in the 2-volume Oxford in what seems to be the NZ sense of a wooden platform outside a house. It seems totally alien to the English experience. How many English houses have decks? Patios, yes but decks, no. Is it from Oz, California, S. Africa?]

Back home in New Zealand, I now look with new eyes on the explosion of decks, patios and outdoor furniture, mostly made from rain-forest timber. New Zealanders recline and drink their beer on wooden chairs on timber decks - timber that was the orang-utan's home. (Jan 26, 2002,Dominion,8)

A pregnant woman who fell two metres when a deck collapsed in Stokes Valley on Christmas Day believes an angel cushioned her fall. (Dec 26, 1997,Dominion,3)

[Advt]. Decking & Landscaping. 100x40 RAD H3 Decking. (Dec 30, 1997,Norwester,7)

decker¶

n. a double-decker tram. [(obs.) ca1930 Wellington Tramways (F. O'Brien)]

n. a hat [(obs.)]

Hence it is that when a humble general ink-slinger meets the turf scribe, his decker',hard-hitter,' or `cap,' is raised in reverential awe. (Jun 11, 1910,NZ Truth,259/4/4)

declamation¶

n.

The work, part of the $18 million Waitangi park development, includes wharf piling, excavation and harbour "declamation" ... (Mar 14, 2005,Dominion Post,A11)

Declaration of Independence¶

n.

The treaty which forms the base of all my proceedings was signed at Waitangi on the 6th February 1840, by 52 chiefs, 26 of whom were of the confederation, and formed a majority of those who signed the Declaration of Independence. This [sc copy of treaty] instrument I consider to be de facto the treaty, and all signatures that are subsequently obtained are merely testimonials of adherence to the original document. (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 17) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 25 Hobson to Bunbury in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 17]

decol¶

n. decolonisation

Julie and I have been running a theory course.. which is really a "decol" course too. Decolonisation. (Dec 1998,Mana,38)

decommoditise¶

v.

Literally, Zespri has "decommoditised" its kiwifruit by differentiating them from other countries'. (Jun 13, 2004,Sunday Star Times,D2)

decompensation¶

n. a reversal of compensation procedures

"While he had been able to compensate for the effects of other personal issues and stresses, this additional stimulus had the effect of causing him suddenly to decompensate, to the extent that he was no longer fit to drive."... The driver had been appropriately treated by the company doctor and the risk of his "decompensation" could not have been predicted... (Nov 1, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

decoy¶

v. (Rural) to entice an animal into a yard or hazard.

NEWTON The decoy pen was so situated that two or three sheep placed in it decoyed others on to the tip. (1949,High Country Days,102)

KERR They took an old trotting hack, Berry, to decoy the foal to the yards and tied it up. (2000,High Times in the High Country,124)

1 n. (Rural) an animal used to attract others into yards or across hazards. (See leader,Judas sheep,pet)

I would strongly advise making use of them [pets] as indicated as decoys. Thus when moving sheep, if the owner of the pet goes ahead with the decoy, it will be found there is little if any use for dogs or strong language. (Nov 1917,NZ Farmer,1238)

JONES I then took up about twelve very quiet cattle and used them as decoys to drive with the wild ones into the paddock. (1933,Autobiography of an Early Settler,45)

MILLS ET AL As the occasion arises he will hold a few sheep in the race to act as decoys to those which are a bit tardy entering the crush pen. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,77)

STACEY .. taking a small cut of about 50 sheep, I drove them partly up the hill and left them as decoys. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,107)

KERR To calm the nervy, a decoy would be tied up on the Bog Roy side, and a shepherd called 'the catcher' would run up, slip a lead over her and pull her across, or step over her, kick her bum and go maa-maa. (2000,High Times in the High Country,117)

decoy horse¶

1 n. (Rural) a horse used to attract wild horses into yards for breaking.

CHINN With every rider now concentrating on his duties, we drove the wild horses towards the station bullock yards where several decoy horses were quietly feeding (1963,Packtrack to Highway,74)

decoy mob¶

1 n. (Rural) [mustering of wild or bush cattle] a small mob of tame cattle to lead wild beasts.

SHARPE On a morning of brilliant sunshine I moved the decoy mob of young cattle slowly along the Big Bay beach. (1966,Fiordland Muster,89)

decoy pen¶

1 n. (Rural) a pen beside a dip or loading race where decoy stock are kept to encourage others.

NEWTON The tip, a small pen capable of holding 10 or 12 sheep, was situated a foot or so above and partly overhanging the dip. ... with the aid of a lever it could be tipped and the sheep sent slithering into the dip below. The decoy pen was so situated that two or three sheep placed in itdecoyed others onto the tip. (1949,High Country Days,102)

The decoy pen acts as an inducement for incoming sheep ... (Jan 1, 1929,NZ Farmer,24)

With side-delivery dips, often a decoy pen is used - on far side of dip. (Sep 30, 1940,Taranaki Daily News,23)

RIDDOLLS The tip platform extends from the sheep entry gate to the decoy pen gate. The tip platform consists of three parts - the frame, the tipping portion and the decoy pen. (1958,Farm Engineering,365)

Decramastic¶

n. a variety of roof tile [Suggested as possibly NZ, but found in California, Australia, and Jamaica.]

Dee¶

n. Pl. often the Dees; a policeman, esp. now a detective. see also demon. [[In fairly gen. use, but first recorded in NZ.]]

WHITWORTH These ... are gentlemen who give their talents and time to the paternal Government for a certain modicium [sic] of payment, and are as known D's. [check cit. ?D.s??] (1869,Comic Guide to Dunedin,27)

I was informed that the D's were hanging around that vicinity. (1895,Diary of Jonathan Roberts,18)

Wellington Detective Department showed a mean sort of spirit over Detective Sergeant Cassell's farewell. As is well known the popular demon' has been transferred to Napier, ... The uniformed branch of the police ... wished him all sorts of good wishes, but the other branch, theDees', was not represented, ... (Jul 22, 1911,NZ Truth,1)

I asked a young man what was the matter, and got the reply, `Oh, it's nothing! Only the d's pinchin a little piece.' ... I found that d's were detectives ... (May 1930,National Education,197) [NOTES: (C.J. Hickson)]

SAR GESON [Barman speaks] That and not letting that bloody dee bulldoze me. (1946,That Summer,74)

MUIR The bloody Ds told me she was ... bloody lucky she didn't get clink. (1960,Word for Word,252)

WATSON `Bloody bastards, those dees are,' said Tabetha. (1965,Stand in the Rain,90)

BAXTER The second day he was beaten up by the cops/ For telling a dee his house was not in order. (1979,Collected Poems,347,(1966) ed.)

MASON Sittin' there, broodin'. Waiting for the D's to catch up with him. (1974,Hand on the Rail, The,39,(1981 TS) ed.)

McCAULEY `See that dee though. He was right pissed off; He's gonna be after you, my son.' (1982,Other Halves,132)

McGILL & TILLEY We left as soon as the Ds arrived. (1980,In Praise of Older Buildings,18)

BAXTER Once a dee, always on the outer. (1967,Man on the Horse, The,152)

McGEE He'll do well in the force, he's got the same look as all those C.I.B. Dees - hard, cold, dead, as if what those eyes have looked at, or for, in people, has killed the light in them. (1981,Foreskin's Lament,69)

n. a D-shaped iron clip or loop on a saddle serving to carry suspended articles.

BARKER We were well mounted, and all our luggage consisted of my little travelling-bag ... and what is termed a swag' in front of F--'s saddle; that is, a long narrow bundle, in this instance enclosed in a neat waterproof case, and fastened with two straps to theD's,' which are the steel loops let in in four places to all colonial saddles, for the purpose of carrying blankets, &c.; they derive their name apparently from their resemblance to the letter. (1866,Station Life in NZ,82,1870 ed.)

Dee (d&emacr.), n. [Written also D.] A steel loop attached to a saddle, for suspending packages; - so called from its shape, which resembles the letter D. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2021)

BUTLER He rolled his Erewhonian dress and small toilet necessaries inside a warm red blanket, andstrapped the roll on to the front part of his saddle. On to other D's, with which his saddle was amply provided, he strapped his Erewhonian boots, a tin pannikin, and a billy that would hold about a quart. (1901,Erewhon Revisited,ch ii,(Everyman edn. 1932 (1960) 207) ed.)

STUDHOLME When not in use, whips were carried coiled up and fastened to the back `D' on the off side of the saddle by a short strap that could be quickly undone when required. (1940,Te Waimate,150,1954 ed.)

dee, D. n. D-shaped metal loop or clip on a saddle. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

2 n. (See cits; see also deeing)

R. GILBERD A ropey' will learn to snipe - which is a highly-skilled operation. The butt end of a clean-trimmed log is trimmed of angles. V's are cut at points opposite each other at the butt end (usually) and are connected by a Dee which runs round in a D from one to the other. In the Dee is laid astrop', a short length of cable with an eye in each end. The eyes are connected with each other and to a short chain by a shackle; and the chain is attached to `the rope' with a hitch. (1950,Personal Communication) [NOTES: R. GILBERD Okaihau]

DEE: A groove in the front end of a log into which a strop is fitted for hauling. (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

MOORE [The log] was hauled by wire rope or chain bridle. This was attached sometimes by cutting a D' in the top half of the nose of the log, or more often by two heavy spikeddogs' which were driven in each side of the log ... (1969,From Forest to Farm,42)

deed of settlement¶

n.

Ngai Tahu were granted statutory acknowledgement over the lagoon as part of their Deed of Settlement. (Feb 21, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

Ngai Tahu were granted statutory acknowledgement over the lagoon as part of their Deed of Settlement. (Feb 21, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

deeds land¶

n. land subject to the deeds system

deeds system¶

n. a system introduced in 1842 by the Conveyancing Ordinance providing for the registration of documents affecting land ownership [Jim Cameron writes: Largely historical. This system has long been almost wholly replaced by the land transfer system.]

The land transfer system contrasted with the older deeds system, introduced in 1841 as a reformed version of traditional English real property law whereby rights to ownership depended on the existence and validity of a chain of documents. The term title deeds derives from this. (Jan 1999,NZWords,1)

deeing¶

n. putting dees (n.2) into logs.

CRUMP During the next few weeks Jack learned about scarfing, backing, limbing, deeing, sniping, [etc.] (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,42)

deek¶

n. shortened form of "decoy"

We put out a couple of deeks [decoys] and just wait for them. (Dec 20, 2000,Evening Post,21)

deeming¶

n. having a narrow strip of private land to allow private access along waterways where public ownership does not exist

The Acland Report discussed various forms of "deeming", that is, having a narrow strip of private land to allow private access along waterways where public ownership does not exist. (Dec 3, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

deener¶

n. a shilling (piece); pl. usu. deener, when used with a numeral. [ca1950 (Wellington barber) used c1930-1935 ca1951 (P.S. Arden) `a shilling' used c1920 Auckland]

Following are other local money-names ... ls. - deener, bob, colonial robert or penny ... (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: (Letter from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

... grasping that piece of current coin known to wicked bookies and others as a `deener', he banged gaily on the counter and demanded its equivalent in the diet which sends its genial whiff about 200 yards down the street against the strongest gale. (Jul 20, 1912,NZ Truth,369/7/1)

Mug is a humorous sort, and seen after the race in question, he remarked, She has cost me about 60 googs, but I'll take my oath the squib will not cost me 61 (?) Not anotherdeener.'[punctuation sic] cf zwei-deener 'twopence' =2s. (Feb 27, 1909,NZ Truth,193/2/8)

I put the nips into one the other night 'n he came to light with a couple o' dener. (Sep 19, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,63)

We use midgic for a shilling, where the Australian habitually uses deener. (1941,NZ Slang,52)

We use midgic for a shilling, where the Australian habitually uses deener. (1941,NZ Slang,52)

SARGESON I'm on the beach myself, I said, but I can make it a couple of deener. (1946,That Summer,77) [NOTES: [reference to 1930-35]]

I couldn't even drink beer as I was down to my last deener. (Jan 1952,Here & Now,21)

deener ... n. (Sl.) shilling [Ital. denaro, money]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

DUGGAN Obol and diobol, the two in the one like a symbol of something. ... Two zacs to the deener, too. Nonsense. (1970,O'Leary's Orchard,130) [NOTES: (`Riley's Handbook')]

For the shilling bob was the most common nickname in use, but also recorded is deener. This latter name was used more widely in New Zealand and Australia than in Britain. The sixpence attracted many slang terms - tizzy, tanner, sprat, bender, and a kick. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

2 n. occas., and mistakenly, a sixpence [ca1940 Marlborough, -->ca1963 Auckland (V. O'Sullivan)]

3 n. a penny. [[Is Mackenzie mistaken here; or is this a shift of meaning? I have heard deener mistakenly used c1940s and 1960s fo sixpence.]]

MACKENZIE deener a penny (1980,While We Have Prisons,96) [NOTES: (Lag's Lexicon)]

deep ground¶

n. in goldmining spec. applied to places well below surface-levels; ground in which the gold-bearing material lay well beneath the ac surface.

MAY DEEP SINKING: putting down a shaft to tap a deep lead. No absolute figure can be given but `deep ground' usually required shafts of over sixty feet. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1962 ed.)

Large quantities of gold have been extracted from the ground at the rear of the township, and it is well known that several rich leads of gold run into the deep ground which the lessees are unable to work with the limited capital and appliances at their command. (Jul 10, 1888,Star, The,3)

Intelligent miners inform me that it would be an exception to get gold in this river drift, or on the reef underlying, also that it is an exception to get gold in the deep ground on the Arrow river. (Sep 14, 1888,Otago Daily Times,4)

To miners who are working deep ground this is not of so much consequence, as they can stack their dirt, if it is worth it, until an opportunity of washing it occurs. (Jan 18, 1869,West Coast Times,2)

This society was formed expressly to test the existence of gold in the deep ground, and their success has, therefore, a significance far greater than the mere value of what they themselves may obtain. (Apr 5, 1862,Press, The,3) [NOTES: The Deep Sinking Society!]

It has been an unusually fine winter, which gave the miners a good chance of working the deep ground, and the majority of the claims have paid well. (Oct 13, 1877,Tuapeka Times,3)

Deep Jay¶

n. deep jungle

But controversy over Eder's account of New Zealand soldiers killing Vietcong prisoners while on deep jay (jungle) patrol has sharpened public awareness for his book. (Apr 22, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

The "Deep Jay" in soldiers' parlancemeans out in the jungle. (Mar 19, 1995,Sunday Star Times,D5)

deep lead¶

n. a lead (alluvial deposit of gold along the bed of an ancient river) which can be tapped only by deep-mining operations. [goldmining]

PFAFF We had a claim ... over the terrace on a deep lead. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,146)

... the alluvial miners thought they were dealing with superficial alluvial deposits; ... Deeper workings showed that the beds dipped steeply, and the gold continued downwards, the conglomerates were then called `deep leads', probably in the belief that they resembled the deep leads of Victoria. (1933,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,14/272) [NOTES: (Macpherson)]

EVANS This dredge received its name from the fact that the McGeorge Brothers prospected for and found a new `deep lead' or layer of gold-bearing wash deeper down and separated from thelayer that other dredges in the area had worked upon. (1962,Waikaka Saga,39)

WOOD The downfolded remnants in the valleys now form the deep leads', the whitequartz wash' of many areas ..., while the gold from the ... sediments became re-concentrated in the younger terrace gravels and alluvium, or `younger drifts' of the miners. (1970,Gold Trails of Otago,81)

MAY Neither the development of ground-sluicing nor the tunnel claims made Ross and Donoghue's distinctive. The absorbing topic at `the Ballarat of Westland' was the deep leads. These produced the most imposing mining works on the West Coast and gave Ross a permanenceunusual for an alluvial goldfield. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,188,1962 ed.)

deep sea diver¶

n. a fiver, a five-pound note. [(prisoners') rhyming slang]

I had promised to give her a deep sea diver for the Duke of Kent. deep sea diver ... fiver (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

deep sea fishing¶

n. whaling from ocean-going ships as distinct from shore whaling [(whalers')]

TERRY [Whaling] is carried on in two ways - either by vessels that remain absent from their port for a certain period, which is termed deep sea fishing', or by establishments in the large bays ...denominatedshore-fishing'. (1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),241)

deep sea perch¶

n. Orange roughy [Hoplostethus atlanticus]

[species name] orange roughy .. [scientific name] Hoplostethus atlanticus other name(s)] deepsea perch (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

deep sea spotty¶

n. scarlet parrotfish

FISHER A number of Parrotfish (they do not live in schools) were following me around and picking up the broken off crayfish legs. The Banded Parrotfish is the most common in the shallows - it blends in with the seaweed - but deeper down the Sandaggers Parrotfish and the Scarlet Parrotfish, often called the `deep sea spotty', take over. (1977,Angels Wear Black,37)

deep sinking¶

n. the mining of deep ground or deep leads.

The deep sinking has not realised the sanguine expectations once entertained regarding it. (1862,Otago: Its Goldfields and Resources,18)

MUELLER The greatest drawback with beach diggins is, they are so quickly washed out. Unless they find gold in the Ranges, and have deep sinking, there is very little prospect of the diggers now at the Coast remaining long. (Jan 2, 1866,My Dear Bannie,100,1958 ed.)

MAY DEEP SINKING: putting down a shaft to tap a deep lead. No absolute figure can be given but `deep ground' usually required shafts if over sixty feet. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1962 ed.)

The Australian diggers soon found out, that hitherto only the superficial deposits had been worked, and that they had not yet come to the bottom', where ... the richest treasure was to be expected. They begandeep sinkings', and after having dug to a depth of about 130 feet ... struck a second gold-bed. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),113)

Deep South¶

n. usu. Otago and Southland. Contrast Far North.

MANTELL Mightn' mean anything but he comes from the deep south. Dunedin. (1980,Murder and Chips,150)

STEWART He was a South Islander from the deep South and he rolled his r's. (1985,Gumboots and Goalposts,67)

Gore was an unexpected eye-opener...; make sure this town is on your agenda when touring the Deep South. (2009,NZ Memories,77/2)

deep thinker¶

n. a member of later reinforcements. Contrast debt-dodger. [(WW2)]

HENDERSON Puzzled, we hear of Deep Thinkers'. A member of the 5th Reinforcements, nearing the last of the volunteer New Zealand soldiers becausethe rush to the colours' in this war was much more subdued, was heard to observe: Yes, I must admit I did some deep thinking before joining up.' From then to the end of World War Two, the 5th Reinforcements were known as theDeep Thinkers'. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,260)

McGILL Deep Thinkers Fifth Reinforcements, 2NZEF, WWII, from one saying: `I did some deep thinking before deciding to join up.' [Jim Henderson] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,35)

deep-sea end¶

n. the hold; to work in the deep-sea end, to work in the hold. [(watersiders') ca1949 Robert Lamb, Wellington]

deep-sea trevally¶

n. [Otago]

WILSON DEEP-SEA TREVALLY A name once used for Bream (Hyperoglyphe porosa) when they were common around Otago. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,60)

AYLING BLUE-NOSE WAREHOU Hyperoglyphe antarctica (Blue-nose grouper, griffins silverfish, bonita, deepsea trevalla) ... [302] They are caught regularly on hapuku long lines along with hapuku and bass and are sold as hapuku. (1982,Collins Guide,301)

Deepfreeze¶

n. [The operational name for the original 1955-56 summer pre-IGY US Navy Expedition to the Ross Sea and Antarctica, subsequently applied to later expeditions and, with the establishment of a Deepfreeze Base in Christchurch, applied in NZ to any US Navy or US Science Foundation operations or personnel associated with the Antarctic.]

There was a woman in Hornby, who only went for Yanks; she had three kids by different American fathers. Every spring Operation Deepfreeze servicemen flew in from Hawaii and Guam, and with each intake there was a new one to be crazy about; the one to take her away from all this, the flat dusty suburbs, the mean benefit and snooping social worker calls. (Aug 7, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

The [American] Ambassador said thesurface unit component of Task Force 43,which would carry on "ExpeditionDeepfreeze" would include two Navyicebreakers (Sep 19, 1955,Dominion,8)

There were rumours in Christchurch beforethe arrival of "Deepfreeze" that anunderstanding had been reached betweenthe New Zealand and American authorities... All this.. would not have been necessaryhad someone in authority had theforesight to issue a directive to theChristchurch and Lyttelton police aboutprocedure in the event of any of thepersonnel of "Operation Deepfreeze"getting into trouble.. in New Zealand.about maintaining shore discipline. (Dec 14, 1955,NZ Truth,15)

Operation Deepfreeze was planned in twostages. Deepfreeze I in the summer of1955-56 was to establish an airfield atMcMurdo Sound capable of taking the heavyaircraft that would ferry supplies to theSouth Pole base which was planned for thefollowing year... Deepfreeze II in 1956-57 was to see a permanent station builtat the South Pole. (1985,Antarctica: great stories,272)

Unfortunately the New Zealand Post Officeor Deep Freeze took it into their headsto collect the mail and send it on in afew massive loads instead of the usualdribbles on every plane leaving for theice. (1971,Penguin Summer,115)

n.

[Hdg] Deep-Freeze Moves Afoot...Plans are afoot to move some of theUnited States Deep Freeze Operations fromHarewood base. (Nov 10, 1987,Evening Post,00)

[Hdg] Police Not Told, How to Dealwith "Deepfreeze" Offenders. (Dec 14, 1955,NZ Truth,15)

MacFARLANE Was this topic traversed when you went tothe Deep Freeze briefing? (1991,Erebus Papers,113) [NOTES: Quoted from 1981]

YOUNG We promptly put them to work unloadingall the packs and sledge boxes from thecar and carting them in to the DeepFreeze desk... I had always loathed putting "housewife"; it sounded so middle-aged and staid.Besides, it would look quite daft on aDeep Freeze form. (1971,Penguin Summer,29)

Operation Deep Freeze base commander RonChrans said yesterday the pilot had toldAmerican controllers at McMurdo he wasmaintaining contact with Auckland airtraffic control. (Nov 30, 1979,Dominion,1)

HICKSON Mike Hatcher was in a Deep Freezeclubroom catching up on news from the icefrom some fellow Americans who had justreturned. Ibid. The first message from McMurdo to Deep Freeze Headquarters in Christchurch described the crash site as.. on thenorth side of Mount Erebus. (1980,Flight 901 to Erebus,36)

Deepfreezer¶

n. a member of Deepfreeze Expeditions

HENDERSON Since then the chapel has been added to and improved by various 'Deepfreezers'. (1962,One Foot at the Pole,128)

deepsea¶

adj. as an epithet in the names of fish [see: anglerfish, bombay duck, bristlemouths, butterfish, cod, dogfish, dory, flathead, groper, lizardfish, slickhead, smelt, snagletooth, soldierfish, spotty, trevall]

deepsea cardinal fish¶

n.

AYLING DEEPSEA CARDINALFISH Epigonus telescopus ... The deepwater cardinalfish ... is regularly trawled ... on the continental slope. The same species is widespread in deepwater in the Atlantic Ocean and has been caught and marketed commercially in Europe for hundreds of years. (1982,Collins Guide,212,1984 ed.)

deepsea cod¶

n. mainly a commercial name for ribaldo, aka googly-eyed cod

SORENSON COD, DEEPSEA (a) Scientific name: Mora pacifica (Family Moridae). (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Deepsea Cod. (c) Other common names: Morar; Googly-eyed Cod. (d) Principal localities where taken: Off Mana Island and off Island Bay (Cook Strait). (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,16)

deepsea flathead¶

n. Hoplichthys sp.

AYLING DEEPSEA FLATHEAD Hoplichthys haswelli ... It is impossible to confuse this fish with any other; a huge flat head accounts for almost a third of the total length of the fish ... (1982,Collins Guide,198,1984 ed.)

GRAHAM Deepsea Flathead Rhinoplichthys haswelli (McCulloch) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,112) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 112]

[species name] deepsea flathead .. [scientific name] Hoplichthys haswelli .. [other name(s)] spiny flathead, flathead (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] flathead, deepsea 1228-9 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

deepsea shark¶

n. [not a specifically NZ term; one ref]

[species name] centroscymus sp. .. [scientific name] Centroscymus sp. .. [other name(s)] deepsea sharks (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

deepsea soldierfish¶

n.

deer bed¶

n. a position repeatedly used by deer for sitting and cudding.

LENTLE & SAXTON deer bed: position repeatedly used by deer for sitting and cudding. These places often become slightly hollowed out. (1991,Red Deer in New Zealand,183)

1 n. (Rural) a hollowed ground position repeatedly used by deer for sitting and cudding.

LENTLE & SAXTON deer bed: position repeatedly used for sitting and cudding. These places often become slightly hollowed out. (1991,Red Deer in New Zealand,183)

deer crush¶

n. a stall to hold and treat deer

[Advt] Take the hard work and knocks out of working deer with a Newlands Deer Crush. This is a simple, maintenance-free, easy side-loading crush, requiring no power, designed for velveting. (Nov 29, 2002,Dominion Post,C10)

deer farm¶

n. [[Get cits.]]

deer farmer¶

1 n. (Rural) a farmer who breeds and grazes deer for velvet and/or venison.

FORRESTER The advent of the deer farmer was to bring a new era and another fortune for helicopter hunters. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,42)

FORRESTER In 1975 a group of deer farmers got together at Mr Peter Elworthy's property at Timaru and formed the first deer farmers' association. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,50)

The GIB will be acting as a source of funds to give deer farmers a majority shareholding in a new company formed to take over the operations of Challenge Venison. (Dec 14, 1988,NZ Farmer,2)

Early indications from deer farmers show that the Game Industry Board should at least remain or at best have more powers. (Oct 8, 1998,NZ Farmer,7)

Waikato and Bay of Plenty deer farmers will take part in the area's annual stag walk on Wednesday November 28. (Oct 26, 2001,Dominion,18)

deer farming¶

n.

Olly said this town had sawmilling, deer farming, a hospital, ... (1985,G'day Country,98)

1 n. (Rural) the breeding and grazing of deer for velvet and venison.

FORRESTER To tidy up warring, allow for deer farming, and include helicopters in the regulations, the Government instituted yet another Lands and Agriculture Committee ... (1983,Chopper Boys, The,24)

deer fence¶

v. (Rural) to build high fences appropriate to the containment of deer.

'I've been deer fencing ever since,' he said. (Nov 1, 2002,Dominion,C9)

One large paddock was already deerfenced and within six months the couple bought their first fallow deer ... (Jul 2001,Lifestyle Farmer,34)

Along with pioneers such as Wanaka-based Tim Wallis, Brian deer-fenced some of his lower hill blocks and began breeding captured deer for meat and the much-prized antler velvet used in Chinese medicine. (Feb 20, 2010,Your Weekend,8)

1 n. (Rural) a high fence of a prescribed height to contain deer, made with deer netting, high posts and netting gates.

FORRESTER I called at a deer farm to photograph a new, electric deer fence. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,72)

This property has it all. Flats, rolling views, good fertiliser history, deer fences, deer complex. (Nov 23, 2001,Manawatu Evening Standard & Property Guide,56)

deer fencing¶

1 n. (Rural) high fences used to enclose paddocks running commercially farmed deer.

Improvements include an immaculate 4 bedroom home, deer shed, woolshed and yards with deer fencing throughout. (Nov 23, 2001,Manawatu Evening Standard & Property Guide,56)

Several fencing options work well, including 'deer' fencing and low-cost hex-mesh. (Sep 1996,NZEF Times,2)

Excellent deer fencing, contour and water. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,102)

Deer fencing has provided summer work for the boys ... (Jul 10, 2002,NZ Deer Farmer,10)

He caught the hind and then realised he had one deer and no deer fencing. (Nov 1, 2002,Dominion,C9)

deer netting¶

1 n. (Rural) wire netting which is several metres in width, used for deer fences.

Clearing sale: .. bobby calf pen, deer netting, sheep netting ... (May 11, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,47)

deer puller¶

n.

These crosses [sc. greyhound-collie/terrier, etc], sometimes euphemistically called lurchers, areexcellent deer-pullers. ... Only with great lu ck and fitness... can the hunter be in on the pull with the knife. On the whole it is better not to have dogs so fast as to be able to pull deer unless you are going in for that line exclusively (Dec 1951,Here & Now,15)

deer shooting¶

n.

STRONACH We called it deer shooting, not stalking, and we were right. Stories of the difficulty of getting deer leave me cold. Stalking - trying to get a good head or one particular stag - may be difficult, but shooting deer when they are fairly numerous, as they are on many stations, is child's play. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,62)

deer track¶

n. [(deer shooters')]

In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both track and trail and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hardto follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between track and trail. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through The Tramper, I could not find deer trail used until 1944, but deer track occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime deer track still seems to be used far more than deer trail. (Sep 1958,Tararua,25) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

deer-culler¶

1 n. (Rural) hunter of feral deer.

NEWTON Deer cullers, men who shoot deer professionally for the government or an acclimatization society. (1947,Wayleggo,153)

FORRESTER This country now had deer-cullers with hot barrels ... (1983,Chopper Boys, The,23)

PICKERING When their numbers grew out of hand the government committed itself to doing something about it and so inaugurated the day of the government deer-culler. (1988,Hills, The,7)

deer-culling¶

n.

NEWTON Deer culling is one of the roughest and hardest of jobs, but it is a life with an appeal of its own ... (1952,High Country Journey,73)

SHADBOLT And when he was satisfied he could do no more, ... he went deer-culling for a year. (1959,New Zealanders, The,113,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (Paua Gatherers)]

MANTELL Tried different jobs, finally settled for deer culling. (1978,Murder in Fancydress,87)

HOOPER There had been a boy Parkin, who had wanted to spend a year deer-culling in the South Island; ... (1981,Goat Paddock)

1 n. (Rural) the shooting of feral deer by Government-employed deer cullers.

THOMSON But the hankering for a real job was with us, and as soon as we heard of the Gvernment's deer-culling programme, we wrote to Internal Affairs ... (1952,NZ Deer Farmer,31)

NEWTON Deer culling is one of the roughest and hardest of jobs, but it is a life with an appeal of its own. (1952,High Country Journey,73)

BEACH At this time I still had ideas of wanting to go deer-culling ... (1993,Over 30 Years Pig Hunting,17)

CURTIS I think a fair example of animal populations and the difficulty of control by limited numbers of foot shooters is illustrated in the history of West Coast deer-culling. (1997,Murphy's Law and the Hunter,124)

deer-fenced¶

adj. (Rural) [of an area or property] fenced with netting and wires to a height to enclose deer.

FORRESTER .. they would be released into the yards, and finally into deer-fenced paddocks, free for ever from hunters' guns. (1983,Chopper Boys, The,13)

Well tracked and fenced with front portion of 230 acres completely deer fenced. (May 12, 1993,NZ Farmer,32)

Wintering 7962 sheep; 30 acres deer-fenced .. wintering 2000 ewes, 1100 hoggets, 50 rams and killers, 120 breeding cows .. Fully deer-fenced .. 16ha deer-fenced which could easily be extended. [deer fenced] (Dec 1, 2000,Press, The,59)

defat¶

v. to scrape the fat (from rabbit-skins).

TRAIL The skins were turned inside-out, wired and defatted and then hung to dry outside in a warm, sunny spot. (1984,Child of the Arrow,98)

defaulter¶

n. conscientious objector

In the defaulters' detention camps, established at Strathmore and Hautu for conscientious objectors to military service, 230 men are at present accommodated. (Jun 1, 1942,NZEF Times,I/49)

Defence Force¶

n. (historical)

Mr. Mair, late Interpreter to the `Defence Force' (Colonial cavalry); ... (Dec 16, 1864,Ride Through Disturbed Districts) [NOTES: 1864 Dec 16 Meade Ride through Disturbed Districts in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 427]

deferred payment¶

n. (Rural) [sp. NZ use] the payment for land in instalments, 19th cent. [.. a legal phrase. Land on deferred payment';Deferred payment settler'; `Pastoral deferred payment.' These expressions in New Zealand have reference to the mode of statutory alienation of crown lands, known in other colonies as conditional sale, etc., i.e. sale on time payment, with conditions binding the settler to erect improvements, ending in his acquiring the free-simple. The system is obsolete, but many titles are still incomplete.]

Both the aim and the object of those who frame laws in favor of special settlements, free selectors, deferred payment, and small farm associations are admirable .. the example set by the Southland deferred payment selectors will no doubt open the eyes of our lgislators [sic] to some of the dangers of the present system. (May 1, 1880,Hawera Star,2)

An industrious and steady man of experience could start on a 100 acre deferred payment bush section. (Jul 1887,NZ Farmer,196)

.. before the Roads are better; and Road Board income is less than half what it was in the good times of high-priced deferred payment land, of large Government subsidies and before the capitalisation system had reduced income from deferred payment settlers to less than half its previous amount. (May 26, 1888,Egmont Star,2)

ROBSON The first block of land thrown open on the deferred payment system was the Toi Tois block, consisting of 5,000 acres. (1967,Bits and Pieces,68)

dehorning crate¶

n. a crate to hold animals during horn removal

[Advt] ...drench pump, calf dehorning crate, gas debudder... (May 5, 2004,Wairarapa News,30)

dehye¶

n. (informal) dehydrated food. [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

PICKERING The second dilemma for the cook is trying to make dehydrated foods not taste like dehydrated foods. Meat substitutes should be avoided, but faced with packets of risottos, chow meins, peas, soups, curries and flavourings, you would surely think that something else would emerge that would not inevitably taste like `dehye'. But you would be wrong. (1988,Hills, The,73)

delamp¶

v. [Internet search Feb 2006: used also in Austral, N Amer, Canada]

'You can also delamp - removing excessive or overly powerful bulbs,' says Australian green buildings expert Steve Hennessy. (Feb 4, 2006,Dominion Post,c11)

delayed telegram¶

n. (historical) a cheap-rate telegram, cf. letter-telegram, tannergram (see Morris).

VINCENT A system of `delayed telegrams.' (1885,Forty Thousand Miles Over Land and Water,158)

MOORE ... `delayed telegrams' [sixpence for 20 words] (1890,New Zealand For the Emigrant,173)

WILSON B. also sent me several messages, which they call here `delayed telegrams', because delivered by the postman with the letters instead of by special messenger, which would be costly. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,52) [NOTES: 1890 Jan 20 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 52]

I understand that no matter at what hour a delayed telegram is received the orders are, that it be not posted until after 8 o'clock p.m., which renders it impossible for the person to whom it is addressed to receive it before the following morning. (Jul 25, 1878,Otago Daily Times,3)

The merchant can order what goods he wants by post or by delayed telegram. (Aug 26, 1887,Mataura Ensign,6)

Under the old system many people substituted delayed telegrams for letters, because they realised that the prompt delivery of their communications was worth the additional cost. (Nov 22, 1900,Star, The,3) [NOTES: Year is incorrect]

The Telegraph authorities are so satisfied with the result of the delayed telegram experiment that it is probable that the system will be permanently adopted. (Apr 1, 1886,Star, The,4)

delec¶

adj. (informal) delectable [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

McGILL delec desirable, of person or thing, short for delectable; 1960s teen jargon; eg `Isn't Troy Donahue just delec!' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,35)

delicious tremblings¶

n. D T's, delirium tremens

... delirium tremens, or `delicious tremblings', as the digger's name is for this fell destroyer (1888,Rock Colonists,26)

delimbing machine¶

n.

Two loaders with long metal claws grab at a giant unruly woodpile, effortlessly flinging three- and four-metre saw-logs onto neat stacks or dragging entire trees to the delimbing machines at the edge of the skid. (Jul 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 64/104)

delivery muster¶

1 n. (Rural) a gathering of sheep on a property for sale [in order to assess their value.]

KERR Another reason to muster is to audit flock or herd numbers and value them when a property is sold. It's called a 'delivery muster.' (2000,High Times in the High Country,165)

delivery pen¶

1 n. (Rural) counting-out pen [where individual sheep are placed immediately following shearing. ]

.. every individual shearer had a separate shoot to a delivery pen. (Mar 1895,NZ Farmer,96)

demerit points¶

n. penalties incurred by motorists for traffic offences, expressed in numbers which when aggregated to a certain amount (currently 100 points) result in suspension of licence or disqualification from driving. [Jim Cameron writes: see Land Transport Act 1998, s.88. The British equivalent seems to be penalty points which are totted up.]

demi¶

n. a demijohn [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

51 The McRaes all used a family recipe and their whisky was better than the legal stuff.'Ah, beautiful stuff.' They used to take a demi in and leave it at the Winton Police Station as a Christmas present.'Some others just sold it raw - real poison.' (Jul 23, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

demijohn¶

n. once the popular container for beer, vinegar, etc., a usu. 2 to 5 gallon stoneware jar with a narrow neck, often encased in wickerwork, and often called peter, rigger; now replaced as anartefact and word by (half-gallon) flagon, jar. cf.

He had a demijohn of beer there, for them to keep dipping their whiskers in, ... (1927,Me and Gus,75,(1977 Gus Tomlins ed Sturm) ed.)

BEATTIE I remember him riding along with a demijohn strapped on his back and he met Alderman Gibbs who liked a drop and who asked him for a swig. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,46)

demo¶

n. demolition

[Hdg] Island Bay Bait Shed demo not settled yet. Last week we reported the Bait Shed in Island Bay was to be demolished. (Aug 10, 2000,City Voice,2)

Demo work in progress. (Nov 24, 2004,Ephemera) [NOTES: Construction notice at VUW]

demoiselle¶

n. damselfish.

DOOGUE & MORELAND DEMOISELLE ... Other names: Chromis dispilus. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,255)

At a depth of 160 feet, diver Jeff Pearch is surrounded by a shoal of demoiselles as he swims behind the branches of a long-armed red sponge. (Dec 29, 1967,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5/1) [NOTES: [OED2]]

WILSON DEMOISELLE A broken lateral line is the chief distinguishing feature of this neat little fish. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,60)

AYLING DEMOISELLE Chromis dispilus ... The demoiselle is a small schooling fish ... (1982,Collins Guide,236,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] demoiselle 1443 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

AYLING ONE-SPOT PULLER Chromis hypsilepis (Single-spot demoiselle, brown puller) ... [238] There is ...a single white spot on each side of the back ...One-spot pullers are common off south-eastern Australia ... and are now regularly seen off the north-east coast of the North Island (1982,Collins Guide,237,1984 ed.)

demolition party¶

n. [Cf house-trashing.]

Recent cases of `demolition parties' in the city have prompted landlords to call for more legal safeguards against malicious damage. (Oct 18, 1987,Sunday Star (Auckland),A6)

demon¶

n. Often in pl. the demons. A policeman, esp. a detective; =dee n2.; dinnies demons

[Bloke's patter] ... And a Demon' is aNark.' (Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,41/6/11)

According to a well-known Christchurch demon, the slang of three months in thieves' argot is a drag'.Critic' thought a 'tec was the `drag' when he pinched 'em (Aug 1, 1908,NZ Truth,163/1/5)
