The brand new rank was to be known as Detective-Sergeant,' ... Thedemon' upon whom this overwhelming honour was bestowed, was to receive the enormous increment of 6d per day house allowance, over and above common of garden `D's,' ... (Jun 17, 1911,NZ Truth,312/5/8)

PARTRIDGE Demon. 3. Cf. the C. 20 Australian and New Zealand c. or low sense (rarely in singular): a detective. Cf.: (1937,Dictionary of Slang,214)

When they got to the station a big demon walked into Joe's cell with his coat off. (Nov 1950,Here & Now,16)

PARTRIDGE (Usually pl.) A policeman: Australian: since ca. 1880: 1889, B and L, The demons put pincher on me',I was apprehended'; 1891, F and H; ob. They are the very devil' - from the criminal's point of view. Hence, a detective: New Zealand: 1932, Nelson Baylis (private letter); by 1935, also Australian; 1941 Kylie Tennant, The Battlers,Demons' or plain-clothes detectives'; 1942, Baker; extant. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,183,1961 ed.)

BAXTER I told a bloody demon, though he didn't understand, ... (1960,Collected Poems,215,1979 ed.)

Talk of demons' andjokers' being hooked' ... proved too much for Mr L.G.M. Sinclair, S.M., in Auckland Court. Te Atatu mussel curer, Benjamin Patrick Nathan, 28, explained.Demons', he said, were detectives. ... (Jul 30, 1963,NZ Truth,5)

WATSON `I had them demons really worried about you.' (1965,Stand in the Rain,96)

MORRIESON What sort of questions did the demons ask you?'The demons?' The police,' said Mervyn.The bulls'. (1974,Predicament,36,1981 ed.) [NOTES: [1930s-40]]

HILLIARD Bloody demon all right, plainclothes. (1974,Maori Woman,36)

The police, they are just doing their job; ... But it's all cool now. The demons they came in the pub and apologised for coming up to me all the time. (Dec 4, 1981,Dominion,1)

NEWBOLD DEMON (n) Detective. In the sense of an ordinary policeman, Australian since about 1880. As a detective, a New Zealand specialist usage since about 1932. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

NORGROVE The police!'Yeah, he wanted to get the demons in on the act.' (1987,Shoestring Sailors,14)

Demon of Dissension¶

phr. a description of Robert Semple

Bob' Semple - dubbedthe Demon of Dissension' by those who want the mob tame flunkeys - said at Waihi that New Zealand's Premier was being gushed over by the `snobs.' (May 26, 1911,Maoriland Worker,12/6/4)

Demon Post¶

n. a nickname for the Dominion Post newspaper

For the Dominion Post (or 'Demon Post' as the kids are calling it nowadays) to say outright that copying CDs .. is illegal is both fearmongering and foolish ... (Feb 17, 2004,Internet - see Notes)

The Demon Post editorial featured the Bucket Man again as they commented on this bylaw [making it illegal to sleep in public]. (Jul 7, 2003,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.stonesoup.co.nz/incremental/archives/2003]

deMondayised¶

adj. of public holidays, not restricted to celebration on the Monday on which they fall. (See Mondayise)

Occasionally such decisions are reversed and the word demondayized is heard ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,156)

demonstration farm¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm usually administered by the Department or Ministry of Agriculture, or an educational institution that demonstrates new methods and research results to farmers or aspiring farmers.

It was their business as the committee of a demonstration farm to test the efficiency of the different machines on the market before purchasing any particular make. (Dec 11, 1920,Hawera Star,10)

Mr Benoni White, of Mangorei Road, waited on the Taranaki County Council on Monday afternoon with reference to the establishment of a demonstration farm in North Taranaki. (Aug 2, 1924,Hawera Star,9)

He [John Baker] said the farms would be 'halfway between monitor and demonstration farms', generating as much discussion as possible on the system. (Feb 28, 2001,Manawatu Evening Standard,12)

demonstrator/demo¶

n. A vehicle or other object used as a demonstration model. [Peter Whiteford suggests that the usual term for this is "demos" leading to "ex-demos". The word does not appear in dictionaries in this sense until American Heritage 2. A product, such as an automobile, used for demonstration and often later sold at a discount and 3rd Macquarie 3. One of a line of products used to demonstrate the qualities of the line. Oxford and earlier US and other dictionaries tend to use demo for (1) a political demonstration and (2) a demonstration tape or recording.]

[Advt] Demonstrator Clearance Sale. Demonstrators, Almost brand new. Almost nothing on the clock. Falcons, Festivas, Escorts, Mondeos, the lot. All with factory new car warranties. (Jan 20, 1999,Dominion,13)

[Advt] Demonstrator Sale. 1999 Saab.... (Dec 13, 1999,Dominion,13)

[Advt] Significant Savings on Demonstrators... We know their history, we guarantee their future. (Nov 16, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B1)

demountable unit¶

n.

We had a look at a demountable unit, developed in the Hawke's Bay Education Board area. (1965,NZ Parliamentary Debates,342/387)

dempsey¶

n.

This would read "dempsey n. 1. an outrageous bluff designed to explain the unexplainable. 2. an own goal. 3. a bizarre suicide attempt assisted by legal advice. 4. an egregious joke. v.t. minimise the effects of an appalling error of judgment ((That nuclear bomb we just dropped on Paris, I had no idea these things could do so much damage.) (f. early 21st-century soccer administrator with too many lawyers and an irrational fear of fax messages)"...Charlie would simply stand his ground, and take the custard pies while reducing the nmedia to fits of laughter with a steady stream of prepared dempsies. For example, in explaining the millions of dollars being tossed away through public servants living in Auckland and flying to work in Wellington, the likely dempsey would be :"It prevents their being delayed on the northern motorway." (Jul 15, 2000,Dominion,20)

den to den¶

n. a children's game [(children's game) 1952 June 7 R. Mason letter (Wellington) Den To Den 1920 Pukekohe School A game played by the girls at Pukekohe School. The seats along the wall of the school and the seats on the opposite side of the narrow playground are dens. The players run across from den to den whenever they see a good chance to avoid being caught by whoever is it'. A player who is caught then becomesit' immediately.]

dental clinic¶

n. a state centre for the dental treatment of school children; shortened form of school dental clinic, the building (or room) usu. in a primary school grounds set aside for the treatment of first teeth by a dental nurse under the schools dental programme

A survey of Hamilton schoolchildrensuggests a visit to the dental clinic isno longer considered a trip to the"murder house". (Nov 6, 1993,Dominion,11)

The Education Estimates included GBP1000 with which to make start on a travelling dental clinic for country schools. (Sep 18, 1917,Auckland Star,8)

In numbers of Auckland schools children from Standard 2 upwards will no longer receive dental care at the School Dental Clinics ... (Dec 1952,Here & Now,30)

(1979,Heinemann Dictionary of NZ Quotations)

JACKSON Crouched under the lawsonianas by the Dental Clinic, a sense of loss ... seized me. (1988,Rainshadow,61)

KEITH She had an appointment that day at the school's "Murder House" - the dental clinic, with its treadle drill ably wielded by the dental nurse. (1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,24)

The first [cruelty] has been there for truly as long as I can remember: a small, weatherboard shed, which you hope might be used to store a lawnmower, rakes, spades, axes, a wheelbarrow, perhaps some firewood or bags of coal, but in fact is the Omanu Primary School dental clinic... The bell rang at three o'clock - my worst memory of school is being called to the dental clinic one afternoon at five to three. (Nov 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

...you will see such trouts in boarding schools, dental clinics and Social Welfare offices the length of the country. (Feb 28, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

The first dental clinic was established in Greytown on March 1st, 1928, the intention being to establish rooms in the schools at Featherston, Martinborough and Carterton, the nurse travelling to these schools in turn. (1961,Carterton District Centennial Celebration,13)

Hawera had been moving in the direction of having a dental clinic established, not necessarily in Hawera, which would serve a number of schools near the town. (Dec 13, 1923,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

For the rest of the day there was a constant stream of children to and from the Dental Clinic. (May 15, 1947,NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,3)

The teacher brings his class to the dental clinic - a suite of specially fitted up rooms in one of the central school [sic] . (Nov 28, 1904,Manawatu Times,2)

dental nurse¶

n. [aka school dental nurse] (See school dental nurse,dental clinic)

The number of dental therapists, formerly called dental nurses, has dropped from 860 to 500 since 1990. (Dec 22, 2004,Dominion Post,A1)

Another aspect of the less well-publicised parts of school life were the activities of the dental nurse of the time. (Feb 1989,North & South,34)

She was four-and-a-half years old when she got the first filling in her teeth. A big smiling dental nurse drilled out the tiny little bad bit ... (1974,Islands,9/271) [NOTES: Ghent (The Tooth Fairy's Dead)]

KEITH She had an appointment that day at the school's "Murder House" - the dental clinic, with its treadle drill ably wielded by the dental nurse. (1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,24)

Well do I remember.. the dental nurse..whose clinic was behind a huge, thick,chocolate-coloured painted door with aheavy brass doorhandle. (May 1992,North & South,41)

In 1929 a room for the dental clinic was prepared in the wooden school in readiness for Carterton to receive a visit from the Greytown domiciled dental nurse. (1961,Carterton District Centennial Celebration,13)

The first Dental Nurses School was established in Wellington in 1921, with 35 students. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,II/522)

The scheme.. provided for the training of dental nurses, who could treat the teeth of young children in the schools to which their clinics were attached. (1989,Illustrated Encycl. of NZ,299)

In the afternoon.. there was the dental nurse's lesson. (May 15, 1947,NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,3)

dental nursing¶

n.

ELDRED-GRIGG The real reason dental nursing appealed to me was that it was a chance to get away... Dental nursing would mean I could live in another city, far away from Mum. (1995,Mum,176)

dental therapist¶

n. a dental nurse

The number of dental therapists, formerly called dental nurses, has dropped from 860 to 500 since 1990... The Health Practitioners Competence Assurance Act, which came fully into force in September and allowed dental therapists to work in the private sector, was predicted to worsen shortages. (Dec 22, 2004,Dominion Post,A1)

Denver leg¶

n.

Luckily I had some of the world's best meat to work with - our own deliciously tender ready-chined racks of lamb and denver legs of venison. (A denver leg is broken down into all of its muscle cuts and has all the sinew removed so it's ready for use). (Apr 22, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

depart to/for¶

v. [1988 Oct 25 L. Bauer p.c. standard English would prefer DEPART FOR (Auckland); NZ English admits DEPART TO HWO NZE always LEAVE FOR; DEPART TO ?used only of people departing: DEPART FOR of vehicles when a destination terminus is meant -departing for Auckland station, airport etc.]

Department of Conservation¶

n.

An Act to promote the Conservation of New Zealand's natural and historic resources and for that purpose to establish a Department of Conservation. Ibid. 264. There is hereby established a department of State to be known as the Department of Conservation, which shall be under the control of the Minister. (1987,NZ Statutes,65/260)

It is an Establishment Bill to form the Department of Conservation, which promotes conservation of New Zealand's natural and historical resources. Ibid. 7883 I do not say that the officials form the Department of Conservation have had an easy job, because there has not been a department. (1987,NZ Parliamentary Debates,479/881)

Department of Conversation¶

n. a play on Department of Conservation

I know why the department [sc. Department of Conservation] is sometimes called the Department of Conversation. (Jul 22, 2004,Dominion Post,A4)

depasturage licence¶

n. the right, by payment of a fee, to graze stock on specified Crown land; = depasturing licence

When the selection [of the N.Z. Company share of the Otago Block] had been made the Crowngrant was to be issued, and there was an understanding that if Colonel Wakefield desired stillmore land he was to have it. This was the origin of what was afterwards known as thedepasturage licences, under which settlers were authorised to run cattle and sheep in the adjoining districts. Ibid. 138-139 Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,59)

depasturage licensing system¶

n.

HOCKEN Much of the country [in Otago] had been taken up as runs under the depasturage licensing system, ... (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,149)

depasture¶

v. to put sheep or stock to pasture.

... adapted for the depasturing of sheep. (Jul 1844,Nelson Examiner,235) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)1844 Jul D.Monro in Nelson Examiner in Hocken Contributions 235]

WANTED TO PURCHASE, 500 SCABBY SHEEP, to depasture at Rhodes Bay. (Jul 19, 1851,Lyttelton Times,1)

... certain parties have been Pig-Hunting on my run, between Mount Pleasant and Godley Heads - by which dogs my sheep there depasturing, have been scattered and several killed; ... (Jul 1, 1857,Lyttelton Times,1)

Farmers depasturing sheep near the confines of the borough are suffering severe losses by the ravages of dogs. (May 7, 1932,Oamaru Mail,6)

WOODHOUSE [Reproduction of official license application.] Application for Depasturing License... I hereby apply for a License to Depasture Stock upon the Land hereinafter described, subject to the 'Rules and Regulations for the issue of Licenses for the Occupation of Waste Lands of the Crown'. (1856,Blue Cliffs,4)

v. [1898 citation is of noun depasturing]

HOCKEN The rock here is a dry crumbling basalt, so that both the herbage and the natureof the ground are admirably suited for the depasturing of sheep. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,235)

A month later [April 1855] a Christchurch paper reported the discovery of "a plain of immense extent capable of depasturing sheep" - behind the mountains in which Mackenzie had been captured. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(10); 4)

Four horses were depasturing in the immediate vicinity. (Apr 26, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,16)

Mr. J.D. Enys.. while depasturing his flocks, gathered wild flowers on the mountains. (Apr 27, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

1 v. (Rural) to stock land.

Wanted to purchase, 500 scabby sheep, to depasture at Rhodes Bay. (Jul 19, 1851,Lyttelton Times,1)

C W RICHMOND We have just advised the Governor to assent to the new land regulations of the province under which pasturage leases will be granted for 14 years at a yearly rate of 1d. per head on the sheep depastured. (Jan 29, 1857,Letter,257) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

POTTS Years ago, on the Rakaia, the writer depastured a large herd of breeding cattle. (1882,Out in the Open,47)

HALL-JONES A.T. Clark depastured his sheep nearby. (1944,Kelly of Inverkelly,85)

depasturing¶

n.

It was assumed the Board had power to grant a depasturing licence to the Union Sash and Door Company. (Aug 16, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,15)

depasturing licence¶

1 n. (Rural) a lease licence for stock to be grazed and occupied on unused land [1800s.]

DEPASTURING LICENCE No. 111 `Whereas Alexander McNab of Knapdale has made application for a Licence to Depasture Stock upon the Waste Lands of the Crown ... Dated at Dunedin this 4th day of November, one thousand eight hundred and fifty six. ...' [Also frontispiece to 1984 Kerse (ed) The Knapdale Run] (1962,Waikaka Saga,88) [NOTES: 1856 Nov 4 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 88]

SCOTTER There was also [in Otago] the unsold land open for grazing. Each year, therefore, those who wished to graze stock on this open country applied for a depasturing licence - ... (1948,Run, Estate and Farm,15)

WHEELER A race for the Lands Office would follow, there to fill in a `Depasturing License'. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,1)

The Government was advised to issue depasturing licenses for large areas, which were called runs or stations. (1910,Tapanui Station,5)

WILSON & FRASER The tenure was by depasturing license. (1936,Book of the Pioneers, The,5)

The areas outside the surveyed districts were known as waste lands. This could be farmed under de-pasturing licence which was a 14-year term, subject to cancellation at any time and the fee was 1d a sheep. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,41)

HARTLEY The ambitious Sidebottom was issued with a depasturing licence for 75,000 acres by the Land Office in Christchurch on 1 May 1855. [de-pasturing licence; depasturing license] (1993,Colonial Outcasts: A Search for the Remittance Man,55)

depatch¶

v. to expel from a gang by removing the identifying membership patch. - [(gang jargon)]

If we find the ... people responsible, we willdepatch' [expel them from the gang] [sic] them and ensure they give themselves up to the police,' Mr Mamfredos said. (Dec 16, 1986,Dominion,1)

deposited plan¶

n. In modern times subdivisions of urban and rural land are defined in terms of a surveyor's plan lodged in the office of the currently appropriate administrative entity (Lands and Survey, DOSLI etc) and known as a deposited plan (DP). [Jim Cameron writes: Individual properties are lots on such a plan and so described on the title. Eg "[20 perches] more or less being part of section 32 Karori District and being Lot 4 on Deposited Plan 8018..." Note pre-metric NZ use of perch to define area. NSOD describes this use as "more fully, square perch ... now rare exc. hist". Until 1968 perch (never square perch) was standard in legal and popular use to describe the area of sections smaller than a quarter-acre.]

deprivatisation¶

n.

De-privatisation indicates a different social agenda at work. It is hardly a "great leap forward", but it is certainly pointing in a similar direction. (Jul 5, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

depth charge¶

n. [cf. dynamite pill. ca1941 boarding school and army]

Peters had seven `depth charges' - a pint of beer with Drambuie - and the manager, not realising that he was a guest, told him to leave. (Jan 19, 1982,NZ Truth,5)

derb¶

n. a cigarette

der/ derb; durb: smoke (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

O'SULLIVAN While Bob lay thinking then as now, that for a heavy smoker life indeed could be worse than keeping a gutter eye out for what his old man called derbs. (1990,Snow in Spain,24)

dere¶

n. a small valley or gully. [(WW1 Gallipoli)]

All the ends of the "deres" (gulleys) were stopped with countless lines of barbed wire. (Dec 1916,Roll Call,6)

WAITE [caption] AN EARLY VIEW OF ANZAC COVE. The mule lines did not stay long unmolested. ... They were then shifted up the deres for protection. Ibid. 318 Dere .. .. Valley with stream. Ibid. 286 Up the deres, great wire gates had been erected so that if the force was attacked the gates would be shut down ... (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,82)

derision¶

n. sleety bad weather; drizzle. Compare murk. [(Wellington trampers') ca1940 R. Mason Taraura Tramping Club, Wellington Usually stronger than `muck': hail, heavy cold rain, wind-driven rain generally holds some idea that human beings are at the mercy of the elements.]

PASCOE Of the crossing in blizzard conditions over Mounts Alpha ... I can only remember ... the surprise when Kime Hut flung itself out of the derision at us. (1952,Land Uplifted High,11,1961 ed.)

Derision has been an accepted term among trampers and climbers for at least twenty years for bad weather - cold, stormy and wet. Not too tropical is known to everyone for pretty chilly'. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,27</i>) [NOTES: Ruth MasonTrack and Trail']

dero¶

n. (informal) a derelict [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

He reckoned he would have to spend $10.000 each on the houses "and all the deros and wankers who've moved in there". (Jun 6, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

MOORE ... I took it [sc. a job] and rented a room in a shabby Ponsonby boardinghouse, which [18] I shared with `deros' and down-and-outers. (1987,Hard Labour,17)

JACKSON Outside the Hotel Hollywood,the deros sat in the gutter amidst broken glass. (1988,Rainshadow,170)

SCOTT It was the room of a person no longer bound to life, an old derro, impersonal and final. (1988,Glory Days,98)

I know most of the deros by sight and Isay hello to them. (Oct 1992,Metro,126)

derrick¶

n. a euphemism or hypocoristic in occas. use for penis'. [ca1935 Havelock To children. ca1950 p.c. James K. Baxter, Wellington:fairly comm]

derris dust¶

n.

Her father used similar powers in the garden: 'He showed me.. how you taught.. the bugs and insects that they didn't have a place on the pieces of vegetables that we ate.' She adds that 'a bit of derris dust' also helped. (Apr 9, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

derry¶

n. to have (occas. get) a derry on, to have a strong dislike for or aversion to.

WRIGHT They hadn't such a derry on the bloke upon the track. Ibid. 58 I ain't down on them if they aint got a derry on me. [1945 Glossary Derry - another word for dislike or aversion.] (1897,Station Ballads,30) [NOTES: (The Swagger)]

Now, I think if you leave England alone, and just look after your own country, you will find plenty of matter in it to fill your paper, including immorality. You seem to have a derry on the Home people. (Jun 1, 1912,NZ Truth,362/7/4)

derry n. sl. prejudice.-to have a derry on to be prejudiced against, have a `down' on (playfulallusion to hey derry down derry,' as refrain of old songs). (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

BENNETT Another familiar variant is to have a derry on', derry being a substitute for down, apparently from the association of the two words in the refrainderry down', `to have a derry on blowflies' is to have a strong dislike of them. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90)

BALLANTYNE [She] had had a derry on that crowd ever since Hilda took her to an evening service. (1948,Cunninghams, The,63)

derry, to have a v. have an aversion to. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

derry n. NZ & Austral. have a derry on hold in disfavour. [song refrain derry down, cf. DOWN] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,201)

Derwent potato¶

n.

The Derwent potato, for which North Otagowas at one time famous, has almostdisappeared. At time a tuber of thevariety is to be obtained, but it is apoor apology for the mealy, fullflavoured sort that was so abundantduring the year[s] 1864 to 1885. The lateMr. Hassal, of Cave Valley, brought themearly into prominence, and they weredistributed over Otago as the Cave Valleyflour balls. (May 15, 1916,Rangitikei Advocate,8)

Derwenter¶

n. Occas. used for an ex-convict (from Tasmania). [(hist.)]

ROCHFORD Here [in Canterbury] we engaged a new steward ... who I think was a Derwenter, from what I have since seen of them. [fn] Derwenter: convict; so called from the River Derwent in Van Diemen's Land. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,16)

Derwenter n.pr. emancipated or released Tasmanian convict. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),614)

Desert Gold¶

n.

Many an instructor whiles away the wearyfew minutes devoted to "Smoke O" bydiscussing the merits of Desert Gold, andthe price Carbine was sold for. (Apr 18, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/16 : 87)

You want to see them at it [sc. workinghard]! They remind me of "Desert Gold." (Jul 5, 1918,Christchurch Girls' High School,IV/47 : 247)

Desert Road¶

n.

Chionochloa rubra, the red tussock, is the species that imparts the rich, red-brown colour to areas bordering the Desert Road and other tussock grasslands. (Aug 27, 1999,Dominion,14)

Wait till the worst days of winter areupon us and the Desert Road is dangerouswith snow. (May 30, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),24)

The Desert Road was only half an hour away from where we were staying in the mountains and I just jumped in the car and headed there... (Jul 4, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),25)

desert sore¶

n. [(WW2)]

LATHAM The juice was necessary for the troops from the desert whose `desert sores' were a form of scurvy caused by lack of fresh fruit and veges. (1986,WAAC Story, The,23)

2 n. (fig.) A medal (ribbon) (?Africa Star)?; ??a wound stripe.

HENDERSON The man on the Wellington tram looked at my black and white New Zealand shoulder- titles. He looked at my Desert Sore' ribbon.Where did you get wounded, soldier?' (1945,Gunner Inglorious,110,1974 ed.)

designer lettuce¶

n. (coloured) lettuce used for decorating food

And so, franbkly, is the food, big plates of honest-to-god grub. None of that designer lettuce stuff here. (Oct 3, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),27)

destock¶

v.

LINZ is failing to protect the public interest, It allows grazing to continue of tussockland and shrublands which should be destocked... (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

destocking¶

n. [OED has this but only in the sense of a grocer destocking his shelves. The Australian and S African dictionaries do not have it but Webster's Third has it as African in the senses of removing livestock from an (overgrazed) range or pasture. (second and third citations belong with the verb to destock)]

[His] farm is carrying only half its usual number of ewe hoggets... Further destocking will be necessary if there is no respite next month. (Jan 28, 1999,Dominion,2)

Farmers have been de-stocking since September, shedding animals they calculated were unsustainable before Christmas. (Jan 31, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C3)

Farmers have been more responsive this time and have been de-stocking, and a lot of cattle have been moved. (Oct 29, 1999,Dominion,11)

1 n. (Rural) the removal or sale of stock from a farm property [often as result of drought or flooding.]

.. if it is a dryland property, destocking in the summer months is a typical strategy. (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,Aug/Sept 43)

detective¶

n. an over-inquisitive person [(prisoners')]

NEWBOLD DECTECTIVE (n) Over-inquisitive person. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

detention dam¶

n.

MACLEAN They were dry, 'detention' dams designed for storing floodwaters to prevent the inundation of the Wairarapa Plains. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,236)

deucer¶

n. [(shearers')]

BOWEN DEUCER. A shearer who regularly shears or tops the tally of two hundred sheep a day. (1956,Wool Away!,156) [NOTES: (Glossary: Shearing Terms)]

Deutz¶

n. a sparkling wine

Deutz followed in 1987 and Lindauer went on to become the company's biggest brand. (Oct 14, 2001,Sunday Star Times,E5)

Development Farm¶

1 n. (Rural) a government-sponsored experimental farm, where bush, swamp and poor soils are developed into pasture.

The Department of Agriculture has Pedigree Stock for sale at its several Farms as follows:- Ruakura Farm of Instruction, Hamilton East, Central Development farm, Weraroa, Moumahaki Experimental Farm, Waverley. (Jul 1923,NZ Journal of Agriculture,20 xv)

development right¶

(the right to develop land commercially) n.

Ms Mahuta said her constituents would be upset if the Government extinguished customary rights and economic development rights that flowed from them... Maori commercial development rights was just one of the issues. However, Miss Clark said officials' advice was that "a development right is not a customary right". (Dec 12, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

deviation¶

n. a road (or rail) detour, now commonly used of any (esp. new) formation which deviates from an old route. [ca1952 July 27 R. Mason reports: A speaker at the Tararua Tramping Club meeting said: `That was when the deviation was put in on Middle Ridge.']

WRIGHT [County Council minutes] G. Pott was authorised to ... lay off a cutting and procure estimates for a deviation north of the Mimi Bridge. (1989,Clifton,15) [NOTES: 1885 Mar 1 in 1989 Wright Clifton 15]

DOUGLAS ... but the new deviation will be beyond the funds of the county council, as I expect ... (Jan 30, 1894,Letter) [NOTES: 1894 Jan 30 Douglas Letter to Roberts in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 209]

Dryden was acting under the instructions of Mr Furkert, the engineer in charge of a gang of men engaged on `The Deviation' on the Waiouru section of the North Island Main Trunk line. (Oct 7, 1911,NZ Truth,7)

Connection of the Wilson deviation to the main railway line ... (Jul 3, 1952,Evening Post,10)

CONSTRUCTION of the South Rangitikei railway bridge, north of Palmerston North, is getting close to completion. The 300-metre bridge is the longest of three on the nine kilometre Mangaweka deviation, ... The deviation is being constructed to eliminate a steep winding section of the North Island Main Trunk. When the project is completed late next year the new deviationwill replace the old Mangaweka Viaduct, ... (Dec 29, 1980,Evening Post,28/1-2)

devil¶

n. often pl., a European or settler not considered favourable to missionary interests [(hist)]

...the natives were quite surprised to see so many white men going to Mass when none go to Turner's preaching - men to whom the missionaries gave the name of devils." (Turner was a Protestant missionary.) (Jun 2, 2002,NZ Catholic,5) [NOTES: Written by Thomas Poynton about 1838]

MATTHEWS Of great numbers of our countrymen I truly say that they are the vilest of the vile; and such Europeans are distinguished by the name of `devils' by those natives who know them.' (Apr 8, 1839,Matthews of Kaitaia,121)

(Letter from E.J. Wakefield) ... the rangatira missionary will come out along with the devils, as the missionaries have kindly christened every European not of their own cloth. (1840,NZ Journal,1/16/202)

WAKEFIELD Turoa made another speech at me; saying that he wanted the devils, and not the missionaries, who had told him lies, on his land ... [ibid Mar31] ... what was the meaning of the word Devilwhich [the missionaries] had chosen to apply to all pakehas but themselves. (Mar 29, 1840,Diary) [NOTES: 1840 Mar 29 (1839) E.J. Wakefield MS Diary]

To those whom Mr.Coates terms unprincipled colonists', the natives are taught to give thename ofdevils'. (May 25, 1840,Letter) [NOTES: 1840 May 25 (Port Nicholson) Joseph Somes to R.Vernon Smith in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 143]

n. a small cake

devil n. a small cake of flour and water baked on hot ashes; ... (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

2 n. a Maori unconverted to Christianity.

BIDWILL A Dunedinite, Michael Abbott, is pitting himself against the worst that the wilds can throw at him ... It sounds rather curious to hear a native, in answer to a question as to whether he is a missionary or not, reply quite coolly, `No, I'm a devil!' (1841,Rambles in NZ,44,1952 ed.)

JAMIESON The unconverted tribes of the interior [of the North Island] receive the appellation of devils. (1841,New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW,262)

All the Mauries about there were Missionaries ... my party ... were all Devils' (a term to be explained thereafter) 1841 May 30 <i>Ibid </i>319 In fact Hospitality is the universal attribute of all white menDevils' (a term used to distinguish them from the members of the Mission) residing in New Zealand, ? (Apr 3, 1841,Journal of Ensign Best,284,1966 ed.)

HEAPHY An old native, from whose ear a large shark's tooth was hanging as an ornament, on being questioned by me as to the danger to which they were exposed while in the water from those animals, replied, that the missionaries had told him that the converts need be under no apprehension of danger from them, but that thedewaras' (devils) or unbelievers would certainly be devoured.' ... On being answered in the negative, he appeared satisfied; at the same timecomplaining, that the missionaries did not treat him with due respect, but called him a `devil,' because he would not be converted. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),53)

ANGAS Those natives who are still heathen are generally styled devils' by the Christianized people; and they themselves adhere to the [153] appellation. Hongi Hongi, ... in answer to my inquiry as to whether he was amihorari' or a pikopo'(Catholic), confessed with evident delight that he was adevil'. (1847,Savage Life,2/152-153)

Devil River Volcanics¶

n. Geol. definition [Used internationally, usually referring to outstanding antipodean examples.]

Thus there is a general similarity in colour and symbol for the Waingaro Schist and Devil River Vocanics (hd and hw), the Karamea Granite (ko) anad the Onehau Granite (so). (Jun 1972,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,32/27)

devil weed¶

n. spurrey

HILGENDORF SPURREY (Spergula arvensis) is frequently called yarr, and in Marlborough, devil weed. It is found as a serious weed on [cold, sour] cultivated land in both islands, ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,80,1967 ed.)

devil weed [=] Mexican devil: mist flower: spurrey [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,21)

devil's claw¶

n.

devil's claw [s] Proboscidea louisianica (Mill.) Thell. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,21)

devil's darning needle¶

n.

SALE I surmise from their size and general colour on the wing that they are probably what somesimply call large dragonflies, or others name more colourfully Devil's Darning Needles, or Horse Stingers (or, in Scotland, Flying Adders). [92] ... My book on native insects says the `darning needle' nickname derives from a tradition that the dragonflies sew up the ears of delinquents. And that a Maori legend records a chief who dispatched an army of them (he would have calledthem kapokapowai) to destroy an enemy and all his habitations. (1982,Four Seasons,91)

devil's dice¶

n.

DAVIN So when I wasn't reading any novels I could lay my hands on I was filling myself up with Gordon's Mining and Engineering and Miner's Guide and back numbers of the Mines Department's annual reports, the New Zealand Mines Record and all the rest of it. Before long I could have written you a dictionary from adit to winze and what I didn't know about dredges, hydraulic sluices, alluvial mines, lodes, faults, throws, heaves, slides, blocking out, stopes, dollies, devil's dice and drills could have gone on the back of a halfpenny stamp. (1959,No Remittance,47)

devil's finger¶

n.

HILGENDORF DOAB (Cynodon dactylon), often called Indian doab or Doobj, Bermuda grass, five finger, and devil's finger, is a twitch very common in the North Island. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,40,1967, p. 40 ed.)

devil's fingers¶

1 n.

HILGENDORF SUMMER GRASS ([Panicum] sanguinal[e]), also called crab grass, finger grass, devil's fingers, five fingers and summer paspalum, is a weed of garden and cultivated lands ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,25,1967 ed.)

2 n. a fungus

MARTIN We have a number of black fungi of which the CHARCOAL FUNGUS (Daldinia), the black but White-fleshed DEVIL'S FINGERS (Xylaria), ... (1929,Flora NZ,42,1961 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN XYLOSPHAERA POLYMORPHA, devil's fingers. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,10)

devil's grip¶

1 n. (Rural) a pronounced dip behind sheep's shoulders that allows moisture to drain from fleecewool, preventing rotting of the wool.

HENDERSON Drainage of moisture into the fleece may be helped by a pronounced dip ('devil's grip') behind the shoulder and drainage may be hindered by a broad flat back. (1868,Growing Better Wool,60)

Devil's Henchmen¶

n. a mainly Pakeha bikie gang

Behind one set of palisades are the Devil's Henchmen. Inside the other are the Road Knights. Both are motor-cycle gangs, mainly Pakeha. (May 11, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

devil's highway¶

n.

HAAST With every step, the effects of the enormous glaciation become more manifest, all mountains and hills have not only the roche moutonnee[e1-acute] form, but glacier shelves at different altitudes and lying one above the other, are cut deeply into the hillsides. Some of these are so regular that the settlers have called them carriage roads, devil's highways, or by some similar epithets. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,121)

devil's missionary¶

n. (historical, derogatory) a name applied to a pre-1840 European. Compare devil 1.

WAKEFIELD [The low whites] really deserve a name which has been given them - that of `Devil's missionaries.' (1837,British Colonization of NZ,31)

They [sc. low whites] really deserve a name which has been given them - that of `Devil's Missionaries.' (1839,Voyage of the Beagle,61) [NOTES: 1839 Voyage Adventure and Beagle 61]

[Low types, vagabonds, etc.] `devil's missionaries' as they were [??are chk] appropriately called. (1839,Colonial Gazette,29/474)

WARD There are upwards of two thousand British subjects now settled in different parts of the islands, of whom several hundreds consist of a most worthless class of persons, - such as runaway sailors, convicts who have escaped from New South Wales and Van Diemen's Land, keepers of grog-shops and other vagabonds of dissolute habits; who ... practise fraud ... promote and take part in wars ... have infected the natives with disease and a taste for ardent spirits. They really deserve a name which has been given them, `Devil's Missionaries.' (1840,Information Relative to NZ,108)

devil's purse¶

n. Clathrus cibarius, = basket fungus, fairies' closet.

CLATHRUS CIBARIUS, THE BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously asbasket fungus,'lattice fungus,',Devil's purse,' tutae whetu,'tutae kehua,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand] (Dec 1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/247) [NOTES: (Cunningham)]

devil's snuff box¶

n.

In my boyhood days we used to call these ripe puff-balls "devil's snuff-boxes" because when kicked or suddenly compressed they emitted a puff or little cloud of brown dust. (Jun 24, 1924,Otago Witness,66) [NOTES: This is from GM Thomson - therefore may be speaking of UK]

devil's stink egg¶

n. = basket fungus (cf. devil's purse)

HYDE `It's a toadstool. It's a Devil's Stink Egg. You'll turn black in the face and die.' (1938,Godwits Fly, The,107,1970 ed.)

devil's thorn apple¶

n.

HILGENDORF THORN APPLE (Datura stramonium), often called devil's thorn apple, is not uncommon in gardens and waste places in good soil as far south as Canterbury. It is an annual growing 2 feet or more high; ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,154,1967 ed.)

devil's thorn apple [=] thorn apple [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,21)

devil-on-the-coals¶

n. a small damper; see also beggars-on-the-coals. [(hist.)]

devil-on-the-coals n. small quickly-baked damper. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

devil-weed¶

1 n. (Rural) Spergula arvensis, a pasture weed usually growing in out-lying areas, also known as yarr or spurrey.

The weed sent is yarr or spurrey (Spergula arvensis) a very common weed on cultivated land. It is especially serious in Southland among winter-sown cereals, and is frequently termed 'devil's weed.' (May 20, 1914,NZ Journal of Agriculture,547)

'Oh yes, I know it,' said Mr Ward, 'it is spurry, or better known perhaps as the Devilweed.' (Apr 10, 1920,Hawera Star,7)

CARR There must have been about 100 acres of pasture on the steep hillside, with here and there a clump of bush and quite an area of devil-weed. It was all manuka here, about six to seven feet high, but gave way to devil-weed and fern in the gully, as we crossed over onto the first ridge. (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,14)

SALE .. even the fluffy flowers of the Mexican devilweed have a glow ... (1987,Country Diary,87)

CARR We all peered at the vista of bush gullies, fern patches, stands of kanuka and devilweed - real pig country. [devil's weed] (1997,Wild Boars of Oruaiti, The,14)

devils on horseback¶

n. prunes in a blanket of bacon

Other menus include prunes instead of dates, a morsel known as devils on horseback that has never gone out of flavour. (Jul 10, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

devo¶

n. (informal) a deviant [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

I'm not a devo [deviant] trading in hardcore porn, but thats the label that's been applied. (Apr 23, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

Devonport whitebait¶

n. anchovy

McDOWALL The anchovy - the so-called Devonport or Northcote whitebait - is easily distinguished by the lower jaw which is distinctly shorter than the upper. (1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The,21)

Devonporter¶

n. resident of Devonport, Auckland

Paddingtonians, like Devonporters, know which side their real estate bread is buttered on. (Jan 9, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Devonshire tea¶

n. scones with jam and cream served with tea or coffee. [compare Devonshire cream (Devonshire in England)]

McLauchlan ed. 'When the trees are topped,' she said, 'this will be one of the warmest spots on the section, and it could be set up for barbecues, maybe Devonshire Teas.' (2000,Morrieson's Motel,145)

dew nappy¶

n.

McGILL Fred has the pensions' used for fantan, round metal discs with a square hole in the middle, and adew nappy', the ivory half-ball that the game was played with. Pensions were put on the four corners of the card, or points between, and two people took the bank. Even money was paid on the corners and three to one in the middle. There would be several hundred pounds sometimes waiting on the half-roll of the dew nappy. (1980,Ghost Towns of NZ,93) [NOTES: Check with DMcG whether he means to refer to fantan or to a game dew nappy.]

dew neck¶

1 n. (Rural) a fold of loose skin or flesh extending from the jaw to the brisket in an animal.

WHYTE Dew neck can not be tolerated in a dog. i.e. a fold of loose skin or flesh extending from the jaw to the brisket. (1927,Sheep-Dog, The,88)

dewimpify¶

v.

John has run firewalks throughout New Zealand, in order to dewimpify physics. (Dec 1999,North & South,129)

dezoning¶

n. the removal of school zoning

Hence, dezoning has worked a treat for middle-class parents and the top layer of low SES families who have managed to move up the education ladder into middle-class schools, but has been very bad news for the bottom 20 per cent who have been stranded in "sink schools". Ibid. 46 The job's become much tougher since dezoning: "When they eliminated zoning, all the kids that could.. shipped out.." (Apr 1998,North & South,40)

dfc¶

abbr. direct to customer [Radio 17/2/2003: Mistake for dtc?]

DHB¶

abbr. District Health Board

Ballooning budget deficits could jeopardise plans to establish district health boards during the next six months... "There is significant risk of dhbs being unable to meet public and political expectations in their first six months of existence." (Dec 29, 2000,Dominion,2)

I am told district health boards (DHBs) are having trouble getting good people on to committees... The deposed Health Funding Authority's flexibility to manage its budgets by shifting funds between service areas and regions and build up a risk reserve can't be copied by the much smaller DHBs. (Jun 3, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C6)

dial-a-powhiri¶

n.

Laurie lets out an impatient groan. "That sounds to me like dial-a-powhiri and I think that's insulting to everyone because it's not being done properly," she says. (Feb 4, 2006,NZ Herald,22)

dial-again leader¶

n.

"He is not one of your so-called dial-again leaders." (Oct 15, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Dover Samuels, Nine to Noon]

diamond¶

n. ellipt. for diamond-back(ed) flounder. (See flounder)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SAND FLOUNDER ... Other names: Rhombosolea plebeia; diamond, tinplate, dab, square; patiki (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,216)

MORELAND SAND FLOUNDER [Rhombosolea plebeia] ... Other names are dab, diamond, tinplate, and square. The Maori name patiki, originally generic, is now loosely used for most flounders. (1967,Marine Fishes,32)

1 n. (Rural) a diamond-shaped stock yard with gates opening to four other yards and often to two races.

HARTLEY Working in the confined space of the diamond, the young dog inclined to bite will quickly take advantage of the opportunity afforded. (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,43)

From the diamond, through the crush pens, the drafting race and the full length of the main race, all have been concreted. (Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,35)

DU FAUR .. it is a good idea afterwards to let fifteen to twenty-five sheep at a time into the pen, preferably the diamond or race-filling pen. (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,152)

SALISBURY Mr Williams was most fastidious when culling his two-tooth ewes. We would have to put seven in the diamond at a time, while he stood in the yard with a long thin manuka stick on which was tied a small bag of crushed raddle. (1994,I Was So Lucky,36)

GORDON The race is empty, then so is the crush and if you haven't patched the gate, so is the diamond ... [diamond pen] (1996,Trouble with Stock Agents, The,40)

Diamond Dinks¶

n. see Dink

diamond fish¶

n. (See diamond)

WILSON DIAMOND FISH A species of sand flounder. See Flounder. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,50)

diamond flounder¶

n. = sand flounder

Many people claim that the flesh of the sand flounder is the best and sweetest of all our flatfish ... -->(?)Otherwise known as the diamond or dab flounder, it is easily distinguished by its diamond shaped body . (Dec 8, 1982,Evening Post,37) [NOTES: check cite]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] flounder, diamond 2284 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

diamond pen¶

n. a diamond-shaped pen which channels stock from receiving yards on to their destination

BOWEN Receiving yards. These must have the capacity to take incoming mobs. They communicate with the forwarding yards, or diamond pens, which are much smaller, and lead up to the crush pens or forcing pens. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

diamond-back moth¶

n.

PERRY Of late years ... owing to the attacks of the aphis and diamond-back moth the rape crop has been a precarious one to grow, ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,70)

SHOT-HOLE MOTH, DIAMOND-BACK MOTH, CABBAGE MOTH. (Plutella ruciferarum). (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,591)

Diamonds¶

n. (usu. as the Diamonds) an Auckland-based netball franchise competing in the National Bank Cup.

...the Shakers can still make it given their remaining matches against the lower North Island Flyers, the Auckland Diamonds and the Otago Rebels. (May 10, 2004,Dominion Post,D1)

Dianella nigra¶

n. turutu, inkberry

MOORE & IRWIN DIANELLA NIGRA. Turutu, blueberry, inkberry, or whistles thrives in lowland scrub, on clay banks, and along bush tracks. ... The reddish leaf-base leaves a yellow scar when broken ...; often it is folded into a tube so that skilful blowing can force air out in an ear-splitting whistle. Shining berries, ranging from palest grey to almost purple, or clean blue and white like old china, ripen in great numbers but they drop at a touch; ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,182)

[caption] Dianella nigra, commonly called turutu or inkberry,... Turutu is distributed throughout the North and South Islands, where it can be found on the forest floor and bush edges. (Feb 4, 2006,Dominion Post Indulgence,18)

Dianthus armeria¶

n.

Deptford pink [s] Dianthus armeria L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,21)

TAYLOR DEPTFORD PINK (Dianthus armeria) European biennial. ... Deptford pink grows in scattered places on stony, sandy or pumice soil, ... (1981,Weeds of Lawns,49)

diarrhoea bags¶

n. knickerbockers

McGILL diarrhoea bags knickerbockers; recalled in NZ Oral History Unit Martinborough study. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,35)

diaspora¶

n. the overseas dispersion of emigrant New Zealanders

This is where the diaspora comes in. It is our insurance policy against isolation and Erewhonitis - and why it's possible to stop spooking ourselves about people leaving. (Jan 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

BRIAN EASTON My guess the use may have come out of the Knowledge Wave Conference of 2001, precipitated by the parallel with the Irish Diaspora, which is thought to have contributed to the revival of the Irish economy. (The numbers however are very different400,000 NZers against 70m of Irish descent.) The Irish use may be recent too, perhaps as a result of Mary O'Regan(?) president of Ireland who made a major speech (about 1990 I think) in which she said that Ireland should reach out to its emigrants. Coming out of the KWC, there has been formed KEA (Kiwi Expatriates Association) to harness our diaspora for New Zealand's benefit. (Dec 6, 2002,Personal Communication) [NOTES: e-mail]

With 800,000 Kiwis already living outside New Zealand, the country has one of the largest diasporas of any country in the world for its size. (Dec 14, 2002,Dominion Post,F1)

dibbly-dobbler¶

n. a medium pace bowler in cricket [Also dibbly-dobblies below (bowlers or balls?)]

There was a need now to concentrate more on faster bowlers than the "dibbly-dobbly" medium-pacers that have been such a part of the Black Caps' approach. "Perhaps the days of the dibbly-dobbler are gone." (Jan 31, 2001,Dominion,60)

They were, to use the parlance of the game, "dibbly-dobblers", seemingly inoffensive New Zealand medium-pacers of an earlier age whose control and subtle variations rendered them ideal for the limited-overs game, especially in home conditions. (Feb 24, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.stabroeknews.com/index.pl/article_sports?id=45116525Accessed 28 Feb 2006. Stabroek is a West Indian news paper found online.]

[heading] Dibbly-dobblies stymie S Africa (Oct 23, 2005,Sunday Star Times,B8)

dibs¶

n. marbles

McGILL dibs marbles; originally dibstones, a children's game with small stones or sheep's knucklebones. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,35)

DIC¶

abbr. (coarse slang) dick in child, a child molestation charge [ORIGIN: acronym]

Examples [of acronyms] include.. D.I.C.(Dick in Child - a corruption of Drunk in Charge) for a child molestation offence; 'he's in for being caught D.I.C.' (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

dice¶

v. to quit, get out of; get rid of [?omit Aust.].

SYDER & HODGETTS To quit the situation, undertaking or thing, because it is a harassment. .in 4;`So they diced every bit of gear, and all the specimens when their mate was hurt. They had to get him out in the fastest possible time.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],249,(1962-63 ed.)

dichondra¶

n. Dichondra repens.

COKAYNE (And) (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

dichondra [s] Dichondra repens Forst. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,22)

TAYLOR DICHONDRA (Dichondra repens) ... Cosmopolitan native, widely distributed throughout the country under trees and in hill pasture. (1981,Weeds of Lawns,51)

dick¶

v.

Not keen on a coalition with either party, "Labour dicked them on the foreshore". (Sep 26, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

"The next time they're shocking and getting dicked," says another...Harbour, despite Buck's exhortations, was, alas, "dicked" by Taranaki. (Nov 8, 1998,Sunday Star Times,F11)

We've been dicked again. (Nov 12, 1998,Radio NZ / National Radio,Kim Hill Show)

It's real easy to get dicked, especially at the moment when they're all freakin' out about the decline in music sales worldwide, due to the net and piracy. (Mar 19, 2004,Salient,No. 5/33)

dicken¶

exclam. constr. (aw) dicken! or dicken on that!; an exclamation or interjection of disbelief, disgust, etc., never commonly used in NZ and now (1984) obs in many localities even in children's usage.

MARSH Aw dikkon, Mr A!' said Wade.What did you say?' Haven't you heard that one, sir? I suppose it's New Zealand digger slang.Dikkon'. It's the same as if you'd say Come off it'. Used to hear it on the Peninsula.Aw dikkon, dig'' [check cit and edn] (1937,Vintage Murder,238)

BAKER In constant use by our youngsters ... dickin! (1941,NZ Slang,51)

WILSON `Ah, dicken! I know what makes things tick between you and Bert. He's a decent joker.' (1984,South Pacific Street,58)

dicken interj. exclamation expressing incredulity, dissent, prohibition, or rejection. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

dicken int. NZ & Austral. sl. (also dickin, dickon) come off it! cut it out! [foll.] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,207) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng.Dict.]]

McGILL dicken disgust or disbelief or surprised belief, in form of an interjection, largely replaced by really!' orreally?'; an antipodean contraction of the dickens' orwhat the dickens!', being a euphemism for the devil. - dicken on that! go easy, will you!; eg `You want me to help you lift that dirty big post? Dicken on that, mate.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,36)

'... It has not been restrained by any fear of the penalties that are provided for the offence known as 'contempt', but by a desire to assist in preserving the dignity of the court and in upholding its authority.' Dicken! (Apr 1, 1911,NZ Truth,310/4/3)

[Caption] "Say Kiwi, some coot told meyou were a wingless bird." "Dicken Yank,yer gotter have arms when there's a waron." (Apr 10, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/41 : 101)

exclam.

DAVIN Dicken on that for a joke. (1949,Roads from Home,237)

The accused [, Harman,] said: `Murder ... dicken on that, me murder anyone.' (Nov 6, 1950,Evening Post,8)

SLATTER What in hell are ya doin in Christchurch anyway? Bludgin on the [check] social security, I spose?'No. Dicken on that.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,44)

McGILL - dicken on that! go easy, will you!; eg `You want me to help you lift that dirty big post? Dicken on that, mate.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,36)

dickey¶

adj. stupid.

McCAULEY ... I thought your husband looked a bit dicky if you ask me.'Why would I ask you?' (1982,Other Halves,20)

McGILL dickey stupid; eg 'Well, I don't think Billy T's dickey at all, I think he's neat.' [Alison Gray] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,36)

dicky rice weevil¶

n.

dicky rice weevil n [prob. fr. the nickname Dicky] : a weevil (Malenterpes spinipes) common in Australia and New Zealand whose adults feed on foliage and whose larvae feed on the roots of citrus and other fruit trees (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,627)

DiColl¶

1 n. (Rural) a unique New Zealand fabric woven from flax fibre and possum fur.

The new product is called Di-Coll. "It's named after Diane Collins, a friend and mentor." (Jun 25, 2001,Dominion,1)

didn't come down in the last shower¶

phr. not be easily fooled

McGILL I didn't come down in the last shower I am not a fool; to which the reply is: You mightn't have come down in the last shower, but you're pretty wet all the same.' NZA variant of Royal Navy'sI didn't come down in the last bucket.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,60)

McGILL shower , phr. I didn't come down in the last shower claim to be not gullible, but shrewder than given credit for. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,102)

didn't leave an oat¶

phr.

McGILL she didn't leave a fucking oat horse racing c/p for a filly the day after winning a race, indicating how well she came through it. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,99)

didymo¶

n. Didymosphenia geminata [Internet search Feb 2006: also used N Amer (Missouri), Austral] (See rock snot)

In 2004 didymo was discovered in New Zealand, the first time it was found in the southern hemisphere. To restrict its spread, the whole of the South Island of New Zealand was declared a controlled area in December 2005. (2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Didymosphenia_geminataAccessed 10/02/06]

[advert] We need you to knock the snot out of Didymo. Didymo is an invasive Northern Hemisphere algae that threatens many of New Zealand's rivers. (Dec 14, 2005,Dominion Post,C7)

The biosecurity crises of didymo and seasquirt are an abrupt reminder that all our activities are conducted within the context of a natural world that has no innate repect for our interests. (Oct 27, 2005,Dominion Post,B4)

Biosecurity's allocation has fallen by $21 million to $151 million, due to spending in the year 2005-06 year being lifted by "one-off' funding for all responses to disease - namely fall webworm, painted apple moth, didymo, sea squuirt and the southern saltmarsh mosquito. (May 31, 2006,NZ Herald,A6)

die¶

v. Usu. die well, die badly etc., of stock killed for meat, to provide a high (etc.) quality carcase. Compare kill.

PERRY They [sc. Southdown sheep] die well, i.e., have a small percentage of offal, and the bonesbeing small there is little waste. Ibid. The Ryeland kills well, and produces meat of a fairly good quality, ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,56)

die-off¶

1 n. (Rural) a winter death of possums.

MARSHALL I'm certain that big die-offs occur in harsh winters. (1984,Possum Hunting in New Zealand,13)

died in the hole¶

phr. (Rural) [shearing] having not quite reached one's tally.

PETER Died in the hole: shearing term: not quite reaching your expected tally.i.e. 99, 199, 299. One short. (2000,Peter Glossary,6)

Dieffenbach's rail¶

n. [(?obs)]

BULLER `Dieffenbach's Rail. . . . This beautiful Rail was brought from the Chatham Islands by Dr. Dieffenbach in 1842, and named by Mr. Gray in compliment to this enterprising naturalist. The adult specimen in the British Museum, from which my description was taken, is unique, and seems likely to remain so.' (1988,Birds of New Zealand,121)

DIEFFENBACH The forest is enlivened by numerous tuis or mocking-birds; a little green parroquet flocks in hundreds to the potato-fields ... The mako-mako, the finest songster in New Zealand, is also found here, being another species of the honey-eater. The large New Zealand pigeon, called `kukupa', finds plentiful food here ... A new kind of rail was formerly very common; ... (1840,Journal of Royal Geog. Society,11/195-215) [NOTES: 1840 Dieffenbach An Account of the Chatham Islands Journal of the Royal Geographical Society 11 pp195-215 in 1984 Holmes Chatham Islands 95]

BULLER RALLUS DIEFFENBACHII. (DIEFFENBACH'S RAIL.) ... Native name. Moeriki. ... [180] This beautiful Rail was brought from the Chatham Islands by Dr. Dieffenbach in 1842 ... [1888 edn, 2/12, places this specimen in Hutton's Cabalus modestus as Hutton's Rail.] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,179,1888 2nd edn 2/123 ed.)

FALLA et al. Note: Dieffenbach's Rail (Rallus dieffenbachi), once abundant in the Chathams Islands, was similar to the Banded Rail in so many respects that that it may be regarded as a strong sub-species of philippensis. The last specimen was obtained in 1840. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,105)

131.b. Rallus philippensis dieffenbachii Gray, 1843 Dieffenbach's Rail Chatham Island, extinct (one specimen, 1840). (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,41,1980 ed.)

The second wave [of extinction] occurred gradually over centuries as the native crow, owlet nightjar, giant coot and Dieffenbach's rail were lost. (May 2003,Forest & Bird,No. 308/2)

Diehards¶

n.

There used to be much more of the push element around Christchurch than there is now, and it frequently occurred that pushes [i.e. youths belonging to these groups] like the Tigers,' theDiehards,' the Scalpers,' and theSkull-Draggers,' faced the music before the beak. (Feb 3, 1912,NZ Truth,345/7/3)

2 n.

WAITE By 4.30 a.m. on December 19 [1915], the last beetle cleared from the shore leaving the Diehards' of the Division, only 3,000 strong, to hold the line against a mighty army. ... [286] Thelast ditchers' were to be sacrificed for the army. There was no lack of volunteers. ... men of Anzac and Suvla alike - vied with each other in an endeavour to become included in the Diehards'. [288] Previous parties had taken theDiehards' kits and impedimenta. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,285)

dier¶

n. an old sheep on the point of death [(farmers')]

NEWTON This number pretty well accounted for all the old "diers" - sheep that would not have seen another winter out. (1966,Boss's Story, The,48)

1 n. (Rural) a farm animal in poor condition.

NEWTON Dog tucker and mutton on a place that size will add up to 300 or more sheep and this number pretty well accounted for all the old 'diers' - sheep that would not have seen another winter out. (1966,Boss's Story, The,48)

a sick sheep: a dier. a sick cow: a dier. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

dieselise¶

v. use only diesel buses and no petrol-driven buses

Right, we're dieselising tonight. (Dec 16, 2004,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Wellington Bus Controller to bus driver, p.c. David Norton]

Diet¶

n. England [Checked thus Dict: is this supposed to be The dart?]

diet n.-The Diet n. sl. England. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

diff up¶

v. to separate, break up. [ca1950 Should a husband and wife diff up later on.]

different tin of fish¶

phr. variant of different kettle of fish [ca1952 R Mason, Nov fide D.S.H. (Wellington) -]

diffie¶

n. the differential (of a motor vehicle), cf carbie [1955 (R. Mason) `Occurs in a set of instructions for running the ski-tow at Temple basin. (Christchurch Ski Club)]

SUTHERLAND In affectionate terms we discussed the innards ... - of their carbies' and theirdiffies' and their `con-rods'. (1956,Green Kiwi,199,1960 ed.)

DIFM¶

abbr. do it for me [ORIGIN: acronym, Also UK.]

DIFM is the oposite of DIY. Short for Do it for Me... (Feb 6, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,15)

Dig¶

n.

Be shrewd, sweet Dig, and let those whowill die working. (Jun 21, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/221)

dig¶

v.

I would not go and dig for any man under [pounds]3 per day. It is killing work. (Aug 14, 1861,Letter) [NOTES: 1861 Aug 14 letter from Tuapeka in 1867 Hochstetter NZ 110fn]

n. innings [cricket (not in SOED, ODE)]

[Hdg] Astle's dig among the game's greatest. (Mar 19, 2002,Independent Herald (Wellington),23)

dig deep¶

phr. to draw on all one's reserves, make an intense effort [not in ODE, SOED]

dig down¶

v. usu. constr. for, to pay out of one's own pocket. Compare dip south.

Kia Ora [pounds] 5000 Art Union./ Dig down for that half-crown right now. Be in on the last 5000 [pounds] Art Union without fail. (Sep 15, 1926,Aussie (NZ Section),XV)

dig-in¶

1 n. (Rural) an action caused by poorly aligned points on a buckrake.

How frequently a 'dig-in' could have been avoided .. if the tines had been correctly aligned. After a 'dig-in' the points should be always kept within at least 1 in. of their true line. (Nov 5, 1953,NZ Farmer,9)

dig-out¶

n. =digger n2.. [(obs. prisoners')]

Prisoners [in the Terrace Gaol, Wellington] frequently complain that if the chief gaoler gets a snout on them they go into the dig-out on the slightest provocation. (Aug 19, 1905,NZ Truth,9/3/5)

digger¶

n. prison detention unit/cell

NEWBOLD With the key in our possession it became possible to supply any friend of ours who was in the digger with as much tobacco, matches, food, and other delights as he wanted. (1982,Big Huey, The,136)

Seven days in the Digger on number two diet... They let you have a choice from a selection of books, most of them insulting nursery-rhyme stuff deliberately chosen by Mr Stone, the unhappy screw on day duty in charge of the Digger. (Aug 29, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

FOOTE Rangipo Prison layout was the usual rectangular plan, two sets of cells facing each other across a central grassed area with one special cell called 'the digger' or 'dummy' to isolate a troublesome inmate. (2000,Bread and Water,41)

n. miner

A hundred and one pubs and danceshanties, and them fine girls shakinga leg with the diggers and all goingstrong till daylight. (Nov 7, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,14)

HAAST Many of the diggers and storekeepers whohad brought loaded waggons from Otago..were now obliged to leave them behind andtake their stores on with pack-horses. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,68)

I am happy to say that the fossickers and mica diggers have "cut it." (Nov 7, 1855,Nelson Examiner,2)

These "specimens" as they are called by the diggers, show no - or very little sign of being water-worn. (Jul 8, 1859,Auckland Provincial Gazette,VIII(14) : 90)

DAVIES Dick Dickson had been a good deal at sea,but for a "digger" was well educated. (1884,Poems & Other Literary Remains,265)

I saw a shepherd's wife take her child out of a cradle and sell the latter to a digger for a GBP5 note. (Jan 22, 1924,Otago Witness,7)

These Irish Diggers (they hated to be called miners) made the place as bad or worse than Donnybrook. (Dec 28, 1920,Otago Witness,53)

adj. [goldmining]

McNEISH Fred Smith of the Digger's Rest introduced a sport which topped the bill - rat-baiting. (1957,Tavern in the Town,234) [NOTES: 1966 edition]

HOCHSTETTER Mining statutes and digger licenses [sic] were issued, gold commissioners were installed, and escorts were established, who conveyed the gold produce [sic] every fortnight under guard toDunedin. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),112)

The knowledge that he has beenrecommended by his C.O. for recognitionhas met with the warm approval of all his"digger" cobbers. (Aug 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/49 : 8)

Digger¶

n. a New Zealand soldier

We.. pulled up to announce our arrival to a rather officious-looking officer who wasn't very impressed by a few Kiwi Diggers. (Dec 20, 1944,Hutt & Petone Chronicle,12)

Some of the Mounted Rifles who have recently returned to Christchurch are objecting to being called Diggers... It appears that the term was practically unheard of in Palestine and Egypt. (Oct 1919,Quick March,61)

SMITH And splendid with medals and ribbons,/ Old Diggers - the country's cream - Boyd from the days of the Crimea,/ And some from the Boer War,/ (1988,Southlanders at Heart,17)

The common method of addressing a New Zealander is to call him "digger," which, from being an abusive term, has been readily and universally adopted and approved by the Pig Islanders themselves. We, the N.Z.R.B., prefer to be addressed as "diggers" rather than "dinks" which was the original mode of address. (Apr 30, 1918,Wanganui Chronicle,4) [NOTES: From a letter by Rifleman C A Palmer of Wanganui (nb: date entered in NZDE database was 31/4/1918)]

"Digger" is now the common form of salutation between privates. It applied to the Maoris only at one time. They do a lot of pioneer work, such as digging trenches, but as we all do more or less navvy work, the term is universally used among the New Zealanders. Really the meaning is "Friend" now. (Aug 13, 1917,Wanganui Herald,6) [NOTES: This is from a letter from an Auckland soldier;]

Tommies and overseas Kangaroos andDiggers enter into conversation withpeasants, which turn often intoconferences. (Jan 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,III/36 : 286)

In the colloquial parlance of the"Digger," they came a gentle "gutzer". (Jul 19, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/48 : 274)

Digger Dick¶

n.

Who is better equipped.. than "Digger Dick," practical miner, Empire builder, and the very active personality behind "Seddon, New Zealand?" (Feb 6, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

digger plough¶

1 n. (Rural) [now used elsewhere, but first and widely in NZ] a winged plough that breaks down the furrow slice. [also digging plough below]

Digging-ploughs are now coming into general use. (Jul 1892,NZ Farmer,Supplement 1)

The digger plough, especially on clay land, is to be recommended for preparing land for wheat. Care must be taken, however, to turn up too much clay at the first time of ploughing with a digger. (May 1909,NZ Farmer,353)

The lea land should be turned over with the digger plough ... [digging plough] (Jul 2, 1923,NZ Farmer,923)

digger's delight¶

n. a large felt hat; = digger's hat (WW2) (AND 1940)

BAKER New Zealand terms, recorded during the closing twenty years of last century, [include] ... digger's delight, a large felt hat worn by gold-diggers in New Zealand. (1941,NZ Slang,46)

digger's delight n. large felt hat worn by N.Z. gum-diggers; (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

digger's hat¶

n. a wide-brimmed felt hat [(goldfields and early rural)] (See also digger's delight)

BARKER I must say, [the bushmen] were the most picturesque of the party, being ... dressed in red flannel shirts and leathern knickerbockers and gaiters; they ... wore `diggers' hats,' a head-dress of American origin - a sort of wide-awake made of plush, capable of being crushed into any shape,and very becoming. (1867,Station Life in NZ,182,1870 ed.)

digger's lantern¶

n. a bottle lantern (= bush lantern, colonial lantern, miner's lantern)

LUSH The evening was very dark and I had taken up as I left home, a digger's lantern'; this is usually made out of a brandy [68] bottle with the bottom broken off and a candle stuck in the neck and which, held by the neck, makes a capitalrough and ready' lantern. (Sep 8, 1869,Thames Journals,67,1975 ed.)

HEINZ ... the other went off in the dark to search the creek bed, using a digger's lantern which was a glass bottle with the bottom removed and a candle stuck in the neck. (1952,Prospecting for Gold,11)

digger's shirt¶

n. a blue (? Crimean) woollen shirt.

O'REGAN Men ... dress fine and do the grand/ For the age of digger's shirts has passed away. [cf 15. The moleskin and the Crimean shirt are growing scarce apace.] (1894,Voices of Wave and Tree,11)

digger's weed¶

n. (See also Californian stinkweed)

HILGENDORF STINK WEED ([Navarettia] squarrosa), [formerly named Gilis squarrosa] and called Californian stink weed, digger's weed and yeast plant, occurs chiefly [in river beds] on dry pastures and fields in Marlborough and Otago, where it sometimes becomes dominant over all other herbage. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,139,1967 ed.)

digger's weed [=] Californian stinkweed [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,22)

Californian Stinkweed, Digger's Weed (Navarettia (Gilia) squarrosa) . . . It is sometimes erroneously called "Bathurst burr." (1895,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,III/121)

Californian Stinkweed, Diggers' Weed (Navarettia (Gilia) squarrosa) . Ibid. 2 It is sometimes erroneously called "Bathurst burr." (1895,Leaflets for Farmers,No. 22 : 1)

digger-mania¶

n. gold-fever.

COOPER It is called by some digger-mania, by others digger-phobia. This dire disease is usually developed about a month after the victim has commenced digging; its symptoms are very varied and curious, and are anything but agreeable to those who are unfortunately connected with the poor afflicted one. (Dec 19, 1867,Digger's Diary,23,1978 ed.)

Diggerland¶

n.

Other miscellaneous historical (obsolete) names from the early 20th century include.. Diggerland, coined in World War I. (Oct 2000,NZWords,4 : 2)

[Title] "Diggerland"... Can you see thewaving tussock grass that yellows in thesun, To the soft blue haze of thedistant hills that quiver into one?.. (1918,New Zealand At the Front,77) [NOTES: Title of the poem is "Diggerland". The word does not seem to be used anywhere else and not in the poem.]

Diggers, the¶

n. a NZ concert party (WW1 and after)

HURST Another aspect of the influence of the Great War was evident in 1919, with the appearance of the Diggers. (1944,Music & the Stage in NZ,60)

DOWNES The New Zealand Pierrots were at a loose end by this time [sc. 1919] and, more or less as a body, they became the principal members of the new group - the Diggers... For the next twelve years the name of Pat Hanna's Diggers became a byword throughout both countries [sc. Australia & NZ]. (1979,Top of the Bill,58)

WOLFE Formed in 1917, this group eventually evolved into the Diggers and were led by Pat Hanna. (1991,Kiwi,34)

Diggerville¶

n.

WOLFE These birds were less of a permanent troupe, although they once converted a barn into a theatre, and named it Diggerville. (1991,Kiwi,34)

Just a stone's throw from H.Q. and A.Coy. is what used to be a big farm, butwhich is now known to the boys as"Diggerville". (Aug 30, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,V/51 : 57)

digging¶

n. [goldmining; incl attrib]

In the meantime Mr. C. Ring found it necessary to abandon the first digging, owing to the obstruction offered to his reaching bed rock by the presence of large Quartz Boulders, ... (Nov 9, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/26/165) [NOTES: (Report of Sub-Committee on Recent Gold Discovery in the Coromandel District]

HARPER ... I went amongst them every day, and we talked of their digging experiences; ... (Dec 20, 1864,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,79,1914 ed.)

n. pertaining to a diggings; mining. [(obs.)]

FITTON The digging population is not now what it used to be. Diggers are now hard-fisted in more senses of the word than one. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),344)

... while her decks were cleared, to allow of a search for stowaways, and of those other processes known to Custom-house officers and immigration commissioners, her 700 and odd passengers, laden with their swags, digging utensils, and bright tin pannikins and dishes. (Sep 20, 1861,NZ Goldfields,5,1976 ed.) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 20 in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 5]

2 n.

BATHGATE There are always a few of these unsocial miners [hatters] about every digging. (1874,Colonial Experiences,138)

WASHBOURN The term billy ... originated on the [Collingwood] digging and is still in general use. (1933,Reminiscences of Early Days,5)

DOBSON He replied that as he had to hold a service at Antonio's Flat (a digging on the Grey Valley) next morning, ... (1930,Reminiscences,137)

DILKE ... a gang of diggers and sailors, dressed in the clothes which every one must wear in a digging town unless he wishes to be stared at by every passer-by. (1868,Greater Britain,1/335)

MONEY [Prospective diggers] had only arrived to find the whole thing what is called in digging parlance a duffer' - i.e., that there was comparativelynothing' to repay them for even the trouble of digging a single hole. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,121)

MONEY ... at dinner we had the pleasure of the company ... of a publican from Nokomai, a digging township on the road we were going. Ibid. 197 Pinkerton and Lady came board. Pinkerton is a publican who has made a lot of money in the digging time and his lady or rather as he calls her `My old woman' has ringlets. (Jan 23, 1873,Knocking About in NZ) [NOTES: 1873 Jan 23 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 146]

HARPER [The West Coast] has become, from a digging point of view, a field of far less importance. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,30)

Lyell is a picturesque little digging township ... (Dec 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,163)

WASHBOURN ... the gold ... [was] so much of a gold-leaf character ... I have frequently [c1860s] seen large specks floating in and out of the dish when panning out there, and these in digging terms are `floaters.' (1933,Reminiscences of Early Days,4)

digging plough¶

1 n. (Rural) a style of plough with an extra projecting wing. (See also digger plough)

WALLACE Howards Digging Plough .. turns over the furrow slices most perfectly and breaks what is left at the surface by means of a projecting wing or continuation of the mould-board. (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,272)

Digging-ploughs are now coming into general use. [digging-plough] (Jul 1892,NZ Farmer,Supplement 1)

diggings¶

n. a goldfield usu. where surface or alluvial mining in registered claims is being carried out (1851-1853 usu. with reference to Australia or California, often in quotation marks, and prefixed with gold). [Early spg (or var. form) diggins, occas. digins. [Spec. use of digging(s) applied to a goldfield in California, then Australia and NZ.] [1853 Adams Spring Canterbury Settlement 56-57 diggins.] Common pronunciation was `diggins' [check] (Griffiths Collection). 1. [AND 1851.] (Collect. pl. or pl. regarded as a sg., the diggings.)]

STEPHENS Thousands of people had already flocked to the diggings from Sydney. Ibid. 546 ... the diggins ' (1851,Letters & Journals,514)

STAFFORD diggings ... (1851,Papers,1/94) [NOTES: 1851 Stafford Papers [TS] 1/94 (Featherston) ...]

LUSH The excitement respecting the gold `diggings' in Australia rising to fever heat in Auckland. (Jun 23, 1851,Journal) [NOTES: 1851 June 23 Lush Auckland Journal (1971) 79]

TAYLOR ... gold diggings ... (1852,Journal,7/278,1833 ed.) [NOTES: 1852 R. Taylor Journals (1833-) 7/278]

FITTON If there be one point on which all those who have visited the diggings agree, it is this - (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),355) [NOTES: 1852 Dec J.R.Godley's Address in 1856 Fitton NZ 355]

SWAINSON ... the public was again reassured [of gold discovery] by the appearance of the following noveladvertisment:- sale of/ AUCKLAND GOLD/ Connell & Ridings/ Will sell by Public Auction, at their Mart, Queen-Street,/ This day, Saturday, 11th December,/ ... / A Quantity of Gold Dust, and Gold-bearing Quartz,/ From the `Wynyard Diggings,' Coromandel. (1853,Auckland,105) [NOTES: 1852 Dec 11 Advertisement in 1853 Swainson Auckland 105]

SWAINSON Some very fine samples of gold from the Waiau diggings ... were brought into town today ... thequantity about five ounces. -->1853 Rochfort Adventures of a Surveyor 20 [He] was always in debt, and shortly after he ran away to the diggings, leaving his salary heavily mortgaged. (1853,Auckland,107) [NOTES: 1852 Dec 13 Gold Circular in 1853 Swainson Auckland 107]

Never mind - the diggings will not always draw people away. In a short time the overflowings of disappointed diggers will bring Ships and labour back and the tide of Immigration will flow again. Ibid. 1/123 Many houses to let in consequence of some persons having gone to the diggings - others over the hill (as they call it) into the Plains. (1853,Journal of Henry Sewell,1980,1/144 ed.)

... the annexed tabular report of the work at this Gold-field since my arrival. ... wherever I and the Messrs. Ring have `prospected' on the Kapanga ..., we have found gold, and that the greatest number of flakes in the prospecting dish, appeared upon washing some earth yesterday at a bar about half a mile lower down the stream ...; and below all the present diggings. (Dec 10, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/30/183) [NOTES: (Heaphy's Report) Kapanga River Diggings,/ Coromandel harbour,/ 4th November, 1852.]

EARP ... emigration to New Zealand has given way to the mania for the Australian gold diggings. Ibid. 248 They have their `Long Tom' at the junction of a small tributary with the Kapenga, below all the other diggers. Neither of the men have ever been at any other diggings. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),98)

On the resumed diggings, the parties ... washed [7 1/4oz of dust] ... the quantity set forth, and are continuing their work with every prospect of finding eventually the matrix Gold, which the nuggets now obtained indicate to be in the vicinity of the workings. (Jan 12, 1853,NZ Government Gazette,6/1/2) [NOTES: (Heaphy's Report from Coromandel)]

The gold seems a little more promising according to reports. Bearded losels wandermore and more up and down the beach [at Nelson] - to and fro the diggings. (May 5, 1857,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/263,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A. Domett)]
