The character of the diggings is improving; the yield of gold is much better. (Jul 4, 1857,Lyttelton Times,5)

... at the end of three months (his nose having got exceedingly red in the meantime and smelling worse that ever of bad tobacco), he goes to that refuge for the destitute, the Nelson diggings. (Aug 12, 1857,Lyttelton Times,3)

MUELLER I ...am now at the Manokaiou where the diggins are. (Dec 1, 1865,My Dear Bannie,81,1958 ed.)

Nothing but one loaf of bread left, could hardly get firewood enough to boil one billy full of tea. Met some mourays who told us of the new digins. (May 9, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,37,1950 ed.)

WALKER The diggings [at Dunstan] extend 80 miles one way and fifteen another. If you want to boil a pot you have to hunt about for dead Wild Irishmen' a nasty prickly little shrub. The high lands abounded withSpaniards' I suppose from their cut-throat propensities. A kind of very thick grass, grows in a little lump. (Jan 7, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker))

NESFIELD We travelled to ... the Grey, and back to the Buller, calling at Charleston and Waite's Pakihi's; all familiar diggings to any west-coast digger, and very rowdy diggings too. (1881,Chequered Career,76)

A TRAMP Bullen ... owned a clothing store in the principal `diggins' of the day. (1891,Casual Ramblings,111)

diggings: place where gold is mined. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173)

diggings ... A place where gold-mining is carried on. b. on the diggings, the idiom (rather than in) within the precincts of a goldfield. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),122,8th ed.)

MONEY ... I slept for the first time `on the diggings;' and ... I confess I would have preferred a warm bed ... to the slab table with which I was compelled to content myself, every bunk and bed-place being preoccupied, ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,10)

THATCHER He'd a mart on the diggings here, and in addition,/ He did a great deal selling things on commission. (1875,NZ Songster,No.5/49) [NOTES: Life of an Auctioneer]

2 n.

McLEAN Someone found a `diggins' at the Hutt. (1857,Papers,14/272)

ELWELL The men were only diggers who had caught sight of the tent, and thought that Ernest and Harold had a good `diggings' there in a quiet way. (1878,Boy Colonists,184)

diggings, what the¶

exclam. what the dickens!

SMYTH What the `diggings' do you think you're doing? (1930,Wooden Rails,144)

diggler¶

n. an egg

McGILL digglers eggs. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,25)

diggly bones¶

n. [(children's game) ca1922 Pukekohe R. Mason]

dilberry¶

n. a foolish or naive person.

Any man who thinks and reads beyond the immediate requirements of getting a good job is a fool - wet',gormless', dilberry', etc. <i>(Sep 1952,Landfall,23/221</i>) [NOTES: (PearsonFretful Sleepers')]

dill¶

n. stupid person; fool; dupe (occas.), awkward, clumsy person. [ca1941 St Patrick's Silverstream]

PARTRIDGE A dupe; an easy victim: Australian, esp. confidence tricksters': since the 1920s. In, e.g. Baker, 1942. Perhaps silly billy>Billy>Billy?)> Bill> by `rhyme', dill; but prob. ex daffydill, illiterate for daffodil ... (cf pill @n with similar, though harsher, connotation) perhaps dialectal relation to dull (OE dyle), or perhaps a NZ shortening from dilly (aj) (though the reverse may be true, dilly (aj) from dill @n; dill is a more friendly term than dool (aj doolish) which is applied in anger or disgust with somebody's stupidity. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,186)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the [slang] expressions listed by children in two schools are: Up the shoot, going eyes out, bullswool, go jump in the lake, ... shivery dick, shiver me timbers, ... you're telling I, got iton the brain, like smoke in a wheelbarrow' (Kaitaia),Sheila, crow, bud, frig it, grub, holy moses, blast it, mole, balls to you, shut your face, ... nerts to you, go bite your back, have a roll, fluff off, scram, ants in your pants, rag bag, ... you're bats, dronk, drongo, dill, dip, dippy, ya big lug, greetings gruesome, who dented your beak. (South Wellington). (1953,Unorganized Games,2/677)

MUIR `Yeah. The others are proper dills. Except Arthur's side-kick.' (1960,Word for Word,261)

SUTTON-SMITH [c1920-1950] there are vigorous Slanging Contests in which the contestants try to outdo each other by using phrases like the following: You're up the shoot.' ...Dronk!' Drongo!'Dill!' Dippy!'Drip!' (1972,Folkgames of Children,138)

WILSON You're a dill to do things like that with a sheila like that. Don't get tied up with her. (1973,NZ Jack,124)

MANTELL `Besides I'd have looked a bit of a dill reporting something like that to the police.' (1978,Murder in Fancydress,85)

dill n. Austral. inf. a fool [C20: < DILLY 2] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,313) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 209]]

dillbrain: idiot (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

McGILL dill, dillbrain silly or incompetent person, possibly from daffodil, where daffy' means daft; egWear ear-muffs with that weedeater, dillbrain.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,36)

dillbrain¶

n. a fool (an elaboration of dill).

The Nats have had so many absolute political gifts lately, but the minute they get the Government on the ropes, the dill-brains start slogging themselves on the chops instead. (Jul 19, 1987,Sunday News,37)

McGILL dill, dillbrain silly or incompetent person, possibly from daffodil, where daffy' means daft; egWear ear-muffs with that weedeater, dillbrain.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,36)

dilly¶

adj. silly; cranky; foolish. (See also dill n)

His Worship: Was the accused sober?' Witness:Well, he looked muzzy.' His Worship: What do you mean by that?' Witness:He looked either drunk or a shingle short.' His Worship: A what?' Witness:A screw loose.' His Worship: I don't understand you.' Witness:He seemed to have a rat in his garret.' His Worship: Oh, speak English!' Witness:Off his dot - balmy [sic] - dilly.' Sergeant: He says the man was mad, your Worship.' Witness:No, I didn't. I said he was either drunk or ratty.' (Apr 16, 1910,NZ Truth,251/1/6)

dilly a. NZ & Austral. stupid, silly. [daft and silly] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,209)

dilly adj. Austral. sl. silly [C20: < E dialect, ? < SILLY] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,313) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 209]]

dim as a Toc H lamp¶

phr. very dim

SLATTER Dim as a Toc H lamp he was - This country would be in the cart properly but for us Scandies - (1968,Pagan Game, The,162)

dim as a Toc H lamp (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

dim-bulb¶

adj.

Best character so far: Calvin, Ben and Frank's dim-bulb brother. The elevator may not go all the way to the top floor, but on this show he fits right in. (Jul 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

dimple¶

1 n. (Rural) an underground depression in land, caused by ploughing of native land unsuited to cultivation.

CUMBERLAND The dimples usually occupy individually an area of 2 to 5 square yards. (1944,Soil Erosion in New Zealand,100)

CUMBERLAND Subcutaneous dimples developed on deep loess near the foot of the Port Hills ... (1944,Soil Erosion in New Zealand,116)

dimpling¶

1 n. (Rural) underground soil erosion caused by ploughing, that results in concave depressions on land surface.

CUMBERLAND Subcutaneous dimpling appears to be limited to land which, in the course of European occupance, has been ploughed at least once. Under these circumstances dimpling replaces sub-surface sheet wash. (1944,Soil Erosion in New Zealand,100)

CUMBERLAND From Marlborough to Southland, short steep slopes ploughed out of tussock or ploughed after bush burns, exhibit dimpling in various stages. (1944,Soil Erosion in New Zealand,101)

ding¶

v. to dent or damage

[Hdg] New jet dinged by snow plough... The first of two identical second-hand aircraft bought to replace the air force's troubled Boeing 727s was damaged when a snow-clearing vehicle backed into it and left a gash under its nose. (Apr 16, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

1 n. a (small) dent (in a car's bodywork etc.)

Ihimaera Dylan barges past, putting a ding in my aging bodywork as he goes, releasing the ball to Rajiv. (2007,Ask the Posts,107)

2 n. money? [NZism?]

Since rather more than half the voters were too stupid to vote for the far-sighted Dr Brash..the politicians are going to have to do something with the ding. (Dec 18, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C8)

Of course, people are not going sentimentally to put their ding into something just because it has a proletariat or patriotic political flavour. (Jul 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

ding-a-ling¶

1 n. (Rural) a station cook.

station cook - a ding-a-ling. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

ding-dong¶

adj. the gen. Eng. intens. (1864), used for dinkum; related to dinkum cf 1944.

[Aunt Ada'] ... Ding-dong New Zealander, that's me a ding-dong New Zealander' for the catchphrasea dinkum New Zealander' (Aug 11, 1941,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

dingbat¶

n. a stupid or fooish person

RENEE And Gertrude snorts. 'Another bloody dingbat,' she says. (1997,Snowball Waltz, The,183)

Why on earth do you employ such a dingbat columnist as Frank Haden? (May 26, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A6)

I'm not suggesting that there was any malice involved. There were one or two dingbats, but that's life. (Apr 21, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59)

1 n. (Rural) a cobbler, or sheep that is difficult to shear.

MCLEOD 'I don't know what the hell I'm doing up here shearing these f-- dingbats,' he would say .. Look at these dingbats - wool all over their eyes ... (1970,Glorious Morning,147)

dingbat - a cobbler. (2000,Peter Glossary,3)

A sheep that is difficult to shear: a dingbat (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

2 n. a halfwit

HILLIARD Drongos,' Max hisses.Wart-heads. Dingbats. Halfwits.' (1976,Send Somebody Nice,32)

dingbat n. Austral. sl. a crazy or stupid person. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,314) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 209; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 135]]

dingbat n. an eccentric; (Coll.) officer's servant in World War 1. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

McGILL dingbat odd or silly person; plural form means madness, either of rage or delirium tremens; singular was an Anzac officer's servant in WWI, said to be a merger of dingo and batman. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,36)

2 n. [(transf.)]

McLEOD I don't know what the hell I'm doing up here shearing these f---- dingbats,' he would say.... Look at these dingbats - wool all over their eyes; ... A man must be bloody mad to shear them? (1970,Glorious Morning,147)

dingbatitis¶

n. drunkenness or excessive drinking.

LORD Dingbatitis',drinking', doped',dizzy', or on `the drunk' (1921,Ballads of Bung 'Stunology',1976 ed.)

dingbats¶

n. delirium tremens, a mad fit (esp. in phr. have the dingbats)

'Ave you got the dingbats. (Sep 27, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,109)

DEVANNY George, 'e 'ad the dingbats. (1926,Butcher Shop, The,96)

Dingbats. - Slang, of Australian origin, for delirium tremens. The dingbats, I believe, are really the snakes, weasels, etc., which a sufferer sees. ([1890-1910], but since when I am not sure.) (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

PARTRIDGE 2. the dingbats. Delirium tremens: Australians' and New Zealanders': C.20; ob. - 3. Hence, madness: id.: from ca 1905; ob. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,221)

dingbats n. (Sl.) delirium tremens; have the dingbats, to be off one's head. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

BAKER (Ac) ... dingbats, delirium tremens (1941,NZ Slang,42)

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... dingbats: delirium tremens (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

SLATTER Boozin' again! You'll end up with the dingbats, you will. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,42)

BAXTER He had lain for a month in a native hut visited by pubescent girls who supplied him with home comforts and African beer. ... `I had the dingbats for a while,' he said. ...@Well, when I had the dingbats there was a bloody great Negro's face an inch away from me all the time. It must have been the bad grog.' (1985,Horse,25) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game) 25]

dingbats n. (Sl.) delirium tremens; have the dingbats, to be off one's head. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

BAXTER GRADY: It could be the dingbats. [of an alcoholic who has died] (1982,Collected Plays,124) [NOTES: (1968) 1982 Baxter Collected Plays (Band Rotunda)124]

adj. mad; crazy. [ca1941 Havelock e.g. Go dingbats, `go mad']

[Children yell] Your mother's dingbats. (1949,Landfall,11/146) [NOTES: [?check ?3]]

dinginess¶

1 n. (Rural) [wool handling] dust, sand or soil in fleecewool.

HENDERSON .. great differences in dinginess can be found among fleeces from a flock of sheep that have all the same opportunities to become affected. Quite apart from a certain amount of dinginess which might come about through particular living habits, for example, the habitual grazing locations of individuals on a block ... (1968,Growing Better Wool,81)

HENDERSON Depending on the source and kind of dinginess some reasonable means of control can be suggested. (1968,Growing Better Wool,82)

dingle stick¶

n.

HELMER This little hori's damned hungry,' Crump said, lifting the tea billy from the dingle stick.I could scoff a real binder, just quietly.' (1964,Stag Party,80)

dingles¶

n. [pl. diggles, taws. ca1957-1963 Horowhenua The marbles your put in the centre of the ring.]

dingo¶

n. [Australian]

What's worse; what r-u-u-l-l-y hurts, is that far too often they have been beaten by those they call the dingoes - Australians like Nicole Livingstone, Phil Adams, Martin Vinnicombe and Sean Carlin (Jan 29, 1990,Sydney Herald)

n. (Rural, informal) a Merino sheep.

Merinos are generally known as dingoes. (2000,Peter Glossary,4)

dingy¶

adj. (of wool) discoloured by condition or dust. [(woolgrowers')]

Dingy: Discoloration due to condition and dust. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

1 adj. (Rural) [sp. use] [of fleece-wool] carrying excessive amounts of sand, earth and dust.

dingy - a yellow discoloured wool, heavy in condition. (1919,Wool in NZ,20)

HENDERSON Dingy wool - in practice this kind of wool is described with a variety of names. In New Zealand the most common names are 'dingy' .. There [in Australia] the term 'dingy' is most often used to describe discolored wool in general. The following discussion is confined to wool bearing excessive amounts of sand, earth and dust and for simplicity it is called dingy wool. It is the rule rather than the exception to find very weak back wool in dingy fleeces. (1968,Growing Better Wool,81)

dining room¶

n. in a NZ house often a name for the best' room, thefront' room; lounge.

BALLANTYNE He said he wouldn't mind [a cup of tea], so she went out to the kitchen ... When she returned to the dining-room he was sitting on the chesterfield. (1948,Cunninghams, The,159,1976 ed.)

BARTLETT On the mantelpiece in the dining room, among the ornaments and family photographs, stood an especially fine piece of kauri gum the colour of clear honey. It had probably been dug by Bob on his farm or on a gum-digging `holiday'. (1947,Emigrants, The,102)

Dink¶

n. with various descriptive epithets, from shape of shoulder patches. Arse-up Dinks, Fourth Battalion[an upside-down triangle??]; Diamond Dinks, First Battalion; Square Dinks; Triangle Dinks, Second Battalion; see (Square) Dinkums.

McKINLAY See Square Dinks/ Fair Dinks. (1939,Ways & Byways,24)

In the Great War there were Square Dinks, the Triangle Dinks and I won't tell you what we called the other ones but their triangle was upside down - you know what soldiers mean. (Feb 12, 1953,2ZB) [NOTES: (Lux Money-Go-Round Programme)]

AITKEN Next came the New Zealand Rifle Brigade from Mersa Matruh, first the 2nd Battalion, nicknamed the Square Dinks' (asquare dinkum bloke' being idiomatic Australian for a genuine fellow) from the distinctive black patch on the upper sleeve; later the `Diamond Dinks', who wore a diamond patch and had been in action with British and Sikhs in the defeat of the Senussi on Christmas Day. The alternative name of the Rifle Brigade, the E.L.O. (the Earl of Liverpool's Own) had been quietly allowed to lapse. (1963,Gallipoli to the Somme,46)

McGILL Triangle Dinks Third Battalion, NZ Rifle Brigade, WWI, from shoulder flash. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

n.

HENDERSON ... a few days after Messines, D Company 4 Battalion, NZRB walked out of Plocgsteert Wood. A complete mystery. Can any old Dink throw any light on it? (1978,Soldier Country,123,1990, p. 82 ed.)

[Hdg] Trophy of "The Dinks". How Christchurch's much discussed howitzer was captured. (Jul 4, 1928,NZ Free Lance,11)

Williams was an "Ak Emma" and Henrys was a "Dink", a fair dinkum "digger". (Nov 27, 1926,NZ Observer,Xmas Annual : 28)

THOMSON Sometimes even Dinkums proved too long and was shortened to "Dinks". (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,10)

The common method of addressing a New Zealander is to call him "digger," which, from being an abusive term, has been readily and universally adopted and approved by the Pig Islanders themselves. We, the N.Z.R.B., prefer to be addressed as "diggers" rather than "dinks" which was the original mode of address. (May 31, 1918,Wanganui Chronicle,4) [NOTES: From a letter by Rifleman C A Palmer of Wanganui]

We were talking with the 'Dinks' thatevening. (Mar 14, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/14 : 41)

Originally there were two canteens inthis camp, but since the "Dinks" camehere in September both have beenenlarged. (Jan 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,III/34-35 : 24)

That Dink now gets quite mad when theboys taunt him about a certain pigskinH.E. (Jul 19, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/48 : 272)

The Drill Hall barely accommodated 100"dinks" from all over the Dominion whoattended the reunion of veterans of theNew Zealand Rifle Brigade on Saturdaynight. (Jun 7, 1948,Dominion,8)

n. the Dinkums [(WW1)]

ANON I have seen a number of university men of the Rifle Brigade, generally known to us as the Dinks - a name they have cheerfully accepted and try to live up to. [fn] The newspapers urging enlistment in 1915 declared that the later men, joining the forces with motives of reasoned patriotism, would be more praiseworthy than the impetuous spirits' of the Main Body. Hence thesardonic nickname ofthe Dinks' - dinkum soldiers - attached to the new brigade. (Mar 11, 1916,Letter) [NOTES: 1916 March 11 Letter from Egypt in 1965 Malthus ANZAC 156]

INGRAM This evening the C.O. ... imparted to them the information that the Divison with the exception of the Rifle Brigade (`The Dinks') was going back ... (Sep 1, 1917,Anzac Diary,40,1987 ed.)

102 Our Brigade (2nd) and the Dinks were to advance with the Australians. (Oct 28, 1917,Great Adventure,1988) [NOTES: (Gray)]

The Dinks were laying cable in the forward areas, ... (1987,After Z-Hour,171) [NOTES: [WW1]]

STEWART Colloquially the Rifle Brigade Battalions were known as `Dinks', a term applied to them on their arrival in Egypt, 1916, and alluding to the special patronage which they enjoyed of the Governor-General of the Dominion, and to their peculiarities of drill and dress. (1921,NZ Division,vi fn)

HYDE The Dinks - the New Zealand Rifle Brigade - had been getting it in the neck here with every sort of music the opposition could turn on. (1936,Passport to Hell,204)

The New Zealand Rifle Brigade, perhaps better known as the Dinks', will hold a reunion in Wellington ... (How did they get their name? The black buttons, badges, and blazes, and theunusual drill of the New Zealand Rifle Brigade led to their being dubbedthe dinkum soldiers.' Shortened to `The Dinks' it was accepted as an honourable title.) (Mar 13, 1955,Evening Post,12)

SLATTER ... he spent most of his time ... playing poker and drinking beer with ... his old cobbers who were in the Dinks in the first war. (1968,Pagan Game, The,153)

adj. pertaining to the Rifle Brigade, or a member of it. [(WW1)]

MILLER A Dink officer got one in the arm. (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,159) [NOTES: >[1917 Oct 12] 1939 Miller Camps, Tramps, and Trenches 159]

INGRAM At about 9.30 last night we started off in [112] the pouring rain to relieve the Fourth Dink Battalion. (Sep 13, 1918,Anzac Day,111,1987 ed.)

dink¶

v. (See double-bank)

n. ducking movement

Tidy cover defending, clever dink through for Gear's first try. (Nov 28, 2005,NZ Herald,C3)

n. money, cash. Compare jink [(obs., ?children's) ca1930 Dunedin schoolchildren's p.c. A. Campbell. ca1939 Havelock c. (schoolboys' obs.) [?F.?a different root for something worthless: or ?ironic use; nf OED2.]]

n. a cheap clay marble; dinky [1931 p.c. George Turner Diary (Dannevirke]

2 adj. Usu. in collocations fair dink(s), true dink to express or imply doubt or assert the truth of a statement.

BENNETT The Australian asseverations Dinkum',fair dinkum' (honest, straight') have produced in New Zealand the meaningless variantfeather dinks'. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,91)

That is beyond me, dinky di. (Nov 15, 1934,Evening Post,12)

dinkum¶

adj.

Perhaps his band was not of the "dinkum"sort! (Sep 15, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/2 : 48)

I haven't done anything - dinkum I haven't. (Aug 19, 1924,Otago Witness,73)

I'm a dinkum saw-doctor, too, though I sez it meself. (Nov 23, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

I've dinkum swallowed it this time. (Jul 5, 1943,NZEF Times,III/106)

HENDERSON Its crossing was treated with a little bit more care - the dinkum pioneer treatment our grandparents used when travelling a wild, untamed New Zealand. (1967,Return to Open Country,19)

"Dinkum pub-keepers are a pretty decent run of jokers." (Mar 17, 1937,Tomorrow,3(19) : 310)

It's the real dinkum Kiwi heritage. (Jan 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Dinkumite¶

Up to muddy Trentham came the Dinkumitesone day. (Mar 14, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/14 : 41)

Dinkums¶

n. [When my eye first fleetingly caught this par, I thought it referred to NZers. This actually states that it refers to Australians but the similarity of names is such that I wonder if this is a sub-editor's misinterpretation of the review or his precis of another paragraph.]

THOMSON Sometimes even Dinkums proved too long and was shortened to "Dinks". (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,10)

A reviewer of Captain Bean's book "Letters from France," quotes the nicknames of the successive drafts of Australian forces to fight for the cause of the Old Country. "The Tourists" came first, - people out to see what the adventure was like. The next shipment were the "Dinkums", the true men; followed by the "Super-Dinkums". Then arrived the "War Babies" and the "Chocolate Soldiers", and after them the "Hard Thinkers" who thought very hard before they came, and last of all the "Neutrals". (Oct 9, 1917,Wanganui Herald,4)

The "Dinkums" have been tested, and tested in a manner even comparable to what our most early arrivals had to stand on that fateful day, April 25th, 1915. (Sep 29, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,52)

dinner suit¶

n. a formal suit (full tuxedo)

Dinnergate¶

n. [The media hype surrounding Mrs Shipley's dinner with Kevin Roberts, the man from Saatchi and Saatchi.]

[Hdg] Dinnergate Ibid. 21 However, Dinnergate has not been the only recent occasion when the outpouring of the Roberts charisma and gusto has been a mixed blessing. (Mar 6, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

"Dinnergate" showed Shipley is perilously accident-prone under heavy fire, and Labour will be searching for the issues that probe the Prime Minister's weaknesses. (Mar 7, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C2)

Mr McCarten said "Dinnergate" had checked National's upward surge at the start of the year... Mr Munro conceded that the public was still struggling to work out what "Dinnergate" had been about. (Mar 16, 1999,Dominion,2)

Check his new website and.. You can read that the nastiest thing anyone's ever done to him is "skewering by assorted media commentators on dinnergate." (Aug 7, 1999,Evening Post,10)

DINZ¶

abbr. Deer Industry New Zealand [ORIGIN: acronym]

Deer Industry New Zealand (DINZ) has taken the unprecedented step of teaming up with the British Deer Farmers Association (BDFA) in order to stimulate public demand for farm-raised venison. (Jun 2005,Deer Industry News,20)

dip¶

n. mine entrance

HUNT They'd have to put in another "dip" - another entrance [sc. to the mine]. (1981,Southern Monthly Magazine,132)

n. (Rural) a bath in which sheep are washed, to kill parasites in skin and wool.

MONEY .. leading to the dip, an enclosed floor, resting on a pivot, which, when filled with sheep tilted up ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,7)

MEREDITH At the end of the dip are two draining-pens, used alternately. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,88) [NOTES: (1935)]

After sheep dipping, the dip is used for soaking the droppers in. (Aug 1900,NZ Farmer,331)

PERRY It is wise to build a dip. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,20)

RIDDOLLS The yards consist of two essential parts: a) crush pens leading to the dip; and b) drainage pens leading from the dip. (1958,Farm Engineering,358)

THORNTON An alternative to the swim dip or race type was the 'pot.' (1986,NZ Heritage of Farm Buildings,213)

THORNTON There are various forms of dip such as race, well, pot and shower dip. [dip-wash, walk-through, tub-dip etc] (1986,NZ Heritage of Farm Buildings,257)

Now I flung it, flung it into the poisonous dip, the trough full of sheep piss and Cooper's yellow chemical to kill the parasites. (Oct 20, 1991,Dominion Sunday Times,25)

The Provincial Government have set off a piece of ground at Wanganui as a sheep dip. (Jul 8, 1873,Wellington Independent,2)

v. put (sheep) through a dip

n. a sheep dip (the bath)

n. sheep dip (the chemical liquid) [aka sheep dip]

1 v. (Rural) to rid sheep and cattle of lice, keds, other parasites and fungi by placing in a spray, race, swim, pot or swim-through dip or by using pour-on.

To dip a thousand sheep in tobacco water costs, in material alone, GBP13 10s.; while with sulphur and soda the material would only cost GBP4 18s. (Aug 22, 1862,Colonist (Nelson),4)

These sheep, after being landed, must be dipped. (Oct 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

WELD .. make use of this as soon as your sheep arrive, and are fit to bear it, dipping them in a strong decoction of tobacco ... (1860,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,26)

Sheep have to be dipped three months before they quit Nelson ... (1860,BLANK ENTRY,43) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

.. and if a man's sheep trespass on to his neighbour's run he has to dip his neighbour's also. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,44) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

MEREDITH As the sheep are slightly infected with scab, we have to dip them periodically. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,87) [NOTES: (1935)]

Dipped ram hoggets. (Jul 9, 1878,Johnston Diary)

MOWAT Drafted off the woollies, dipped the rest. (Jan 27, 1917,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

Hoggets that weren't dipped when they were shorn in October, or lambs not dipped at weaning may need dipping with an effective pour-on off-shears in autumn. (2002,Wool Grower,Autumn 7)

In New Zealand she sheep farmer is required to dip by law. (1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,100)

NEWTON All told, with wethers, some dry ewes and the hoggets, there were just on 5,000 to dip. (1966,Boss's Story, The,19)

Accused also said that his sheep had already been dipped once, and that he intended to dip again next week. (Jun 22, 1859,Lyttelton Times,5)

1 n. (Rural) a powder, paste or liquid that is mixed with water for the dipping of sheep.

TIFFEN The dip was mixed in four-hundred-gallon tanks ... (1845,Journal,108) [NOTES: in Cresswell (1949) Early New Zealand Families]

It would be decidedly a good plan to dip both ewes and lambs off the shears with a good non-poisonous dip. (Nov 20, 1915,NZ Journal of Agriculture,456)

There are several kinds of dips, such as fluid, powder and paste. (1919,Wool in NZ,13)

SCOTT I think that the most unpleasant part of the job was scrubbing the posts and rails and gates of the sheep yards with 'dip' but it had to be done to stamp out the disease [scab]. (1922,Reminiscences of a New Chum in Otago,18)

The best feature about these dips, however, is the beneficial results so noticeable in the wool at shearing time. Each of these dips is ideal for its own particular purpose. (Jan 1, 1929,NZ Farmer,23)

It is obvious that the different dips which are now available are all produced for a specific purpose. Ibid. Oct. 25 [It] should give protection against maggot fly for 2 to 3 months when used in plunge or shower dips. (Oct 1972,NZ Journal of Agriculture,24)

The basic ingredient used in all poisonous dips is the powerful poison arsenic.Ibid. 199 Sheep should not be dumped into the dip head first. (1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60/105)

The dip manufacturers.. are reluctant for trade reasons to recommend any definitive number of sheep after which the wash should be discarded. (1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60/201)

Please forward to Waihoa Downs at your earliest convenience another five cases of "Puritas Sheep Dip." (Nov 27, 1926,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

There are many who use a solution of arsenic as a dip for sheep, which has undoubtedly the recommendation of economy of cost, and I believe, when judiciously applied, to be quite as efficacious as tobacco, as far as curing the scab goes. (Dec 2, 1857,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

dip one's lid¶

phr. to raise one's hat [ca1935 (Havelock) -->19 - Partridge D.S. [?p] Dip one's lid ... Aust: -1916 Dennis]

dip paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a field or paddock containing a sheep dip.

NEWTON Out in the dip paddock a few enthusiasts were busy marking out the pitch and planning boundaries. (1949,High Country Days,58)

NEWTON Sharp on twelve, all hands trooped to the dip paddock ... (1949,High Country Days,59)

dip post¶

1 n. (Rural) a specially footed and stayed post used in a dip or incline on a fenceline.

RIDDOLLS Dip posts in soft boggy spots to be securely anchored by fastening two strands of No 8 wire ... (1958,Farm Engineering,414)

Hunter fence is particularly suitable for hilly country as it eliminates 'dip posts.' (Jul 1971,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

ADDENBROOKE We had one dip-post being stapled, ready to force the wire under ... (1992,Home from the Hill,55)

Fence posts on a bend (angle posts) or in a hollow (dip posts) need special attention in fence construction ... [dip-post] (Feb 10, 2002,RD1.com,Farm Management Agfact.)

dip south/tip south¶

phr. to put one's hand in one's pocket for money

PARTRIDGE South, dip . To put one's hand in one's pocket for money, esp. if it is running low: New Zealanders': C. 20. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,803)

`To dip South' is to spend much needed money; ... (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

BAKER Terms originated in the first Great War [include] ... to tip south , to put one's hand into one's pocket (1941,NZ Slang,50)

dip yard¶

n.

NEWTON Gordon Edge had built a first-class set of drafting yards.. and alongside these the old dip yards were a real eyesore. (1966,Boss's Story, The,112)

dip-hand¶

1 n. (Rural) a worker at dipping yards and sheep dip.

The first dip-hand was the yarder up, whose duty it was to keep working the sheep forward as the final small pen and the yard leading into it were emptied. (1888,Textile Educator I,261)

.. the third dip-hand, an old soldier, had the responsibility of keeping up the supply of hot water and soap. (1888,Textile Educator I,262)

dip-yard¶

1 n. (Rural) sheepyard adjoining a sheep dip.

BRABAZON Worked at dip-yard fence. (Feb 27, 1908,Brabazon Diaries)

MCLEOD As soon as the dip-yard gate was opened, they knew what to expect, and fought every inch of the way to the water's edge. (1954,On the Hill,23)

dipped¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] bathed or sprayed [in dipping fluid to kill parasites etc.]

BISLEY .. we have received into our own stores wool from the same station, and from the same class of sheep, dipped and undipped ... (1897,Practical Treatise on Wool and Sheep Breeding,51)

MILLER The dipped sheep had to be confined to a certain part of the Run ... (1958,Sturdy Sons,128)

SALISBURY On the way back to Te Rata I met Mick Williams the head shepherd from Waipaoa Station with three shepherds taking a very large mob of dipped lambs up the river. (1994,I Was So Lucky,107)

dipper¶

n.

He says locals in the know will be heading to "the dipper" for a prime view of cars sliding their way around the hill. (May 27, 2004,Wellington Contact,4)

He says locals in the know will be heading to "the dipper" for a prime view of cars sliding their way around the hill. (May 27, 2004,Wellington Contact,4)

1 n. (Rural) a person employed at the sheep dip and dipyards.

FISHER Ralph's attitude towards the 'drifters' - gangs of scrubcutters, shearers, crutchers, footrotters, dippers, fencers and dockers was quite different. (1978,Dolphins and Killer Whales,45)

. . we have in this country persons who go from farm to farm and find all the apparatus at so much per score, and get a good living at the business, and the farmer runs no risk afterwards by using poisoned tubes, as these are brought by the dipper. (Mar 21, 1846,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,10)

The slovenly manner in which sheep are sometimes dipped leads, with the former variety , to an imperfect solution and unequal distribution of the remedial agent, with, as a result, death of some of the last to be dipped, or loss of fleece, besides the poisoning of grass and impregnatioin of water courses, while the so-called non-poisonous dips are ineffectual, unless more time and care is bestowed than the average dipper cares to take. (Mar 6, 1894,Bruce Herald,4)

dipping¶

n. sheep dipping

Dipping would be over in a week or two followed a month or so later by crutching, (Dec 9, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

One single important error at the time of dipping can seriously affect the end result. (Oct 1972,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

We have finished dipping our sheep. (Apr 8, 1924,Otago Witness,72)

By systematic dipping this particular disease [sc. scab] has been eradicated from New Zealand flocks. (1938,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57/477)

Careless dipping is a waste of money. The early pastoralists were faced with the necessity of treating their ever-increasing flocks in an expeditious manner - and so were developed the swim dips and draining pens and other arrangements with which every sheep farmer is now all too familiar. (1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60/101)

If you started chipping men after a few hours' dipping, you'd soon be without any men at all. (1966,Boss's Story, The,20)

Control [sc. of green blowfly] is by dipping, spraying or jetting with organophosphates. (Feb 1972,NZ Journal of Agriculture,20)

n.

McRAE Tobacco was grown mainly for dipping scabby sheep in the juices, although scab was not at that time a major problem. (1963,By the Braes of Balquether,32)

n.

The Government seem to be in part alive, by.. erecting a dipping apparatus nearly adjoining the cattle sale-yards at Remuera. (Sep 20, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,13)

1 n. (Rural) the washing of sheep to rid them of parasites, insects, fungi etc.

WELD .. an apparatus for dipping in case of disease, should at once be erected. (1860,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,26)

MEREDITH If a single infected sheep is left undipped on the run, it will infect all others, in which case all the trouble and cost of dipping is wasted. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,87) [NOTES: (1935)]

In the case of sheep affected with lice or ticks the Inspector can order an immediate dipping. The dipping of long-woolled and crossbred sheep is made compulsory once a year. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,223)

RIDDOLLS Although dipping is compulsory, the dipping material, providing it is effective, is left to the choice of the owner ... (1958,Farm Engineering,358)

WATERS Dipping time was hard work in the old swim-through type of dip, especially if the sheep had 'ergot'. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,11)

.. the practice of dipping is less than 200 years old and was developed in Australia and New Zealand. (2001,Wool Grower,Summer 32)

dipping crutch¶

1 n. (Rural) a long pole with an S-shaped hook on the end, used to push under sheep's heads in a swim, pot, or plunge dip. (See crutch,dipping pole)

GASCOIGNE My task was on the edge of the dip, armed with a dipping crutch to plunge each sheep under, for lice swarm up on to the heads of affected sheep as they swim. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,35)

COATES .. the older sheep did all they could to hold back from that cold plunge and the following push to the bottom of the dip by the man on the dipping crutch. (1995,Dining With the Cats,67)

dipping muster¶

1 n. (Rural) a gathering in of sheep for dipping or spraying.

SHARPE On high or rough country there are always straggler sheep which dodge the dipping muster. (1962,Country Occasions,74)

VANCE In those days there were three annual musters - for shearing, dipping and autumn muster. (1965,High Endeavour,188)

dipping pen¶

1 n. (Rural) a small enclosure at sheep dipping yards, where sheep are drafted into small numbers appropriate for a dipping bath. (See dipping yard)

.. sheep entering the dipping pen will run much easier if they see the decoys before they see the dip itself. The dipping pen will hold 30 sheep. (Jan 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture,11)

FERNANDEZ Then with a gesture typical of him, Andrew pulled his cloth hat down over his forehead and made for the dipping pens. (1973,Tussock Fever,191)

dipping season¶

n.

A step in the right direction would be to have the dipping season shortened to one month for all travelling sheep. (1898,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VI/47)

dipping tank¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep dip for washing sheep prior to shearing.

HOBHOUSE The necessary features of a station are a dwelling house for the manager, as store for the supply of rations, clothing and horse ands bullock gear, a woolshed with dipping tank etc and pens for the sheep in waiting ... (Nov 4, 1859,Letter)

dipping yard¶

1 n. (Rural) a yard in proximity to a sheep dip [often a draining yard.]

The sheep should be paddocked conveniently to the dipping yards. (Dec 1, 1928,NZ Farmer,1481)

MCMILLAN And in about the dipping yard and round the shearing shed ... (1981,Tales of the High Country,12)

LOUGHNAN It [a forcing pen] differs from a crush pen in as much one of these is needed only where physical force may be required, eg in the dipping yards. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,32)

dipping-pole¶

1 n. (Rural) a crutch with an S-hook used to push sheep under dipping fluid in a dip-bath. (See crutch,dipping crutch)

PORTER .. the yell of a musterer whose dipping pole slipped off a sheep's head and he fell into the dip. (1970,Under the Nor'West Arch,33)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Long dipping poles each topped with a horizontal S-hook were used. Mr Know called these poles crummachs. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,66)

dippy¶

1 n. (Rural) a student studying for Diploma in Agriculture at Massey University. [also at Lincoln University (TD)]

Dippies, aggies, Redbands and Swanndris - forever tied to Massey University ... (Mar 23, 2002,Midweek,24)

dippy sheep¶

n.

He had been contacted by North Islandshearers who have suffered blurredvision, dizziness and nausea afterhandling sheep that had been recentlydipped [with organophosphates]. The riskyanimals were known in the trade as "dippysheep"... A Rangiora sheep dipcontractor.. said he had heard reports ofshearers being affected by dippy sheep inhot wool sheds. (Jun 4, 1995,Sunday Star Times,A10)

direct report¶

n. someone who reports directly to a superior

After becoming aware of the relationship, organisational development manager Joe Guthrie wrote to [him] saying the company would not condone a personal relationship between a manager and a "direct report"... The authority held that [he] had been unjustifiably dismissed as "no fair and reasonable employer could have concluded that he had committed serious misconduct simply for failing to acknowledge that he had exercised poor judgment in entering into a relationship with a direct report, particularly after that direct report had resigned." (Jul 6, 2002,Dominion,7)

direct-drill¶

1 v. (Rural) to oversow pasture or crop with seed.

Establishment data from the experiment on direct-drilling Ruanui or Nui into existing swards indicate that Ruanui was not as suited to this method of introduction as the more vigorous Nui. (Mar 1979,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57)

He has a variety of special purpose pastures. We saw one of his latest which had been direct drilled with Nui 28 kg, Manawa 6 kg... (Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,16)

After the cereals we direct-drill greenfeed into the stubble. (Sep 4, 1997,NZ Farmer,17)

When we direct-drilled one of our poorest paddocks with that mix, it went from 26 to 27 days to 21 to 22 days between grazings. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,48)

direct-drilling¶

n. [verb as well as noun in the citation]

By September and October we'll be direct-drilling summer crops, as well as working ground from peas and sweet corn."... Many Hawke's Bay farmers have taken on the concept of direct-drilling in the past few years... (Aug 26, 2004,Dominion Post,Farming Supplement p. 9)

dirt-scratcher¶

n. the driver of large earth-moving machinery

For their part, underground miners speak condescendingly of the "dirt-scratchers" who drive the big diggers and trucks of an opencast operation. (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/44)

dirt-tracker¶

n. a rugby football name for those members of a touring team who play midweek rather than the choice weekend games

One: "In the last week, before the third test, the management said they didn't want to see us dirt-trackers around the hotel, just to keep out of the way." (Jun 19, 2005,Dominion Post,7,Lions on Tour Supplement ed.)

He stood by me all the way, and when he came back from the meeting he ordered the dirt-trackers [the others were all playing the next day] all to be rounded up. (Jul 19, 2001,Evening Post,13)

ROMANOS I might be pencilled in as one of the dirt-trackers, but you never know what can happen during World Cup month. (1997,Black,133)

dirtsurfer¶

n. scooter with BMX wheels

Tagged the skateboard on steroids, the dirtsurfer - built for careering down mountain sides or ripping up a mellow grassy slope - has the same fluid turning motion that has hooked every surfer, snowboarder and kiteboarder... Dirt surfers have an "aircraft aluminium" frame, a flexible deck for suspension, two knobby BMZX tyres and calf-operated brakes. (Aug 8, 2002,Dominion Post,A8)

dirtsurfing¶

n. (Sport) sport using a type of scooter with BMX tyres

Dirtsurfing is becoming the new craze in Australia, Switzerland and America. (Aug 8, 2002,Dominion Post,A8)

dirty¶

n. a dirt-tracker, one who mainly plays in secondary games on tour

We were initially hoping to take 26 All Blacks and a smaller NZ A squad and play some of the All Black 'dirties' with NZ A. (Sep 27, 2000,Evening Post,38)

n. (Rural) a sheep that requires dagging prior to shearing.

FOSTER & WRIGHT After an hour's riding a block is mustered off and 2000 sheep driven to nearby drafting yards. There the 'dirties' - the sheep in need of dagging - and the rams are drafted out. (1983,Stockman Country,141)

FOSTER & WRIGHT Head shepherd Tom Fleming drafting in the Bottom Six yards. He separates out the rams, "dirties" and strays from the ewes. (1983,Stockman Country,151)

1 adj. (Rural) [of farm working conditions in exposed areas] exceedingly wet and windy.

NEWTON One of the dirtiest days I've had on the hill was on that block. (1964,Straggle Muster,18)

NEWTON .. I had only just hit the high ridge when a dirty driving sou'west storm hit us. .. the storm was one of those quick dirty busters and it was over in about two hours. (1966,Boss's Story, The,90)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR But Jim Clews had a theory that we did more harm than good in riding round the ewes in dirty weather. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,112)

dirty burn¶

1 n. (Rural) an incomplete or black burn where there is no remnant white ash.

NEWPORT This [scrubcutting] was so that all the undergrowth and vines would dry and help carry the fire when the bush was burned. Otherwise there would not be a satisfactory burn - commonly known as a 'dirty burn.' (1989,Footprints Farewell,164)

dirty dairying¶

1 n. (Rural) the flowing of dairy shed effluent into waterways.

Fish and Game New Zealand backed up its "dirty dairying" campaign rhetoric yesterday with scientific research by soil and water experts that claims a firm link between intensive farming and waterway pollution... The institute's report says waterways are in poor condition mainly because of "dirty dairying" and are likely to get worse. Ibid. 12 Mr Polson claims (June 19) that Federated Farmers is doing something about "dirty dairying" and he lists a series of schemes. (Jun 26, 2002,Dominion,9)

Something has to be done about dirty dairying and our polluted streams and lakes, and the lack of biodiversity in a country with so much grass, the terrible impact of introduced pests on our forests. (Feb 20, 2011,Sunday Star Times: Escape,3) [NOTES: Paul Callaghan]

Fonterra has promised the Government and regional councils to wipe out dirty dairying. In an accord signed at Parliament yesterday, the industry giant spelled out how it would make farmers fence streams, bridge or culvert water crossings and stop fertiliser runoff into waterways. (May 27, 2003,Dominion Post,A6)

Dirty dairying debate will not go away. Mr Lodge's comments at the annual meeting of Federated Farmers' dairy section in Wellington came in the wake of a year's debate about so-called 'dirty dairying' degrading water quality in waterways and in ground water. (Jun 18, 2002,Dominion,23)

Waikite Valley farm company fined for dirty dairying: A North Island dairy farm has been fined $11,000 after cowshed effluent was discharged on to land. (Jun 25, 2002,Waikato Times,2)

Agriculture minister Jim Sutton has apparently shrugged off the 'dirty dairying' campaign and is continuing to back the dairy industry to regulate its own environmental issues. (Sep 12, 2002,Wanganui Chronicle,16)

Fish and Game, a non-profit organisation representing the country's anglers and hunters was to assume the unpopular role of whistle-blower on dirty dairying. (Oct 2002,North & South,10)

Mr Johnson, leader of Fish and Game's "dirty dairying" campaign, says instead of attacking the Government, Federated Farmers ought to be trying to earn public respect by doing something about farming's pollution of waterways. (Nov 27, 2004,Dominion Post,A9)

Mr Johnson is the first to declare that he doesn't consider all dairying as dirty, and the Fish and Game Council has suggested that the "dirty dairying" phrase should not be used... The article also quoted the chairman of Federated Farmers' dairy section who said there was not a problem, and that dirty dairying was a myth. (Jun 19, 2002,Dominion,15)

dirty dirty¶

n. a rugby player outside the selected players

"...that was the first time I was a Dirty Dirty for a team, but I think I'm a better person for it... It's made me think back to the guys who were the Dirty Dirties in those teams and the jobs they did." Being Dirty Dirty is a thankless job. During the week the unwanted players are used as cannon fodder for the team, running in defence at training and trying to simulate a game atmosphere without (of course) injuring the guys playing in their place. Closer to the match they have to disappear, to give the playing 22 a bit of space, then on game day they are used for everything from ferrying bags to picking up the dirty playing gear after the game. (Dec 3, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,8)

Simon's been an unsung hero. He's had to carry a lot of the burden of a dirty-dirty [someone outside the playing 22]. (Jul 16, 2004,Dominion Post,C12)

He has to carry a lot of the burden as a dirty-dirty. He has done a lot of work for us in simulating opposition lineouts and he has run the reserves really well against the pack. (Jul 15, 2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://xtramsn.co.nz/sport/]

[Caption] Afarto So'oalo, Con Barrell, Steve Lancaster and Andrew Mehrtens [were in] the 'Dirty Dirties' and watched the game from the stand during the Super 12 game played between the Crusaders vs the Waratahs at Jade Stadium, Christchurch, New Zealand, on the 5th May 2000. (May 5, 2000,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: www.sportphotos.co.nz/display.aspx?image]

After breakfast the Dirty Dirties (squad members not playing on the weekend) met at 9.40am and we went and played badminton. (Nov 20, 2004,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: www.allblacks.com/index.cfm Jerome Kaino]

It's an interesting mix with uncapped players John Afoa, Jason Eaton and Isaia Toeava among the players who were effectively the "dirty dirties" last week. (Nov 7, 2005,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: http://xtramsn.co.nz/news (Duncan Johnstone)]

Fearing a trap, Toeava said he didn't want to answer such questions before Oliver came to his rescue by saying they had enjoyed themselves as the non-playing dirty dirties in London. (Nov 25, 2005,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,7)

Greg Somerville - 6.32. Another player who spent most of his time among the dirty dirties. Did start in two games but failed to do anything startling. (Aug 24, 2005,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: www.tvnz.co.nz/sport/ (David Long)]

[Caption] Highlanders'dirty/dirties' during the Super 12 semi-final played between the Crusaders and the Highlanders at Jade Stadium, Christchurch on the 18th of May, 2002 (May 18, 2002,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: www.sportphotos.co.nz/display.aspx?image (nb this may be a recent caption on an old photo)]

First caps going to the Hurricanes pairing of Neemia Tialata and Chris Masoe, and domestic season dirty dirties Ryan and Smith strting, along with injury comeback boys Kelleher and Oliver. (Nov 3, 2005,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: www.rugbyweb.co.nz]

For a group of dirty dirties, the tour is clearly over. (Nov 22, 2005,TV1,News)

dirty fern¶

n. Dryopteris velutena [[get cit: JD says ??]]

FIELD (And) (1890,Ferns of NZ)

dirty paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) farm area carrying rough feed or weed.

Ewes can be used to clean up any dirty paddocks. (Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,219)

disc¶

v. [also spelt disk]

I have ploughed 1,250 acres, hustled 1,000 and disced, drilled, harrowed, etc., a fair amount. (May 28, 1928,NZ Free Lance,45)

Should the land have been ploughed and worked down or disked and harrowed, all cultivation possible should be given while the fern is growing. (1938,NZ Journal of Agriculture,234)

About 50 acres of land has been turned over.. and now it has to be disced. (Oct 1, 1937,Morrinsville Star,4)

disc harrow¶

n.

EVANS Up to the late 70's tine harrows were popular for preparing land for sowing, but during the 1870's the first Disc Harrows were imported from America. (1956,History of Farm Implements,12)

[Caption] At work with the disc harrows on an East Coast farm. (Oct 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,46)

EVANS One of their [sc. M.J. Hooper & Co's] most notable achievements was the production of Hooper Giant Disc Harrows. (1984,History of Farm Implements,Appendix 21)

disc-harrow¶

v. [also as verb to disc q.v.]

[Caption] Disc-harrowing with a bullock team. (Jan 26, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,39)

He was disc-harrowing in a paddock on the Saturday. (Oct 20, 1917,NZ Truth,6)

discs¶

n. [also spelt disks; see also disc harrow noun]

CRUMP "Never heard of anyone using six horses in the discs," he cried. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,38) [NOTES: 1970 edition]

The soil should be stirred occasionally during the summer with disks and harrows until late February or early March. (1938,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57/52)

Where rolling has been left rather later, a cut with the discs will be helpful in preparing the land for subsequent rolling. (1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60/415)

HILL A set of discs is a real bonus when it comes to dealing with the paspallum [sic]. (1988,More from Moaville,8)

disengage¶

v. (of police) take early retirement

Officers are leaving - 75 per cent of them "disengaging" (Police National Headquarters preferred term for taking their Police Employment Rehabilitation Fund, or PERF) - faster than they're coming in. (Oct 1997,North & South,35)

disking¶

n. [cf. disc verb]

In the early spring disk harrows should be used to disintegrate the furrow before reploughing, and further disking to break up the soil before summer dryness makes the work difficult. (1938,NZ Journal of Agriculture,57/52)

Disneyland¶

n.

Disneyland: Where a player goes when he takes "a heavy knock"; that is, his head has been stamped on. (Oct 2, 1999,Evening Post,7)

Disneyland Dad¶

n. a father with access to his children at weekends and holidays

Some fathers who lost full custody became "Disneyland dads", taking children out for a good time during visits and neglecting to keep their behaviour in check. (Dec 5, 2003,Dominion Post,A5)

Disputes Tribunal¶

n. a judicial tribunal designed to determine small civil claims cheaply and informally. [Jim Cameron writes: Known as a small claims tribunal 1976-1988. Presided over by referees. Disputes Tribunals Act 1988.]

Some obsolete terms (e.g. entail, foreclosure, probation) are not noted as historical only. Even the Dictionary of New Zealand English (DNZE) (1997) is patchy in its coverage of legal terms, having for example no entry for disputes tribunal, family protection, incorporated society, Maori option, protection order, resource consent. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2(1) : 1)

dissolution kit¶

n.

Do-it-yourself marriage dissolution (divorce) could become common practice if a recently released dissolution kit takes off. (Feb 23, 1983,Evening Post,10)

distributor¶

n.

HAWKE & SCOTT Ridgers could also be a separate implement, as were early distributors forfertilizer. (1985,Early Farm Machinery in NZ,67)

District Board¶

n.

A copy of the petition and its annexes must be sent to the District Board [sc. of the Hospital] at least fourteen days before it is presented to the Governor. (Oct 8, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

District Council¶

n.

The forced amalgamation of six small authorities into the Far North District Council in 1989 forced us for the first time in our history to co-ordinate our varying interests. (May 1, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

The broad scheme of the Bill is to set up district councils which will replace existing borough and county councils and may take over the functions of many ad hoc bodies such as catchment boards..pest destruction councils, and so on. (1974,NZ Parliamentary Debates,394/4555)

District Court¶

n.

Magistrates courts were renamed district courts and their presiding judges district court judges in 1981, but the term magistrate in New Zealand denoted stipendiary magistrates rather than justices of the peace, who were and are usually referred to simply as justices or JPs. (District court has itself a history. Originally district courts were intermediate courts created in 1858; they were squeezed out between the Supreme Court (now the High Court) and the magistrates courts and were formally abolished in 1925.) The latest episode of this serial is the creation in 1998 of community magistrates to sit in district courts and exercise minor criminal jurisdiction. (Jan 1999,NZWords,1)

district high school¶

n. (historical) originally a rural primary school offering some secondary instruction; later a rural secondary school.

BROOKING Tate suggested that the solution to New Zealand's agricultural education problem lay with the District High Schools. (1977,Massey - Its Early Years,19)

Owen Marshall Dylan Ormond had been at the district high, but only because even his mother and father knew that the expense of a city education would have been wasted on him. (2005,Watch of Gryphons,240)

District Judge¶

n.

Shortly after his appointment as a District Judge, his Honor went on circuit to Hamilton. (Oct 16, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

district licensing trust¶

n. [Jim Cameron writes : Since 1989 this term has become largely though not wholly historical.]

district nurse¶

n.

BAKER "I'm from north Hokianga... I was a district nurse there." (2000,Kokopu Dreams,66)

district plan¶

n.

Other distinctive NZE terms include district plan, regional plan, heritage order, access strip, and esplanade strip. There are dictionary entries for scenic reserve but not, for example, historic place, maritime park, or soil conservation reserve. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

The Mayor.. stressed that the audit's recommendations had not yet been included in the Council's District Plan. "They have been left out deliberately so that the Council can consult with all interested parties prior to the District Plan being finalised in approximately two years time"... (May 1996,NZ Historic Places,58/5)

ditch and bank¶

v. (Rural) to form a fenceline or barrier by digging an embankment over which stock can not pass.

Did some ditch and banking in the morning ... (Mar 29, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,30) [NOTES: (1950)]

In Tuesday's issue of the STAR I noticed a letter signed 'H.B.' in reference to the Maoris ditching and banking on a Sunday. (Aug 21, 1885,Hawera Star,2)

1 n. (Rural) a formation of a fenceline, embankment or barrier with the digging of a ditch.

GRAHAM Fencing, ditch and bank with a hurdle fence on top. Cost 1/6 per perch. (Dec 12, 1844,Letter,88) [NOTES: in Kalaugher (1950) Gleanings]

We have now all but finished one paddock of about 400 acres, with a ditch and bank. (1848,BLANK ENTRY,51) [NOTES: in DEANS (1964) Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains]

TAIT Two ditch and bank fences and an old plough share were the only evidence of any previous cultivation. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,122)

ditch light¶

n.

All locomotives have lights on top of their cabs, but Tranz Rail is adding "ditch lights" lower down that will flash when horns are sounded, making trains more visible to motorists. (Mar 20, 2001,Dominion,1)

ditch, the¶

1 n. the Tasman Sea (across the ditch: to or in Australia) [attributive use of across-the-ditch in first citation below]

After all, the New Zealand economy is not in bad shape compared with the United States or our across-the-ditch cousie, Australia. (May 5, 2001,Evening Post,13)

Vine was across the ditch helping his son buy a house. (Jan 24, 2006,Dominion Post,B4)

In business and pleasure, the rough Tasman passage - more than ever before - is just "the ditch", no longer even a psychological barrier to movement. (Feb 15, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

[Hdg] Clark's agreement with Howard widens the Ditch. (Mar 5, 2001,Dominion,2)

Like many New Zealand companies it crossed the ditch because it couldn't grow much more here. (May 5, 2001,Evening Post,15)

So thank God for the bonds of affection that will endure between the hundreds of thousands of us whose friends and families straddle this ocean we used to call the ditch. (Mar 29, 2003,Dominion Post,A14)

Later in the year there'll be a major cartoon exhibition - with the provisional title, 'The other side of the ditch'. (Apr 11, 2001,Capital Times,10)

"Even Australians have to concede and go 'if we're going to make good film, then we've got to go across the ditch. (Dec 2, 2005,Dominion Post,B6)

[He] is the latest of a series of Australian executives who have jumped the ditch and landed at the helm of a New Zealand electricity company. (Jun 25, 2003,Dominion,C4)

My solution to unrequited love is to pick the eyes out of the cultural calendar, find cheap flights and look for a few weekends a year across the ditch. (Jul 10, 2001,Dominion,15)

The bulletin is broadcast, disconcertingly, from across the ditch. (Feb 28, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),79)

2 n. Cook Strait [cook straight sic in citation?]

[heading] Across the ditch (cook straight, that is) (May 20, 2005,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,8)

ditch-digger¶

1 n. (Rural) a piece of heavy machinery used for ditching.

KERR A ditch-digger and a D8 bulldozer gnawed away at it. (2000,High Times in the High Country,152)

Div¶

n. (informal) (as the Div) = Divvy

O'Sullivan But my father arranged it [the funeral] and rang around their cobbers from the Div... (2006,Pictures by Goya,150)

div¶

n.

None of the Bullstown "pubs" are paying heavy "divs." (Feb 26, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,35)

diversion¶

n. n. in criminal procedure, a system for giving a chance for a first- time criminal defendant in lesser crimes to perform community service, make restitution for damage due to the crime, obtain treatment for alcohol or drug problems and/or counselling for antisocial or mentally unstable conduct. If the defendant cooperates and the diversion results in progress, the charges eventually may be dismissed. Usually diversion may not be granted for a second offense. [definition from Californian based law.com dictionary, entered 8/10/2001 [http://dictionary.law.com/]]

Diversion is a system by which first-time offenders can be charged with a minor offence and escape without a conviction. (Mar 15, 2004,Salient,No. 3/33)

However Wellington Police Community Services Coordinator Detective Tony Moore disagrees, He sees youth initiatives like family group conferences and diversion as worthwhile. (Nov 1, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),3)

Divide¶

n. the Southern Alps [also Great Divide]

BEARDSLEY ﻿"Richard the Lion-hearted uncrowned kingof New Zealand, had cross the GreatDivide." "Last seen heading for theCass," said Jimmy Jude, and there was alaugh. (1984,Blackball 08,18)

The vista of the Divide peaks aheadprovides an incentive which can neverfail to spur him on. (1934,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,III/64)

At dusk I observed many of the dreaded"hogsbacks" rolling across the Divide. (1934,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,III/64)

divider¶

1 n. (Rural) a dog that divides sheep in a carefully gathered mob [in a fit of impatience or over-enthusiasm.]

STAPYLTON-SMITH Mostly these dogs are of inestimable value, but at times, in an excess of zeal, they may become 'splitters,' or 'slewers,' or 'dividers.' (1990,Other Side of Farming, The,201)

dividing range¶

n.

Resolved, That the Department be informed that the proposed road is inpracticable [sic], and recommending that a new road be surveyed on the diving range between the two roads. (Dec 11, 1890,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

Our guide shewed us another small valley three miles nearer the Lake than the one through which we had travelled, where he said there was a path leading to the valley of the Pakuratahi; with a little time devoted to asertain where a line may be carried, so as to avoid the highest points of the dividing range of hills, I have no doubt a road may be made so as readily to unite Wairarapa with the valley of the Hutt, at a cost perfectly insignificant, if we regard the extent of level and fertile land which it would be the means of rendering available, or the advantages it would confer on the first and principal settlement. (Dec 22, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

The eastern boundary proceeds from the Mokutapu, thence along the summit of the dividing range of the Maitai and Pelorus for a distance of eight miles, from thence the southern boundary commences, and proceeds in a straight line to the southern angle of section No. 8 Suburban South, thence along the northern boundary of sections Nos. 19, 99, 76, 75, and 77, Waimea East district, to high-water mark. (Nov 8, 1851,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,148)

".. Eighteen years afterwards, far on the eastern side of the big dividing range, and near the Hutt River, some bushfellers found the bones of the hapless lad." (Aug 5, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,4)

diving petrel¶

n. titi

.. there is a very pretty group including crested grebe, dabchick, grey duck, black teal, and flightless duck ; another taking in the mutton bird, whale bird, stormy petrel, night bird, blue billy, driving [sic] petrel, shearwater, and black petrel ... (Sep 14, 1888,Otago Witness,15)

New exhibits at the Colonial Museum include .. a diving petrel from the Antipodes Island. (Aug 29, 1900,Evening Post,4)

He appends the following list of birds to be found on the Little Barrier in support of his statement .. diving-petrel ... (Nov 16, 1892,Colonist (Nelson),3)

DIVING-PETREL (Pelecanoides urinatrix Gmelin). (1928,Chatham Islands,9/285)

BULLER PELECANOIDES URINATRIX. (DIVING-PETREL.) (1873,Birds of New Zealand,313,1888 2nd edn 2/207 ed.)

HUTTON 124. HALADROMA URINATRIX. Gml. Diving Petrel. Titi. Pelecanoides urinatrix. GRAY. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,45)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Pelecanoides urinatrix - Diving Petrel - Kuaka. Kuaka is also in the North Island a name given to the Southern Godwit - Limosa Novae Zealandiae. (1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,201)

RICHARDS Pelicanoides ... urinatrix ... var. chathamica ... Diving Petrel. KUAKA. (1952,Chatham Islands,87)

Colin Miskelly hopes that one day he will be able to turn off the tape for good and listen to the real thing: the clamour of diving petrels, fairy prions, storm petrels and sooty shearwaters returning to feed their chicks... The first diving petrel chicks were transferred to artificial burrows on Mana, from North Brother Island in Cook Strait, in 1977. (Jun 2002,Forest & Bird,304/8)

Stereophonic seabird calls booming out across the ocean have played a major role in luring diving petrels back to Mana Island, where 14 pairs are now incubating eggs. (Oct 2003,Footnotes,No. 20/5)

n.

Common Diving Petrel Pelecanoides urinatrix (GMELIN, 1789) ... New Zealand Diving Petrel P.u. urinatrix ... OTHER NAMES: Kuaka Chatham Island diving petrel, Kerguelen diving petrel. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,106)

Division¶

n. (Rural) [ell.] an organisation of rural women [the Women's Division of the Farmers' Union (WDFU), later Women's Division of Federated Farmers (WDFF) most commonly referred to as Division, but from 1999 known as Rural Women.]

The work which is being undertaken by the Women's Division widens out and expands over all our country districts. The Women's Division is the only organisation in our country which purposes to help those who are sick and in need of help and to alleviate the hardships of country women and country children. (Dec 1, 1928,Hawera Star,16)

BARRER The Flock House boys and girls became the special care of members of the Division. (1939,Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand,11)

SIMPSON Its Housekeeper Scheme .. was one of its early and most interesting attempts to lighten the load of the country woman; and the Division is apparently able in this way to keep some fifty or sixty women in continuous employment. (1940,Women of NZ, The,183)

SIMPSON This [social and political] extension of the orginal purpose of the Division has been by some members resented and opposed ... (1940,Women of NZ, The,184)

.. she was also a guest speaker at the Women's Division Federated Farmers (now Rural Women) conference. [Women's Division] (Jul 8, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,17)

Divvy¶

n. short for Division (military) [also Divy below]

Who will race to Divvy Base and fetch a Christmas duff? (Dec 22, 1941,NZEF Times,I/26 : 17)

I thought I saw a driver who reallycouldn't swear And got a shirt from"Divy" baths clean enough to wear. (Aug 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,V/49 : 15)

divvy¶

n. (gambling) dividend [also divy below]

The Devonport Ferry Company drew GBP2000 in sixpenny fares during Jubilee week. A big 'divvy' in prospect. (Feb 8, 1890,NZ Observer,8)

The light-fingered gentry of the pickpocket profession struck.. a 'divvy' of over GBP250. (Mar 9, 1912,NZ Free Lance,22)

No. 13, Letter of Credit, won that race and paid a rattling good divvy. (Apr 24, 1926,NZ Observer,6)

He found himself in the happy position of being able to draw three good 'divvies'. (Jul 12, 1890,NZ Observer,9)

A few "mugs," who didn't know anything, scooped in a GBP24 divy. (Apr 16, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,21)

The horse-owner got his divvy. (Jun 25, 1910,NZ Truth,7)

divvy up¶

v. [1917 = pay up rather than divide (which is general English)?]

Petitioner then got a maintenance order against him.. but he never "divvied up." (Dec 1, 1917,NZ Truth,5)

DIY¶

abbr. Do-It-Yourself artificial breeding where the farmer inseminates the cow. [(farming)]

D.I.Y. Do-It-Yourself artificial breeding where the farmer inseminates the cow. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,40)

dizzy¶

adj. drunk.

LORD Dingbatitis',drinking', doped',dizzy', or on `the drunk' (1921,Ballads of Bung 'Stunology',1976 ed.)

DM¶

1 abbr. (Rural) dry matter.

In hay crops, 20kg of potash per tonne of DM is needed. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,88)

DMA¶

abbr. Direct Marketing Association

The Direct Marketing Association (DMA) and the Advertising Standards Authority have devised a code of practice that covers email marketing... It should be emphasised that the DMA is not condoning this kind of behaviour. (Jun 2, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

do¶

v. (Rural) [stock] to thrive.

Lambs do not take to silage or hay and will not 'do' on these feeds. (Jan 23, 1963,Weekly News,38)

GASCOIGNE It looked wonderful and most of us gratefully turned the sheep out. The more observant, however, soon noticed that the sheep were not 'doing.' (1965,From the Top of a Hill,52)

SINCLAIR & TROTTER "Put your rams out on the first of April,' he said. "The early lambs seem to be the ones that do." (1994,From Caithness to Southland,48)

.. the lambs were doing, so obviously the ewes were milking ... (Jun 15, 1994,NZ Farmer,21)

1 v. (Rural) [stockmanship] to cause to thrive.

Ewes have been 'well done by' during the winter. (Sep 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,174)

PERRY Besides the usual pasture, roots and green feed given to the flock it is often profitable to 'do' the show sheep especially well. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,116)

Flock rams noted for their good doing qualities ... 1950 J of Ag Oct 347 The successful management of a sheep run calls for .. an appreciation of the carrying capacity of tussock land to 'do' sheep well without either overstocking or understocking. (Jan 1, 1929,NZ Farmer,56)

do a block¶

phr. (Rural) to muster a large area of hill or high country.

NEWTON While we were doing the block, especially during a shearing muster, we lived like kings. (1947,Straggle Muster,116)

do a button¶

phr.

If you've got to cadge for boodle,/ Then you're said to `do a button'. (Mar 31, 1906,NZ Truth,41/6/4)

do a Carl Lewis¶

phr. to escape

Sporting stars.. are represented by such terms as (do a) Carl Lewis (to run away, make an escape). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

do a flip¶

phr.

WILSON `I'm in the cactus. Done a flip. Just lost three thousand smackaroos on the big race on Wednesday. ...' (1984,South Pacific Street,52)

do a freeze¶

phr. to be neglected or ignored [(watersiders')]

For the foreman had me snouted',/ And I was doing afreeze'. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,110)

do a get¶

phr. to leave in a hurry

Miss Taylor had been carrying on with a boarder, and he was told to do a polite get. (Sep 21, 1907,NZ Truth,118/5/4)

The defendant again got tired of the humdrum existence of domesticity, and once more `did a get', leaving his lady love lamenting. (Jul 31, 1909,NZ Truth,214/7/1)

THOMPSON I prepared to do a get (1909,Ballads about Business,92)

A lady performer followed him out, and said, Go home, Pat.' Bert Hicks also threatened to hit witness unless hedid a get.' (Oct 15, 1910,NZ Truth,277/5/1)

GRACE I must make a git. So long. (1914,Tale of Timbertown,32)

get, do a v. retreat, escape, abscond (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),9)

get n. do a get NZ & Austral. sl. make a get-away, leave hastily. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,316) [NOTES: nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]

McGILL do a get hasty retreat; eg `C'mon, youse jokers, let's do a get before old Musty catches us.' c. 1900. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,37)

do a Kopu/do an Alamein Kopu¶

phr.

Donald and Fitsimons justify this extraordinary balancing act by insisting they are morally obliged to uphold their 1996 pledge to remain in the Alliance for the duration of the current parliamentary term and that to break that pledge would be to "do a Kopu". (Jul 29, 1998,Independent (Auckland),15)

He's going to do an Alamein Kopu. (Aug 8, 1997,Radio NZ / National Radio,Richard Prebble)

I don't actually believe the Derek Quigley for a minute is going to do an Alamein Kopu. (Aug 18, 1997,Dominion,2)

do a line with¶

phr. (of a male) to court, make advances to (a female) [Selected Short Stories SARGESON 196 I was too far gone to care about almost anything except maybe whether I could do a line with Maggie.]

FULLARTON He was doing a heavy line with the saddler's daughter (1944,Troop Target,63)

SARGESON I could do a line with Maggie. (1946,That Summer,91)

GASKELL She was trying to do a line with George. (1947,Big Game,88)

NEWTON Lofty .... was `doing a line' with the governess (1949,High Country Days,151)

SARGESON line: do a line with (a girl), court. (1964,Collected Stories,301) [NOTES: Pearson Glossary]

HILLIARD Silk stockings; and Jinner's strides are half-mast. Here and there a hint of lipstick. Pat's with a grouse new girl again. Must be doing a line with her. (1965,Power of Joy,266)

do a skate¶

phr. to hurry off; to decamp (cf. scale v.) [ca1938 (among schoolchildren)]

McGILL skate phr. do a skate to disappear hurriedly; aka skate off; eg Potts figured there was trouble brewing and did a skate.' c. 1925.</i> - phr. <i>go for a skate</i> a fall, mistake, failure, blunder or dismissal; egIf he doesn't shape up soon he'll go for a skate.' - skate over/around to avoid, move over or blur something disconcerting; eg `She's always skating around the question, never really answering directly.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,103)

do a Taranaki¶

phr. to boast

J WINCHESTER I heard on the breakfast session of 2ZB a few days ago a song composed by Ken Avery which went something like: `I won't be doing a Taranaki/ If I tell you about Wairakei'. (Oct 1963,Personal Communication)

do hard¶

phr. (Rural) [stock management] to restrict the feed intake of stock.

Once the cows have been tupped they are all the better for being done fairly hard until 3 or 4 weeks before lambing. (Apr 16, 1956,NZ Journal of Agriculture,348)

do in¶

2 v. lose, get rid of

John Thomas said he had sacked him for intemperance, which time John [Sullivan] had got another job and `done it in' for the same reason. (Jan 29, 1910,NZ Truth,240/7/3)

The watchhouse-keeper asked where the ring was, and accused said he had `done it in,' meaning that he had got rid of it. (Dec 17, 1910,NZ Truth,286/6/2)

3 v. [Compare do over. 192? K. Mansfield ? Ole Underwood [CHECK]]

do it hard¶

phr. to be angry, worried, upset (over sthg); to suffer (cf. hard doer); to find difficult or hard to bear [ca1920 He did it hard when his wife was dying.]

do one's block¶

phr. to become angry, excited, upset (See cf. do one's bun/loaf/scone; lose one's block)

Hall smelt him, and could detect no odor [sic] of swankey, and concluded that the silent one had `done his block,' to use an ungrammatical vulgarism, and was ripe for the asylum. (Apr 9, 1910,NZ Truth,250/6/1)

A Christchurch bookmaker named Archibald Anderson `did his block' with the aid of hops on March 31, when he went temporarily insane in the Star and Garter Hotel, with a long beer glass clenched murderously in his right hand. (Apr 16, 1910,NZ Truth,251/7/6)

... the clever chap who wrote the epistle would have no hesitation in speaking to this effect: `Dicken! I done me block right enough! I come home and the old finger hit the roof. Tike it from me, he's gotter rat.' (Jul 11, 1921,Quick March,15)

HYDE Don't do your block, but do your best/ To learn your way about. (1934,Journalese,209)

F.G. YOUNG Savage started off and completely did his block; made a vicious attack upon those who supported the resolution and talked about challenging them to a debate ... a challenge ... which we will gladly accept. (Feb 11, 1935,Letter) [NOTES: 1935 Feb 11 F.G.Young to J.Roberts (Roberts Papers 1/12 in 1986 Gustafson Cradle to Grave 161)]

PARTRIDGE Fritz landed a daisy-cutter and the transport driver done his block and took his hook. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

DAVIN The sergeant sounded really irritable. `OK, Sarge, don't do your block.' (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,311)

SLATTER ... a leader of men. He was tough and reliable and never did his block. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,114)

CRUMP And he never done his block about anything that went wrong. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,181)

block, to do one's (Coll. phr.) lose one's temper. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),3)

TOMLINSON But, like most packmen, it took little to annoy him. He was credited with throwing fifty pounds of hard-earned money from the Waiau Ferry Bridge into the flooded river to see if it would float, and then did his block when he never saw the money again. (1968,Remembered Trails,37)

to do your block: to lose your temper (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

CHARLES [DO ONE'S BLOCK, lose one's head] He's done his block and lost his sense,/ (1981,Black Billy Tea,93)

GLOVER Croft tried ... to be hail fellow with everybody, but could sometimes ... do his block. (1981,Hot Water Sailor,224)

SYDER & HODGETTS To be overcome by fear or anger, and act irrationally on the impulse. .;`When he saw the Cop's car after him the silly goat did his block and tried speeding. It only made things worse for him; he never had a hope of getting away.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],265) [NOTES: (1962-63) 1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 265]

MIDDLETON Only a bloody rat ... Nothing to do your block over. (1964,Walk on the Beach,90) [NOTES: (Greaser's Story)]

MANTELL He wanted me to go up country to set another fire. I went ... [sic] and mucked it up. Walker did his block. (1983,Murder to Burn,166)

VIRTUE He really felt like doing his block and telling them just what he was thinking. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,39,1988 ed.)

FULLARTON Don't do your block, Bill. (1944,Troop Target,15)

HENDERSON In the dark, my [disturbed] mind cries out. ... Break it down,' reproves Pilling.Don't do your block.' (1945,Gunner Inglorious,49) [NOTES: [Do One's block, ?go mad, lose self-control]]

do one's bun¶

phr. to lose one's temper (See cf. do one's block etc)

The most important of Army slang expressions, however, has been doing the scone' with its variantdoing the bun', used for losing one's temper. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),II No XIX 24)

SARGE `O.K.! O.K.! don't do your bun,' he answered. (1950,Excuse my Feet!,128)

CRUMP Jock did his bun properly. `So my money's not good enough, eh mate?' he snarled at the driver. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,76)

LELAND ... is to BLOW YOUR FUSE. This, is a temper tantrum but is less general and more directional than to throw a wobbly. One does one's bun at someone. These terms are more often used for adults while children are more likely to throw a wobbly. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,32)

(Goldie Brown Collection) to do your bun: to lose your temper (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland)

McGILL bun phr. do your bun lose your temper; eg `Hey. no need to do your bun, Milt. You'll get your money.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,23)

do one's bundle¶

phr.
