The dog-leg fence, found in North America only in the Maritime Provinces of Canada, reappeared in the Nova Scotian settlement at Waipu, and from there spread to some other bush settlements in the north. It was constructed by driving two crossing stakes into the ground, and in the notch of these placing a third rail which followed the direction of the fence ... It was claimed that it would keep out cattle, but the fence was never widely adopted probably because of its tendency to get out of repair easily. (Oct 1965,NZ Geographer,147) [NOTES: (Hargreaves `Farm Fences')]

BOSWELL So the farm gradually took shape. Small paddocks were fenced, first the crude `dog-leg' of roughly-split light posts, then post-and-rail and later barbed wire. (1955,Dim Horizons,45,1956 ed.)

dogleg adj. applied to primitive fence made of rough timber. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

dog-leg fence NZ & Austral. zigzag fence made of logs supported on crossed poles. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,221) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McGILL doglegged shape of a crooked fence; from the proverbially crooked nature of a dog's hind leg, now more familiar in the dogleg approach to some golf holes. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38)

dog-money¶

n. an official (Public Service) allowance for the upkeep of working dogs. [(deercullers') [Move to dog attrib.]]

CRUMP You'll get five shillings a week dog-money if your pup turns out any good. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,14)

dog-paddle¶

v.

BAKER Bojay shook his [head] and started dog-paddling. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,161)

dog-poor¶

adj. of sheep, very unthrifty

PRESTON But none of the blocks showed the least recovery; there was no second growth. In the Spring we had only 30% of lambs and the sheep were dog-poor. (1978,Woolgatherers)

dog-skin¶

n. the skin of the kuri or Maori dog, esp. as dogskin cloak, dogskin mat

... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics. (Nov 27, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/213,1955 ed.)

FORSTER they had bits of dog-skin at the four corners of their cloaks.. The boghee-boghee, or shaggy-cloak, which hangs round their necks like a thatch of straw, was almost constantly worn by them ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/214)

WILKES In his hand [Pomare] usually carries a short cloak of dog-skin, called topuni, shupuni, or patutu. (1852,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/303)

[The Maori men to the making] of their prized dog-skin, or Kiwi-feather, clothing mats ... (1869,TrNZI,/III/8) [NOTES: (Colenso Maori races)]

adj. dogskin cloak, mat, robe

WILLIAMS He stood in silence leaning on the end of his musket, a bill-hook bright as silver in his belt in front, and a handsome dogskin mat thrown carelessly over his shoulders, ... (Mar 6, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,231,1961 ed.)

WILKES He was very feeble, ... and clad in an old dog-skin robe. (1853,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/307) [NOTES: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1/307]

MACLEAN The elder men were dressed in their best dogskin and kaitaka mats, some of them had their heads decorated with huia and kotuku feathers, not neglecting their mere[es acute] pounamu (greenstone clubs), and every other ancient emblem of chieftainship ... (May 26, 1848,Diary) [NOTES: 1848 May 26 Maclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 36]

He gave me a dogskin mat made by the Ngaticahounas [Ngatikahungunu]. (Mar 3, 1849,Torlesse Papers,72,1958 ed.)

The early voyagers and the first residents of New Zealand all agree in stating that the Maori dog was unknown in the wild state. It was a purely domesticated species ... valued ... for supplying the material for their much prized dogskin mats ... (1894,TrNZI,26/219)

COWAN .. Te Rangihaeata rose, a tall gaunt savage in appearance, clothed in a dogskin mat. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,42)

SUTHERLAND Apart from greenstone heirlooms, etc., the most valuable gifts that can be bestowed include the dogskin cloak, the korowai cloak with black edges, and the kiwi feather cloak. (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,15)

dog-skin mat¶

n.

IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.) The elders in their fly-blown dog-skin mats / yearn for their smoky whares (1982,Into the World of Light,61)

dog-slow¶

adj.

[A NZ yachtsman from Seoul olympic preliminaries speaks about racing;] ... think you're getting up in the water, but find you're going dog-slow. (Sep 15, 1988,TV1) [NOTES: News]

dog-tired¶

adj. (Rural) [used earlier in Brit. but widely in rural N.Z.] exhausted, like a working sheepdog after a long day's work in the heat.

WHEELER The men, and often the children too, sometimes don't arrive home till breakfast time, hungry and dog-tired. (1971,Historic Sheep Stations SI II,31)

COWAN I have seen us leave the station to get home at seven in the evening, dog-tired. Then we would have to feed the horses, have our tea and let the horses out later on. (1998,Goodness Gracious Me,134)

dog-training paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) an area where dogs are run around sheep to train them for trial courses.

KERR On a warm afternoon these days you might find three old gents in my six-hectare dog-training paddock. (2000,High Times in the High Country,201)

dog-trial man¶

1 n. (Rural) a keen participant or follower of dog trials.

NEWTON Frank is a son of old Seymour Lambert, once a leading North Island dog-trial man. This was Dudley Bushe, another noted Gisborne dog-trial man ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,199)

dog-trialing¶

n. as dog trialling

The trick: how to make an entertaining programme without sacrificing too many dog-trialing traditions, to produce a dog-trialing equivalent of one-day cricket. (May 18, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

dog-tucker¶

v.

He [a horse] had the most unusual formline in yesterday's Te Rapa racebook - BLORF - short for brought down, lost rider not in the first nine, ran off and fell. Laugh as much as you like, saysWilson, Blorf isn't ready to be dog-tuckered. (Jul 20, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B16)

n.

DAVIS They wandered about on deck with the superior yet slightly baffled expressions of stud merinos by some horrible mistake drafted in with a mob of dog-tucker rams. (1964,Watersiders,41 ed.)

The dog tucker shed stood on four legs beside the killing shed. (Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

dog-tucker tree¶

1 n. (Rural) a tree in which stock carcases are strung for safe keeping for dog food.

Did you rattle the cowboy along this morning? If so, it's quite probable that by tomorrow the whole district will have heard how you murdered him and hung him up the dog-tucker tree. (Sep 27, 1962,NZ Farmer,53)

AXBEY This went on for a month or so, until one day we returned from fly camping to find the owner in residence and our arch-enemy [a bull] hanging by his hocks from the dog-tucker tree. (1991,Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns,115)

dog-walloper¶

n. (Rural) mustering stick.

mustering stick : dog-walloper. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

1 n. (Rural) musterer or shepherd

PETER A musterer is often known as a dog-walloper. (2000,Peter Glossary,6)

shepherd: a dog-walloper. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

They refer to themselves as .. lizards or dog-wallopers ... (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion,C6)

dog-watch¶

2 n.

The Post Office likewise has its own phrases: clear down',six to clear', `dog watch'. (1950,Post Office English Course [TS],14)

3 n.

EVANS After this he went to the West Coast and worked in the Blackball mine on what was called `the dog watch' because it was an all-night shift. (1962,Waikaka Saga,273)

BENNETT All day and all night there were miners on [128] the move: front shift, back shift and dogwatch. (1980,Canterbury Tale, A,127)

3 n.

SEDDON The younger members called themselves `The Dog Watch.' The debate in the daytime was conducted by the elders. The Dog Watch took over after the older member' day's work was done. (1968,Seddons, The,214)

4 n.

No.25 81 The late, late shift (usually 11 p.m. - 7 a.m.) for despatchers. A naval term - thought to have been coined by those who thought that particular watch to be `a dog of a job'. (Jul 1983,Metro)

dog-whistle/dog-whistle politics¶

n. (politics) a concealed, coded, or unstated idea, usually divisive or politically dangerous, nevertheless understood by the intended hearers. [orig. Australian, now used worldwide]

Are you reading my mind Peter? That's exactly what this Jewish New Zealander was about to say. And there are more gay men in NZ than Jews, I'm sure. .. The whole idea of a "mainstream New Zealander" is bogus anyway .. except as dogwhistle code for "real New Zealander". Which is why Jordan's annoyed. And so am I. (Jun 27, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: Just Left: Jordon Carter 27/6/2005 http://jtc.blogs.com/just_left/2005.06/gays_aren't_main.html]

This, say the critics, is pure dog-whistle, the subtle appeal to racism, sounded at a pitch that is heard only by the right ears. (Jul 10, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C2)

... what are sometimes called dog whistle politics ... (Jul 5, 2005,Radio NZ / National Radio,Nine to Noon) [NOTES: Linda Clark interviewing Jane Clifton]

Critics say the pair - who run Crosby/Textor, a public relations and polling company with branches in Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and London - specialise in "dog whistle politics" - fearmongering that preys on racial disquiet and prejudice ... Some say [they] did not help the Conservatives, whose share of the vote rose less than 1%, and that the dog-whistling backfired. ... (Aug 14, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A8)

That is a dog-whistle National does not want: one that sends the dog after rabbits instead of the ewes. (Jun 28, 2005,NZ Herald,A11)

The net also plays into the Tories' hands by facilitating the "dog-whistle" campaigning at which Michael Howard has become increasingly adept. Just as a dog-whistle is inaudible to humans but is heard by every canine within miles, Howard has been beaming messages at targeted groups-anti-abortion campaigners, and people hostile to immigrants, gypsies and asylum-seekers-which, if broadcast in the normal way, might repel the majority of voters. (Apr 10, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: [the Observer, 10 Apr. 2005] quoted on www.worldwidewords.org/turnsofphrase/tp-dog2htm Not a Kiwi quote]

dog-whistler¶

n. (usually politics) dog whistle a concealed, coded, or unstated idea, usually divisive or politically dangerous, nevertheless understood by the intended hearers.

On race, however, Brash has proved a diligent dog-whistler. (May 1, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C10)

dog-worrying¶

n. sheep-worrying by dogs 1899; here indexed as sheep-worrying. [1899 Dept Ag Rep 2 Stock Inspector's Report (Griffiths Collection) Perhaps an idiosyncratic slip]

dogable¶

adj. suitable for a dog

My house has its dogable area out the back, already fenced off. (May 3, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

dogbox¶

n. the office boy, the gopher

When the Arnetts started, each was the dog-box boy. (Apr 15, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

n. a type of railway goods wagon or a substandard compartment in a railway carriage. [(?obs.)]

MILLER Our crowd moved off from Headquarters in the railways goods waggons known as `dog-boxes' ... (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,2) [NOTES: 1917 Jan 19 in 1939 Miller Camps, Tramps and Trenches 2]

n. The `guard's storage compartment at the rear end of a unit or railway carriage (the 1970 cit. (as does the 1969) may refer to a special box or cage, or space for carrying dogs in the guard's van).

HASCOMBE `The dog in the carriage with you? ... He'll have to go in the dogbox.' ... Because there was not enough room for us all in the dogbox, ... we were allowed to stand in the guard's van.] (1969,Down and Almost Under,31)

McNAUGHTON The guard put the two dogs in the dogbox, and Stewart climbed aboard the train for Garston. (1970,Tat,93)

A TRENTHAM schoolboy was last night undergoing surgery ... Lower Hutt police said last night it appeared the boy had tried to get into the dogbox part of a carriage while the train was moving. (Apr 23, 1981,Dominion,1/5)

2 n. poor or cramped quarters, lodgings, or room; a small sub-standard house. Compare dog-house. [ca1952 (during a Parliamentary debate, referring to small substandard houses) [I have never heard the term applied directly to a DOG-KENNEL]]

Mr Connolly, MP, Dunedin, said: Houses for 700 pounds? - substandard housing, that's what it is.' Interjector:Dog-boxes, I'd say.' (Jul 4, 1952,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1952 July 4 2YA Wellington: Parliament Broadcast]

McGILL dogbox cramped quarters, originally the guard's van cage; in the dog box out of favour, in disgrace; eg `I see Jim's staying at the pub again. In the dogbox with the missus, eh?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,37)

2 n. prison official's office [dog informer (spec. prisoners')] (See dog informer)

NEWBOLD DOG BOX (n) Prison official's office. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

Newbold Dog-boxes are just steel cubicles with perspex windows and bars, so that the screws inside them were as much prisoners as we were. (1982,Big Huey, The,90)

3 n. [(obs. rural)]

NEAVE Later, traction engines [for threshing] ... had their own galley and cook, and it was a great sight to see engine, mill, water-cart and dog box - a two wheeled hut. The boss and Water Joey slept near the machinery to be handy to get up steam in the morning, and then get the cookshop going. (1980,Land of Munros, The,90)

4 n. wooden box-like cover over the engine of an openboat

Nearly all the [Otago fishing-] boats are fitted with good cabins and weather-dodgers, the open boat with only a dog-box over the engine having fallen into disuse. (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/100)

dogfish¶

n. [[?earlier name = ?].]

HUTTON 128. SCYLLUM LATICEPS. Dumeril. Dog Fish. (1872,Fishes NZ,79)

SHERRIN Scyllum laticeps .. Dog-fish. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,115)

  1. Ponui Passage. - Mullet, kanae, dog-fish, stingaree. Ibid. 24/204 24. Puysegur Point - Hapuku, kahawai, trumpeter, moki, pig-fish, trevally, rock-cod, perch, butter-fish, red-cod, dog-fish (1892,TrNZI,24/203) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

Cephaloscyllium laticeps, Dumeril. The dog-fish is very common. (1906,TrNZI,38/552) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

n. = spotted stargazer

WILSON DOGFISH: ,see Stargazer Ibid. 208 SPOTTED STARGAZER Similar to his cousin the Common Stargazer but thicker and with more distinctive, spotted markings on body and fins. ... Other names are Catfish, Monkfish and Dogfish. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,44)

MORELAND SPOTTED STARGAZER [Geniagnus monopterygius] ... Other names include monkfish, catfish, dogfish, and flathead. (1967,Marine Fishes,20)

DOOGUEW & MORELAND SPOTTED STARGAZER ... Other names: Geniagnus monopterygius; catfish, monk, dogfish; kourepoua (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,263)

n. . (See northern spiny dogfish)

Conservation Department marine ecologist Clinton Duffy said it was believed that at least five species of dogfish were being described as northern spiny dogfish. (Jul 14, 2005,Dominion Post,A9)

PARKINSON All the coves of this bay teem with fish of various kinds, such as cuttle-fish, large breams, ... small grey breams, small and large barracootas, flying gurnards, horse-mackarel, dog-fish, soles, dabs ... (Jan 15, 1770,Journal,114)

FORSTER [We] indeed caught some fish [near Long Island] which are common to Europe, viz. the horse-mackarel, the greater dog-fish, and the smooth hound.* [fn] Scomber trachurus, squalus canis, & sq. mustelus, Linn. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/181)

POLACK Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn)

NICHOLAS On these stages were placed a quantity of the dog-fish and sting-ray, which were drying there as a supply against the winter; ... Ibid. 1/322 Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our hakes, tench, bream, snapper, haddock, elephant-fish, pollock, salmon, gurnards, pipe-fish, parrot-fish, leather-jackets, cole-fish, John Dorys, sword-fish, cod; various kinds of skate and cat-fish, sting-ray and dog-fish. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/269)

WAKEFIELD The Shark is rarely seen near the coast, though small Dog-fish, from one to three feet in length, are very common, and considered excellent food by the natives (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,160)

POWER The natives are busy fishing, and one can scarcely go near their Pas on account of the horrid smell of the Kawai, dog-fish, and small sharks, drying by thousands in the sun for winter use. (1849,Sketches in NZ,159)

ADAMS Great numbers of large dogfish prevail. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,52) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

SEWELL Dyer says the Dogfish (a small kind of Shark) makes bathing dangerous. He was chased by one about 4 feet long having gone into the water for a Pigeon which had been shot and dropped. (1853,Journal of Henry Sewell,1/149,1980 ed.)

MACKIE A large party of natives from the South ... brought a great quantity of dried fish, especially dog fish, ..., also some nuts of the `Karaka', Corynocarpus lavigatus. (Mar 3, 1853,Traveller under Concern,84,1973 ed.)

LADY MARTIN After this we came to a long row of poles, on which was hung an immense supply of dried shark (the dogfish split in two), besides baskets of ku-me-ras (sweet potatoes), ... (1884,Our Maoris,26)

Dogfish of more than one species furnish good edible food. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/136) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

dogfish. The name used in Australia and New Zealand for different kinds of fish of the shark family. b. Emissola spp. TH (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),129,8th ed.)

POWELL GUMMY SHARK OR DOGFISH (Emissola antarctica), Manga of the Maoris, grows up to 3 1/2 feet in length ... (1947,Native Animals of NZ,61)

FORSTER They caught a very large Dogfish. Ibid. 2/269 The day before, the greater Dog fish, (Squalus cogris), well described by Mr Pennant in his Br. Zool. Vol. III. was caught, & likewise a new kind of Codfish, [[ed. fn] Gadus bachus of Descr. Anim., p.120.] it has 2 dorsal-fins, & one beard under the Chin, a dark back, but is allover reddish, & even under the belly & on the fins. I had got such another red Codfish some days before ... (Apr 4, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/246)

NATUSCH Family SQUALIDAE Includes two species of Squalus , the brown ( S. blainvillei ) and spotted ( S. acanthias ) dogfishes; one species of Scymnodon (S. plunketi ), which grows up to 5 ft long and is also known as the brown dogfish; one species of Centrophorus (C. squamosus); one species of Centrophorus (C. squamosus); one species of the long-snouted Deania (D. calcea); one of Scymnodalatias , a genus in which the spine is missing; two luminescent sharks of the genus Etmopterus ; and two of Centroscymnus . Of these squalid sharks, Squalus is the most commonly caught. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,199)

Mustelus antarcticus. Synonyms: Galeus antarcticus and Galeorhinus antarcticus. The smooth-hound, or gummy (Mustelus antarcticus) ... is one of the small sharks commonly taken by trawlers around new Zealand, and popularly termed dogfish.' The family is distinguished by the blunt pavement-like teeth - hence the popular namegummy,' in use in Australia, where the species is also common. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/263) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

71 Mustelus antarcticus: Common dogfish, pioke (Auckland), rigg (Canterbury). (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The)

Galeorhinus australis. Synonyms: Galeus canis (in part); Galeus australis; Mustelus australis; Eugaleus australis. The southern tope, or school shark, Galeorhinus australis, is one of the small so-called dogfish commonly taken by trawlers around New Zealand. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/259) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

dogfish shark¶

n. [the group of squaliformes; while there are NZ dogfish species their names are not necessarily NZ and 'dogfish' itself is universal]

GRAHAM Spined Dogfish Shark Koinga lebruni (Vaillant) (Syn. Squalus kirki Phillipps, S. canis Forster, and S. maculatus Richardson) ... Spiny Dogfish Shark Oxynotus brunienis (Ogilby) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,398) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 398]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] dogfish shark, spined or spiny 83-6 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

dogged¶

adj. equipped with, possessed of working dogs. [(musterers')]

NEWTON The gang that year [1932-1935] was the most capable and strongly dogged I have ever worked with. Ibid. 89 Early November found me riding up country again newly dogged and horsed. (1947,Wayleggo,57)

NEWTON Old Jack Kidd ... had the place when I was first there. He wasn't very strongly dogged and, of course, that didn't help matters. His mainstay was a dog called Wad - (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,30)

1 adj. (Rural) [of musterers and shepherds] served with dogs.

NEWTON The gang that year was the most capable and strongly dogged I have ever worked with. (1947,Wayleggo,57)

NEWTON Early November found me riding up country once again, newly dogged and horsed. (1947,Wayleggo,89)

NEWTON One thing I can say is that the musterers of today are better dogged and are more capable in the actual handling of stock .. they were a strongly dogged and capable gang. (1966,Boss's Story, The,121)

NEWTON I struck what was probably the strongest and best-dogged gang I've mustered with at Mesopotamia. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,47)

NEWTON A first-class musterer, always strongly dogged ... (1972,Sheep Thief,27)

dogger¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep used for dog-tucker.

Killed 3 muttons and 3 dogers [sic]. (1896,Glens of Tekoa Station Diary,65) [NOTES: in MCRAE (1963) Glens of Tekoa]

doggie¶

n. a saveloy (? hot dog).

PARK (1949,Poor Man's Orange) [NOTES: check NZ context]

BOOTH [The pie-cart owner] clattered a cup and saucer ... `Like a doggie to go with it?' Darlon nodded and two minutes later he had a saveloy imprisoned in a soggy bread roll and the steaming coffee in front of him. (1961,Long Night,99)

doggin¶

n. a cigarette butt, dog-end [WWII Italy]

HENDERSON By crikey ... wouldn't it be great to collect all the cigarette butts chucked away at the old cinemas back home? Remember all the `doggins' round the lounges and entrances? (1945,Gunner Inglorious,146 or 170 (pb ed).)

dogginess¶

1 n. (Rural) a state of sheep fleece-wool in which the crimp is wide and shallow and often has a distinctive shine.

HENDERSON Fibres responsible for dogginess have been traced to follicles that show a grossly enlarged outer root sheath just above the follicle bulb. (1968,Growing Better Wool,49)

The importance of dogginess as a fault of course depends on the manufacturing performance of the wool and the characteristics of the fabric made from it. The association between very high yolk production and dogginess in New Zealand wool is apparently an artificial one. (1968,Growing Better Wool,51)

dogging¶

n. (Rural) shepherding.

KERR My first dogging job was at Glenlappa Station, from 1943. (2000,High Times in the High Country,45)

1 n. (Rural) [mustering and shepherding] the hassling of sheep by over-eager dogs.

MCGREGOR Some huntaways are continuous barkers and can cause unnecessary dogging and bunching of stock .. Ken Spence warns against all unnecessary dogging and bunching of sheep. (1980,Dog's Life, A,39)

doggo¶

1 adj. (Rural) physically exhausted, dog-tired, deadbeat.

BARDSLEY Usually, we'd be absolutely doggo and went to bed early. (2000,Land Girls, The,72)

doggy¶

adj. lacking a defined staple crimp [(woolgrowers')]

Doggy: Lacking a defined staple crimp. Normally applicable only to Merino wool. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

1 adj. (Rural) [of fleece wool] having a wide and shallow crimp, often with a distinctive shine.

HENDERSON The most outstanding feature of doggy wool is a wider and more shallow crimp than is normal for wool of equivalent fineness. A secondary feature of some doggy wools is a very lustrous appearance. So far doggy wool has attracted notice only in Merino wool and wool from breeds with Merino in their ancestry. (1968,Growing Better Wool,48)

MAF Doggy: Lacking a defined staple crimp. Normally applicable only to Merino wool. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

SQUIRE Doggy - Plain, run-out staple showing little or no character or breeding. Applies to Merino and Merino crosses. (1991,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,17)

doggy man¶

n. (Rural) a shepherd or musterer.

It is my practice, and I think it is the practice of most 'doggy' men to very carefully study the characteristics of a pup before beginning on him. (Aug 19, 1936,Weekly News,85)

NEWTON Eventually it was decided that the musterers could have the 'penner-up' and also draw reinforcements from the doggy men across the river at 'Craiglea.' (1946,High Country Days,59)

NEWTON The local pub was booked out to the last bed; doggy men all, several of the boarders hailed from local stations. (1949,High Country Days,185)

KERR Doggy men out in the paddock applaud a long pull or a 'short head.' (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,179)

1 n. (Rural) man who follows or participates in dog trials with fervour.

At one time the Trials were confined to sheep men only, but close settlement, also low profits of sheepfarming, have driven a large number of our doggy men into the cow bail. (Apr 1932,NZ Farmer,255)

I would like you to know that your notes are very much appreciated by all doggy men. (Sep 13, 1951,NZ Farmer,27)

doghair¶

n.

Kemp grows for only a certain time, and is then shed ... There is in some South African sheep an occurrence of kempy' fibres with even thicker medulla than in ordinary kemp, and these are known asdoghair' and `gare' ... (1928,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,9/182)

doghook¶

n. Dog-hook is also occas. used (e.g. by watersiders) for bale-hook, a small steel hook with, usually, a wooden handle at right angles to the curve of the hook (see Web3), and this is its sense in b. below.] a. (bushmen's) use) An iron bar with a bent prong [i.e. a `dog' or iron claw] for securing or hoisting a log, etc; see also [?what] [?canthook, ?chain jack]. [(obs.)]

Z.W.WELLS Tools hid in the bush under the first pine log west of my stream: Auger, truck irons, axe, mattock, doghook, hoe, Tools. (May 4, 1863,Diary,51,1970 ed.)

n. to hang on very firmly or tightly

I don't take much stock of texts, mum, but I reckon that one over your head is the real straight griffin, and a fellow ought to hang on to it with both hands and a doghook. (Sep 30, 1905,NZ Truth,15/7/8)

dogman¶

n. (Rural) a farmer or dog trialist who is an enthusiast or expert about sheepdogs.

And this is how quite a long association started with the three top NZ dog men. (Jun 8, 1994,NZ Farmer,13)

GORDON If you ever ask a real dog man about his dog, and the animal's at hand, he'll never look at you, just at his workmate while talking of his time together. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,27)

KERR When a dog man meets another dog man, usually each knows the other by reputation - their strengths and weaknesses, style and skill. Old dog men can talk good sense and not cover much old ground talking about dogs until the candle gutters or the whisky gives out. (2000,High Times in the High Country,85)

KERR Bill Elliott from Glenlappa walked in with his head shepherd, and he and I talked about dog men. He was talking about a shepherd he knew ... (2000,High Times in the High Country,85)

KERR .. he was also a top dog man, who had won lots of trials ... [dog man] (2000,High Times in the High Country,140)

n. one who gives directions to a crane-driver, often riding on the crane's dog-hook, or on materials lifted [chk award].

on crane mishap in Auckland [Crane-drivers, like driving a remote-controlled helicopter] All helped by men on the ground called dog-men. (Jan 28, 1987,TV1) [NOTES: News]

[HEADLINE] Crane ballast fall hurts dogman [CAPTION] A young construction worker on the truck suffered head injuries from the fall. ... Part of the block fell on to the rear of the truck, missing the injured dogman by about two metres. (Feb 22, 1990,Dominion,10)

1 n. (Rural) a shepherd

NEWTON Another well-known hillman was Jim Binnie, a man born and bred of dog men. (1947,Wayleggo,57)

MCLEOD In the back country, men have not only to be dog men - to some extent, they must be horse men too. (1951,NZ High Country,30)

NEWTON Today with her family off her hands she is filling the role of shepherd and at the time of my visit she and West were the only dog "men" on this 6,000-acre place. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,237)

dogmeat¶

n. (See dog tucker)

Every office has a wretch... They are almost always at the bottom of the heap, mad and unloved, and their job status may as well be called dogmeat... It's a dog-eat-dogmeat world. (Apr 22, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

dogroll¶

n. prepared dog food done up in a roll

Luka Warring, from Kilbirnie, Wellington, isn't quite ready to allow family dog Pardu the dogroll given to him by an animal control officer at Lyall Bay... For the next fortnight, Wellington City Council's animal contractors DSS Management will reward dogs doing the right thing with 630 grams of dogroll. (Nov 4, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

dogshit¶

n. But this is poss. merely the use (or poss. an extension) of a term of common abuse; or of dog-->, a prison term for an informer. [(prisoners')]

BEATON DI: ... I just said, she's different to the usual run-of-the-mill dogshit, that's all. Ibid. 42 DI: ... Someone told her [the new inmate] I could score, so I helped her out. ... MA: Bit risky, weren't it? DI: Nah, she's clean. You know how I feel about dogshit. Ibid. 51 HELEN: ... Tell me something, Ma, what's dogshit? MA: It's a name the Boss uses. HELEN: Yeah. What's it mean? MA: Junkie. HELEN: So? I'm not the only one in for using. Ibid. 109 Dogshit: an abusive term, used by Di to mean middle-class, well-meaning educated junkies. (1984,Outside In,42)

dogstail¶

n. (See grass,dogstail)

dogwood¶

n. Cornus capitata Wall.

dogwood, strawberry [s] Cornus capitata Wall. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,22)

doing¶

adj. to describe how stock are growing, or their state of health (sc. doing well or badly) not doing `performing badly'); see do v1.. [(farming)]

Doing: To describe how stock are growing or their state of health, e.g. doing well or badly. `Not doing' =performing badly. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,4)

doing a march¶

phr.

They call it 'doing a march': marching the dealers at gunpoint to their plot, or stash, or cash reserves. (Jan 30, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

doing a Tuku¶

phr. (See Tukugate)

Everyone know what "doing a tuku" is, but the event that inspired it is already fading into the footnotes of scandal, and I doubt its linguistic life has long to go. (Apr 10, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

doing over¶

n. see notes here and do over. [ca1941 e.g. I gave him a good doing over for losing the money (dressing down'); The maid gave the room a good doing over with the electrolux (cleaning up'); I didn't get much of a doing over from the quack (`examination, check-up, going over')]

doing the black¶

phr. poaching paua

"Between the three of us we would catch up to 300 lb of paua in a weekend, that's around three grand ... we called it 'doing the black' ... it's like black gold." (Mar 16, 2002,Evening Post,3)

doing the lot¶

phr. serving life imprisonment.

NEWBOLD LOT (n) e.g., Doing the -. Life imprisonment. (1982,Big Huey, The,250) [NOTES: glossary]

doings¶

n. the ingredients, the makings, the drink

A drop of the doings has now become boutique, handcrafted and from micro-breweries. (Jul 3, 2004,Dominion Post,E8)

dole-bludge¶

n.

Dole-bludge denial was the last straw. (Dec 13, 2000,Dominion,2)

dole-bludger¶

n.

ELDRED-GRIGG 'Dole bludgers,' says Jimmy... 'No hope for no-hopers.' (1995,Mum,224)

The myth of the Kiwi dole-bludger has been exposed by statistics. (May 31, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

People would have categorised my humouras kind of dole-bludger sit around and donothing humour. (Apr 24, 1996,City Voice,5)

The mythh of the Kiwi dole-bluidger has been exposed by statistics which show the percentage of unemployed Australians in New Zealand is just about the same as the percentage of unemployed Kiwis in Australia. (May 31, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

When I was working as a journalist in Sydney in the 1980s (when Kiwis were labelled "dole-bludgers"), statistics came out showing that immigrants always contributed far more to the economy than they ever cost it in social services. (Dec 14, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

BAXTER The odd-job man, old bludger, worn-out soak/ (1979,Collected Poems,80,1949 ed.)

Strewth! Forget about Kiwi dole bludgers lying on Bondi Beach - the Aussies are claiming and spending our student loans here. (Sep 14, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A14)

dole bludger (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

dole-bludger n. Austral. sl. a person who draws unemployment benefit without making any attempt to get work. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,330) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

The term `dole bludger' was not, for instance, uttered even once from the [National Party] conference floor during the recent party get-together in Dunedin. (Aug 20, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),136)

The mermaid was evidently inclined to the liberal or left-wing spectrum for she never used the term `dole bludger' except in the most ironic tones. (Jun 1984,Landfall,150/148)

WEDDE `Some young pisshead ...[sic] dope fiend ... dole bludger ... sex pervert ...how did they know he wasn't a Courtenay Place bus-shelter sherry boob-head?' (1986,Symme's Hole,70)

When every vote was needed to obtain power there were no such things as `dole bludgers', either - only potential votes. (Jan 11, 1988,Dominion,8)

[Hdg] Wrong signal for bludgers... The Government... is abolishing the "work for the dole" scheme begun by former employment minister Peter McCardle. (Nov 14, 2000,Dominion,8)

It is inconceivable that Northland MP John "Hone" Carter would have called talk-back radio pretending to be a Maori dole bludger in 1995 if the thousands of Maori in his electorate had been able to show their displeasure at the next election. (Aug 10, 2006,Dominion Post,B4)

With unemployment sitting at its lowest point in nearly two decades, it becomes fairly hard to generate widespread public outrage about dole-bludgers. (Oct 9, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

dole-bludging¶

n.

Although there is less talk of dole-bludging these days there is still an unrelenting criticism from pockets in the community. (Dec 24, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

The peril that dole-bludging presents in New Zealand today is hardly of that order - particularly as the government provides for a degree of cheating in that area. (Feb 6, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

adj.

No compensation let there be / to mothers on the DPB / No compensation ever paid / to Maoris waving their Treaty. / Give us strength; make our hearts stout / To cut the general super out / from the whole dole bludging band / God defend New Zealand. (Jul 18, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

dolie¶

n. a person on the unemployment benefit.

HILLIARD `Thirty bob? ... Is that all your dolie old man can afford, thirty bob?' ... to the well-off it seemed that all who worked for wages [in the 1930s] were dolies or red-feds, whatever that was. (1965,Power of Joy,213)

dollar¶

n. as in New South Wales, a Spanish dollar; see also holey dollar.

KENDALL And could I now part with dollars, .. (Feb 26, 1822,Letter) [NOTES: 1822 Feb 26 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 186]

F.MATHEW [The Governor's] distribution of presents [to the Maoris] gave ... much dissatisfaction; and one vagabond who actually begged a Dollar of him had the impudence ... to bring it back, and at Captain Hobson refusing to accept it, threw it in the River. (Feb 16, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 16 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 53]

POLACK The Spanish dollar is the favorite coin, as in all barbarous countries, where the distinction in coinage is known; ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/183)

MONRO After shaking hands he [John Tuawaike] pulls out his watch, and, having satisfied himself on this point, he pulls out a dollar, and orders the steward to fetch him a bottle of wine. (Jul 20, 1844,Nelson Examiner) [NOTES: -1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 234 [?Aust col or US]]

H. WILLIAMS It appears that Satan through the means of these his agents has been very industriously circulating the idea of our intention to seize the Chiefs in a short time, ... and that for those who receive our instruction we are to receive dollars according to the rank of the individual. (Apr 21, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,308,1961 ed.) [NOTES: [??Sydney dollar]]

n.

Down to Wellington we travel, M.H.R. and M.L.C.,/ Where we blow the hard-earned dollars of our bleeding counteree./ (Jun 15, 1892,Auckland Star) [NOTES: 1892 June 15 Auckland Star in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 82]

... she ought to be worth some dollars. (Sep 30, 1905,NZ Truth,15/1/5)

GRACE Where's the gold, the dollars. (1914,Tale of Timbertown,117)

SUTHERLAND Dealing with the tendency of the Maori to refer to all money as dollars' - a practise persisting to some extent with the Pakeha today - ... [fn] Some New Zealanders use the termhalf-dollar' for `half-a-crown'. (1941,Numismatic History of NZ,63)

2 n. [(? rare, obs)[check to see that TS and 1960 edition agree: TS or MS have 16?].]

1/84 We succeeded in hiring a small canoe for the sum of ten [? sixteen] shillings or four dollars as they [? Maoris] call it. [check this quot against MS: ?16: my orig TS versio has 16 shillings] (Feb 23, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960)

2 n. before decimal currency, the sum of five shillings; esp. half-a-dollar half-a-crown' (cf wheel); the fig. pl. usemoney' is rare.

SCANLON Could you lend me a dollar till tomorrow? (1925,Much in Little,31)

HYDE A job at a dollar a day fighting for your king. Ibid. 73 You can have a job at a ha'penny a day blocking the swamps, or a job at a dollar a day fighting for your King. (1936,Passport to Hell,70)

MATTHEWS The collection amounted in gold to [pounds]20/10/-, dollars [pounds]3/4/-, half-crowns [pounds]5/2/6, shillings [pounds]16/12/-, sixpences 16/6 - total [pounds]46/5/-. (1940,Matthews of Kaitaia,148) [NOTES: [a collection taken up in Northland in 1841]]

We use a colloquialism for half-crown and five shillings and call them a half-dollar and a dollar even now. (Oct 8, 1963,Dominion,4/4)

DAVIS ... What you boys want, Curly?'Dollar.' ... Yes. Dollar it is,' ...A whole five bob?' (1964,Watersiders,51)

TURNER The present colloquial ... use of dollar, usually in half a dollar, `half a crown' in New Zealand, but in Australia, where half-crowns are not in use, two shillings, should help the natural adoption of the new official term (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,133)

The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. The only instance recorded of Cockney rhyming slang term for a coin is Oxford scholar, the derivation from dollar being obvious. The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

dolly¶

v. to crush auriferous quartz with a dolly, an apparatus for crushing and extracting gold

HUNT I dolly in it too if I come across quartz reef. (1981,Speaking a Silence,47)

n. [(?obs.)]

MANNERING The only way I could sit him was to have a dolly' in front and crupper behind ... (Adolly' was a stout stick wrapped in a sack and held with straps on the dees of the saddle.) (1943,Eighty Years,42)

McARA It may have been that the white hungry' appearance of much of the quartz on the surface discouraged earlier prospectors and they did not bother to test it bydollying' and washing a few samples. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,29)

n. a homosexual partyner [(prisoners') Cf Mrs, Darl.]

Female offenders of all ages were tattooed almost exclusively with tattoos that marked homosexual relationships they had with their young Mrs.,' teenageDarls,' or adult Dollies,' ... <i>(1970,Genetic Psychology Monographs,No.81/92</i>) [NOTES: (1968) 1970 A.J.W. TaylorTattooing...' in 1970 Genetic Psychology Monographs No.81/92]

n. a tub with revolving blades or paddles (the `dollies' proper) for washing various materials. [(fellmongers')]

Sheep and lamb skins are conveyed into another building, called the fellmongery, and after being washed in a `dolly' they are painted on the flesh side ... (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/165)

The pelts are first washed in pits or `dollies', with paddles revolving, in order to thoroughly remove as much as possible of adhering detritus. (Aug 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/158) [NOTES: (Wright)]

MACDONALD Generally there has been little change in fellmongering practice since 1892. Skins are still cold-water washed in `dollies' or paddles, deburring machines are no longer used, but the de-wooling paint is applied on a moving conveyor instead of on the piled skins. (1957,Canterbury Frozen Meat Company,69)

n. methadone

Amongst addicts methadone is known as dolly or done ... (Apr 17, 1986,TV1) [NOTES: Close Up programme]

v. [(obs.)]

... dollying dirty duds ... (Aug 26, 1905,NZ Truth,10/4/4)

v.

BUTLER As there is barely room in this passage for [the sheep] to swim up and down, they `dolly' one another, and rub all the dirt out of their fleeces. (1886,Glimpses of Maori Land,128)

n.

In other words when you drop a dolly of a catxch in a lower grade cricket match, which costs your team the game, you only have to suffer with 10 other players. (Apr 30, 2002,Independent Herald (Wellington),19)

n. (Rural) a curing vat, containing agitating paddles, in a fellmongery.

LOUGHNAN dolly: ii. a curing vat, containing agitating paddles, in a fellmongery. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,26)

1 n. (Rural) a ewe

LOUGHNAN dolly: i. a ewe. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,26)

a ewe - a dolly. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Dolly bill¶

n. A bill introduced to Parliament by Labour MP Dianne Yates, proposing the banning of human cloning, commercial surrogacy, and the sale of sperm, ova, gametes and embryos

Dolly down the reel¶

phr. French knitting (See French knitting)

An odd [cotton] reel can be turned to useful account for making French knitting, rat-tail knitting or "Dolly down the reel", as it is frequently called. (Feb 2005,NZ Memories,No. 52, p. 19)

dolly pot¶

n.

HUNT He dug up a complete dolly pot, lid and all. That's what the real old-timers used when they found a quartz reef; they were very heavy pots with extra thick bottoms. (1981,Speaking a Silence,47)

The dolly-pot.. is the goldminer's morter [sic] and pestle, with which gold-bearing rock is powdered for the pay-dust. (Dec 28, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,33)

dolphin¶

n.

There are also two species of dolphin very plentiful, which could be easily secured and used for oil and their skin for leather. (1885,TrNZI,17/198) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

Porpoises and dolphins are most valuable for their skins and oil, ... (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/137)

GRAHAM Dolphin Coryphaena hippurus Linne (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,406) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 406]

DOOGUE & MORELAND DOLPHIN ... Other names: Coryphaena hippurus. Only dolphin is used in English speaking countries. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,278)

MORELAND DOLPHIN [Coryphaena hippurus] ... Dolphin or dolphinfish are the only names in use here. (1967,Marine Fishes,46)

[index to common names 283-293] dolphin 1397-8 DOLPHINS 1397-8 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

dolphinfish¶

n. Coryphaena hippucus

WILSON DOLPHIN Coryphaena hippucus: A truly international blue-water fish with an extensive distribution throughout the oceans of the world. It usually described as dolphin-fish in order todistinguish it from the intelligent sea-mammal of the same name. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,50)

MORELAND DOLPHIN [Coryphaena hippucus] ... Dolphin or dolphinfish are the only names in use here. (1967,Marine Fishes,46)

AYLING DOLPHINFISH Coryphaena hippucus ... The dolphinfish, bot to be confused with the true dolphin ..., is a spectacularly coloured oceanic pelagic species. (1982,Collins Guide,1984)

domain¶

n.

RIVES I took a constitutional in the domain before lunch but owing to the flatness of the country there is little to be admired. (Mar 7, 1875,Jottings on the Spot,10)

WESTON ... the Domain ... (1890,Ko Meri,114) [NOTES: ?where]

The whole is admirably set off by Hagley Park (400 acres in extent), the Domain and Botanical Gardens (79 acres), Lancaster Park, the Town Belts, and other public and private gardens and plantations. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,55)

And two pimply boys/ Whisper tales/ Of intercourse with schoolgirls/ In playgrounds and domains. (Sep 1952,Here & Now,30)

McCORMICK Only two patches of bush had been preserved ...: one stood ... within sight of our home; the other ..., known as the Domain, covered the banks and papa cliffs for a mile or so on either side of the river. (1959,Inland Eye,8)

n. a public park; often in local use the Domain, a public park, recreation ground; public reserve; originally A green area or belt of public land set aside by the New Zealand company. [1839 [to be checked with NZ Company Papers 3/1Secretary to Smith 1 August 1839]]

The water in question is obtained from ponds excavated in a hollow in the Domain. (Dec 7, 1872,Auckland Weekly News,8)

The lovers rambling in the Domain... A merry Christmas to you all! (1890,NZ Observer,Xmas : 8)

The gallant veteran.. is William Buchanan, of Te Aroha, where he is better known than the Domain or the baths. (Jul 19, 1913,NZ Observer,5)

Lee manages to maintian her formal poise throughout, despite being rquired to link items from a quirky variety of Asian landmarks such as.. the Auckland Domain, a wind-blasted West Coast beach, and the middle of some commercial strawberry fields. (Mar 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

Our Domain Board (if there is such a body) have surely gone to sleep, judging from the state of the domains here, which, to say the least, are simply disgraceful. (Sep 25, 1890,Otago Witness,19)

A long, narrow bridge led to the memorial hall, garage, grocery store, domain. (Apr 29, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Miller Radiating from this well-planned centre [of Wellington] were to stretch one hundred and [44] ten thousand fertile acres, divided into hundred-acre farms linked by roads, and the town sections were to be separated from the outer rural district by a broad belt of green domain. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,43)

The transfer has resulted.. in less being done for the Domain than ever. (Jan 15, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,17)

You ascend a wide grassy avenue lined with pohutukawa which was once planned as a road into the Domain. (Jun 1992,Metro,33)

PARK Down on the Domain half-a-dozen straddled the cross-bars of the football goals, dreadfully uncomfortable and nervous of failing, but possessed of an unparalleled view of the Southern Cross as it swung its silver nose into the sunlight and headed right across the dreamy green saucer that was Te Kamo. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,134)

I feel I should head to the Domain for my Christmas biscuit, glass of orange and the start of this well-travelled tour. ((25/0/1993),Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

I feel I should head to the Domain for my Christmas biscuit, glass of orange and the start of this well-travelled tour. (Dec 25, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

n. ?Orig surrounding Government House, Auckland, ??but generalised.

H. Government Domain. ... as it is only five acres in extent, and is situated in the very centre of the town, overlooked from every part, it is utterly unfit for a Government Domain. -->1842 Aug 12 Map of Auckland in GBPP 1842 (No.569) [facing] 136 TEMPORARY GOVERNMENT HOUSE AND DOMAIN (Oct 1842,GBPP,(No.569) 185) [NOTES: 1841 Oct F.Mathew to Hobson in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 185]

n.

ASKEW [In Auckland] on the right, is the Government domain, a large tract of land reserved for botanical gardens. (1857,Voyage to Australia & NZ,350)

(E.W. Stafford) I am also going to get trees, seeds & plants sent out for the Govt domain and by the way the receipts for pasturage there shd. not be carried to the Genl Acct but be placed to the credit of a special fund for keeping up the Domain. (Jun 19, 1859,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/467,1960 ed.)

A large coarse grass, common in woods and warm gullies, not hardy in the Government Domain; eaten by cattle; ... (1872,TrNZI,4/301) [NOTES: (Report on Grasses)]

n. surrounding Government or Parliament House, Wellington

[Legend] H. Government Domain [approx where Parliament Buildings now are] (Aug 12, 1842,GBPP,(No.569) facing 185) [NOTES: 1842 Aug 12 Map of Wellington [drafted F.Mathew 1841] in GBPP 1842[Legend] H. Government Domain [approx where Parliament Buildings now are]]

n.

(A.S. Atkinson) ... Read the papers & did Maori, went for about half an hour in the Domain & found a fantail nest (young ones) & a riroriro's with two young ones & an egg. I am inclined to think the egg is a pipiwharauroa's (white, with purple spots at the larger end). Splitting firewood in the afn. I found a fine large centipede - a weri - body brown, with the articulations very plainly marked, legs a pale blue ... (Oct 20, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/645,1960 ed.)

NICHOLL In the afternoon we went for a walk in the domain, there were a good lot of people there but no swells. (Jun 12, 1864,Journal,238)

BAINES Presently on my road to town I fell in with two Maories. I was sitting on a hill side in the [Auckland] Domain when up came my two Antipodean aboriginals who ... shook hands ... (1874,Edward Crewe,20)

SENIOR I had strayed into the Domain, or Botanical Gardens; and the acclimatization gentlemen of Auckland have the pleasure of knowing that they have provided, in that cool grove a ... concert ... (1880,Travel & Trout,187)

HULL At easter time we held our sports/ Upon the wide Domain, sir,/ (1907,College Songs,18) [NOTES: 1903 in 1907 Hull College Songs 18]

HYDE Bede Collins (no longer, unless by courtesy, Sister Collins) was attending Anzac Day service in Auckland. There was a church service before the parade and laying of wreaths at the foot of the Cenotaph, which would follow in the Domain grounds, ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,236)

STEAD [Akd] I was walking in the Domain pushing my baby Christopher in his pram. (1984,Some Other Country,129) [NOTES: 1965 Stead `A Fitting Tribute' in 1984 Some Other Country 129]

SARGESON But presently, as I took my usual short cut through the Domain, I saw the car ... had pulled up not far ahead of me. (1975,Man of England Now,159)

Auckland possesses a vast, open stretch of tree-fringed village common called The Domain. (Jul 2, 1983,Evening Post,14)

n. [1986 a U.S. food-writer's written remarks: p.c. Tui Flower NZ Woman's Weekly (14 Jan 1987) Then ... you can find a pleasant site beside the road or in a domain (park).]

TEXIDOR The Domain in front of the hotel was packed out with cars and lorries. (1987,In Fifteen Minutes,159) [NOTES: 1944 Texidor in 1987 In Fifteen Minutes 159]

EVANS [In 1913] T. Middlemiss gained a tender of 10s. per acre for eight acres to `digger plough' the domain. At a working bee in August [1913] tussocks and other plants were removed. (1962,Waikaka Saga,172)

HOWE When the train arrived, most people made straight for the [Te Aroha] Domain to secure a shady spot for their picnic lunch. (1964,Stamper Battery,99)

McDERMOTT ... when you read domain' thinkpark' ... (1976,How to Get Lost & Found in NZ,32)

LELAND a domain is a locally administered PARK usually in the COUNTRY. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,33)

MARSHALL Ken wanted to stop at the store by the domain. ... The grass of the domain was silvered by fine rain, and the trees stood motionless, ... (1982,Master of Big Jingles,65)

domain ... 5. N.Z. & Austral. a park or recreation reserve maintained by a public authority, often the government. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,330) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 222; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 143]]

It was a hundred small towns. You used to drive through them ..., anywhere in the North Island. Fair Square grocery ... A stringy little park labelled TOWN DOMAIN. (1984,High Country Weather,5)

HARTLEY It seemed to me that the farm was the centre of gravity of the district - a stone's throw from the school, the tiny post office ... in one direction and five minutes' walk from the store, domain and tennis court in the other. (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,104)

2 n.

[Dannevirke] has pleasant domain gardens - ducks and deer, elm and ash trees. (Mar 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

A bridge crosses a small stream which tumbles down from the Domain duck pond. (Jun 1992,Metro,33)

Domain Board¶

n.

Tommy Wells ought to be acknowledged as the owner of Cambridge Domain. He has virtually himself been the Domain Board for thirty years. (Feb 13, 1904,NZ Observer,7)

EVANS The area was surveyed and handed over [in 1913] to the newly constituted Domain Board as a sports area. (1962,Waikaka Saga,172)

NORRIS As an amateur actor and producer he shone in local productions, but he will be best remembered for his work on the local Domain Board. (1964,Settlers in Depression,201)

The Domain board is defunct. (Jan 15, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,17)

dome¶

n. the usual NZ term for a stud-, snap-, or spring-fastener. [ca1935 Havelock]

FRAME The pair of little blue glass slippers ... which now housed buttons, domes, needles, hooks and eyes. (1963,Reservoir, The,39) [NOTES: (Royal Icing)]

LELAND Dome. The SNAPS that you commonly find on garments in North America and don't find in some expected placed in New Zealand. Would you believe pajama flies? (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,33)

dome NZ & Austral. press-stud. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

The main shortages are in Mum's darningbasket - elastic, pins, domes, andbuttons. (Jun 25, 1945,NZEF Times,IV/209 : 2)

n.

MACKENZIE dome central area of Mt Eden from which the cell wings radiate (1980,While We Have Prisons,96) [NOTES: (Lag's Lexicon)]

Dominican¶

n. Ellipt. for Dominican gull.

There was a luscious `Paua' or Mutton-fish decaying on the beach, a great screaming of hungry Dominicans overhead, . (Mar 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,482)

Dominican gull¶

n. = black-backed gull

... the Karoro, or Black-backed Gull, in the wild and dreary solitudes of the Ocean Beach. ... named Larus Dominicanus (Dominican Gull) from his likeness to the mendicant brothers of that order ... (Mar 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,482)

  1. Larus dominicanus Lichtenstein, 1823 Southern Black-backed Gull (Karoro [Dominican Gull]) Circumpolar ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,53,1980 ed.)

Dominican Gull Larus dominicanus LICHTENSTEIN, 1823 ...The New Zealand population has increased this century. ... OTHER NAMES: Karoro, southern black-backed gull, kelp gull. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,221)

dominie¶

n. a schoolteacher. [(Southland-Otago Scots ?obs.) ca1900 R. Mason quoting Mrs Christie: ref. Southland at the end of 19C. `We always used to call the teacher the dominie.']

LEE True enough, in these days the Headmaster in school has become merely the Headmaster and is no longer the Dominie or even the `Heedmaister,' ... Ibid. 82 The Dominie would detail a few big boys to apprehend some of the culprits. (1934,Children of the Poor,14,1949 ed.)

HYDE The sight of an eight-year-old schoolboy shambling into the class-room ... was too much for the dominie's sense of humour, ... (1936,Passport to Hell,26)

Dominion¶

n.

I estimate it at about two millions, or ... one-twelfth of the sheep in the Dominion. (1916,TrNZI,48/156)

Dominion Day¶

n.

Yesterday, September 26, will stand in the records as the first Dominion Day. (Sep 27, 1907,NZ Mail) [NOTES: 1907 Sep 27 NZ Mail (Wellington) in 1985 Bromby Eye Witness History 90]

dominion day n, usu cap both Ds 2 : Sept 26 observed in New Zealand as a statutory bank holiday celebrating the anniversary of the coming into dominion status in 1907 (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,672)

Dominion Day birthday shared Eighty years ago tomorrow New Zealand became a dominion and Frances Flett Dominion Daker was born at Arrowtown. (Sep 26, 1987,Evening Post,5)

Dominion goose¶

n. = colonial goose

J.F. CAMPBELL Dominion Goose [fn] Formerly Colonial. (1943,Postscripts of Crowbar,78)

Dominion pudding¶

n.

ELDRED-GRIGG ... she'd just opened the pudding bag to show off a big puffy white dominion pudding. [c 1930s] (1987,Oracles and Miracles,114)

McGILL Dominion pudding raisins and batter, first appearing to celebrate our Dominion status in 1907. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,26)

Dominion sausage¶

n. the orig. patriotic name during WW1 and after of German sausage (also Belgian sausage), now usually luncheon sausage ca1914. (Compare English Spam; and compare the history of `German measles' in WW1.)

Dominion status¶

n.

SINCLAIR Just as Massey had in 1907 opposed the adoption of the title Dominion' ..., now, in office, he declined to participate in the formulation of the concept ofdominion status' ... Massey consistently denied that the Dominions were, for international purposes, sovereign states. (1959,History of New Zealand,238)

Dominion-wide¶

adj.

HUNT Twenty-five years ago I was chairman of a Dominion-wide representative conference on population called under the aegis of the Wellington Chamber of Commerce. (1951,Confessions,107)

Dominyong¶

n. Dominion

It's grim in the old Dominyong, all right. (Aug 30, 1943,NZEF Times,III/114 : 6) [NOTES: Probably a take-off of Peter Fraser, the then Prime Minister]

dommyknocker¶

n. [Get bommyknocker--> from D. NORTON from Joy Cowley; also as dongyknocker.]

McGILL dommyknocker a stick to beat other kids with, aka bommyknocker; origins unknown, though a dommie' was a nickname for a NortonDominator' motorbike and thus for any motorcyclist, while `bommie' is a bombora or submerged reef beyond beach breakers, of interest only to Australian surfers, and their guests. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38)

McGILL dongyknocker a club, cousin of dommyknocker, invoking the concept of a dong or knock, familiar among possum poppers, or trappers. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,26)

Keith Bauer aged 6 knows BOMMYKNOCKER, which occurred in a radio children's story for something to knock your enemies over with: a knobbed stick: check also the term a fisherman's PRIEST. Winifred Bauer also knows the children's term BOMMYKNOCKER (Oct 19, 1988,Personal Communication)

Don Clarke¶

n. a powerful or well-directed kick.

JOHNSTON Then a hefty Don Clarke special connected with Hec Jepson's rump ... (1981,Fish Factory,172)

Don R¶

n. Despatch Rider

He reveals a desire for full coverage in a section on the "Don R's" - the despatch riders who rode their trusty motorbikes across every kind of terrain. (Apr 23, 2003,Capital Times,6)

don't argue¶

n. a strong fend-off

Hand off: Grant McQuoid gives a don't argue to Taranaki halfback James King on Saturday. (Aug 30, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10) [NOTES: Caption]

don't give me that stuff¶

phr.

Don't give me that stuff: a term which may be otherwise or additionally furnished, implying disapproval, doubt or scepticism. (Oct 12, 1942,NZEF Times,II/69 : 6)

don't stand there like a burnt stump¶

phr. i.e. do something, move! [or similar wording]

McCLENAGHAN Don't stand there a burnt stump. Come back up here. (1976,Travelling Man,87)

TUI FLOWER When someone says, `Don't just stand around like a burnt stump,' it means, do something! (Jan 14, 1978,Personal Communication) [NOTES: 1986 B.G. Ostmann U.S. food-writer's written remarks: p.c. Tui Flower NZ Woman's Weekly (14 Jan 1987)]

don't you believe it¶

exclam.

BUTLER A few [colonial] expressions were not familiar to me. When we should say in England, Certainly not,' it is hereNo fear', or `Don't you believe it.' (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,34)

donah¶

n. a girlfriend; sweetheart; sheila.

[Lad of the smart set speaks] Girls were never punctual - even `Donahs.' (1896,Tom Bracken's Annual,1/38)

He was trailing a spoony couple and become so excited when viewing the manner in which the young fellow kissed his `donah.' (Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8)

... a prim and precise donah. (Sep 21, 1905,NZ Truth,21/8/4)

Dancing Donahs. [headline] (Oct 20, 1906,NZ Truth,6)

Donald Duck¶

n. an act of sexual intercourse. [rhyming slang]

NEWBOLD DONALD DUCK (n) Act of sexual intercourse. Rhyming slang. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

Women sleep under here [Grafton Bridge, Auckland] too,' says Brian.All over 18. They like a `donald duck' ... [sic] I don't say no ...' [sic] (Jun 1, 1985,Metro,65)

donatia¶

n. [1919 NZ Plants & Their Story COCKAYNE Donatia novae-zelandiae]

COCKAYNE (And) Donatia novae-zelandiae (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

done¶

v. to donate (blood) [ORIGIN: abbreviation, "Having worked in the Auckland Blood Transfusion Centre, I can vouch for the frequent use of the verb "to done" which rhymes with "stone", most commonly heard in such contexts as "I have been doning [blood] for years". [Marian Barnes]]

1 adj. (Rural) [of farm stock] old or ill.

Old done ewes will, I think, be almost unsaleable .. the sooner they are boiled down the better. (Feb 3, 1906,Farmers' Union Advocate,12)

A sick sheep: a sheep that is done. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

done like a dinner¶

phr. thoroughly defeated etc. (See done like a dog's dinner)

On the ball, warts and all, getta life, fishwife On the box seat, sitting pretty, what a winner Dinkie Di. She'll be right, a box o' birds, tonights the night Stone the crows, and done like a dinner. (Dec 2004,NZ Memories,No 51, p19)

Owen Marshall 'We're going to be done like a dinner by this guy,' said Eddie. 'We're going to be arseholed out and our feet won't even touch the ground.' (2005,Watch of Gryphons,215)

"I was done like a dinner," Mr Atchison recalls. (May 27, 2004,Dominion Post,C5)

done like a dog's dinner¶

phr. soundly defeated [cf. ODE for (like a) dog's dinner]

McGILL done like a dog's dinner comprehensively defeated; eg `Last year just about every other province was done by Auckland like a dog's dinner.' ANZ. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,26)

"We've been done like a dog's dinner," says Rugby League Park convenor Denis O'Reilly. (Jul 19, 2000,Capital Times,3)

dong¶

n. a blow, punch, hit. [ca1935 Havelock schoolboys.]

v. to hit, punch, bash; cf donk, sonk, sock. [(mainly schoolchildren's slang ?onomatopoeic) ca1900 C.R. Carr Dunedin schoolchildren ca1935 Havelock schoolchildren]

PARTRIDGE Dong. To strike; to punch: New Zealanders' and Australians': C. 20. Perhaps ex the dong emitted by a bell when struck; perhaps a blend of ding + dot. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,233)

[Slang of the N.Z.E.F.] To dong' andto knock cold' are plain; ... (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

COOZE I'll dong him one in the eye. (1946,My Little State Home in Suburbia,34)

ASHTON-WARNER What are you writing?'My twin she dong me on the boko.' What isboko', Whareparita?' (1958,Spinster,25)

McLEOD Joe had the hind legs [of the pig] and Toss had the ear and wouldn't let go, and Joe was trying to dong him with his mustering stick and swearing and shouting ... It was a proper Donnybrook for awhile ... (1959,Tall Tussock,72)

SLATTER What's biting ya? Ya'd never rush outa the boozer in the old days. Too proud to drink with ya old cobs? A man oughta dong ya. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,45)

HILLIARD I'll dong you if you say it any more. (1960,Maori Girl,133)

MUIR `A joker ought to dong you; you know that?' (1960,Word for Word,255)

ASHTON-WARNER (1963,Spinster,183)

HARVEY So I donged her on the head with the breadknife. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,77)

BALLANTYNE `I'll dong you, boy!' he shouted. (1968,Sydney Bridge,6)

dong v.t. hit, usually over the head. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

I got donged on the nut and then I was sitting up in the team dressing room,' he said.I think I must have bitten someone's finger as they tried to do something with my mouthguard.' (Jul 27, 1983,Dominion,1)

`Someone came out and donged him with a billiard cue.' Another bystander said he saw the man hit with the cue and the hammer and being punched and kicked . -->?As he came, I caught him, my feet in his stomach. (Jul 17, 1983,Dominion,5)

dong NZ & Austral. sl. 1 n. heavy blow. 2 v.t. hit. [imit.] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,223) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 144]]

[a woman gang member] could be sitting in the pub ... and some woman would come up to me and dong me in the face. (May 1986,More Magazine,231)

McGILL dong to strike or punch, perhaps from the sound of the word: `If you don't piss off quick smart, I'll dong you one.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38)

Despite requests from his children to 'dong the rats', David does not intervene, believing the sacrifice is worth the valuable public awareness conveyed by the image. (Nov 2002,Footnotes,No. 18/8)

I donged a guy one Saturday. He was walking and he thought he would rush through as I put the arm down. So he got an egg on the head. (Sep 10, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

v. [??dateline ... it strikes me that if the man who performed the feat of carrying that great awkward saw in, had been with Hillery [sic] and Lowe on their first Himalayan trip, Everest would probably have been donged sooner than it was.]

I read in the paper the other day of a man who was fined $100 with court costs $35, and was then donged $3.50 GST on the court costs. (Oct 25, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

dong-beater¶

n. masturbator

GEE Why do I always think of sex? ... Guilt. Presbyterian drug-beater's [??dong-] guilt. A dread disease. A killer (1972,In My Father's Den,147)

dong-wallop¶

n. (coarse slang) penis (extension of dong) [Also dong-walloper ca1935 Havelock schoolboys. ca1950 Wellington]

COLIN GORDON When jokers cut themselves there is a nurse [employed by the Works] to do up cuts, etc.; so others try to make out they have cut their cocks, and the terms [associated with] this are to cut your dong-wollop, kidney-puncher, bean-tosser, hawk-sword, family maker. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works]

MASTERS (1960,Back-Country Tales,29)

donga¶

n.

The land [at Anzac] rises gradually in [126] a series of hills and ridges ... It is broken by deep nullahs and dongas. and is covered by thick scrub, ... (Aug 26, 1915,NZ Herald) [NOTES: 1915 Aug 26 NZ Herald (Auckland) in 1985 Bromby Eye Witness History 125-126]

ANZAC ... over dongas and gullies. [Ibid. p2 refers to the `men who had seen service with the Maorilanders in South Africa'] Ibid. 153 ... in the bottom of a ten foot donga. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,123)

AUSTIN ...held up ... by m-g [check] fire from a donga. (1924,Official History NZ Rifle Brigade,41)

n. [?poss. from golfing usage]

SLATTER The O.C. said when the Japs land we'll chase them into the donga, we'll chase them into the matagouri and he really believed it because he was in the first war. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,225)

n. a depression in land; a (small) narrow gully, or dry water course, used by NZ military since the Boer War. [Mashall's use of "on" rather suggests he is confusing it with kopje, a small hill.]

MARSHALL Like a Havelock boy ending up getting shot on [sic] some Boer War donga. (1999,Harlequin Rex)

HAWDON [Trooper Barry quote] `some of our scouts were down a donga and could not get out in daylight.' (1907,New Zealanders & the Boer War,64)

2 n. a dip in the course; a shallow gully or hollow. [(?mainly Wellington, golfers') ca1948 p.c. K.J. Cullinane (Featherston).]

Tee shot finishing in `Donga' may be brought back on to fairway without penalty. (1960,Ephemera) [NOTES: 1960 Hutt Municipal Golf Links: Card of Local Rules. No 7:]

3 n. (Transf.? from 2) Pothole (in road). [ca1952 Ohingaiti hotel bar, patron speaks. You've got to watch out for the dongas in the road.]

donger¶

n. a heavy wooden club (for stunning fish with. [(mainly fishermen's)]

HILLIARD Netta saw the dong hanging from a piece of wire and the donger on a loop of leather. (1960,Maori Girl,84)

[Fishing Col] Within seconds a beautiful blue [Mao Mao] was threshing in the bottom of the boat and Johnny was reaching for the cray and his donger ... Doubling the crayfish over he pounded the claws into a pulp against the gunwale and the shredded pieces streamed away in the drift. (Apr 4, 1963,Evening Post,29)

n. a penis

BENTLEY & FRASER During choir practice at Otorohanga/ The bell-ringer displayed his new donger;/ Some thought it much thicker/ Than the curate's or vicar's,/ And everyone said it was longer. (1985,Grand Limerick Tour, A,[No.]40)

McGILL donger penis, by association with preceding entry. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38)

LAY How's the donger?'Bit of suturing, but still in one piece.' (1988,Fools on the Hill, The,51)

n.

"Then the big boys of the wholesale vege business moved in and I went down the donger, didn't I. I went bloody broke, virtually." (Sep 19, 1998,Dominion,17)

2 n.

TRAIL I did not fully understand what this dawn ritual was all about and was horrified to discover that some of the trapped rabbits were still alive and had to be donged on the head. I was to be the donger while he was busy skinning the dead ones. (1984,Child of the Arrow,87)

donger-knocker¶

n. (See dommyknocker)

donie¶

(/douni/) n. excrement; poo [(children's) ca1935 Pahiatua neighbourhood: F. O'Brien]

donk¶

n. a donkey or mule

WAITE [caption] `DONKS.'/ These big mules of the N.Z. Divisional Train were bred in North America. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,33)

MANSON And it's just the most glorious day possible, ... and all the villages alive with blue-gowned fellaheen marketing; dear little donks and groaning old camels .. (1960,Doctor Agnes Bennett,75) [NOTES: 1915 Agnes Bennett in 1960 Manson Doctor Agnes Bennett 75]

n. a var. of dong [(primary schoolchildren's) ca1935 Havelock schoolchildren I'll donk you (one)' orI'll give you a donk.']

n. an engine [Spg donk' (?airforce, fishermen)]

It was not until 1963 that those dependable old donks made way for 95 hp Gardiners, which pushed the Echo across the strait at seven and a half knots. (Aug 2004,NZ Memories,No. 49/45)

JOHNSTON Better pull the motor and gear-box out and get them both done up, Jamie. I've heard your donk' in the mornings and it's running rough. (1981,Fish Factory,121)

CHARLES Young Bradshaw's the boy who is flying this plane,/ She is as full as a tick and it's pouring with rain./ Things are not going good - his donk's on the blink -/ Then he puts up a blue and she dives in the drink./ [fn] his donk's on the blink: his engine is giving trouble (airman's slang) [Charles had served in the RNZAF in WW2] (1981,Black Billy Tea,89)

n. a penis [ca1938 Havelock schoolboys]

v. to hit, wallop, punch [(schoolchildren's) ca1935 Havelock e.g. I'll donk you (give you a donk) if you don't watch out.]

2 n. pl., esp a racehorse. Compare moke.

NEWTON However the station still has a few old donks at the homestead. (1952,High Country Journey,76)

SLATTER She was always doing her money cold on the donks. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,71)

MUIR There's no such horse as Kiwi Song.'Too right, there is. Just a young donk but not a bad pacer at that.' (1960,Word for Word,224)

donkey¶

n. Spec. use of donkey-engine; or fig. as doing the `donkey work'; hauler [(forestry)]

HAULER. A portable engine equipped with drum and cable, and powered by steam or internal combustion. syn DONKEY (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

2 n. a deer [(deerhunters' joc.)]

McGILL donkey deer, to those who stalk deer. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,26)

donkey bird¶

n. a nickname for a penguin

Woe betide [visitors] should at the same time nesting penguins have tenancy of the under-floor space; for the night calls of these birds have earned for them the soubriquet "donkey birds." (Feb 1947,Forest & Bird,3)

donkey deep¶

adj. deeply immersed

"Donkey deep" may have been used with a crude meaning by New Zealand soldiers in Egypt, but then many expressions acquired temporary unsavoury angles in wartime. (Sep 14, 2005,Dominion Post,B5)

If Helen Clark used the expression "They are donkey deep in it" as you reported (Sept 9), is it appropriate that our prime minister should resort to using obscenities when attacking the opposition? (Sep 14, 2005,Dominion Post,B4)

adj. immersed, up to one's neck (in a thing) [ca1951 Dunedin (from a Southland man) p.c. R. Mason]

I'm donkey-deep' in fractions/ Since I got the ha'p'ny rise/ I'm on theskin' in decimals,/ And my brain is all afire/ To try and make the increase spread. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,67)

The T.M.'s are donkey-deep in cricket. (Aug 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/49 : 12)

donkey lick¶

v. to defeat decisively (in sport).

In the expressive idiom of New Zealand rugby the All Blacks `donkey licked' Transvaal. ... Their victory, decisive as it was ... (Aug 8, 1960,Dominion,13)

donkey room¶

n. a staff cafeteria [as where the `donkeys', or workers congregate]. [(watersiders')] (See also donko)

DEVBANNY Lafe and Holly ranged themselves in the queue in the `donkey room' [to draw their wharf-pay for the week]. (1926,Laura Divine,257)

... the mission was still hoping to move into the upstairs section ... This was formerly the watersiders' dining and meeting area and was known in the old days as the `donkey room.' (May 17, 1975,Evening Post,2/9)

I remember how a bus would distribute cafeteria staff around what were known as "donkey rooms" (or cafeterias), the farthest of which was at the overseas passenger terminal. (Dec 5, 2001,Dominion,28)

donkey vote¶

n. voting by preference for alphabetical order of candidates' names on the ballot paper.

ROAD safety compaigner Herb Bickley is hoping to win more than the `donkey vote' at the general election on August 15. (Aug 2, 1987,Sunday News,27)

donkey's ages¶

phr. a variant of donkey's years [also heard as donk's ages. Jim writes : "I have not found this variant in any dictionary, but it is not uncommon in informal speech."]

SLATTER Been teaching English for donkey's ages. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,225)

donko¶

n. a room in a workplace set aside for worker's smoko, lunches etc; also occas. crib room. [(industrial workers')]

MORRIESON Up the stairs to the "donko" to wrap the sacking known as "sneakers" around his boots. (1976,Pallet on the Floor,38)

He sits in the donko beside the rotary milking shed on the 235-hectare family farm backing on to the Feilding golf course and explains why [he buys in extra stock feed]. (Mar 15, 2012,Dominion Post,C4)

May I suggest the inclusion of the word Donko' in any subsequent edition of your New Zealand Dictionary. The word, which appears to meanthe lunch room or similar facilities for workers in a factory'. The word appears to have fairly wide usage in New Zealand and I have spoken to several Australians and found them unaware of it. It do not know the origin of the term and would be grateful if any of your etymologists can enlighten me. (Apr 28, 1981,Personal Communication) [NOTES: A.R.Stone letter to editor HNZD]

Can you tell me the origin of the word donko'? My correspondent assures me it is a New Zealand term forthe tea room of a factory or work-place'. The report comes from Wanganui. ... Is it a place where you donk or dunk biscuits in your tea? (Aug 21, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49) [NOTES: [I.A. Gordon]]

... in the woolstores. Smoko was held in the donko, where we'd adjourn after working like billyo. (Apr 14, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

donnie¶

n. Donnybrook

HILLIARD There was a donny down at the Foresters tonight', he saidCouple of them had this bloke down, one of them was belting him with a bottle.' (1960,Maori Girl,257)

CRUMP Some gate-crashing bush-whackers had picked on one of their blokes and it looked like a real donnie coming up. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,164)

donnybrook¶

n. in NZ usu. a brawl or fracas.

THATCHER And in his big fist he had got a shillalah,/ As if it was Donnybrook 'stead of Parnell./ (1862,Auckland Vocalist,4)

GRACE `A good feed to-night - a short, tight sleep - an early march in the morning - another fight about the break of day. Donnybrook will be nothing to it.' (1899,Sketch of the NZ War,134)

... as proceedings wore on, wordy arguments developed into fisticuffs, and there was a general `donnybrook' as a fitting climax to an eventful day. (1914,History of North Otago,103,1978 ed.)

AYSON There was one between a stockman named Thomas Todd and an Irishman named Patsy which nearly led to a Donnybrook. (1937,Thomas,52)

WALSH Doctor and Matron were having a great old Donny-brooke. (1947,Fourth Point of Star,20)

McLEOD Joe had the hind legs [of the pig] and Toss had the ear and wouldn't let go, and Joe was trying to dong him with his mustering stick and swearing and shouting ... It was a proper Donnybrook fora while ... (1959,Tall Tussock,72)

Rev. R.W. CANNELLY I was told one of our [St Bede's College] football' (Rugby) matches developed into aDonnybrook'. (Nov 26, 1957,Letter)

SLATTER There was a bit of a donnybrook but how it finished Erik never knew ... (1968,Pagan Game, The,168)

With this intention I made tracks through the crowd. When I got into Queen Street I found that a donnybrook had already started ... (May 1987,Metro,148)

Donovan¶

n. a potato - but check. [(obs.)]

Planted, with the assistance of Mr.Ogilvie, a quantity of Kidney donovans. (Aug 29, 1842,Piraki Log,144,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

doob¶

n. (See grass)

doobie¶

n. a marijauna cigarette

The law lets me drink myself to incapacity and smoke to my heart's (dis)content so why can't I pass the doobie? (2004,Salient,8/33)

dood¶

n. a pipe (See dudeen)

doodackie¶

n. a thingumebob. Compare doodah, doohickey, hoodackie, etc.; hoojackie. [ca1940 (esp. children's)]

McGILL doodackie thingummybob, or humorous word for something you have no name for; a local variation of doodad, doodah, dooflickey, etc. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38)

doodackied¶
