n. Spruced up; dolled up (? connected with `all doed up').

WALSH Anyway ... Matron must have seen John waiting here, all doodackied up [to meet his girlfriend]. (1947,Fourth Point of Star,12)

doodah¶

n. Fig., a swell; a townie; a non-labourer

He buckled to himself, but, noticing how few hands were engaged, he ran to where the shovels were kept and carried an armful to where a number of city clerks, doodahs with the inevitablebrief-bag - probably containing property they had pinched from their employers that evening. [re Kilbirnie Tunnel cave in: Sentence is incomplete in the original - no subordinate clause verb.] (Mar 2, 1907,NZ Truth,89/3/6)

doodee¶

n. (See dudeen)

doodia¶

n. Doodia media.

POTTS DOODIA, SCENTED DOODIA Doodia caudata. ... DOODIA, TAILED DOODIA Doodia caudata. (1882,Out in the Open)

LOGAN (1875,Ferns of NZ)

doodlum-buck¶

n. a children's game, toodle-em-buck q.v. [aka doodle-em buck, doodlum buck, toodle-em-buck]

There were fancy stalls, produce tents, butchers' shops, skittle alleys, a shooting gallery, the good old game of "Doodlum Buck," bowling alleys, prize quoit boards, etc. (Apr 14, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,5)

SUTTON-SMITH Pitching games were Pitch and Toss, Quoits, Ninepins, Egg Cap and Toodle-em-buck. In the game of Toodle-em-buck (Richmond ([19]19) a piece of broom a foot in length with a button on top of it stood upright in a circle of about two fet in diameter. Players pitched another piece of broom at this upright stick from a set distance in an endeavour to knock it over and send the button out of the circle. The game was played to the cry of `Roll up, Tumble up, come and play the game of Toodle-em-Buck'. There is still occasional mention of Egg Cap (Horoeka, Alexandra). (1953,Unorganized Games,2/471)

SUTTON-SMITH Another universal stone-throwing game was Ducks and Drakes (K-8), or Skipping Stones, which consisted simply in skipping' flat stones across the water. feet in diameter and a button was placed on top of the stick. Players pitched another piece of broomstick of the same size at the upstanding piece in an attempt to knock it over and send the button outside the circle. The game was played to the cry ofRoll up, tumble up, come and play the game of Toodlle-em-buck.' Ibid. 172 An odd pitching game was Toodle-em-Buck (K-28) (Richmond, Nelson, 1919), in which a piece of broomstick a foot in length was placed upright in a circle about two (1972,Folkgames of Children,167)

SUTTON-SMITH There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. .. Canterbury: Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips,Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag;... (1981,History of Children's Play,231)

[Gambling] which disgraces horse-racing, is benignly smiled upon by grandmotherly legislators who know as much of betting and turf gambling as they do of three card monte, or the ways of doodlum-buck. (Nov 6, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

Soldiers' Day Attractions... Cocoanut shys... Doodle-em Buck. (Apr 13, 1916,Stratford Evening Post,3) [NOTES: My uncle used to often used the phrase "The great old game of doodle-em buck" apropos of almost anything which I suppose he must have picked up from a visiting side-show.]

BRUCE Peter Poski ... with his crown and anchor game and his confrere with his game of `Doodlum Buck', ... (1932,Early Days of Canterbury,152)

The various sports, under the superintendence of the committee, according to the programme, consisted of target shooting, target shooting with shot, quoit matches, wrestling, three-legged racing, vaulting with pole, putting the stone, egg racing, running flat leaps, standing high leaps, 300 yards handicap racing, pigeon shooting, hurdle racing, boys' racing, and hop, step, and jump; and last - though not least - "Doodle'em Buck" and the wheel-of-fortune. (Dec 28, 1871,Grey River Argus,2)

THE SKILFUL GAME OF DOODLUM BUCK: A POPULAR FIGURE AT ALL RACE MEETINGS AND SPORTS. (Apr 5, 1905,Otago Witness,38)

Shooting Gallery, Doodlum Buck. (Apr 25, 1891,Timaru Herald,1)

n. a game [See (synonymous) doodlum buck]

DOODS¶

abbr. Dykes Out Of Debt, a Lesbian organisation

DOODS celebrates its 10th birthday this month... Originally standing for Dykes Out Of Debt, it was established partly in response to a funding crisis faced by the Amazon lesbian softball and soccer teams. (Jun 26, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),2)

dooflickey¶

n. a doodackey, a thingumebob. [ca1953 H.S. Gajadhar]

dook¶

v. to shake hands

MEEK DOOK: To shake hands. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

dool¶

n. [ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream and ca1945 Varsity undergraduates. Don't be such a dool.]

Doolan¶

n. a Roman Catholic; A Catholic, esp. an Irish Catholic (occas. Irishman); see also Micky Doolan. [ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream]

CAMPBELL We'd gang up on kids who chucked off at us - like the boys from the Catholic home. They'd call us [from the Presbyterian Boys' Home in Dunedin] Pressbuttons'; we'd call themdoolans', doolies',Mickey Doolans' - or worse. (1984,Island to Island,87) [NOTES: [c1935]]

FINLAYSON A holy medal, eh? Those jokers all doolans you know. (1952,Brown Man's Burden,116,1973 ed.) [NOTES: `Little Gift for Harry']

SLATTER And in peace the civilians must have something to hate too. The Dutchies or the Pommies or the Doolins or somebody. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,60)

BAXTER I don't let any black bugger push me around. Or any Doolan either..Ibid. 36 `I'm not a Doolan, Ivan.' I know you're not. But if you're ever looking for a Church, don't by-pass the onewith the big stone steps ... (1985,Horse,29,C.1962 ed.) [NOTES: (Name and the Game)]

PEARSON They had called him `the Doolan bugger' - Doolan on their tongues meant Irish Catholic. (1963,Coal Flat,63)

SLATTER Webster had brutally reminded him that the original Crusaders had all been Doolins. Ibid. 195 There is a catholic college in the town now and we [in our rugby team] coulduse some of those ... kick everything in sight Doolins. (1968,Pagan Game, The,92)

DAVIN Not that she isn't worried enough about Eric, that's my steady in Wellington, him not being a doolan and all that. (1970,Not Here, Not Now,57)

FINLAYSON doolans: Catholics. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,140)

AGNEW Yes, I'm a Doolan,' I pacified him.At least I was baptised one.' ... It was only a short walk to the Catholic church ... . (1974,Loner, The,100)

MASON SMITHSON: `The New Roman Missal'! Good God. Are you becoming a Doolan now? (1974,Swan Song,14)

LAWRY This fellow measured far short of what they wanted for their daughter, and anyway, he was a `doolan'. (1980,Good Luck & Lavender,77)

BAXTER SKULLY. Once a Doolan always a Doolan. You've got holy water on the brain. (1982,Collected Plays,39) [NOTES: (1968) 1982 Baxter Collected Plays (Wide Open Cage) 39]

BEARDSLEY doolan Roman Catholic (1984,Blackball 08,243)

McGILL Spotted him for a Doolan right enough. Only several removed [sic: =?removes] from the priesthood. (1985,G'day Country,102)

Doolan NZ & Austral. sl. derog. Roman Catholic. [Irish name] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,223) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McGILL doolan Roman Catholic, usually expected to be Irish; presumably from Doolan being a common name here last century. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,38)

The Roman Catholic church (attended by Micks' orDoolans') was outside this ranking ... (1988,Through the Looking Glass,127) [NOTES: (Meikle)]

The dial tone suggested my luck with the Doolans had run out. (Nov 18, 2004,TV3,17)

adj. Catholic

BAXTER Horse had not been in a Doolan church before. (1985,Horse,42) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Quick and the Dead) 42]

To draw a familiar analogy, white flight' is a bit like that old business where 15% of the population shamelessly segregated their kids from the godless 85% and put them in the care of nuns, brother, friars and other sundry medievals to fill young heads with the harmlesspapist prejudices of a pre-darwinian unenlightenment. As the Post might have dubbed that social malaise,Doolan schoolin''. (May 23, 1986,National Business Review,19) [NOTES: (Warren Mayne)]

SLIGO ... the Doolan priest who was always hanging around the convent, as everybody knew ... (1987,Final Things,8)

doolie¶

n. a Catholic. [ca1935 at least.]

The classics are ignored by St Patrick'sCollege band Downstream Doolies. (Aug 5, 1993,Contact (Wgtn),3)

CAMPBELL We'd gang up on kids who chucked off at us - like the boys from the Catholic home. They'd call us [from the Presbyterian Boys' Home in Dunedin] Pressbuttons'; we'd call themdoolans', doolies',Mickey Doolans' - or worse. (1984,Island to Island,87) [NOTES: [c1935]]

doona¶

n.

Under a doona of grilled,sticky, yum-melted pecorino cheese, its creamy, just cooked texture and taste were a dream. (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E8)

Doonegate¶

n. [Mr Doone: a former Police Commissioner.]

[caption] 'Doonegate' has returned to haunt Helen Clark. (May 21, 2005,Dominion Post,1)

[heading] Why is "Doonegate" in the news again all these years later? (May 21, 2005,Dominion Post,A9)

door-knockers¶

1 n. (Rural) dags.

dags - door-knockers. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

door-stop¶

v. pigeonhole without action. An allusion, resumably to lack of action on the 19** Report on Social Services which was referred to at the time, because of its size, as being mainly useful as a doorstop.

Isn't it more likely that its just going to be door-stopped? (Sep 10, 1996,Radio NZ / National Radio,Kim Hill)

dopestick¶

n. a cigarette. [(?smart slang: ? obsolesc) ca1969 Heard in the Victoria University of Wellington, Staff Common Room. **OED: dope-stick slang (see quot. 1918: examples are N.Z.).]

Cigarettes! smokes, fags, weeds, dopesticks - they are known by many strange names. (1918,New Zealand At the Front,132)

SMYTH Pass me those dopesticks, there's a dear. (1930,Wooden Rails,168)

dopey¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of a ewe suffering from sleepy sickness, twin-lamb disease or preganancy toxaemia] lethargic.

LOUGHNAN dopey or dozey: a ewe which loses interest in life is said to go dopey. Usually she has been suffering the lack of a steadily rising nutritional plane during her pregnancy and often is carrying twins. Her disease is thus sometimes termed twin-lamb disease. More correctly it is pregnancy toxaemia. [dozey] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,26)

dopie¶

adj. of sheep, suffering from dopiness q.v. [(station and farming)]

Dopie. A sheep which loses condition and interest in life, is said to go d[opie]. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

dopiness¶

n. a deficiency disease; a form of bush sickness.

The worst soils for `dopiness' as the local farmers call the disease [sc. bush-sickness]. (1929,TrNZI,59/412) [NOTES: (Aston) [Te Kuiti district]]

Recent investigations ion New Zealand testify to ... the value of top dressing of pastyures with lime and superphosphate where sheep are affected with dopiness diseases. (Nov 1932,Discovery,357/2) [NOTES: [OED2]]

The known deficiency diseases in New Zealand apparently mainly due to the lack of some element in the food of farm animals are:- Bush Sickness' or [mistakenly] Iron deficiency.Dopiness' or Calcium deficiency. Waihi Disease' or Phosphate deficiency.Goitre' or Iodine deficiency... Bush sickness is always found in the volcanic district on coarse rhyolitic pumice soils and dopiness' on soils derived from fine volcanic dust or mud showers. A soil on whichdopiness' develops is a leached loam and is found on deteriorated lands, i.e., lands which originally were highly fertile due to the ashes from the `bush burn,' the land subsequently becoming gradually less productive ... (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,81)

It is at lambing-time that the effect of grass-grub ravages is most severe. Ewes are low in condition and have missed the green bite from the pastures ... The normal green-feed area ... is inadequate. The result is a high mortality in young lambs, an increased susceptibility of the ewe todopiness,' ... (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/323A)

Some green, succulent feed just before and at lambing assists in the prevention of diseases associated with lambing - dopiness (twin lamb disease or ante-partum paralysis) and milk fever. (Jul 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,33/3)

1 n. (Rural) a state of lethargy in sheep suffering from milk fever, sleepy sickness or an associated disease.

.. antepartum paralysis or "dopiness" of ewes is a nutritional disease definitely associated, as a rule, with ewes falling off in condition at the approach of lambing. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,111)

The troubles which are most likely to affect the ewes are (i) ante-partum paralysis, or as the farmer more frequently calls it 'dopiness' 'twin-lamb disease' or 'sleeping sickness' ... (Sep 1, 1937,NZ Farmer,36)

All good sheepfarmers know that 'sleepy sickness' ('dopiness') in ewes can be prevented by proper feeding at the right time. (Jul 22, 1971,NZ Farmer,64)

dopo¶

n. in joc. address, `dope [(WW2 Italy)]

She'll be back at the strip-tease stuff, dopo. (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy,17)

dopper¶

n. a tar-stick for tarring animal wounds.

The boy had the necessary things - the bright new copper [bull-]ring and the steel spike and the old tin can and dopper' black with cattle tar. <i>(1966,NZ Short Stories,19,1976 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (FinlaysonThe Bulls')]

doppler¶

v.

As the past gets dissected, discussed and disputed within, the present intrudes as the thumping bass of a car stereo dopplers past on the seaside strip, a different kind of rap entirely. (Jun 22, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

dopy country¶

1 n. (Rural) calcium-deficient land, more common to the King Country where a metabolic condition known as Mairoa dopiness is found.

.. it affords a distinguishing difference between 'bush-sick' country and 'dopy' country. (Aug 20, 1931,NZ Journal of Agriculture,121)

dorgans¶

n. a large amount; lashings [(?tramping) [OMIT THIS]. ca1940-1950 (?informant) -->Great dorgans of graunch' is interpreteda hell of a lot of work']

dork¶

v. (informal) defeat

I felt like I'd just been dorked. (Aug 2004,North & South,92)

The Counties lock.. warned that the AllBlacks would "dork them" up front unlessthey substantially lifted their effort inset pieces. (May 30, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),40)

They played New Zealand at Lancaster Park and we dorked them 19-0. (Sep 1992,Metro,91)

dorkess¶

n. the feminine of dork

RENeE But oh no, some dork - or dorkess, let's not be sexist here - decided that that would be too easy. (1998,Yin & Tonic,127)

Dorkland¶

n. Auckland

Where are you from, ya fag?" he asks. "Oh? Dorkland!" he jeers. (Jul 18, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),27)

The couple claim to miss nothing about Auckland ... "We call it Dorkland now," Mr Weston laughed. (Oct 18, 2006,NZ Herald,A7)

Dorklander¶

n.

"I'm known down there as a Dorklander, not an Aucklander." (Mar 24, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A3)

South Island apres ski - it can mean trying not to look too much like a Dorklander over a mulled wine (sadly, a dead giveaway) at the iconic Cardrona Hotel. (Aug 14, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

He's trying hard to ignore the shouts of "dorklander" and "jaffa" from the bar. That's how they curse a northerner in the Mainland. (Oct 10, 2001,Capital Times,10)

[Hdg] Dorklanders get Blues in the bedroom. (May 16, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B15)

It was unfortunate this letter be followed by a ridiculous offering..which only lends to help the rest of us understand the true origins of the term "Dorklander"! (Apr 23, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B6)

Dorper¶

n. a South African breed of sheep

The Dorper sheep breed isn't exactly bald but has a mixture of wool and hair which keeps their bottom nice and clean... The Dorper breed was developed in South Africa in the late 1930s by crossing Blackhead Persian and Dorset Horn breeds. They are solid white or white with a black head and don't require shearing. (May 14, 2003,Capital Times,15)

New Zealand's latest sheep import, the wool-less dorper from South Africa, is the fastest-growing sheep breed Queenstown farmer Bill Loft has seen. (Oct 30, 2002,Dominion Post,C3)

dorty¶

adj. anything fine, excellent; beaut [(children's catchword) 1923 Pukekohe p.c. R. Mason (1953) Dorty was a very popular catchword among children for a short time.]

dory¶

n. an edible marine fish, recognised by the curious `thumbprint' markings on its sides [French dore[e-acute] gilded] (See also oreo dory)

RICHARDSON 38. Capros australis Richardson, Zool. Tr. 3. This is probably the Dory mentioned by Polack. (1842,Travels in NZ,2/211) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ]

TAYLOR The Dory also belongs to New Zealand, but is very rarely captured. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,625)

SENIOR Amongst the sea-fishes fit for food there are ... a number of periodical fishes ... and these include frost-fish. barracuda, horse-mackerel, king-fish, dory, warehou, mackerel, and garfish. (1880,Travel & Trout,288)

Of the edible [pelagic] fishes ... such as the frostfish, barracouta, horse-mackerel, kingfish, dory, warehou, mackerel, and garfish; while only the ling, hake and haddock ... are among those of more southern types ... (1892,NZ Official Handbook,167)

AYLONG JOHN DORY (Kuparu) Zeus faber (Zeus japonicus) ... very similar species occur in all other temperate seas. (1982,Collins Guide,180,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] dory [TS] 1034-42 DORIES 1024-54 ... dory, John 1038-43 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

dosing strip¶

n. (historical) an area formerly set aside for the treatment of dogs, against hydatids, sheep measles, etc. [(farming)] (See dog-dosing strip,dog dosing)

dosing strip/dog dosing strip¶

1 n. (Rural) an area in a local rural locality where sheepdogs are dosed and tested for hydatids.

MAF Dosing strip: an area of ground where official dosing by hydatids control officers takes place. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,24)

PATOKA REUNION COMMITTEE The present dog dosing officer Ernie Saker has made many regular visits to the farms and dosing strips in the area for the last twenty-five years. (1985,Podocarp to Pasture,32)

CANDY Haven't I always repulsed all those snarling dogs at the dosing strip? (1988,Every Living thing,115)

MCGILL dog dosing strip: once ubiquitous hydatids depts where dogs got vigorous medicine to stop hydatids worm eggs getting back to sheep and humans, made famous in Peter Cape's ditty 'The Dog Dosing Strip at Dunsandel.' (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,25)

doss-down¶

n. Noun: more often used now than the verb; a shakedown; a rough, makeshift bed; the NZ use is mainly doss-down (cf shakedown @n). [[Form first recorded in NZ.]]

CARRICK [The bed] was accounted a luxury ... compared with the doss-down the digger in pursuit of his calling was accustomed to. (1892,Romance of Lake Wakatipu, A,16)

doss-out¶

n.

HISLOP It was a great place for a doss-out. (1944,Pure Gold,117)

dossing-out¶

n. usu. of a vagrant, sleeping out-of-doors; also doss-out, an out-of-doors sleeping-place.

His offence, if it can so be called, consisted in `dossing-out', or in begging food to keep body and soul together. (Jul 3, 1909,NZ Truth,210/4/4)

dotterel¶

n. [pohowera, see plover.]

HUTTON 64. CHARADRIUS BICINCTUS. Jard. Dotterel. Pokowera (1871,Birds of New Zealand,24)

Amongst birds he has obtained [at the chathams] are ...a Dotterel, differing from the common Dotterel of this country ...; a sea-bird, called by the whalers the `Blue Billy', the beak of which is singularly shaped, and of a blue colour, hence its trivial name; the Nelly Ossifraga gigantea) ... (1872,TrNZI,4/64) [NOTES: (Travers Notes on the Chatham Isds)]

  1. Charadrius bicinctus, Jard. and Selb. Dottrel [sc]. - One of the earlier breeders, whether on the tussock-clad plains or on river-bed spits and flats; ... not in Yate NZ 1835 p65 for Tuturiwata (Griffiths Collection) (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,507) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

CHARADRIUS BICINCTUS, Jard. - Dotterel. (1886,TrNZI,18/126) [NOTES: (Hamilton)]

Pluviorhynchus obscurus Gm. Dotterel. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/76) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds: AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,Vol. IX No. 5 pp.343-382) 358) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs]

2 n. Charadrius bicinctus; a small New Zealand and Australian bird of the plover family, with two bands of colour across its breast, found on shores and riverbeds; also called double-banded dotterell, New Zealand dotterel, tuturiwhatu.

It is also the habitat for many birds, including the banded dotterel, which is threatened with extinction, and the black-fronted tern, which breeds here. (Aug 14, 2000,Evening Post,15)

... the banded Dotteril flies around with warning note ... Ibid. 2/67 (Potts Birds) CHARADRIUS BICINCTUS. Banded Dotterel. (1870,TrNZI,2/48) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

BULLER CHARADRIUS BICINCTUS. (BANDED DOTTREL.) ... Native names.- Tuturiwhata {, Tuturiwhatu,} and Pohowera. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,210,1888 2nd edn 2/3 ed.)

GUTHRIE-SMITH The Banded Dottrel (Charadrius bicinctus). (1921,Tutira,ch xxiii 207)

POWELL BANDED DOTTREL (Charadrius bicinctus ), or Tuturuwhatu is a characteristic little bird of the sand dunes, river beds and tussock clad plains.... It is widespread in New Zealand and occurs also in Tasmania and Australia (1947,Native Animals of NZ,81)

POWELL The banded dotterel (Charadrius bicinctus) runs very fast, as if on wheels. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,261)

FALLA et al. BANDED DOTTEREL Charadrius bicinctus Other names: Double-banded Dotterel, Mountain Plover, Tuturiwhatu, Pohowera. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,122)

WILLIAMS Piopio ...Ochthrodromus bicinctus; banded dotterel. Ibid. 282 ... Charadrius bicinctus; banded dotterel; a bird. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,135)

REISCHEK The birds I noticed were the bell-bird, the blight-bird, the yellow-headed tit, the ground lark, the little parakeet, the banded dotterel, and the native snipe. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,275,1933 ed.)

RICHARDS Ochthodromus ... bicinctus ... below white with a band of black on the chest and another of chestnut on the [80] upper abdomen; ... Banded Dotterel. POHOWERA. (1952,Chatham Islands,79)

.. the men from `down under' ... (Jan 1, 1905,NZ Truth,20/3/3)

While looking for nests of the banded dottrell Mr. R.H.D. Stidolph flushed a pipit or ground lark from its nest. (Nov 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

Pairs of banded dotterel make their nests early in that month [September]. (Feb 2, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,56)

2 n.

  1. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [si], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains,for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,506) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

2 n.

2 n. Charadrius obscurus; also called dusky plover, tuturuwata.

...observing endangered New Zealand dotterel breeding by the Takapuna motorway ramp... (May 2002,Forest & Bird,26)

BULLER CHARADRIUS OBSCURUS. (NEW-ZEALAND DOTTREL.) ... Native names.- Tuturiwhat{i and Tuturiwhatu}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,208,1888 2nd edn 2/1 ed.)

Charadrius obscurus, Gmelin. (New Zealand Dottrel [sic].) (1897,TrNZI,29/191) [NOTES: (Buller)]

WILLIAMS Rako, ...Pluvialis obscurus, New Zealand dotterel. Ibid. 463 Tuturuatu, n. Pluvialis obscurus, New Zealand red-breasted dotterel, and Thinornis novaeseelandiae, the shore plover. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,322)

TAYLOR Dusky Plover or New Zealand Dotterel (Charadrius obscurus) [Tuturuwata]. (1959,Early Travellers,44 fn)

NATUSCH [The banded dotterel's] relative the New Zealand dotterel, ... a larger bird, chestnut-breasted, nests on sandy beaches, mainly in the north. I know it best on the open high country of StewartIsland. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,261)

LOCKLEY New Zealand boasts four endemic waders not found elsewhere in the world. These are the black stilt, now limited to a few pairs nesting on high ground in the centre of the South Island; the shore plover, confined entirely to a small island off the Chathams, where its numbers are fairly strong; and the New Zealand dotterel, red-breasted in summer, rather curiously nesting in two discrete groups, one in the Hauraki Gulf, the other far away at and around Stewart Island - (1980,House Above the Sea,181)

SALE The New Zealand dotterel, while not rare, is classed as an uncommon bird and it is virtually unknown over a large part of New Zealand. (1982,Four Seasons,143)

2 n.

FALLA et al. RED-BREASTED (NEW ZEALAND) DOTTEREL Charadrius obscurus (1966,Birds of New Zealand,125)

SANSOM North of Duck Creek ... is the place to see the red-breasted New Zealand dotterel, the size of a slim bantam hen but not as fussy. (1970,Stewart Islanders,204)

2 n.

  1. Charadrius ruficapillus, Temm. Red-capped Dottrel [sic]. - This wader is now included in the list of New Zealand birds. [Is of Australian provenance] (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,508) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

double¶

n. a bet placed at the same time on two horses to win (often spec. races). cf doubles chart; cits needed.

A local boniface had a ticket on the winning double at Trentham on Wednesday and received nearly 250 [pounds] for his investment. (Jul 14, 1906,NZ Truth,56/2/2)

KEINZLY `It isn't a call-out, Mr Pilgrim, it's an invitation. He said to tell you he struck the double and they're having a hooley.' (1960,Tangahano,71)

He.. had admitted that he had been taking "doubles."... He had never admitted "running any doubles." (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,34)

BIRD A man known as 'Jacko' ran a double on the two contests, 1/- for GBP5. (1998,Viaducts against the Sky,130)

Just as L'Allegro surprised an army of punters.. at Ellerslie in 1932, so did he amaze the optimistic double punters who took on every available shilling on offer about the Jonathan-Star Artist combination. (Mar 14, 1934,NZ Truth,2)

n. to deceive; to use trickery (on) [ca1950 still used]

ROCK . come the double on me ... (1880,Colonists,60)

n. a sheep which has missed a shearing. [(farming)]

McLEOD Double or double-fleecer Double: Sheep which has missed shearing once or more. (1972,Mountain World,310)

NEWTON When he took over [the station], the only domestic sheep were `roughies' - long tailers and doubles that had multiplied from those which had escaped the wind-up muster four years before. (1973,Big Country,86,1977 ed.)

It was away back where roads were unknown, ... and where a few hundred sheep annually evaded the shearing muster, and remained among the scrub and flax bushes to develop into`double-fleecers'. (Apr 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,48)

GUTHRIE-SMITH We lived on wild pig ... and the fat wild sheep and double-fleecers that could be raked in from river cliffs; ... (1926,Tutira,224)

n. a two-ounce packet of prison tobacco. [(prison)]

NEWTON DOUBLE (n) Two-ounce packet of prison tobacco. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

n. twice the standard nip; also called double-header, doubler. Contrast Brit. large.

Bloody oath, Mat what good luck!' ...Shout you eh?' Too right you can. Double whisky.' <i>(1984,Some Other Country,182</i>) [NOTES: 1976 HulmeHooks and Feelers' in 1984 Some Other Country 182]

HULME `Too right you can. Double whisky.' And I get that from him and a jug and another couple of doubles and another jug. (1986,Te Kaihau,79)

JOHNSTON `We've got two doubles down him. Neat. ...' (1981,Fish Factory,78)

HALEY All I had to do was to pour one glass into the another and I'd have my double. ... `Double whisky,' I said. (1989,Transfer Station,41)

n. of locks or doors, to be double-locked

MacKENZIE double locks put on the double so that they cannot be opened with ordinary keys (1980,While We Have Prisons,96)

n. (Rural) [ell. double-fleecer or double-decker] a sheep that has missed at least one shearing.

NEWTON When he took over, the only domestic sheep were 'roughies' - longtailers and doubles that had multiplied from those which had escaped the wind-up muster four years before. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,86)

v. short form of double-bank, also occas. as n.; see also dub. (See double-bank)

SLATTER San Severino and coming down the track on the company bike with Mick doubling me on the bar. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,187)

HILLIARD A bike came past: a big boy doubling a girl on the crossbar. (1963,Piece of Land, A,57)

Philip [aged 5] ... was being doubled on the bicycle by Bonnie Helen Robertson. (Oct 30, 1966,Sunday Times (NZ),44)

GROVER I was the only one who had a bike, and I couldn't double Con and Camille together ... (1967,Another Man's Role,20)

RICHARDS The agent ... came out to the farm [on the motorbike] and doubled me back to town. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,84)

KOEA Once I did let my legs dangle too close to the wheel as I was doubled somewhere on the back of a bike ... (1988,Through the Looking Glass,67)

1 n. (Rural) an event in a dog trial contest with two dogs and six sheep.

NEWTON .. he [the dog]'s a bit lively yet but he had just won a double with him and with age he should be a top dog. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,191)

GORDON All were heading dog competitors and half would compete in a singles course (one dog working three sheep) and the rest in doubles (two dogs and six sheep.) (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,20)

double All Black¶

n.

Double All Black One of the highest honours that a New Zealand sportsman can receive is to represent his country both at rugby and at cricket. The following is the list of double All Blacks who have represented New Zealand in these games: (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/33)

Apart from the rather curious term double All Black, recorded in DNZE from the 1960s and meaning a man who has represented New Zealand at both rugby union and cricket (even though our cricketers have never been called All Blacks), there were no other secondary formations for another 75 years, when the previously overshadowed soccer code in New Zealand enjoyed its finest hour as the national team against huge odds qualified for the 1982 World Cup in Spain (Jan 1999,NZWords,2(1) : 5)

double banking¶

1 n.

HENDERSON DOUBLE BANKING: One horse team added to assist another. (1961,Friends in Chains,186) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 186]

... my three leaders were hooked in front of Tommy's team. Having given him a pull to the crest, they were brought back, ... This practice was known as double-banking, ... [West Coast, c1900] (1961,Friends in Chains,130)

2 n. splitting a train in half to enable one engine (otherwise insufficiently powered) to draw each section up a hill.

McGILL We might make Wharanui in a couple or so hours. Unless ... we stopped on the hill. ... When it did, you had to split the train in half, double-banking. Took one half at a time. (1985,G'day Country,119)

double beat¶

1 n. (Rural) the taking of two areas or beats on a muster, e.g. the top and middle beat.

NEWTON But I was in my twenties and double beats were nothing to me ... (1964,Straggle Muster,1)

Double Brown¶

n. a brand of beer

LACEY He's as sweet a sight as a line-up of frosty DB Double Browns on a mid-summer's day. (1976,Loosehead Len's Bumper Thump Book,24)

double crush¶

n. (See crush,crush pen)

BOWEN In a double crush (i.e. two pens) a good long gate, of approximately four feet width, should [121] be used at the end of the dividing fence to lead the sheep from either pen into the race. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

double cut¶

n. [shearing]

The fleece, being free from double cuts, is worth considerably more. (Nov 27, 1890,Otago Witness,11)

double dipping¶

n. the practice of deriving income from more than one source, at least one being a State benefit or government superannuation. [Jim writes: In NZPOD but not DNZE. Not in Collins. NSOD tags it as NAmer & SAustral.]

double dump¶

v. [Poss. move these dumps to dump n and v??]]

dump, to double dump v.t. compress wool bales, as by hydraulic pressure; dumper wave that collapses suddenly in the surf, tossing surfer on the hard sand; whence, to dump, and getdumped. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

double dumping¶

n.

A powerful hydraulic press forces two bales into the space formerly occupied by one, and they are bound with steel bands, or wires. (This process is called double dumping' ordumping'.) (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,67)

double eyes¶

n. spectacles; glasses. Compare four-eyes.

FOSTON `Where's my specks, mother?' Jacob's double eyes were soon brought. (1921,At The Front,144)

double fleece¶

1 n. (Rural) fleecewool that has been growing for two years.

HENDERSON Looking up he could see about twenty-three double fleece sheep pulling out through a saddle right up in the shingle. (1969,Open Country Calling,39)

double footed¶

adj.

WILSON They were scientific, too, these fences. ... six posts to the chain, six battens between each, strainers double footed and stayed; eight tightly strung wires, the top barbed. (1955,Land of My Children,177)

double G¶

n. (historical) a nickname given by political opponents to Sir George Grey, from joining his initials with an alleged penchant for double-dealing.

... the great landed estates have originated in Sir G. Grey's 5/- an acre regulations. ... The result ought to be a caution to working settlers against such friends as double G. (Dec 27, 1877,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/440) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

double garage¶

n.

The double garage has been accorded the status of temple. (Feb 15, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

double gate¶

n. [(farmers')]

Double gate: Two gates from the race in a sheepyard, which allow the sheep to be let into any ofthree pens, so that a mob can be drafted into three lots at once. Double gates were introduced into Canterbury about 1868. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

double happy¶

n. a large firecracker (and figuratively a large nuclear explosion) [(mainly children's) Pl. spg usu. double(-)happys. ca 1930s (DEH)]

It takes the double-happies-in-a-tin approach to guest selection... (Jul 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

Alistair.. would be riding down Victoria Avenue with Double-Happies strapped to him and being exploded on his BMX. (Dec 6, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

Wrapping a Double Happy in cotton wool we jammedit in the mouth of a full bottle of turps, lit the fuse and ran off to watch. (Oct 30, 2002,Dominion Post,5)

BURGLARS who took $2000 worth of fireworks from a Kilbirnie fruit shop left only one packet of double happys [sic] on the shelves. (Nov 1, 1984,Dominion,5)

It was quite good, but didn't compare with a Mighty Cannon in a tin can. It was round the store [in the ?1960s] we would have our first late October battle with lighted Tom Thumbs and Double Happys. (1985,G'day Country,62)

JONES Guy Fawkes night, double-happys exploded in her metal letter box. (1985,Gilmore's Dairy,9)

`I had a fair idea it was lightning. There was a roar like a double happy (fire cracker) going off inside a rubbish bin' (Feb 17, 1988,Press, The,9)

Does it mean that the protestors approve Communist Chinese doctrines, the thoughts of Mao - and the Nanking nuclear double-happy. (Jul 25, 1972,NZ Truth,2/1)

[Hdg] A night to make you double happy... This year's 15-minute fireworks hatbour spectacular explodes into life at 9pm on October [sic] 5... (Nov 4, 2004,Wellingtonian,4)

double long¶

n.

A "double long", or "doppio espresso" has two shots of coffee for a full cup. (Jan 22, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

double plugger¶

n.

What'll be next to your bed when you waken in the morning?.. Foot falcons or dubble [sic] pluggers. (Mar 15, 2004,Salient,No. 3/11)

double shearing¶

1 n. (Rural) the shearing of sheep twice in twelve months.

Double shearing was begun originally because of trouble with blackberry ... (Nov 7, 1963,NZ Farmer,11)

Ted Lawrence has tried double shearing in order to avoid the hay/wool clash, but found it wasn't worthwhile, as the lambs still had to be shorn in December. (Dec 10, 1964,NZ Dairy Exporter,59)

The difficulties of acquiring labour, due to high wages offering in mines and sawmills, make double shearing a problem for most farmers. (Jan 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture,29)

NEWTON With lambs and double-shearing 35,000 sheep were shorn last year ... (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,161)

NEWTON .. everything is double-shorn and including lambs over 30,00 sheep go over the board. [double-shearing] (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,186)

double unit house¶

n. [1957 Dec p.c. J.H. Robb Some suggestions on N.Z. usage [include]: DOUBLE UNIT HOUSE, a semi-detached house.]

TURNER ... state houses (owned and let by the government) are occasionally double-unit houses. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,172)

double up¶

1 adj. (Rural) a design of cowshed where two cows stand side-by-side to be milked.

Dairy farm - 20 A/S double up shed (40 cups.) (Oct 17, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,19)

double velvet fern¶

n. Leptopteris superba ?Prince of Wales feathers

POTTS (And) Leptopteris superba double velvet fern (1882,Out in the Open)

double(s) chart¶

n. a chart showing horses in the two races on which a doubles bet may be placed; to collect both the chosen horses must win [(bookmakers') also doubles card]

Currently, 'Erb is earning three feeds a day by passing a double-chart around the assembled barflies. (Jan 8, 1947,NZ Observer,16)

Among the material were two doubles cards at 2/- for GBP5. (Aug 24, 1939,Taranaki Herald,5)

BELTON In addition to [day cards] the bookmakers have `doubles charts'. (1939,Outside the Law,24)

Another printed double chart was foundwhich was obviously issued by a big scalebookmaker. (Aug 23, 1939,Taranaki Herald,4)

He had seen men, on race days.. consulting double charts on the footpath. (Aug 28, 1926,Press, The,8)

double-banded plover¶

n. = banded dotterel

Banded Dotterel Charadrius bicinctusJARDINE & SELBY, 1827 ... OTHER NAMES: Pohowera, tuturiwhatu, double-banded plover. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,180)

double-banger¶

n. something which is bi-partite; here, a lottery with two separate prizes to be won with the same ticket

Double-banger winner elusive [heading] Golden Kiwi lottery organisers may spend several thousands dollars searching for the winner of a [dollars]150,000 unclaimed prize in November's double banger Melbourne Cup sweepstake. (Apr 10, 1986,Evening Post,4)

n. a large cracker which allegedly makes twice the bang of the ordinary double happy. [(children's) ca1930 J. Winchester (Wellington) -->ca1940 Havelock children]

Once a "double-banger" was thrown throughan open window, and its explosion causeda commotion in the crowd. (Nov 6, 1928,Evening Post,10)

STEWART There would be the bonfire.. and double-bangers dancing as they double-banged. (1983,Springtime in Taranaki,78) [NOTES: 1991 edition]

2 n. a cracker

GRAY Giving you your bit is she, then? She'd be a double banger I bet. The quiet ones always are. ... Simon blushed ...She's all right,' he said gruffly. `She's a good joker.' (1987,Stepping Out,59)

double-bank¶

v. of horse-traction, to hitch on a second team in difficult or steep places. [to double (up), orig. (so AND) of rowers either in pairs or two to an oar.]]

WRIGHT There the teams double-banked when they tackled the hill - ... (1897,Station Ballads,44,1945 ed.) [NOTES: `At the Foot of the Old Dunstan Track']

v. carry a second person on horseback or bicycle

BEATTIE The doctor came to the north bank and left his horse, and he and [Jimmy] the Needle double-banked across. The Needle was washed off and the doctor rode to the hut. He must have been a bit on' to leave the other in the river. ... he was askedWhere's the Needle?' He replied `In Hell!' (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,178)

SCANLAN As children they had walked along it to school, before they had a pony, on which theydouble-banked'. <i>Ibid.</i> 52 They were ready and waiting when the three children returned from school, riding one behind the other on a fat Shetland pony. They still called itdouble-banking' though young Nicholas had been added to the load at the beginning of the year. (1948,Dusty Road,42,1949 ed.)

SCRYMGEOUR Ruefully he noticed a pal ... sitting on his well-groomed chestnut galloway. Reg,' called Jim,double bank me to the start, the blankey drag has gone'. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,178)

NEWTON ... and as the horse was too touchy to `double bank,' the shepherd had to leave the cook ... and head ... for another horse. (1952,High Country Journey,105)

double-bank vb. Austral. inf. to carry a second person on (a horse, bicycle, etc.). (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,333) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 224; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 144]]

HARTLEY My brother Jack made a scene when he discovered I was to double-bank on his horse. (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,85)

n.

SCANLON `I offered Mrs. Swift a double-bank [on a horse], and she wouldn't come,' Whitton whispered in Trix's ear ... (1948,Dusty Road,75,1949 ed.)

1 v. (Rural) to share a horse with another rider.

Some were on foot, some what is called 'double-banking.' (Jun 2, 1883,Weekly News,6)

Buggies in those days were almost unknown, and fully half the visitors arrived on horseback, many of the younger class 'double-banking.' (1910,Tapanui Station,26)

NEWTON And as the horse was too touchy to 'double-bank,' the shepherd had to leave the cook .. and head .. for another horse. (1952,High Country Journey,105)

HUTCHINSON An old grey mare was the first pre-school teacher and, as each boy graduated to more spirited pony, the next youngest had to double-bank behind the saddle. (1981,Hutchinsons of New Zealand, The,44)

RICHARDS He bought them a horse and told them to double-bank to school with the other riders. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,75)

2 v. carry a second person on (usu. the bar of) a bicycle; see also double, dub; double-dink [ca1920 W.H.B. Orsman (Havelock)]

SCANLAN As children they had walked along it to school, before they had a pony, on which they `double-banked'. (1934,Winds of Heaven,42)

Of course you soon learned to double-bank and take your girl-friend for a spin on a Saturdayafternoon. (Sep 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,90)

Of course you soon learned to double-bank and take your girl-friend for a spin on a Saturdayafternoon. (Sep 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,90)

3 v. In various transf. uses.a. To fight, two men against one.

And the growlers double-bank him/ In the way they alway [sic] fight. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,86)

PETERSON One of my earliest recollections is of watching [?c1890s-1900s] ... one 5th November, while the boys let off their crackers.. One double banger seemed a dud. (1981,Glasshouses,7)

3 v.

LANCASTER I have to inform you ... that I engaged myself to two gentlemen last night and I don't want either of them. ...' ...Two gentlemen. Double-banked. ...' (1938,Promenade,134)

double-banked¶

adj.

Two boys.. who were riding home fromschool "double-banked," collided with atelegraph pole; and one of them..sustained serious injuries to his head,which proved fatal. (May 3, 1917,Stratford Evening Post,3)

1 adv. (Rural) two to a horse.

JOHNSTONE-SMITH We were riding double-banked when we met a Maori. (1975,Battles, Buggies and Babies,69)

double-banking¶

n. = doubling [three, perhaps all four, of the citations below belong with the verb to double-bank (TD)]

May Taylor and another girl were "double-banking" down a hill on their way toschool. (Apr 11, 1917,Otago Witness,23)

[Hdg] Double-banking on motor cycles. (Apr 1, 1916,Evening Post,9)

I saw numbers of children on their way tothe public school... Some of them were onfoot, some what is called "double-banking" on their pony. (Jun 2, 1883,Auckland Weekly News,6)

PARK Times were harder still for many of their pupils, especially farmers' children from the backblocks, double-banking on a barebacked horse. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,29)

double-bar¶

v. double-bank [ca1939 Havelock schoolboys]

double-bottoming¶

n. the theoretical ability to strike two layers of paydirt, one below the other in a claim. [gold mining]

Unless new discoveries - for double-bottoming still appears to be a myth - of which no [46] hint has as yet been given, are made ... the approach of winter will find Gabriel's Gully deserted ... (Oct 16, 1861,NZ Goldfields,45,1976 ed.)

double-bunk¶

v. to sleep two to a (Maori) bunk in a tramping hut. [(trampers') Usu. as vbl n double-bunking]

Huts ... Double bunk if necessary to permit all to have a bed. (1984,Story of Nelson Lakes National Park, The,154)

double-bunking¶

n. [(trampers') ca1945 at least H. Gretton - Trampers' Song in VUW Songbook There'll be no more double-bunking ... for me.]

BAXTER JOHN (Sings) ... No more double-bunking double-bunking, double-bunking,/ No more double-bunking, double-bunking for me. (1982,Collected Plays,285) [NOTES: (Mr O'Dwyer's Dancing Party)]

double-decked¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of stock trucks and loading ramps] having upper and lower levels.

Double-decked cattle loading ramps and drafting areas have also been incorporated into this [saleyard] site to increase efficiency. (Nov 7, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,13)

double-decker¶

n. (Rural) a sheep with several years' growth of wool. (See hermit; double-fleecer)

We are all familiar with the 'double-decker' fleece. (Oct 11, 1951,NZ Farmer,7)

MASTERS The mob were started over [the ford] but the double-deckers, those with two years' wool, ran into bother ... (1960,Back-Country Tales,25)

n. (Rural) a shearing shed of two floors, usually with night pens beneath the shearing board.

NEWTON .. a double-decker capable of holding 2,000 woolly ewes and somewhat unusual in design, it is a striking building and a lovely shed. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,60)

NEWTON An eight-stand double-decker, it is a beauty and worth going to see. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,67)

n. (Rural) a stock truck with both upper and lower tray or deck, often carrying both cattle and sheep.

WATERS It [the truck] was a double-decker and divided into 16 pens, each pen to hold six fat lambs or five adult sheep. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,109)

WASWO The modern livestock truck will carry 600 fat or 750 early lambs. A double decker can accommodate 35 big oxen. (1996,Farming Progress in NZ 1814-1995,80)

This was the first truck in New Zealand to carry a double-decker sheep crate in about June 1922. (2000,Wool Grower,Autumn 28)

n.

Some of the double-deckers [sc. trams] run on the long routes... All the provision that is made for smokers on double-decker cars is needed. (Mar 30, 1912,NZ Free Lance,15)

These trams are all what we call double deckers, and it is the fashion in Christchurch for the ladies to ride on the top instead of inside, so that on a summer's day these vehicles present a very gay and flower-like appearance (Apr 24, 1890,Otago Witness)

The double-decker must go. (Mar 12, 1904,NZ Observer,2)

Whatever the Company may think of the recommendations to abolish the double-decker cars, the proposal is one that finds considerable sympathy with the travelling public. (Jan 16, 1904,NZ Observer,2)

Another treat was the ride on a double-decker tram to Island Bay. (Jun 2001,NZ Memories,No. 30/26)

2 n. double fleecer [(farmers')]

MASTERS The mob were started over, but the double deckers, [26] those with two years' wool, ran into bother on account of the weight of the wool, and started drifting downstream. (1960,Back-Country Tales,25)

LETHBRIDGE A hermit [sheep] must be distinguished from a `double-decker', which is simply a sheep that had missed the muster once and consequently had a double layer of wool. (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,95)

HENDERSON Up in the mountains, young Roy Mytton so proudly succeeded in rounding up twenty-odd old hermits, defiant woolly sheep also known as `double deckers', which had been wily enough to dodge last season's muster. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,80)

HENDERSON In the wool boom in 1951 an orchardist in Hamilton had five "double-decker" sheep in his orchard (they'd missed one shearing and had a double crop of wool)... Being double deckers each sheep clipped close to twenty pounds. (1967,Return to Open Country,163)

double-dumped¶

adj.

... the double-dumped scoured wool was given an extra passage through the willey. (1949,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,30/170)

double-ender¶

n. a double-ended dinghy, that is one with two `bows'. [ca1910 W.H.B. Orsman, Marlborough Sounds and elsewhere.]

double-fleece¶

adj.

DICK . We're shearing the double-fleece stragglers.' (1964,High Country Family,70)

TOMLINSON Most of the sheep went on, except about fifty wild and double-fleece sheep that were put in a scrubyard. (1968,Remembered Trails,58)

1 adj. (Rural) [of a sheep] carrying twice the usual amount of wool.

HALL Got some double-fleece rams off The Mistake. (Jul 7, 1868,Letter,243) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

MEEK If I don't get these sheep shorn they will all be double-fleece. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,22)

DICK We're shearing the double-fleece stragglers. (1964,High Country Family,70)

double-fleeced¶

adj.

After a number of years, when sheep were mustered in from the back ranges, it was noticed that several would die in the yards ..., for they would require to be kept in for drafting on the following day. These dead sheep would be mostly sheep which had missed a shearing, and were double-fleeced, having very long wool. (1895,TrNZI,27/278)

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] having have missed one or more shearings.

Looking out for double-fleeced sheep. (Nov 1869,Balfour Diaries,29)

Double-fleeced sheep were the chief sufferers, the bird [kea] getting hold on the longer wool. (Jan 1906,NZ Farmer,53)

double-fleecer¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep that has missed at least one shearing. (See double-decker)

GUTHRIE-SMITH We lived on wild pig, wild beef shot on Kaiwaka, and the fat wild sheep and double-fleecers that could be raked in from river cliffs ... (1921,Tutira,221) [NOTES: Tutira III (1999)]

MCLEOD If your dogs worked well, it was a good day, and if you came back with a glow of pride to tell how the little bitch caught a mob of "double-fleecers" down the back spur and fetched them right round onto the front face. (1960,Tall Tussock,45)

VANCE Waters snow-raked a mob of twenty double-fleecers out of the high basin of Separation Creek. (1965,High Endeavour,189)

MCLEOD If amongst them there are some "woollies" or "double-fleecers" which had escaped in previous musters the triumph is greater still. (1972,Alone in a Mountain World,5)

HALL Double fleecers are more tricky, as they are likely to have had some real practice in deliberately escaping the muster. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,86)

STACEY As we mustered the various blocks, all the double-fleecers had been kept and driven through the rivers. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,57)

KERR On the missing man's property 18 months later a musterer chased a double-fleecer under a rock that hung over a stream. (2000,High Times in the High Country,130)

double-gate¶

1 n. (Rural) a drafting race with two gates so that the sheep can be run into any one of three check-pens.

LOUGHNAN double-gate: referring to a drafting race having two gates so that the sheep can be run into any one of three check-pens. Very occasionally one may find a triple-gate race; and many saleyards boast, halfway along the race, a second pair of gates for another man. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,26)

double-headed Jack¶

n. (obsolete) a double-headed coin; aka double-header

HYDE ... Wallie Black ... was said to spin a penny or a double-headed Jack better than any other man in the N.Z.E.F. ... Ibid. 60 However, while he had his double-headed Jack the cupboard never went bare. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,59)

double-header¶

n.

A double-header is the term for catching two fish on different hooks at the same time. (Jun 2, 1949,Southern Cross (Wgton)) [NOTES: check year and page]

n.

WILSON `He began drinkin' double 'eaders. ... Then he goes on drinking these double 'eaders, but he don't get noisy, just ... glaring round the bar ...' (1957,Strip Jack Naked,111)

SLATTER `One for the road. But make mine a double. A double-header of rum.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,102)

BAXTER Peter passed the rum to Horse ...It's a double-header,' he said.One for the road.' (1985,Horse,25) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game) 25]

HARVEY Fancy watching grown-ups standing around drinking those things like double-headers and spots and hang-overs Dad was always talking about. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,37)

LEE Whisky!'Yes, double headers. A lemonade for Mr. Brindle.' (1965,Rhetoric at the Red Dawn,194)

RICHARDS Of particular interest ... was the fact that the boat had a liquor licence. ... Singles soon turned to double-headers' as we headed into the ... semi-darkness of the canyons. ... [The liquor] fired [the Maoris'] imagination ... Panic and fear is contagious - it was not long before several of the gang becamepannikin struck'. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,124)

n. a double-headed coin; see also double-headed jack, grey. [(gamblers') ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream.]

DEVANNY Sometimes two pennies are filed down to half their thickness and then joined together. A double-tailer is called a 'grey'; a double-header a 'nob. (1928,Dawn Beloved,163)

1 n. (Rural) a two-day muster.

LOUGHNAN double-header: a two-day muster. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,26)

double-hits¶

n. [(child marble players')]

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

double-picking¶

n.

Sometimes we'd lift our [crayfish] pots twice in the same day - double-picking we called it. (1998,On the Next Tide,91)

double-ridger¶

1 n. (Rural) a special cultivator used in soft or swampy areas.

.. with the introduction of double ridgers, this [ridging] is gradually being overcome ... (Dec 1904,NZ Farmer,945)

The seed (2lb of kale and half lb of turnip seed to the acre) and manure were planted through the double-ridger. (May 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,380)

double-shear¶

1 v. (Rural) to shear twice in twelve months. (See second-shear)

NEWTON Otui double-shore that year and Bob was there for practically the whole season. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,85)

NEWTON .. the practice has been to double-shear everything ... (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,156)

double-striper¶

n. type of large sack marked with two longitudinal stripes

HARGREAVES He would fill up about eight or ten massive wheat sacks we used to call 'double stripers' with crays and sew them along the top. He'd get 2/6 for a sack. That was back in the late 1920s through till about 1935. (1998,On the Next Tide,14)

double-tailer¶

n. (coin)

DEVANNY Sometimes two pennies are filed down to half their thickness and then joined together. A double-tailer is called a 'grey'; a double-header a 'nob. (1928,Dawn Beloved,163)

double-yolker¶

n. a stupid person, buffoon; cf egg. [(prisoners')]

NEWBOLD I was very annoyed and went around referring to Kapua as a weak mug and a double-yolker. Ibid. 248 DOUBLE-YOLKER. (n) Stupid person, buffoon. See also EGG. (1982,Big Huey, The,197)

n. an egg with two yolks

Better still if it turned up on the plate as a perfectly poached double-yolker. (May 2000,Cuisine,No. 80 : 7) [NOTES: Commonly heard in the 1930s]

1 n. (Rural) a ewe gravid with twins.

a ewe known to be carrying twin lambs - a double-yolker. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Dry humour runs thick through through this collection; for example .. double-yolker - a ewe carrying twins. (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion,C6)

doublebeak¶

n. needlefish, Scomberesox forsteri

MORELAND NEEDLEFISH [Scomberesox forsteri] ... Other names are ocean piper, skipper, saury, and doublebeak. (1967,Marine Fishes,16)

DOOGUE & MORELAND NEEDLEFISH ... Other names: Scomberesox forsteri; saury, skipper, double beak, ocean garfish, ocean piper. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,205)

WILSON (1981,Fisherman's Bible,44)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] doublebeak 975 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

doubled-up¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of a milking shed] having two sets of cups per pair of bails.

MCMEEKAN .. there are two lines of walk-through sheds, the single and the doubled-up. The single has one set of cups for each pair of bails, while the doubled-up has two sets of cups per pair. (1960,Grass to Milk,152)

The ideal number of sets of cups for each milker in a doubled-up herringbone is six. (Apr 11, 1968,NZ Farmer,23)

doubled-up shed¶

n.

Milking.. is carried on in a 20-bail doubled-up shed in which 2 men handle 9 sets of cups each. (Jan 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,11)

doubler¶

n. double n&sup5.. [(?obs.)]

MONEY Taking turn about at the duty of shouldering the stretchers, we reached the Wangangaro Redoubt early in the afternoon, and we were served out with a `doubler,' or two lots of grog in one. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,141)

n. an extra condenser for refining spirit; (cf Wilson's[??] biography). [(sly grog distillers')]

OGILVIE For good measure the distillate would be put through a doubler' for further refinement and strengthening. At this stage a copperworm' was used to lead the vapour to its condensation point. (1971,Moonshine County,110)

doubling¶

n. two people riding the same bicycle, one seated on the handlebars or crossbar [1999 citation belongs with verb to double]

Doubling is fun and we ride two and three abreast. (Dec 1996,North & South,47)

STEAD He remembers 'doubling' her on his bike down to Bridge Avenue for a swim, her black hair in his mouth, (1999,Talking about O'Dwyer,54)

FOOTE They tried doubling. As anyone who has experienced it will know, doubling for any distance is mighty hard on the posterior of the one on the bar. (2000,Bread and Water,26)

doubtful¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of stock ] with quality that can not be guaranteed.

All cows and heifers near profit caused keen competition, whilst backward and doubtful calves were hard to quit. (Aug 7, 1900,Hawera Star,3)

dough roaster¶

1 n. (Rural) a cook on a station or farm.

STACEY The packmen left and were replaced by 'no-hoper dough roasters' which did little to alleviate the problem so they were replaced ... (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,78)

PETER dough-roaster: cook. (2000,Peter Glossary,4)

station cook: dough-roaster [dough-roaster] (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

doughboy¶

n. a plain flour and water mixture, occas. with suet or sugar added, boiled, steamed or fried.

SCOTT Ned Ryan and Pat McPhee.. Sat down to Christmas dinner of pork, doughboys and billy-made tea. (1900,Tales of the Colonial Turf,230)

In it there are pork bones and watercress, doughboys and potatoes - a treat for the bros who will pay $7 each to eat it with a plastic fork off a polystyrene plate. (Sep 12, 1998,Dominion,15)

Spread an old newspaper on the floor andon it place a steaming pot of puha,kamo-kamo, riwai, brisket-on-the-bone anddumplings what we call: doughboys. (Sep 7, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

The title Doughboy comes from thetraditional Maori boiler, a pot of puha,pork bones, potatoes and a lump of wetdough, broken into little round balls,thrown in. These little dumplings arecalled doughboys (Mutumutu), and by somecruel of happy fate, depending on how youlook at it, this has become one Maorislang name for gays. (Jan 24, 1996,Capital Times,6)

Dough boys, "sinkers," or "water boys" are prepared in exactly the same manner as damper, except that the dough need not be so stiff. (1905,'Ukneadit' Tried Recipes,105)

TUWHARE She would make doughboys to go with the kamo-kamo. (1972,Sapwood & Milk,15)

HUNT Doughboys, that's what they're called, but we called them buggers afloat. (1981,Speaking a Silence,89)

"Maori language has been my bread and butter - or my boil up and dough boys - for the last four or five years," he says. (Jul 14, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F7)

Nor do you get much more Victorian (or rather Elizabethan) than the miti-miti or dough-boy dumpling which comes with the Paua Bar's boil-up, along with the usual meaty pork bones, some nicely cooked kumara and potato, a little of the cooking juices, and puha - or in this case watercress, lightly boiled in deference to modern tastes. (Aug 10, 2000,Evening Post,21)

BURNETT As for myself after a glorious feast last night of potatoes, bacon, doughboys, and sweetenedcoffee, as I sat up in my sleeping-bag, ... (Mar 1860,Diary) [NOTES: 1860 March Burnett Diary in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 87]

WALKER Fortunately we had brought a bucket ..., so we could make doughboys and cook some bacon on our knives. (Jan 4, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker))

MILLER Sometimes the flour is made into dough-boys - that is, the flour is made into dough and then rolled into balls about the size of your fist. (Jan 22, 1869,Journal) [NOTES: 1869 Jan 22 Miller Captain Robert Strang (1964) 8]

MONEY We had a billy of `skilligolee' to warm us up while the ... dough-boys ... were being got under weigh. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,29)

ELWELL ... the black cook always had a good supply of meat and `dough-boys' (1878,Boy Colonists,52)

Fried chops and `dough boys', the latter being simply flour mixed with water, and fried ... (1888,Rock Colonists,7)

HARPER .. we could only afford two small `dough-boys' - or suet dumplings - for each meal (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,139)

One might have scraped gum and cooked `doughboys' among less interesting surroundings than those of the diggers' camp. (Mar 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,IX/429)

KENWAY flapjack and a doughboy (dumpling) ... (1928,Pioneering in Poverty Bay,7)

Doughboy: A dumpling made of flour, sugar and suet, boiled. It was a favourite dish out mustering. (C.) (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

EVANS They bought rice and a little flour to make doughboys ... (1962,Waikaka Saga,30)

I was always eating ... And I loved doughboys, which are small balls of flour, usually eaten with puwha. ... (1977,Listener Short Stories,86) [NOTES: 1970 Ihimaera in 1977 NZ Listener Short Stories 86]

TUWHARE my favourite niece said she would make/ dough-boys to go with the kamo-kamo, the meat/ and the puha ... [sic] (1972,Sapwood & Milk,15)

dumplings containing raisins, cooked in camp oven. see Buggers Afloat (Jan 17, 1980,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1980 Jan 17 2YA Christine Hunt Stones From Takaka 12:45]

Then, I'd roll out my threadbare Whaariki/ - to help you remember to take your boots/ off - spread an old newspaper on the floor/ and on it place a steaming pot of puha,/ kamo-kamo, riwai, brisket-on-the-bone and/ dumplings what we call: doughboys. (Sep 7, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12) [NOTES: (Hone Tuwhare)]

McGILL doughboy dumpling of flour, sugar and suet, a favourite when out mustering; in America it is flour and rice-based. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

All excess members of the poultry yard were were eaten, ... or the older ones converted into a midweek stew with ... perhaps herb flavoured `dough boys' on top. (Oct 1988,North & South,44)

GEE We ... run home through the twilit streets into the kitchen - doughboy and stew. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,83)

PICKERING Doughboys are dumpling-like globules of flour and baking powder, milk and water, dropped into stews and cooked. Neither damper nor doughboys feature greatly on modern menus. (1988,Hills, The,73)

Like many Maori, the Tamiheres called these flour and suet dumplings "doughboys". Another Irish culinary inheritance, the doughboys were used to supplement the meat and vegetables and make the food go further. (Jun 21, 2003,Dominion Post,F6)

doughnut¶

n. spinning move in a (boy racer's) vehicle

[Hdg] "Doughnut' driver disqualified. A young man whose car hit a girl while he was doing a "doughnut" has been heavily fined and banned from driving. (Aug 12, 1998,Dominion,8)

A teenager was seen yahooing, doing doughnuts and fishtailing the jetski he was riding minutes before he hit and killed a 16-year-old girl in a kayak. (Jun 9, 1998,Evening Post,5)

He began doing donuts (tight circles). He was just being a hoon... [He] revved up again for more donuts, this time in the shallows. (Nov 4, 1997,Dominion,7)

As [the car] moves slowly through a series of screeching circles the acrid odour of burning rubber fills the air. In drag-racing parlance this is a "donut" and judging from the hoots of the spectators it is a good one. (Nov 30, 1997,Sunday Star Times,C3)

McGILL doughnut round-patterned wheelies done in car or on motorbike. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,27)

Showmanship and artistic merit come into it; these guys consider donuts - spinning round in a tight circle - to be an art form. (Oct 31, 2000,Dominion,7)

doughnut economy¶

n.

It can be seen..from the country's newspapers running regular soul-searching articles on the cure for the "doughnut economy"... "The idea that there is a doughnut effect in the economy, that something is missing: that sort of question is abroad fairly fundamentally." (Sep 27, 1998,Sunday Star Times,C1)

doughnutting¶

n. see citation

There was also the blatant "doughnutting" by National backbenchers, notably Wayne Mapp: the phenomenon whereby unknown MPs flock to sit in the seats around well-known ones who are speaking on an important bill, in the hopes of getting themselves on telly. (Dec 12, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

doughy¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of cocksfoot grass seed] with a quality indicating ripeness.

COULSON If it [the cocksfoot grass seed] appeared doughy, it was ready for cutting. (1979,Golden Harvest,35)

Douglas fir¶

n. the timber from the Douglas fir grown locally; in North America usu. called Oregon (pine); also called Oregon pine.

Douglas score¶

1 n. (Rural) a score awarded to deer antlers, using the Douglas scoring system.

ADDENBROOKE It was a nice even twelve, Douglas Score 295. (1992,Home from the Hill,158)

HOLDEN Antlers that added up to 329 3/4 points on the famed Douglas Score system. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,181)

dourigan¶

n.

DAVIN When Martin came back from seeing her off, the family were all sitting round the fire. She was a nice little dourigan, I thought,' his father said. ...But what on earth is a dourigan?' Joe asked. ... `It's the word we used back home for a little potato,' his father said; but his father's smile was only teasing and there were much worse words in his Irish vocabulary. (1970,Not Here, Not Now,134)

dove petrel¶

n. (See also dove prion)

The sea bird known as the prion turtur or dove petrel, was found yesterday in a paddock at Opin, beyond Kennedy's. (Jul 3, 1883,Wanganui Herald,3)

This is the beak of the broad-billed dove petrel (Prion vittatus), one of the three species of whale birds. (Mar 17, 1909,Otago Witness,86)

He appends the following list of birds to be found on the Little Barrier in support of his statement .. dove-petrel, blue penguin. (Nov 16, 1892,Colonist (Nelson),3)

Perhaps the most memorable sight on Stephens Island was the dove petrels. (1969,Open Country Calling,166)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Prion turtur - Dove Petrel - Titi Wainui. (1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,201)

WILLIAMS Pekeha ... Pachyptila vittata, dove prion, a species of petrel. Totorore, ... 2. Pachyptila desolata Antarctic prion (dove prion). ibid. 497 Whiroia, ...Pachyptila desolata, dove prion (dove petrel or whale-bird). = totorore. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,276)

A dove petrel.. was found at Taihape last week... The whale birds, as they are known by sailors, are always very thin and emaciated when blown ashore. (Aug 1, 1918,Wanganui Chronicle,4)

PRION TURTUR, Sol. - Dove Petrel. (1886,TrNZI,18/128) [NOTES: (Hamilton)]

BULLER PRION TURTUR. (DOVE PETREL.) ... Native name{s}.- Whiroia [cf Williams 407 Whiroia ... Pachyptla desolata, dove prion (dove petrel or whale-bird). = totorore.] {and Totorore}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,309,1888 2nd edn 2/209 ed.)

Dove petrels are not the only residents of the island. (Mar 23, 1938,Auckland Provincial Gazette,42)

It is the broad-billed dove petrel Prion vittatus, common round our coasts, but breeding in the Chatham Islands. (Jan 6, 1909,Otago Witness,85)

dove prion¶

n. (See also dove petrel)

WILLIAMS Pekeha[a] ... Pachyptila vittata, dove prion, a species of petrel. Ibid. 497 Whiroia, ...Pachyptila desolata, dove prion (dove petrel or whale-bird). = totorore. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,276)

dove's foot¶

n. an introduced geranium-weed [from the shape of the leaf]; soft geranium, soft crane's bill, wild geranium, also called crane's bill, wild geranium.

HILGENDORF -->1926 [1967] Hilgendorf [and Calder] Weeds 113DOVESFOOT (Geranium molle), or soft geranium or wild geranium or soft cranes bill, is common in all soils and situations, and has been considered a native. It is a diffuse much-branched annual or perennial, softly hairy in all it parts. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,113,1967 ed.)

dove's foot [s] Geranium molle L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,22)

TAYLOR dove's foot [s] Geranium molle L. (1980,Weeds of Crops,40)

dover¶

n. a knife; (pl.) eating tools; often in the run of the dover(s) as much food as one can eat'all necessary food'; cf musterers the run of the dover; ? connected with Dover stove in high country tramping or mustering huts; ? =necessary food. -->cf Pascoe Land Uplifted High 100 - [(obs., farming)]

Dover: [1898 Morris Austral-English] gives the meaning as a clasp knife. George McMillan, who came out in 1858, told me that when he arrived it was the custom for hands to find theirown knife, fork, spoon, plate, and pannikin, which were all called dovers. A man would offer work for `a pound a week and the run of my dovers'. The expression died out in Canterbury before 1860. (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

BEATTIE Once, in lamenting inevitable changes, a runholder exclaimed, I wish I were back in a maimai with a plate of bark and a dover!' The saying then [ca1870] in engaging a hand wasso much a week and the run of the dover.' The dover was a Dover knife, and the `run of the dover' was as as much food as one could eat. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,10)

He said I tell you what, Johnson, these big houses are a curse instead of a blessing. I wish I was back in amaimai' with a plate of bark and a dover!' The saying then in regard to wages was So much the week and the run of the dover.' (Thedover' was a DoverKnife and the `run of the dover' was as much food as you liked to eat) (1989,Pioneer Recollections,1/93) [NOTES: -->19?? Beattie Pioneer Recollections 1/93 (Griffiths Collection)]

KERSE This big house' [built of slabs in 1860] ... was very draughty and McNab at a time when he was suffering from a bronchial ailment, was heard to remark ...,I tell you what, Johnson, these big houses are a curse. I wish I were back in the maimai with a plate of bark and a run of the dover'. (1984,Knapdale Run, The,18) [NOTES: [a1890 in] 1984 Knapdale Run 18 [Alexander McNab: had Australian experience]]

dover n. a clasp knife. [fr. Dover, the name of the maker] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

dover: An old brand of hand shears, and soon used as another name for the shears themselves, hence such terms as `the run of your dover' and flashing your dover'. [This needs checking. He may have go this from Wilkes.] (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/23)

1 n. (Rural) an eating utensil.

MCNAB I tell you Johnston, these big houses are a curse. I wish I were back in a maimai, with a plate of bark and a Dover. (1858,BLANK ENTRY,5) [NOTES: in Wilson & Fraser (1936) Book of the Pioneers]

LOUGHNAN dovers: eating utensils. According to Acland (Early Canterbury Runs) it was customary in the very early years for the employees to supply their own, but the practice, and with it the expression, died out about 1860. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,27)

Dover stove¶

n.

The stove was going good, that old cast-iron Dover there that was secondhand when I got it.. ages ago. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,127)

PASCOE We snuggled into the hut on Goat Pass and built up the scrub fire in a Dover stoveto warm our bones and sleeping bags. (1952,Land Uplifted High,150)

HUNT My pay as a cadet was so small ... [that] I induced the management to provide me with a `bach' fitted up with a Dover stove for cooking and warmth. (1951,Confessions,56)

dovie¶

n. [mining]

At times, some defect in the tunnelling leads to the reappearance of a "dovie". (Mar 23, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,42)

Down¶

n. a Southdown (sheep). [(farming)]

STUDHOLME My experience of the Downs is that they are best suited for dry country. (1940,Te Waimate,97)

down¶

n. have (get) a down on, to have a set on; grudge against; be prejudiced against; (See also derry)

But if someone has a 'down' on the rich as well as people of a different colour or culture, then I guess that is adding fuel to the fire. (Oct 26, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

THATCHER Go on in the old fashion,/ And ne'er improve the town;/ And still on all new comers/ Keep up a fearful `down;' (1862,Dunedin Songster,No.1/2) [NOTES: The Old Identity]

THATCHER I've got no `down' on Travers,/ For he's a clever chap; 'Twas but in self-defence I/ Gave him a gentle rap; (1862,Canterbury Songster,10)

BRADSHAW Sun and wear have had too much of a `down' on that suit for much colour to survive (1883,New Zealand As It Is,3)

He has a decided `down' on Trade Unionism. (Nov 10, 1890,Evening Post,2)

The lad stated that Taubman had ordered him to stand there till the night-watchman came, because Taubman `had a down on him.' (Sep 22, 1906,NZ Truth,66/6/1)

SATUDHOLME My father had a great down on light-coloured beasts. (1940,Te Waimate,118)

down n. from adv. prejudice against, hostility to; have a down on, be prejudiced against. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

McGILL down, in phr. have a down on a grudge, hostile or at least poor opinion of someone; in 1862 Charles Thatcher said he had `no down on Travers'. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

adv. indicating direction of travel or locality reached, in relation to a starting point.

WILLIAMS In the afternoon assembled the committee; when it was determined the Herald should return to the Colony for stores, as none had come down exceptg. flour ... (Mar 16, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,45,1961 ed.)

WAKEFIELD I brought down from Sydney [to Nelson] thorough bred Merino rams ... (Oct 22, 1847,Handbook for New Zealand, The,249)

adv. go/get down sc. from NZ to Chathams (cf Aust to NZ : go down : bring up) ?old whalers' usage ?=go west.

LANGDALE-HUNT One thing that was rather bad in my early years down there was the fact that there was no branch of the Post Office Savings Bank attached to the Post Office. (1985,Last Entail Male,148)

Still in Ch.Ch. looking for a ship. Mrs Briscoe of the Islands is here and very anxious to get down. The Cleopatra is the one expected to go down but she is bar bound in the Grey and may stay so for a month. (Aug 1, 1876,Chudleigh Diary,250)

adv.

FITTON .. there are the drays ... for carrying down the wool after the shearing season, to the ports for shipment. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),220)

v. to pinch, steal; to appropriate [1940 at least: cits needed.]

2 adv.

John & Seal out shooting down the River and to old Whare swamp, killed a couple of swamp hens - (Jan 24, 1857,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,66)

DAVIN Had a bit of a run-in with a pongo MP down the Berka last night. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,209)

BALLANTYNE Where you been all this time?' his mother asked.Down the library,' he said. ... `I bet he's been tarting,' Joy said. (1948,Cunninghams, The,32,1976 ed.)

SLATTER ... who led raids on the apple orchards down the South Belt. Ibid. 140 Down the back the lunkos [sc the hoons, a crudely behaved pair] were playing a crooner complaining to listeners [141] that somebody was `breaking my heart in two', a sentiment I suspected was wasted on them. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,10)

McGILL I was down Whangarei port loading fertiliser. Dust everywhere. Ibid. 159 Young womendown the back of the bus were [160] talking about guys putting the hard word on them. (1985,G'day Country,35)

HUNT Or when we were playing around having a fight down the back, someone would say, `Go away, nigger.' ... Then there'd be a fight. Same thing when the towneyites - thekids from up Kaikoura - came down here. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,98) [NOTES: (Marama, Kaikoura)]

Suppose a friend says to me, `You know that drongo who was on the chain with me at the works last summer? Just a little joker he was, remember? A real serious ankle-biter. Hailed from somewhere down the Wire Wrapper. (Jan 1989,Pacific Way,10) [NOTES: (Sharp New Zildish)]

2 adv.

Down the Sounds. [title] (1922,Journal of Katherine Mansfield,304) [NOTES: (1954 Murry)]

MANSFIELD If we are ever together down the Pelorus Sounds come off with me for a whole day - Will you? -and let's just remember. (1922,Journal of Katherine Mansfield) [NOTES: 1922 in 1954 Journal pp. 309-311 in 1974 Gordon Undiscovered Country 240; also quoting 1928 Letters II, 143]

down country¶

n. (Rural) rural area close to town.

Down country, used (chiefly by people in the hills) to describe the localities near town or on the plains. (Sep 30, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

n. (Rural) an area to the south.

Down country they have had a quite disastrous lambing. (Nov 13, 1975,NZ Farmer,51)

1 adv. (Rural) in the direction of town, from the high country or back blocks.

BATHGATE A dozen or more horses with their pack-saddles empty .. were returning down country. (1874,Colonial Experiences,135)

The wool clip is now being sent down country (says the Dunstan 'Times.') (Feb 1906,NZ Farmer,138)

JONES At first we only had young cattle which we bought down country ... (1933,Autobiography of an Early Settler,41)

NEWTON Kennedy, whom rumour had it was courting, had gone down country 'on business' for a week ... (1949,High Country Days,86)

VANCE The fast transport which we take for granted today makes us forget that in earlier times, the station hand who wanted to go to another station, or down-country, had to 'swag it.' (1965,High Endeavour,67)

PORTER We left spick and span, for the run down country. (1970,Under the Nor'West Arch,39)

1 n. (Rural) the area farmed in the plains and foothills of the South Island mountain ranges.

MCLEOD It happened that Barney had a pup which he had bred himself, and had got someone 'down country' to rear it for him. (1960,Tall Tussock,46)
