LOUGHNAN down country: perhaps the term only really belongs to the South Island, where it means the plains, and the foothills or front country. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,28)

down cow¶

n. [Used also USA] (See downer,downer cow)

When is a down cow not a down cow? (Aug 22, 2005,NZ Farmers' Weekly,3)

Your staff member was late starting, you have had two down cows, one looking terminal, and the somatic cell count already looks dodgy. (May 30, 2005,NZ Farmers' Weekly,5)

down horn¶

1 n. (Rural) a downward-turning horn of cattle.

LOST: A bullock .. he is not branded, has down horns, and a ring in his nose. (Jul 29, 1857,Lyttelton Times,1)

down horns¶

n.

LOST. A Bullock, ... he is not branded, has down horns, and a ring in his nose. (Jul 29, 1857,Lyttelton Times,1)

down south¶

2 adv. (in) the trouser pocket(s).

'Enessy sticks 'is lighted bumper down south into 'is overcoat pocket. (1916,Anzac Book, The,47) [NOTES: [?Aust. in AND]]

He dreamt he'd got his fourteen peg' / And buttoned itDown South'. 3. snow(ing) down south [W3], see snow 2. (May 16, 1917,NZEF Chronicles,137)

down South¶

adv. in modern usage applied to any place considerably to the south of the speaker, esp. the south of the South Island. Contrast up North.

LADY BARKER A Journey `Down South' [sc. from Canterbury, to Otago.] [heading] (May 1867,Station Life in NZ,137,1874 ed.)

.. particularly in that money-making go-ahead province Otago. Surely it may be accepted as a strong argument ... that such sharp business men as those `down South', have readily seen ... the advantages to be gained by the half-holiday. (May 21, 1872,Evening Post) [NOTES: 1872 May 21 Evening Post in 1963 Oct 3 Evening Post 16]

BEATON GINNY: When I was a kid. Down South. (1984,Outside In,106) [NOTES: [the S.I.]]

LADY BARKER All the first class pasture land `down South' as [Otago] was called had been taken up long before. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,93) [NOTES: (Canterbury, to Otago)]

G M WILSON Our first visit [at Wellington] was to a chemist and also to an artist where we saw some views he had taken of the lakes, we had seen down south, and there were two of Manapori, ... (Feb 1873,Diary,176) [NOTES: 1873 Feb G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 176]

TROLLOPE A railway for you gentlemen down South!' [sc. South Island] says a northern member.Certainly, - but on condition that we have one here, up North.' (1874,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

... he [a Wellington man] had married this woman down South [sc. Canterbury-Otago] (Apr 17, 1880,Evening Post,2)

LUSH Very cold this morning, Mahon.'Very Sir: there's been a heavy fall of snow somewhere down-south.' (May 22, 1881,Waikato Journals,175,1982 ed.) [NOTES: [?lower N.I.]]

BRADSHAW The rush recently has been down South [to Otago]. (1883,New Zealand As It Is,340)

Fought the grim fight with Otago, .../ Last year's doings down South ... (1888,College Rhymes,15,1923 ed.) [NOTES: [sc OTAGO]]

PASCOE Oh! yes, down south [sc. on the west coast, SI], they have all drifted into Maori habitsplenty more days tomollow' etc. ...' (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,54) [NOTES: [about Douglas's lethargy]c1894 Roberts to Harper in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 54]

HARPER On one occasion he was `down South', below Gillespies [Beach], and, with five others, was trying to shoot a check-shirt bird close to the hut of another digger, ... (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,147) [NOTES: [ref. point central W Coast]]

BELL ... I remember now he was blamed for firing the tussocks ... on Grassdale run, down south, one night when there was a big Nor'wester blowing. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,18) [NOTES: [in the South Island]]

SATCHELL What part of the country do you come from?'Down South' `Taranaki or Hawkes Bay way?' (1902,Land of the Lost,18) [NOTES: [A Northland man speaks]]

Down South [in South Island], now that the dentists have given up advertising ... (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/6/?)

Down South he is carrying on his pranks. (Oct 21, 1905,NZ Truth,18/1/8) [NOTES: (in SI)]

Insurance agents among the wild and whiskerous `backbone' down south have lively experiences, sure pop. (Jul 14, 1906,NZ Truth,56/1/7) [NOTES: [S.I.]]

Hon. Tam. Mackenzie surely cannot be to a sure of his Taieri seat down south, and constituencies have a habit of biffing out turn-coats, because numerous countrynewspapers are hinting at Tam's desertion of his old love. (Sep 3, 1910,NZ Truth,271/1/8) [NOTES: [Southland or Otago]]

MANDER Already he saw the cream factories which men down south were dreaming as part of every township. (1925,Allen Adair,48,1971 ed.)

HYDE The `Count' [Potocki de Montalk] used to conduct a milk-round down South in New Zealand. (1934,Journalese,46)

HYDE Down south five Invercargill schools ... proudly ... claimed him as an ex-pupil. (1936,Passport to Hell,180)

BALLANTYNE `Reminds me of the time down south when I was watchman at a brewery,' Simmons said. (1948,Cunninghams, The,21,1976 ed.)

HISLOP I happened to meet a very old South otago friend there [in Christchurch]. ... She said `... you know there are no friends like the old ones down South.' (1943,Pure Gold,89)

FRAME Once she went for a holiday down South [from Canterbury to Otago] where snowberries and penny oranges grow on the hills. (1951,Lagoon, The,12,1961 ed.) [NOTES: (The Secret)]

STRONACH Down south, where Bill and Nobby come from, you can ride along a ledge and throw your cigarette butt into a lake thousands of feet below. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,21)

CRUMP Sam got the cowman-gardener's beardie to train for him `like we handle 'en down South.' (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,74)

WILSON He came from down south somewhere. (1965,Outcasts,19)

n. the south of the SI [also attrib.]

NEWTON Lofty, in happy mood, and unfailing in his praise of his native province [Southland], delighted young Wallace with tall stories of `down South.' (1949,High Country Days,69)

Bush whisky makes the boozer think the world is upside down. After three glasses of a brand retailed by a down South publican ... (Apr 7, 1906,NZ Truth,42/1/3)

down the chute¶

phr.

GEE Then, advancing through it, almost subaural, a chatter.. our lives together. It grew into a roar. It rattled down a chute and fell from hearing, and I was empty and must start again. (1992,Going West,219)

If I go west, a lot of jobs would go downthe chute. (May 30, 1993,Sunday Times (NZ),32)

down the dunny¶

phr.

Save them, but for heaven's sake, don't not spend them or the economy'll be down the dunny. (Jul 1, 1998,Dominion,1)

Raised in rural Palmerston North, Walton didn't think too much about faith until his late teens, when his life seemed to be going down the dunny. (Dec 26, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

The fact that a few hundred thousand dollars of public funds have been flushed down the dunny in the meantime might be forgiven if we could be reassured that the arrogance and cynicism behind the editorial judgments on McCormick Rips will not be repeated. (Jul 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Malcolm Walker was The Examinercartoonist before it went down the dunny. (Feb 1993,Metro,12)

down the gurgler¶

phr. washed away, beaten, ruined [OED online: A person or thing that gurgles; spec. in Austral. slang, a plughole, drain; freq. in fig. phrases down the gurgler, etc. (cf. DRAIN n. 1 e).]

Indeed, a slight hiccup in [his] career proves that an unblemished expert on business collapses can inadvertently find himself going down the financial gurgler. (Jan 14, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

[Westbrook Haines a NZ kiwifruit salesperson] Haines had previously worked for the New Zealand Dairy Board where he says he watched the Australian dairy industry go `down the gurgler' while the New Zealand industry went ahead in leaps and bounds because of its marketing skills. (Jun 3, 1986,Bulletin, The (Sydney),32)

(Scott cartoon caption) This country is really going down the gurgler, mate. Even the sheep are emigrating. (Jul 7, 1988,Evening Post,6)

Pessimists ... interpret the polls to mean that the Government is politically down the gurgler. (Nov 13, 1988,Sunday Star (Auckland),A15)

McGILL gurgler plughole, often phr. down the gurgler ruined or lost; eg `There goes another bright idea down the gurgler.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,53)

Employment Minister Annette King opened Parliament's general debate with the accusation that National would be deservedly `down the gurgler' because of its sexist attitude to women. (Aug 17, 1989,Dominion,2)

As far as I can see the country is just going to go down the gurgler because all the kids are using foul language now. (Aug 3, 2002,Dominion,A25)

MARRINER Doing things my way, plead guilty to just the reefer, and I'll personally see all the violence charges go down the self-defence gurgler. (2001,Stonedogs,330)

[Hdg] Plug pulled on trans-Tasman meet as $67,000 goes down the gurgler. (Dec 23, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B6)

We'd had a wonderful marriage for 50 years and it was going down the gurgler. (Nov 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

...it would be nothing like the stoush that would result if we allowed the marine education centre to go down the gurgler. (Feb 12, 2004,Dominion Post,A6)

I flew over and found a place called Cranks that was going down the gurgler. (Nov 2005,North & South,90)

McGill Or was Peat going to win and life as he loved and cherished it go right down the damned gurgler? (1995,Gold in the Creek,29)

TAYLOR The high standards set for thisnewspaper.. have gone down the gurglerand the tubes double quick. (1992,Fast Times at Greenhill High,72)

The only organisation he was in favour of backing was surf lifesaving. "Where does it end?" he asked. Where indeed? Down the gurgler because of the insularity of one small council out in the wop-wops, it seems. (May 31, 2006,NZ Herald,A2)

19-- TV1 commentator at the end of the second Aust-NZ one-day match, which NZ won `Australia is down the googler again and we are two up in the series.' HNZD2 DOWN THE GURGLER: 1. =wastepipe of sink [check] (2006,Dominion Post) [NOTES: 2006: not date of citation; date of entry.]

2 phr. of, esp. beer, down the throat. [Occas. pron @/googler/]

down the tarmac¶

phr. (Rural) on the plains [a hill country term].

LOUGHNAN down the tarmac: down the mudflats (ie the Plains); the opposite of up the burnt spur or up the gully. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,28)

LOUGHNAN Gully, up the: Opposite to down the tarmac. But it also suggests a propensity for avoiding visits to the towns, cities etc. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,37)

down the track¶

phr. in the future

[Employers' advocate] We're down the track on that one [negotiated settlement]. (Nov 23, 1987,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Morning Report National Radio]

[Political union] is something our successors down the track - a long way down the track - may want to look at. (Nov 22, 1987,TV1) [NOTES: 1987 Nov 22 Lange and Hawke on TV]

David Geary 'You see,' said the Mayor...'what you don't realise is we're not just thinking about tomorrow. We're thinking twenty-five years down the track.' (2008,Six Pack 3, The,126)

phr. finished; go down the track: to be sacked.

THOMSON We usually find that a poor worker makes a poor mate; and if we find any that don't pull their weight on the open range, there is no enthusiasm about being mates with them. Usually theyare not long in going down the track. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,21)

ANDERSON `The cook's in bed, and when he recovers he'll be going down the track. Can you cope?' (1981,Both Sides of the River,109)

[During a round-table discussion on farming a stock and station agent says] In five years' time ... if these conditions continue I put it to you farming will be down the track. (Mar 23, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio)

down time¶

1 n. (Rural) [mustering and other rural seasonal work] a period when there is no work.

KERR Mustering work is on-again off-again, so I, like a lot of contemporaries, would live by the gun in down times, like the off-season when I was at Nokomai. There was six weeks of down time around February at Glenaray, just as there was at Nokomai. (2000,High Times in the High Country,35)

Agworkers: Daggers/crutchers - good money with regular work. Can supply down-time work as well. [down-time] (Apr 13, 2002,Dominion,33)

Down Under¶

n. [(?whalers')]

HOLMES The time of migration of sperm whales around Chatham waters' (Down Under' as it was called by the whalers) was November to April each year. (1984,Chatham Islands,20)

n. Australia and New Zealand; now used of NZ (with Australia) by other than New Zealanders though pre-WW1 usage suggests a local acceptance. [also adjective]

Indeed, down under is first recorded as a noun here rather than in Australia (in 1905, ten years before the first Australian use, according to the Australian National Dictionary (AND). (Aug 2000,NZWords,4 : 1)

The young man from "down under" headed later for Detroit. (Jul 18, 1928,NZ Free Lance,9)

What started as a four-week jaunt downunder has become a full-on battle for bragging rights at Mount Maunganui over the next three days as German world champions Jonas Reckermann and Julius Brink take on the New Zealand Open. (Jan 20, 2011,Bay of Plenty Times,A16)

ANZAC Anyway, the men from Down Under were real glad to see them. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,72)

LEE In those days Antipodes meant more than `down under.' The term imaginatively suggested the edge of the world. (1934,Children of the Poor,10,1949 ed.)

SIMPSON [A US writer] The little Dominion of New Zealand is the more or less happy land popularly known as Down Under.' ... It is doubtful whether the origin of the termDown Under' will ever be known. It first came into general use during the World War of 1914-18, when the New Zealanders who fought in the ill-starred Gallipoli campaign were referred to as the men from Down Under', but that was not the start of it. This faraway land, it seems, was known asDown Under' in some parts of England and Scotland before the birth of the present century. The first World War merely [put] the expression into wider usage. An Auckland artist, Mr Trevor Lloyd,made it the subject of one of his cartoons at the very beginning of that great upheaval, and at least one English war correspondent used the term when writing on Gallipoli. After the year 1918 the expression fell into disuse, but during the second World War it again became popular, and I think we must thank the Americans for its revival. ... In England it is also known as the Antipodes. (1945,If You'd Care to Know,7)

SHERWOOD He also uses expressions like down under', which implies implies that there's something wrong with the Southern Hemisphere, andAustralasia', which implies a close connection between New Zealand and her bullying barbaric neighbour, ... (1985,Botanist at Bay,18)

down under inf. Australia and New Zealand (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,145) [NOTES: [Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 336; NZPOD 225]]

McGILL Down Under New Zealand and Australia, as perceived from the Northern Hemisphere. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

`Down Under' boys on Furlough. (1916,NZEF Chronicles,199)

ANZAC .. trained for service with the `Down Under' contingents ... (1916,On the Anzac Trail,2)

SIMPSON ... a Down Under book for overseas friends and relations. (1945,If You'd Care to Know,6)

As well, her Downunder Mr Wonderful had to be warm, caring, considerate ... a man of strict Christian principles. (Nov 8, 1987,Sunday News,21)

"Down under" boys on furlough are intown, Discharged from hospital, repairedand braced. (Dec 27, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/9 : 199)

Let them pause, and hear when nights arestill The other girl who coo-ees from"down under". (Dec 27, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/9 : 199)

With that I tell her how much we're looking forward to her visit Downunder. (Apr 23, 2008,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),13)

3 adv.

FROUDE We were to bid adieu to the `Australasian' ... She had carried us safely down under. (1886,Oceana,92)

HYDE Two big maps, one of the North Island, one of the South, with Stewart Island tacked on down under, showed up on one of the bare walls ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,163)

down-country¶

n. The flat part of a country (as opposed to hilly regions). The noun (and aj and av phrases) is used mainly to distinguish the lower or flat country (often the plains) from the high-country (South Island) or hill country (NI); it also often connotes thecoast',the town', as distinguished from the back country (see also front country), as often New Zealand's flat land is coastal or towards the coast. The usage is US and`colonial'.

LANCASTER In the down-country. [title: sc Christchurch] - (1904,Sons o' Men)

Acland quoting 1872 Apr 4 Wakatip Mail Down Country. See COUNTRY (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15)

n. the flat country on a farm as opposed to the high or hill country.

STUDHOLME At Waimate we ran Cross-bred sheep on the down-country and Merinos or Half-breds on the hills. (1940,Te Waimate,97)

THOMSON There's a subtle difference between back-country men and those enslaved to industry and commerce. ... The blokes up here think with their hearts,' said one of my mates one night after a session in a country pub with a crowd of cullers, musterers and shearers.Down country they only think with their heads.' (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,20) [NOTES: [?n in the dc; ?av equiv. up here] ']

1 adj. (Rural) [of foot-hills, rolling and flat land] closer to settlement than the high country or back country.

It will be the duty of down-country farmers to get the shearing over as soon as it can be managed, in order that the men go up country. (Nov 1917,NZ Farmer,1226)

STEVENS The new comb will also find full use in down-country flocks for the out-of-season shearing of breeding ewes, young sheep and rams. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,81)

VANCE The stock and station agency tried to put down-country sheep on Rollesby. (1965,High Endeavour,208)

The down-country cockies like nothing better than a nice line of blacks and will pay accordingly. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,35)

LOUGHNAN One may detect in those who live up-country a slight hint of envy which is cloaked under a pose of smugness and scorn for down-country dwellers and which needs to be kept hidden because the down-country men do arrive at the annual ewe fairs to spend lots of money! (1981,Loughnan Glossary,28)

HALL Down-country sheep often look a bit pink after shearing because they're closely shorn, but in the high country a bit more wool has to be left on them. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,21)

2 adv. towards or on the flat land near the coast; towards or near the town (esp. send (animals etc.) down country).

BATHGATE A dozen or more with their pack-saddles empty ... were returning down country. (1874,Colonial Experiences,135)

BARRY We were mustering the sheep and getting ready to start down-country.Ibid. 263 I sent herdown-country [sc. to Dunedin] in a coach. (1879,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,20)

BEATTIE Once or twice he had gone down-country with an empty dray ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,133)

BEATTIE Another fire, started up about Greenvale in 1858, came `lolliping' down-country over the Merino Downs country, finally dying out about Waipahi. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,25)

BEATTIE After being at Hogburn the best part of a year he decided to leave before the worst of the winter came on and so he returned down-country. (1947,Pioneer Recollections,3,1956 ed.) [NOTES: [Hogburn =Naseby]]

When an inhabitant of the Mackenzie goes beyond Burke's Pass, he talks of going down country.' The phrase implies a moral as well as a physical descent. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,122</i>) [NOTES: (from Korero, AEWS magazine) 122 (Mackenzie Country')]

Many [high-country men] are born `down-country' as we say (1951,High Country,42)

NEWTON However, I saddle up and set out down country' for Pukaki. <i>Ibid.</i> 21 He dule?) took a job down country, finished with the back country for good. Six months later he was back again ... He'd got footrot down on themud flats' and had to come back to the hard country. (1952,High Country Journey,20)

THOMSON The deer hides from the same parties were brought here by packhorses for a final check, then stored until transported down country to skin buyers or agents. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,66)

And Christmas as Tarndale was better held drunk than sober, because down country all our people were hanging up stockings and being kissed under the mistletoe and getting plenty of mail and good things, while we slept on wire netting and tried not to think of home. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,20)

MASTERS ... as I lay in my bunk doing a bit of thinking I came to theconclusion going by the way I had evaded Macdonald, that it was high time I headed down country and started associating with people before I went crackers. (1960,Back-Country Tales,59)

McNAUGHTON In November, when Bluey finished at the station, he headed down country for his sister-in-law's place. (1970,Tat,91)

PINNEY Because of its position Benmore had to sell stock almost always down-country. (1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,25)

He was puzzled why any kea would be found so far down-country [near Hokonui] (Jul 29, 1986,Southland Times,19)

3 adj. esp. South Island, of or pertaining to the flatcountry away from the mountains or hills

HISLOP ... `Shiner' ... had called with his usual thirst at one of the down-country hotels. (1943,Pure Gold,126)

MARSH Late snows that came down into lambing paddocks, noisy rituals of dipping, crutching, shearing; the final down-country journey of the wool-bales. (1945,Died in the Wool,13)

SUTHERLAND It was a down-country drover returning from an assignment to the west coast ... (1953,Golden Bush, The,188,1963 ed.)

McCASKILL How many down-country paddock farmers would be happy with an equal result? (1969,Molesworth,192)

[sic] While the tussle was going on I managed to get in touch with a down-country drover whose dogs could manage these sheep. (Canterbury) (1978,Woolgatherers,112)

down-creek¶

1 adv. (Rural) in a direction towards the mouth of a creek.

SHADBOLT .. each morning she continued her journey on the cream-launch all the way down-creek to the high school in the town ... (1959,New Zealanders, The,22)

down-string¶

1 v. (Rural) [stock] to move downhill in a single file.

MCKEE WRIGHT .. and the hoggets down-stringing through clover ... (1897,Station Ballads,13)

down-table¶

adj. of Cabinet Ministers, placed away from the head of the cabinet table; cf down market.

Last week I noted how many down-table Cabinet members, and even MPs had lost the ability to drive themselves, as, indeed, has a substantial proportion of the military officer-class. (Apr 29, 1987,Contact (Wgtn),2)

down-trou¶

n. a lowering of trousers (also as verb) [Spears "Slang & Euphemism" gives "trou" as US 1900.]

Prime aim: avoid the down-trou. (Jan 14, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D3)

BROSNAHAN Children home and the party went on/ Still keeping pretty clean / Though one of the fellows did a down trou' / After I left the scene. (1998,Glenaray 1898-1998,80)

McGILL down trou male (usually) party trick of standing on the table, and dropping trousers, shared with certain Brits, as author witnessed when several All Blacks and Lions rugby players downtrou-ed in a Wellington restaurant in 1983. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

Ihimaera Yay, so there is a God - one who had covered up my indiscretions and sent my sons home before I had done my down trou. (2007,Ask the Posts,86)

down/downers¶

n. [(whalers')]

GRADY Down, downers - The time a submerged or diving whale stays underwater. (1982,Perano Whalers,226) [NOTES: (Cook Strait Whalers' glossary)]

downcast¶

n. [(mining)]

Under present conditions the miner from the moment he sets foot upon the cage or steps inside the downcast in reality takes his life out of his own hands. (Apr 20, 1911,Maoriland Worker,8/2/3)

downcast shaft¶

n.

McARA319 Downcast shafts: Those shafts into which the air flowed from the surface, as opposed to upcast shafts which discharged the warm spent air. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)) [NOTES: (Glossary of Waihi Mining Terms)]

downed¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of hunting stock] killed or injured.

PORTER It was good to put my freezing hands into the warm gut of a downed deer. (1970,Under the Nor'West Arch,62)

downer¶

n. OED: fig. A depressing person or experience; a failure; a downward trend, esp. inbusiness or the economy. Cf. UPPER n.2 2. orig. U.S.

It was a kind of a downer after the way I had been going. I'd been so stoked with my game. (Feb 22, 2002,Evening Post,25)

n. (See down n3.)

1 n. (Rural) a sick cow or sheep.

Since the drainage has been done there have been fewer downer cows and fewer milk fever losses. (May 13, 1982,NZ Farmer,28)

I wonder how many farmers have tended 'downer' cows during storms not realising that they may be seeing an aftermath of facial eczema ... (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,80)

I have often told the story of the downer cow in a storm in 1973 ... (Jun 1994,NZ Dairy Exporter,94)

In spring there are inevitably the odd downer cows that have difficulty calving and cannot get up. [downer cow] (Sep 2001,Growing Today,64)

downer cow¶

n. [Also used in USA.] (See downer,down cow)

.. one Waikato farmer who last week found the rules have changed when it comes to getting downer cows picked up for pet food. (Aug 22, 2005,NZ Farmers' Weekly,3)

downland¶

1 n. (Rural) the lower, flatter and foothill land in proximity to alpine and high country.

BROSNAHAN With the development of the downland country came the need for better utilisation of the improved pastures. (1998,Glenaray 1898-1998,71)

Mr Hewson was brought up on a family farm near St Andrews in South Canterbury, and later farmed the downland in partnership with his brother. (Sep 26, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,17)

downpipe¶

n.

OGONOWSKA-COATES Downpipe. Length of non-flexible [sic] pipe through which power is transmitted to the machineshearer's hand-piece. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,96)

downtown¶

adj. to and around the central shopping and entertainment area of a town [Jim writes: NSOD tags this as chiefly NAmer, Collins as US, Canadian & NZ. All OED citations are North American or refer to North America, except one from Australia in 1969. A New Scientist article in 1966 found it necessary to translate the word for English readers. However, I have recently heard and read it in British TV programmes and publications with reference e.g to Adelaide and Santiago. Is it used of British cities and since when? It has been common in NZ at least since the 70s esp but not solely in relation to Auckland and Wellington.]

IHIMAERA It certainly wasn't the night for a leisurely stroll down town or to be loitering in shop doorways, and yet a surprising number of the city's population were doing just that. (1982,Into the World of Light,79)

[Hdg] Discover Downtown. Downtown Wellington combines four richly different experiences, all within walking distance from each other. (Oct 12, 2000,Evening Post,29)

FRAME I went about my daily tasks at home - milking the cows, often sharing the ride with Bruddie, taking my "turn" at riding Dad's bike downtown for the messages. (1982,To the Is-Land,220)

Downtown is walking distance from everywhere, and the harbour's so close that it's the city's front yard. (Nov 23, 2000,Dominion,4)

n. an amphetamine derivative

downy¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in plant names (See brome,hakea,ironheart,rata)

downy country¶

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use] the farmed downland adjacent to the South Island high country.

MCLEOD It had little flat land, and not even much 'downy' country like the other side of Forest Creek. (1970,Many a Glorious Morning,180)

MCLEOD One of the troubles of this kind of 'downy' country is that there are no defined routes for sheep. (1970,Many a Glorious Morning,186)

He prefers cattle to sheep on his downy country during droughts. (Jul 8, 1971,NZ Farmer,32)

doze¶

n. [(forestry)]

DOZE. Decay or incipient decay in timber. (1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

doze off¶

v. (Rural) to use a bulldozer blade to level or flatten land, erections, scrub or trees.

How many extra acres would you have if you could smooth off that gully .. clear out that fence row..move those rocks .. doze off or pull out brush and trees? (Mar 1967,NZ Journal of Agriculture,68)

dozie¶

adj. of land where sheep lose condition; of sheep so affected with a deficiency disease; see also dopie.

Dozie: Country where sheep lose condition and do not thrive - go dopie, in fact - is called dopie. I have heard shepherds speak of d[ozie] sheep also. It is very likely the Scots for dopie. (C.) (Oct 7, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

1 adj. (Rural) [of poor country] where sheep do not thrive.

ACLAND dozie: country where sheep lose condition and do not thrive - go dopie, in fact it is called d. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,370)

DPAG¶

abbr. Dunedin Public Art Gallery

At the time, the Dunedin Public Art Gallery (DPAG) had no idea that the Hotere works were heading to Gore...Pitts argues that the DPAG does have an "active" programme of local artists. (Nov 15, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

DPB¶

abbr. Domestic Purposes Benefit [ORIGIN: acronym]

Mothers with young families who are forced into taking up the DPB get an enormous amount of flak. (Nov 1999,North & South,75)

Most were in their 20s and some were on the DPB, the rest were on the dole. (Oct 1997,North & South,76)

Dr Cathy Wyllie, a social researcher, did a major survey of women on the DPB in 1980. (Mar 2, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

The dpb was introduced in 1973 to help women leave violent relationships and to allow unmarried mothers to keep their children instead of giving them up for adoption. (Jun 27, 2001,Dominion,10)

There is no evidence.. that teenagers get pregnant for the DPB; there are more men than single teenage mothers on the DPB. (Mar 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

It's the pits being on the DPB but if it's the only way you can get income to feed your kids you do it, eh? (1995,Mana,No. 10 : 31)

OLIVER She's a good little mother is kanga/ scraping / along on the d p b/ no mr about the place just roo/ (1982,Poor Richard,18)

... they feel neglected, especially those on long-term benefits like DPB. ... [fn] Domestic Purposes Benefit (Feb 1984,Public Service Journal,10)

Studies to date offer no evidence that the DPB encourages women to get pregnant, ... A woman struggling to get off the DPB and into the work force ... might as well give up and go home. (Apr 26, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

Despite the fact that most of these women qualify for the DPB, many choose to work instead. (Jul 1986,Metro,130)

After dissolution of marriage by separation agreement there was the DPB. (May 1987,Metro) [NOTES: Roger `Auckland Life']

Clergyman opposes cancelling of dpb [headline] (May 19, 1987,Dominion,2)

Just once I would like to read an article with a positive approach to `solo mums'. ... I am on the DPB ... (Feb 1988,North & South,34)

The [Collins English] dictionary does not, however, contain entries for DPB, EFTPOS, GST, CNG, first fifteen, street kids, May holidays, and it is still too early for orange roughy, night shelter, and Rogernomics, twink and lotto (New Zealand-style) ... (Feb 27, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65) [NOTES: (G. Kennedy)]

MACRAE It was a cheap loan but while she was on the DPB, more than enough to cope with. (1988,Awful Childhoods,24)

We thought bracken beds might be a good way of stopping DPBs procreating, but it was pointed out that they would have been gathering bracken from the roadside, and not paying transit New Zealand for it. (Dec 28, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),124)

She thinks the domestic purposes benefit (dpb) should keep up with the cost of living, but believes some people waste their benefit money... (May 22, 2004,Dominion Post,E1)

These days he's a solo father on the DPB. (Aug 1991,Metro,60)

"I'm getting $141 a week and they're trying to get me to pay $102 a week liable parent because my ex is still on the dpb." (Dec 19, 1991,Dominion,9)

In the early 1980s the National Government conducted an inquiry into abuse of the DPB.... Currently, almost one New Zealand child in eight is being raised on the DPB. Even so, the DPB is not a ticket of life-long dependence on the state. (Feb 13, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

DPMC¶

abbr. Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet

The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet (DPMC) has, at times, managed to ace the other two because its boss is the boss. Under this government, the Treasury has had everything confiscated but its calculators, and the DPMC is less a department than a secretariat to a very determined PM. (May 5, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

drabbie¶

n. a drab, colourless person

FED UP. [a restaurant] 244 Ponsonby Rd. BYO. No bookings. Small, crowded with drabbies. Menu long overdue for a change, but still good value. (Jul 1986,Metro,20)

dracaena¶

n.

Dracaenas and their other relationscordylines (cabbage trees) can be used togreat effect. (Oct 1992,Metro,28)

drack¶

adj. awful or ugly

McGILL drac(k) awful or ugly, as in Dracula. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

draco¶

n. short for Dracophyllum spp.

HULME We could walk past the peat bogs. But if you went off the planks you got quickly lost in the draco... [sic] (1986,Te Kaihau,167)

dracophyllum¶

n. genus of trees and shrubs

So lonely below the tupare and dracophyllum. It is inhabited by ghosts. (Jan 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

Time out at the hot pools of Hanmer then.. climbing away from the beech forest into a West Coast garden of Dracophyllum, mountain holly, flax and harebells, descending into the Taramakau Valley. (Mar 17, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C5)

BIDWILL As we went on, the land became more and more barren and level, till it became a mere moor, without a shrub, and almost without vegetation; a few bushes of the miserable-looking Dracophyllum being all that occurred to break the monotony of the plain. Ibid. 100 I here first saw the great Dracophyllum; it formed a small tree about six inches in diameter, and twenty feet high; it is one of the most curious plants in the world; the leaves grow in tufts at the ends of the branches, just as in the dragon tree (Dracaena), and are the same shape, but in this species they are elegantly reflexed, like the feathers of a soldier's plume; they are a foot long and an inch broad at the base. (1841,Rambles in NZ,53,1952 ed.)

DIEFFENBACH The forest [near Rotorua] was mostly tawai (Leiospermum racemosum), miro, and hinau; the Dracophyllum, which often grows to the size of a small tree, and the reddish leaves of which render it a very remarkable and beautiful shrub, was ... to be met with. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/399)

We followed deer tracks zigzagging up through snow totara and Dracophyllum, then plugged up through soft snow to Brodrick Pass (5,308ft.), taking nearly two hours from camp. (Sep 1958,Tararua,49)

draft¶

n.

Ibid. 162 The climax came to a head, when on a draft of stud ewes paddocked handy and pushed in on the late afternoon, to make a handy mob before Saturday half-day gave all a welcome respite from duty. ... My extra choice store lambs are [pound]1 per head'. That evening a Mr. Wright ... asked casually if an offer could be procured of 800 to 1000 lambs for immediate fattening.Yes,' said Jim, I know of a draft,' roughly describing same. ...'I leave to-morrow for Fielding [sic] to attend a sheep sale there, and may pick up some suitable fattening lambs.' (1960,Memories of Maoriland,49)

He obtained the good average of 49 guineas for his draft. (Nov 22, 1937,King Country Chronicle,5)

NEWTON We had a small draft of sale ewes that year. (1966,Boss's Story, The,88)

n. a group of animals separated from a main mob for a special purpose.

draft n. a body of cattle, etc., separated from a herd; ... (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

draft v.tr. to separate or sort cattle. n. the separated body of cattle. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),165)

draft ... 7. Austral. & N.Z. a group of livestock separated from the rest of the herd or flock. ... 12. Austral. & N.Z. a. to select (cattle or sheep) from a herd or flock. b. to select (farm stock) for sale. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,336) [NOTES: [See NZPOD 226, DRAFTING; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 146]]

v.

PHILLIPS All hands drafting at woolshed - (Jan 3, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,91 ed.)

T.C. KIERNAN C.H.S. and T.S. drafting and putting shorn sheep out to the paddocks. (Feb 27, 1879,Diary,91) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 27 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie Smith Tutira 127]

v. to remove certain animals from a group by separating them or by driving them up a race and removing them through a drafting gate.

DUNCAN First we had to draft [the sheep] off and boat them across the arm of the lake. (1888,Wakatipians,64)

STRONACH Arriving at Tarndale, we drafted off the woollies and sent them to Molesworth to be shorn. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,37)

Draft off: Removing certain animals from a group. This can be done by driving the animals out of a group (cut off or drift off) or driving them up a race and removing them through a special gate (drafting gate). (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5)

v. to sort (farm animals) into particular groups; to separate a large mob into smaller groups.

BOWEN With the race and gates shown sheep can be drafted six ways. (1955,Wool Away!,123)

The sheep drafted in through a race from the yards into pens running down the centre of the shed, were taken from these pens by the shearers. (Sep 23, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

finished drafting wethers which were put accross [sic] Wedderburn ... Number including hogs about 1540 (Nov 11, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary)

... got a small mob into the yards 19 of which we selected and it took us the rest of the day to draft them ... (Apr 11, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,32,1950 ed.)

The armies of sheep were only being drafted (that is sorted) for sale. (Mar 28, 1867,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/237,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

WILLIAMS & REEVES Dagging the hoggets, or drafting the rams. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

WILSON The sheep ... are ... placed in smaller ... enclosures adjoining the wool-sheds, from which are drafted, from time [243] to time, a number sufficient to keep the pens ... full. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,242)

Draft: (i) To divide stock into classes, either in a yard or (cattle) by cutting out (q.v.). In the old days sheep were hand drafted, i.e. lifted over a rail or manhandled through agate. (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement],p.135) About 1864 it was found possible to run sheep one at a time through a drafting race and move a single gate as they came, so drafting into two lots. See double gate. Cattle are usually now drafted in a stock-yard (q.v.). See also shed. (G.P. W.) (ii) A number of stock sent for sale, e.g. `The annual Stonyhurst draft of four-year-old ewes will be offered.' When the draft is actually offered it is usually spoken of as a line. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

CHERRILL Sometimes she would draft a mob to the stock yards, but ... prices ran low. (1950,Story of a NZ Sheepfarm,113)

SCOTT Presently Larry was summoned to help draft the sheep. (1953,Breakfast at Six,34)

draft ... v.i. to sort cattle, etc., into different groups. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

draft v.t. to separate or sort cattle; n. separated body of cattle. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

McLEOD Drafting sheep: The process of dividing a mixed mob into sexes or ages or any other required types. (1970,Glorious Morning,253)

When witness had finished "dagging," hedrafted the sheep. (Oct 24, 1914,Stratford Evening Post,2)

v. (Rural) to sort or separate stock, especially sheep, for the purposes of sale, breeding, pasture management or treatment.

Finished drafting wethers ... (Nov 11, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary)

WILLIAMS & REEVES Dagging the hoggets or drafting the rams. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

MOWAT Mustered the sheep out of the house paddock, put them in the yards and drafted them. (Oct 8, 1914,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MCLEOD A few more minutes and Bill would have been there to help him; now he had had a box, and the sheep would all have to be drafted. (1954,On the Hill,26)

MAF Draft off or drafting: Removing certain animals from a group. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5)

1 n. (Rural) an animal or group of animals that is separated from others in the process of drafting for sale, treatment or culling.

Sent a draft to Isolated Hill by upper road. (Dec 12, 1856,St Leonard's Station Diary)

MOWAT Brought Pahau draft up from Pukeroa and we drafted off all shorn sheep. (Nov 25, 1915,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

GUTHRIE-SMITH There was endless labour in paring the hoofs of the limping brutes, in running the lame drafts through the arsenic troughs. (1921,Tutira,157) [NOTES: [1999]]

WILSON & FRASER .. after the boiling-down works opened at Woodlands, large drafts were sent there every year. (1936,Book of the Pioneers, The,30)

NEWTON The coastal flats of Homewood and the adjoining properties are great fattening country, producing big drafts of fat stock. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,48)

WATERS Put the rams out early, lamb early, get your fat lamb drafts away early ... (1976,Mostly a Farmer,78)

The last draft killed at Affco averaged 367 kg and 92% were in the P1 or top grade. (Sep 4, 1997,NZ Farmer,13)

draft off¶

v. (Rural) to select or separate animals within a group or mob.

MOWAT Drafted off the steers from the heifers. (Nov 23, 1915,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MOWAT Drafted off the tops. (Apr 6, 1931,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

Contrary to common practice, I don't draft my lambs off before shearing. (May 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,501)

If rams remain with the ewes for more than 4 weeks, they should be raddled on the brisket so that the late-lambing ewes can be drafted off. (Mar 1955,NZ Journal of Agriculture,264)

These [twinners] are all drafted off and held in separate paddocks. (Apr 25, 1968,NZ Farmer,51)

MCLEOD When we had mustered all we could catch, the lambs were drafted off their mothers and turned out ... (1970,Many a Glorious Morning,231)

LOUGHNAN shed: (ii) (v) to draft off sheep or cattle in the open paddock. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,71)

The top 100 calves are drafted off at weaning ... (May 19, 1993,NZ Farmer,19)

ASPINALL All the sheep had to be mustered on the station and the sale lambs drafted off. (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,65)

draft out¶

v. (Rural) to select or separate stock within a mob or group.

Draft out the ewes and bring them to the scrub pen. (1847,Pharazyn Diary,147)

Drafted out 1200 sheep. (Mar 18, 1863,Haldon Station Diary,249) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

BALFOUR Drafted out the run sheep. (Mar 6, 1873,Balfour Diaries)

BALFOUR Drafting out the run sheep from the Leicesters and the rams. (Mar 7, 1873,Balfour Diaries)

BARKER .. after next shearing we'll have a good mob of sheep to draft out and stock it. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,94)

Drafted out strangers and ewes and lambs. (Feb 16, 1888,Tutira Station Diary)

Some shepherds make a practice of drafting out the ewes as they lamb and put them on to better feed. (Sep 1, 1925,NZ Farmer,1329)

DU FAUR As lambs that are thriving can carry a heavy worm burden without being significantly affected it is essential to draft out the unthrifty and 'tail-enders'... (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,131)

FOSTER & WRIGHT There the 'dirties' - the sheep in need of dagging - and the rams are drafted out. (1983,Stockman Country,142)

Draft out and milk cows with clinical mastitis in a separate mob, after the main milking herd. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,51)

Watch for shy feeders and draft out when necessary. [draft off] (Feb 28, 2002,Fencepost.com,Expert farmer Livestock)

v.

Templars sheep came in the morning - Drafted out most of Newton's - (Feb 18, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: [cf cut out also used]]

CRAWFORD Draft out rams as flock is dipped and keep them in a separate flock. (1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,46) [NOTES: 1860 Duppa in 1949 Crawford Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury 46]

BUTLER You will see fit to draft out all the lambs that are ready for weaning. Ibid. 154 Should you be drafting out sheep or taking your rams out, let the sheep ... be let into yards D and E. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,x 153)

T.C. KIERNAN Drafted out all woolly sheep and took them to the shed. (Feb 27, 1879,Diary) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 27 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie Smith Tutira 127]

draft up¶

v. (Rural) to draft.

MOWAT Drafted up small poor wethers. (Feb 9, 1931,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MOWAT Drafted up most from No 3 and 4. (Feb 17, 1931,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MOWAT Brought sheep in, picked out the tops, then drafted up some odds and ends. (Feb 26, 1931,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

drafted¶

adj.

It being too late to get down the river tonight I only crossed the drafted cattle over one stream and took them on one mile. (May 5, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,181,1950 ed.)

drafter¶

n. one who drafts stock.

Draft'.er (dr&adot.ft'.&etilde.r), n. One who drafts; esp., one who separates sheep into flocks in a drafting yard. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2021)

drafter n. man engaged in drafting cattle. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

1 n. (Rural) the person who operates a drafting gate or selects stock.

.. the carcase was bruised through the drafter having pulled the wool of the lambs. (Mar 1931,NZ Farmer,221)

Drafters, like Alex Guy, are experts in their field and use their ability and experience to ensure maximum returns. (Nov 27, 1975,NZ Farmer,97)

At the height of their working season, drafters are intensely busy. (Sep 12, 1985,NZ Farmer,27)

The drafter couldn't believe that we hadn't touched them apart from docking them. (Jun 15, 1994,NZ Farmer,21)

STACEY The drafter's arms work the gate as though computerised. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,81)

A number still use a stock agent. If you are using an agent you should check the consistency and accuracy of your drafter against the killing sheets. (Dec 21, 2001,Fencepost.com,Expert farmer Livestock)

They were drafted commercially, and the drafter didn't know if he was taking a lamb from a little ewe or a big one. (2002,Wool Grower,Spring 21)

drafting¶

n. the process of separating stock from a main mob

Finished drafting and when we came to take the rams out ... we found 40 of them had nocked down a rail ... (Jan 9, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,117,1950 ed.)

PEACHE Think some got out as made out there were 14,000 in hand after drafting. (Jan 21, 1883,Journal) [NOTES: 1883 Jan 21 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 63]

WILLIAMS & REEVES drafting, culling, cutting and tailing [etc] (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

.. whenever the mobs were mustered for ...shearing or drafting, these `cranky' [that is a genetically shortwinded race of sheep of Strath Taieri] (as they came to be called) were left behind. (1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/173)

On a cattle-run the tasks of mustering and drafting the stock and branding the youngsters are very heavy work, needing the display of considerable powers of rough- riding among thehorsemen; while on a sheep-run the lambing and shearing seasons tax every power of the station-hands. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,157)

After a number of years, when sheep were mustered in from the back ranges, it was noticed that several would die in the yards ..., for they would require to be kept in for drafting on the following day. These dead sheep would be mostly sheep which had missed a shearing, and were double-fleeced, having very long wool. (1895,TrNZI,27/278)

BELL The yards were small and inconvenient, and of a temporary character, and the work of drafting was difficult. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,79)

CARR A new hand ... is wise investing in a good huntaway or a heading dog. He can practice [sic] on the `killers' i.e. the sheep kept handy for station use, or better still, a good noisy yard dog, as allstation hands are liable to be called upon to assist in drafting, etc. (1913,Country Work,33)

BEATTIE One who was present has told me of a cattle drafting on the Beaumont Run, above Wrey's Bush. ... what with cutting-out the beasts wanted, rounding-up the remainder, dodging wild charging brutes, ... there was some ... exciting work done that day. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,44)

drafting n. NZ & Austral. drawing off or selecting livestock for particular purpose; drafting gate swing-gate at end of drafting race; drafting pen pen to hold selected animals; drafting race narrow alley down which animals are driven for drafting. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,226) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

n.

BOWEN Four-way drafting is a feature of the design. (1955,Wool Away!,125)

1 n. (Rural) the dividing of farm stock into separate mobs for sale, breeding or other purposes.

WATERS He would arrive at a farm in his gig, tie the horse up to a fence and get on with the drafting. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,38)

WATERS Be it understood the drafting of fat stock for the overseas market can not be done by the man in the street. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,39)

DREAVER When the shearers knocked off, there would still be drafting and shedding up for the musterers and we would all get home for a very late tea. (1994,Catlins River Wisp Run,57)

drafting gate¶

n.

BOWEN The sheep are also more easily seen by the man on the drafting gate when walking up hill. (1955,Wool Away!,119)

In drafting one sheep witness thought wasaccused's ran into his lot and witnesscould not catch it at the drafting gate. (Oct 24, 1914,Stratford Evening Post,2)

n. a two-way gate in a drafting-race for separating farm animals into special groups.

RIVES After dinner we draughted out strangers and woolly ones and a devilish hard job I had standing at one of the draughting gates counting out the woolly ones. (Feb 26, 1875,Jottings on the Spot,7)

Drafting gates 3ft. wide. (Sep 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,220)

STUDHOLME In later years we had stockyards at different parts of the Station where the drafting was done. The cattle were driven up a narrow race, with double gates at the further end, which were worked by a man standing on a platform. These yards were specially built for handling wild cattle, and had narrow gaps between the hinge of the drafting gate and post, through which a man could escape from a charging beast. (1940,Te Waimate,136,1954 ed.)

ACLAND He could hardly tell his own buggy horses ... and would never take the drafting gate ... (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,153)

NEWTON DRAFTING: The main feature of sheepyards is the drafting race. This race, perhaps eight yards in length, is only wide enough for sheep to pass through in single file; at the end of the race are two swinging gates which can be manipulated to turn the sheep into different yards, and so separate them into different `lines' or mobs. (1949,High Country Days,194)

drafting-gate A gate used in separating cattle and sheep into classes or herds. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),131,8th ed.)

drafting gate n. gate used to separate sheep or cattle (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

FERNANDEZ The boss was there working the drafting gate - two-tooths to the left-hand gate, six-tooths to the right. (1973,Tussock Fever,1)

Draft: Removing certain animals from a group. This can be done by driving the animals out of a group (cut off or drift off) or driving them up a race and removing them through a special gate (drafting gate). -->to remove certain animals from a group driving the animals out of a group (cut off or drift off) or driving them up a race and removing them through a special gate (drafting gate). (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,5)

1 n. (Rural) one of a pair of gates in a drafting race that is used to separate stock into two or three mobs.

CAIRD .. men have to go in on foot to force the animals through drafting gates ... (1874,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,23)

Drafting gates 3 ft wide. (Sep 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,229)

MILLS ET AL As the man at the drafting gates is practically indispensable, the man filling the crush pen is largely responsible for keeping an even flow of sheep going up the race. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,75)

MALLOCH For 65 years he raddled lambs for that firm and even in his 80s he could be seen clutching the drafting gate at Waikaia Plains. (1992,From the Tops,112)

GORDON Yards are full, race is full, gates are latched .. except the little one by the drafting gates! (1996,Trouble with Stock Agents, The,40)

drafting pen¶

n.

MULGAN There were stables and ... a huge wool-shed and drafting pens. (1934,Spur of Morning,314)

BOWEN This drafting race divides sheep into the separate lots required, and these are then handled by the drafting pens, check pens, and holding yards, which should correspond in size to the receiving yards. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

WALLIS There a baler was a brochure number, a header a price. Somewhere outside ... there were salesmen talking to farmers, ... sitting astride the drafting pens discussing dips and shearing machines and drug dispensers ... (1963,Point of Origin,18)

1 n. (Rural) a pen in a stock yard that is adjacent to the drafting race.

In larger sets of yards one of more of these drafting pens communicate via a gate ... (Jul 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,7)

BOWEN This drafting race divides sheep into the separate lots required, and these are then handled by the drafting pens, check pens and holding yards, which should correspond in size to the receiving yards. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

RIDDOLL There should be as many drafting pens as there are ways of drafting. The check pens should be adjacent to the drafting pens and should equal them in number. (1958,Farm Engineering,334)

drafting race¶

n. a race for drafting stock into smaller mobs. See cit 1966.

Geary A drench salesman had sworn he'd once seen Craven break alkathene across the rear of one hyena-looking huntaway that wouldn't stay out of the drafting race. (2003,Man of the People, A,132)

W.H.S. ROBERTS At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, as everything was new ... The yard was divided into three - one large and two small - but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring branding. (Dec 18, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43-44]

PERRY [The sheep yards] should consist of receiving yards at each end, forcing pen, and drafting race. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,16)

BOWEN This drafting race divides sheep into the separate lots required, and these are then handled by the drafting pens, check pens, and holding yards, which should correspond in size to thereceiving yards. (1955,Wool Away!,120)

SCRYMGEOUR `Teviot' had a magnificent stone and steel woolshed [built 1880] ... with two complete drafting races, much wool storage room, two ancient screw presses, and stands for 26 blade shearers, for this was the era before the Ferrier Woolpress, ... (1960,Memories of Maoriland,17)

NEWTON DRAFTING: The main feature of sheepyards is the drafting race. This race, perhaps eight feet in length, is only wide enough for sheep to pass through in single file; at the end of the race are two swinging gates which can be manipulated to turn the sheep into different yards, and so separate them into different `lines' or mobs. (1966,Boss's Story, The,186)

At times foot-rot troughs are at the bottom of the drafting race and covered over.. when not in use. (1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,229)

1 n. (Rural) a long alley through which stock are driven for separation for sale, culling or for processes of dipping, troughing etc.

PERRY They [sheep yards] should consist of receiving yards at each end, forcing pen and drafting race. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,16)

Now begins the long struggle at the drafting race. (Mar 23, 1967,NZ Farmer,33)

All the drafting races were in yards that have seen many years service. (Sep 12, 1985,NZ Farmer,27)

drafting stick¶

1 n. (Rural) a waddy or pointer, used in drafting yards.

Those modifications [to a farm bike] include carriers back and front, and holders for shepherd's crooks, a drafting stick etc. (Jun 7, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,25)

drafting yard¶

n. an enclosed yard into or out of which stock are drafted; also pl., the collection of pens, yards, races used esp. for handling stock.

ALLOM `I will conclude this part of the subject with a few words about stockyards. They are generally made of stout posts and rails; the corner posts ought to be much stronger than the rest, as they often have to bear the weight of a heavy bullock in branding and other operations. The yard is generally divided into three portions - viz., a large yard for the whole herd, a drafting yard, and a milking yard, at one end of which is placed the milking shed, cow bails, and calf house, the whole being so arranged that a calf can be let out to suck its mother on one side while she is being milked on the other.' (1853,Letter) [NOTES: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ 123 (Wairarapa)]

Drafting yard and cow bails. (1849,Notes on NZ,26)

PAUL ... use a hurdle-yard for shearing ... have your permanent drafting-yard elsewhere. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,90)

J.G.WILSON Donald and Mick went over to the Bush at Sandy's to cut posts for the Drafting yard. (Apr 29, 1874,Diary) [NOTES: 1874 Apr 29 J.G.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 186]

T.C. KIERNAN T.C.K. went to Tutira to mend gates at drafting-yard. (Feb 19, 1879,Diary) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 19 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie Smith Tutira 126]

PERRY Sheep Yards. - The erection of drafting yards is one of the first improvements to be attended to by the young sheep farmer. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,16)

DARE We had to move the whole lot to the drafting yards. (1956,Rouseabout Jane,167)

drafting-yard A yard or enclosure for drafting cattle. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),131,8th ed.)

drafting-yard n. yard divided into compartments for drafting sheep or cattle into groups. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),7)

FERNANDEZ Barbara ... dawdled across the horse paddock by the homestead heading for the dusty, noisy, drafting yards. (1973,Tussock Fever,1)

1 n. (Rural) a stockyard and race used for sorting stock into separate groups.

Hours spent in the drafting yards mean, often, unpolished floors. (Oct 29, 1927,NZ Dairy Exporter,36)

These two pictures show two completely different approaches to the problem of providing cattle drafting yards. (Sep 14, 1961,NZ Farmer,7)

NEWTON The drafting yards on the ground floor are all of dressed timber. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,76)

MACINTOSH .. when a difficult muster is completed and the sheep are in the drafting yards and holding paddock ... (1974,Never a Dull Moment,113)

FERNADEZ Barbara and Kathie dawdled across the horse paddock by the homestead heading for the dusty, noisy, drafting yards. (1975,Tussock Fever,1)

drag¶

v. to hold others up in an activity

PARTRIDGE Drag the chain. To be at the rear in a race or in a game (of, e.g., cribbage): New Zealand: C. 20. Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939, `The ploughman's term to designate his slow horse that does not keep its chains tight'. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1035) [NOTES: 1939 in 1949 Partridge Dict Slang Addenda 1035]

PROF. W. CAMERON A trampers' term applied to those who go very slowly (uphill). (1951,Personal Communication)

v. See cit. Not otherwise recorded.

PARTRIDGE Drag. v. ... -3. v.i. and v.t., to take a portion of the stakes in a gambling game as a reserve for future play: Australian and New Zealand: C. 20. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,240)

v. to search thoroughly [[?Is this merely an extended metaphor thus OMIT???]]

See him [sc. a shepherd] drag a gully full of tomos and patches of scrub and guarantee ... you wouldn't find one straggler. (1966,NZ Short Stories,127,1976 ed.) [NOTES: (Middleton `Saving the Breed')]

n. the pull with a whale in tow back to the mother ship. [whalers']

Capt. Joy Second Mate had his boat robbed ... of a bottle of rum, it being customary to carry it here so that in case of a hard drag to give it to the boats crew ... (May 6, 1836,Log) [NOTES: 1836 May 6 Capt. Joy Mary Mitchell log in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 439]

n. a drag-saw. [(sawmillers')] (See also drag-tooth)

MANDER By day the whole bay vibrated with the whistle and screech of the circular saws, the tear of the break downs, the rasp of the drags, ... Ibid. 198 They watched the progress of the log from the booms up the skids to the side of the breakdown platform... Halved and quartered, it was then levered ... on to greased rollers and rushed towards the big circulars, which turned it into flitches. Then the small circulars, the drag, and the goose completed its metamorphosis into the regulation strips ... (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,159,1974 ed.)

n. a three-month gaol sentence.

According to a well-known Christchurch demon, the slang of three months in thieves' argot is a drag'.Critic' thought a 'tec was the `drag' when he pinched 'em. (Aug 1, 1908,NZ Truth,163/1/5)

n. (See dragstone)

n. in full drag ball [quartzmining]

These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver andground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain,and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings. (1876,TrNZI,8/179) [NOTES: (Goodall Thames Gold-fields)]

drag hunt¶

1 n. (Rural) a horseback hunt where the quarry is not live game, but a sack or sheepskin which has been impregnated with anise or a similar strong smell, dragged over the course.

CHINN A Drag Hunt Club was formed. The quarry in this type of hunt was not live game, but a scent was laid down before hand by a sack or sheepskin, impregnated with some strong smell such as anise, being dragged over the course.' (1963,Packtrack to Highway,42)

KERR Arthur Barker at Winchester and W Postlethwaite at Raukapuka had packs of beagles too, and the type of hunting indulged in then was the 'drag-hunt' when a bag doused with aniseed was dragged along the course to be followed by the hounds. (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,396)

HAYES Jasper Nicols was one-time Master of the Drag Hunt, which was a picnic outing for those who could not ride but still came in buggies to watch. (1978,From the Toss of a Coin,90)

drag off¶

v. [Not recorded elsewhere: but OMIT???]]

A tearful Putaruru Mongrel Mob leader admitted in the Napier High Court yesterday that he wastrying to `drag off' another car when his car smashed head-on into an oncoming station wagon and killed a man, his wife and two of their three children. (Jul 15, 1987,Dominion,3)

drag one's hook¶

phr. to leave a place

CRUMP I think it's time we dragged our hook, Sam. It's about time a man had a little holiday. I can feel the itchy feet coming on. (1962,One of Us,105)

drag rake¶

1 n. (Rural) an implement used to clear drains etc.

STACEY The creeks and streams had not been cleared for years, and it was backbreaking job cutting the weeds into manageable sizes and pulling them out to the bank with a drag rake. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,39)

drag the chain¶

phr. (Rural) [shearing] to work slowly.

Drag the chain, to. To be the slowest shearer in a shed. (Jan 20, 1934,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

BAKER From the New Zealand shearing sheds came those effective expressions to drag the chain and swing the gate, phrases applied to the slowest and fastest shearer in a shed respectively. (1941,NZ Slang,39)

phr. to be slow or behindhand in any group or competitive activity. [(mainly shearers and drinkers)]

Drag the chain, to.-To be the slowest shearer in a shed. (Jan 20, 1934,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

BAKER From the New Zealand shearing sheds came those effective expressions to drag the chain and swing the gate, phrases applied to the slowest and the fastest shearer in the shed respectively. (1941,NZ Slang,39)

Drag the chain: To be the slowest shearer in the shed. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,366)

TURNER To drag the chain is a shearer's term meaning `to be a slow worker'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,122)

dragging the chain: A shearer is said to do this when he lags behind the rest because he is slow, lazy or inexperienced. The origin is from bullock driving where it is said that the rear bullock attached by a chain to the wagon, `drags the chain' if it slows down. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/24) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

SLATTER But stop dragging the chain. Drink up and have one on me. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,45)

TURNER Stop dragging the chain supplies a need where the etiquette of drinking requires rapidconsumption of liquor: it means hurry up with your drinks so that the next round can begin'. <i>Ibid.</i> 131 To drink more slowly than the group isto drag the chain'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,122)

SLATTER Shagging about like an old moll at a christening - Dragging the chain - (1968,Pagan Game, The,164)

SLATTER Shagging about like an old moll at a christening - Dragging the chain - (1968,Pagan Game, The,164)

McGILL dragging the chain holding up a group's activities, such as a drinking school; originally the slowest shearer in the shed; eg `Larry's dragging the chain again on keeping his berm mowed.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

There's old timers we knew, and some who shot throughA hard case, drag the chain, done a bunk,As busy as a blow fly, and bugalugs - from the boo-aiThe rouseabout, as drunk as a skunk. (Dec 2004,NZ Memories,p18)

drag tooth¶

n.

BAINES Cross-cut saws have what is called a peg-tooth and cut both ways. It is a great improvement to sharpen every fifth tooth, counting from the centre to the ends, as a drag tooth, that is, a tooth filed square across and with a considerable hook, this arrangement tends to keep the cut clear of sawdust. (1874,Edward Crewe,173)

drag-tooth saw¶

n. a drag saw [-] (See also drag n)

... crosscuts known as drag-tooth saws. (1951,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: [ca1914] 1951 H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 2: TS]]

dragger¶

n. [(Post Office technical)]

SLATTER Some of his best days had been spent working as a postal assistant ... He had been a spreader in the mailroom and a dragger on the landing. (1968,Pagan Game, The,85)

dragline¶

n.

...fully 20 cars start up and rumble out of the parking lot... The dragline is in operation. The convoy rolls south down the motorway, keeping in touch with each other in the thin traffic by flashing their hazard lights. (Jan 26, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

dragon¶

n.

dragon fruit¶

n.

Dragon fruit: Otherwise known as pitaya and grown in the Bay of Plenty, this fruit is usually exported but you can find its distinctive shape in chic fruit and vegetable shops. (Jun 16, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D1)

dragon-palm¶

n.

REISCHEK In spite of this warning I climbed down a steep bank to the cave, but found no bones, only a beautiful group of dragon-palms - a rare coincidence. The leaves of these Dracaenae - called by the Maoris tohi-palms - possess flexible fibres out of which the natives weave their waterproof rain-mats (pureke). (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,176,1933 ed.)

dragon-tree¶

n. cabbage-tree, ti [??occas. nikau].

FORSTER We met with a great many Cabbage-palmtrees, [Cordyline australis] as they were commonly called by our Sailors, but upon Examination we found them to be a kind of Dragon tree (Dracaena Linn): for we met with the fruit and flowers of them. Ibid. May 13 2/277[?nikau???] ... an infinite variety of high trees & shrubbery [in Dusky Bay], among which theNew-Zeeland Dragon-tree (Dracaena antarctica) [ed. fn Cordyline australis] is very remarkable; (NB Our Sailors called them the Cabbage-palm, but it is different; though the middle most leaves may be eaten & taste almost like sweet fresh Almonds). (May 7, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/270)

FORSTER [??=nikau] These trees, however, were not the true cabbage-palms, nor did they belong at all to the class of palms, ... They were properly speaking a new species of dragon-trees, with broad leaves (dracaena australis) of which the central shoot when quite tender, tastes something like an almond's kernel, with a little of the flavour of cabbage. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/176)

NICHOLAS A species of Dragon-tree, the central shoot of which partook at once both of the flavour of cabbage and of an almond kernel. Ibid. 2/247 [=??nikau, though prob. Cordyline cabbage as Andersen says: Nicholas ref. to Forster 1/176 above] They [Cook's people] found here also ... a new species of dragon-tree, the central shoot of which partook at once both of the flavour of cabbage and of an almond kernel. [reference Forster 1/176] (1817,Voyage Round the World,2/245) [NOTES: [page no and cit. need rechecking]]

(1841,NZ Journal) [NOTES: (Andersen) [=TI]]

BIDWILL I here first saw the great Dracophyllum; it formed a small tree about six inches in diameter, and twenty feet high; it is one of the most curious plants in the world; the leaves grow in tufts at the ends of the branches, just as in the dragon tree (Dracaena), and are the same shape, but in this species they are elegantly reflexed, like the feathers of a soldier's plume; they are a foot long and an inch broad at the base. (1841,Rambles in NZ,100,1952 ed.)

DIEFFENBACH Ti - sweet root of the dragon-tree (1843,Travels in NZ,2/387)

ANGAS The tropical-looking dragon-trees (dracaena), called ti by the natives, and the karaka-tree, grow up the steep sides of the hills ... Ibid. 2/9 [ti] Onwards, through gently undulating fern-land, interspersed with bushes of phormium tenax and an occasional dragon-tree, we againfound belts of forest-land. Ibid. 2/28 A grove of dragon-trees (Ti). (1847,Savage Life,1/240)

EARP .. the sides of the [Wellington] hills ... are almost tropical in their character, from the abundance of the ti, or dragon trees, with which they are covered. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),92)

`When this name was given the tree was Dracoena australis.' (Jan 1856,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal,(NS)) [NOTES: 1856 Jan Tancred Notes on Natural History Canterbury]

LAING & BLACKWELL Cordyline belongs to the sub-family Dracoenoideae, and is therefore related to the dragon-trees. (1940,Plants of NZ,9)

2 n.

HARPER In places [in the Otira district] a stunted mountain birch grows freely, and a curious Dracena, or dragon tree, with a seed that resembles a pineapple, of deep red colour. (Jul 20, 1868,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,130,1914 ed.)

dragonet¶

n.

AYLING DRAGONET Foetorepus phasis (Callionymus phasis, Yerutius phasis) ... [285] They ... give off a very strong smell when captured, giving rise to an alternative common name of stinkfish. (1982,Collins Guide,284,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] dragonet 1989 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

A stranger from the deep arrived at the Canterbury Museum yesterday - a rare dragonet fish caught recently in 90 fathoms of water by the crew of the Lyttelton based trawler Ida Marion. ... The fish appears to be confined to waters off the east coast of the South Island and southern Australia. (Sep 10, 1987,Press, The,2)

dragonfish¶

n. (See starry dragon)

dragonfly¶

n.

HOCHSTETTER (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),170) [NOTES: [cit there if needed]]

drags¶

n.

Tom Pollard and the members of his company became the guests of the officers of the contingent, driving out to the camp in drags. (Jan 18, 1900,Otago Witness,57)

dragstone¶

n.

This faulting has effected a considerable `drag' of the vein to the eastward ... (1907,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.4 (NS) 114) [NOTES: (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)]

This north-north-east fault effects a vertical displacement ... and its `drag' has caused the conglomerates to assume the steep dip of 70 [degrees] to the east-north-east.] -->[?Definition:check geol.] (1934,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,16/125) [NOTES: (Branch and Dagger)]

Buhman further casts doubt on the so-called `dragstone,' theposition of which influenced prospecting for the lost portion, and doubts its value as an index to the direction of movement; he mentions that drag quartz diminished when followed up the fault-plane and along the strike of the fault, whereas the amount of dragstone should have increased as the lost portion of the ore-body was approached. (1938,NZ Geol. Memoir,No.4/74) [NOTES: (Modriniak and Marsden, Reefton)]

No.42 (NS) 53 ... i.e., that the continuation of the lode was relatively upthrown south-west of the fault, as appeared to be suggested by the up-turning of the lode against the fault and drag-stone. ... The channel may be offset, but dragstone should indicate in which direction to seek. (1948,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin) [NOTES: (Gage, Reefton)]

drain weed¶

n. starwort.

HILGENDORF STARWORT (Callitriche verna [spp.]), sometimes called drain weed or even duckweed, is not uncommon in still and slow-running water. ... [It is native to New Zealand.] (1928,Weeds of New Zealand,129,1967 ed.)

Drainage Board¶

n. (historical)

Mr Bell by some means has got the Drainage Board to do all the draining through his property as somehow his land is left out of any drainage board. (Nov 28, 1909,Chudleigh Diary,450,1950 ed.)

draining¶

n.

For nearly six weeks I have worked hard from daylight to dark, stumping, draining and scrub-cutting. (Jul 11, 1928,NZ Free Lance,7)

draining pen¶

n. a pen in which animals emerging from a dip can shed surplus liquid for draining back into the dip.

MEREDITH At the end of the dip are two draining-pens, used alternately. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,88,1935 ed.)

RICHARDS Dad was `crutch' man and also responsible for timing each dip full of sheep before opening the gate and letting them out into the draining pens. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,48)

1 n. (Rural) a pen where sheep are held after dipping, so that drainage is returned to the dip or bath.

MEREDITH At the end of the dip are two draining-pens, used alternately. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,88) [NOTES: (1935)]

BRABAZON John boarded draining-pen, filling dip ... (1908,Brabazon Diaries,14)

PERRY The draining pen will be made on the highest ground, the floor at the lower end, namely at the gangway ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,22)

The sheep have to be directed to the draining pen. (Dec 1, 1928,NZ Farmer,1481)

RIDDOLLS The yards consist of two essential parts; a) crush pens leading to the dip; and b) drainage pens leading from the dip. (1958,Farm Engineering,358)

RICHARDS Dad was crutch man and also responsible for timing each dip full of sheep before opening the gate and letting them into the draining pens. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,48)

drainlayer¶

n. [The common term in NZ - see Yellow Pages where "drainlayers" is a heading]

drake¶

n.

HILGENDORF DARNEL (Lolium temulentum), sometimes called drake, is an annual a good deal like Italian rye in appearance, not uncommon [occasionally found] in cultivated fields and waste places in both islands. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,47,1967 ed.)

drapes¶

n. curtains [OED - chiefly US]

drapetes¶

n. an alpine plant, Relleria dieffenbachii

The common drapetes, Relleria dieffenbachii, a plant commonly found in alpine fellfields from the Coromandel mountains to Stewart Island, is named in his honour. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/49)

draught(ing)¶

n. (See draft(ing))

draw¶

v. in absol use, of a harpoon, to draw out. [(whalers')]

1 P.M. saw a whale ... Mate got fast but his Iron drew - (Jul 16, 1836,Piraki Log,39)

n. [(Northland bushmen's)] (See also sliver,stringer)

ROY GILBERD [The fibres of wood in a tree just about to fall] do not part all in one plane and stringers' ordrawers' are drawn out of the barrel, sometimes several feet long. Sometimes men on contract, trying to save timber, place their saw-cut too low and some of the wood-fibres break off up in the barrel. These are stringers' while they are breaking, andslivers' or `drawers' when they are left upright in the sloven. (1950,Letter) [NOTES: (Northland)]

REED A draw' was a serious defect, but was not due to any fault in the living tree. When a tree fell before it was quite severed, it sometimes, in the act of falling, wrenched ordrew' out a portion of the butt, leaving great jagged, fang-like splinters adhering to the stump. The damage was, of course, always to the heart wood ... [Ibid. 156 [Edward Thompson] ... very often, before the saw got within a foot or so of the front scarf, the tree would start to fall gradually, and the uncut timber between the saw and the front scarf would have to break, and seldom cleanly; the heart, being more brittle than the sap, would break here and there, several feet above where thesawcut would have been standing straight. As the tree fell, these pieces, still attached to the stump, would draw out of the tree, and being almost heart-wood constituted the chief defect we call `draws'. (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,151) [NOTES: [?c1900]]

draw a marble¶

phr. win an opportunity

Phil Moore's introduction hints at a possible larger gathering next year, but in Hawkes Bay, so even if I'm lucky enough to draw a marble for it, I have still missed a chance to look at those crucial Gisborne areas on the ground in company with some geologists whose competence and judgement I respect and admire. (Jan 1983,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,59/68)

dray¶

n. In NZ of two main types,(1) a high-platformed two-wheeled shafted single-horse-drawn cart with sides, often a `spring dray'; and (2) in early settlement, a bullock-dray-->, a usu. four-wheeled pole-wagon without sides (occas. draycart--> (OED2 1719) as in:

WAKFIELD ... except for the conveyance of heavy goods, for which dray-carts drawn by bullocks are chiefly used, locomotion [in Wellington] is much easier on foot.] See also pack-dray. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,97)

1 v. (Rural) to transport by dray.

C W RICHMOND We found him away 'draying' Mr Moore's wool. (Oct 21, 1857,BLANK ENTRY,318) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers I]

FULLER Such tracks .. for draying down the squatters' produce. (1959,Five Years' Residence in New Zealand,149)

Drayed down goi on R ridge. (Jul 16, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary)

.. peat sheds, from where peat dust was drayed on the paddocks ... (1862,BLANK ENTRY,92) [NOTES: in BEATTIE (1947) Early Runholding]

Wilson draying scrub to Clark. Chaff cutting and draying stones to dam. (Apr 29, 1867,Puketoi Station Diary)

BARKER My house..is being cut out in Christchurch and will be drayed to our station next month. (1869,Station Life in NZ,39) [NOTES: Station Life (1874)]

WOODHOUSE There is mention in the station diary of a contract to 'dray out' the wool for the coming season. [dray in, dray down] (1959,Guthrie-Smith of Tutira,35)
