droppo¶

n.

There is Spit Wilson, a 16-year-old streetwise "droppo" who becomes a courier for the mysterious Mr Blyss. (Sep 26, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

dropsies¶

n. tendency to drop a ball

Umaga suffered the most co-ordinating with new five-eighth combinations, got a case of the dropsies in the test against England and would have found more space playing on a postage stamp. (Jul 13, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B3)

Black Caps catch dose of dropsies (Oct 25, 2005,Dominion Post,C14)

[Hdg] Bad case of the dropsies has Fleming stumped. New Zealand captain Stephen Fleming is baffled by their case of the dropsies against Pakistan at Jade Stadium on Saturday. (Jan 12, 2004,Dominion Post,D10)

drought master¶

n.

These "drought masters" are bred in a harsh environment at Otamauri on the Napier-Taihape Rd. (Jun 20, 2003,Dominion Post,C5)

droughtlander¶

n. an Australian [obs.]

At the dinner to the English cricketers in Melbourne a jovial `drought-lander' with some knowledge of English and fond of music sat beside a dashing batsman of the visiting team. (Dec 7, 1907,NZ Truth,129/3/3)

drove¶

n. The word is in use in NZ, but earlier drive (q.v.) would poss. be preferred.] [?More cits or omit or have one entry at verb.???]

BEATTIE ... this noteworthy drove. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,52)

n. Pa. tense droved; =drive (travelling stock).

Counsel: You drive for a living?' Witness:No, I'm a drover.' Counsel: Well, you drive sheep for a living?' Witness:No; I drove.' Counsel: Do you mean you used to drive?' Witness:No, I drove now.' Counsel: H'mph! What does your brother do?' Witness:He's got a timber contract.' Counsel: Oh, he's a bush faller.' Witness:He's a bush feller.' (Apr 23, 1910,NZ Truth,252/1/6)

drove v.t. to drive animals, as a mob of cattle, etc.; - v.i. to act as a driver of animals. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

see cit. drover. (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

MUIE There must have been great loss and expense in droving the stock overland. (1960,Word for Word,38)

RENNIE During the 1700s ... when great mobs were droved between Scotland and England the specifically Scottish Collie is believed to have come down into England. But the name Borderwas never heard of until after 1900 when it came to denote an area [Scottish or English] in which a series of sheepdog trials were held ... (1985,Working Dogs,7)

v. (Rural) to drive farm stock on hoof.

CRESSWELL 'The way to drove cattle is,' he said afterwards, 'a step and a bite ...' (1949,Early NZ Families,16)

BARDSLEY Margaret met her husband while droving sheep. (2000,Land Girls, The,156)

DOMINY Then men were still droving thousands of sheep off the hillsides ... (2001,Calling the Station Home,176)

1 n. (Rural) the driving of sheep or cattle on foot or hoof, or the stock being driven on foot or hoof.

C W RICHMOND You can tell a drove of sheep a long way off by the cloud of dust which looks, in the valley exactly like smoke. (Mar 28, 1867,Letter,238) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers II]

A short time ago, a drove of full-mouthed ewes from Napier, in rather poor condition, were sold upon arrival at 7s to 9s each. (Aug 1888,NZ Farmer,291)

SILK The Puhoi settlers soon became accustomed to see large droves driven through the settlement; with the result that on the 29th September, 1877, the first cattle sale was held at Puhoi. (1923,History of Puhoi,84)

MILLER Year after year huge droves of sheep used to pass Tauroa for shearing at Waikuku. (1958,Sturdy Sons,171)

SINCLAIR They were not the most civilised cattle on the road .. so the drove was not without incident. (1973,Boot in the Stirrup,45)

ASPINALL Instead of those early droves to Cromwell, taking up to ten days, we can now have a truck and trailer drive into the yards ... (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,102)

.. there are still people who like to buy in autumn and winter, graze their purchases on the highways and by-ways and have them home as spring approaches. Two such droves are in progress. (Jul 13, 1995,NZ Farmer,21)

PULLEN The night paddock was at the bottom end of Arohana Station which isn't too big a drove, but by early afternoon it was raining. (1996,On the Road Again,37)

drove boss¶

1 n. (Rural) a head drover in a large mob, usually droving long-distance.

GORDON Not far into the mob a traveller would come across the first of three drovers. Usually he would be sitting on a horse at a vantage point quietly watching was happening ahead. Generally this would be the 'drove boss.' (1990,Matawhero, Elsewhere and Other Things,32)

drove-track¶

1 n. (Rural) a path by which stock are driven.

GUTHRIE-SMITH .. sometimes an old drove-track can be picked up by its tall manuka at a distance of miles ... (1921,Tutira,183)

drover¶

n. one who drives sheep or cattle for a living. cf stock-driver, stockman.

Two routes were successfully burnt through dense vegetation by determined stock drovers, both converging on the Acheron Valley. (Dec 22, 2003,Dominion Post,B6)

"The Bald Eagle" - Haast cattle drover and horseman Kevin Nolan, 82 when he died, was one of the last links to pioneer days in the South Westland region. (May 8, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

Yes, we're all going to hell in a drover's hat, thanks to environmental exploitation, blind patriotism and.. the media. (May 1, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

...Haast cattle drover and horseman Kevin Nolan, 87 when he died, was one of the last links to pioneer days in the South Westland region. (May 8, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

At Oeo a party of drovers were refreshing themselves, their dogs and their stockwhips. (Jan 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

She knew the drover with the blue eyes only as Jim. (Nov 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

WAKEFIELD Cattle have been driven from Oihoa (or Go-ashore), ... to Akaroa in about eight hours; ... my informant was one of the drovers. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,343) [NOTES: 1842 Nov Capt. Smith's report in 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 343]

... the hills at [the run's] south-west extremity present no serious obstacle to the drover ... (Mar 8, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

E.J. WAKEFIELD Their drovers were forced to abandon them in a labyrinth of mountains. (1851,Letter,12) [NOTES: 1851 E.J. Wakefield Letter to Grey 12]

FITTON The vulgar delusion that, in order to be a colonist in earnest, it is expedient to dress like a drover, ... is now quite out of fashion. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),278)

At Lyttelton. ... Took the sheep over the hill myself with 2 drovers (Mar 2, 1904,Chudleigh Diary,420,1950 ed.)

Drover: One who drives stock for a living. In Canterbury they were usually spoken of as sheep- or cattle-drivers until about 1900. There is a newly formed verb, to drove, trans and intrans, coming into use. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]; stock-driver, C.R., p.104) (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

BEATTIE The drovers camped that night and the next day arrived at Basstina's station. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,112)

BEATTIE In my boyhood [1880s] we called a man driving sheep a drover, and a man driving cattle a stock-driver or stock-rider or stockman. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,12)

MEEK DROVERS: Men who drive sheep or cattle on the road. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

TOMLINSON After camping the night there, we had to cross Kerr's Hill which was covered with tutu, a poisonous plant for sheep, and the curse of drovers. ... Odd sheep started to get `tooted' and instead of pushing on the men started bleeding the sheep. This was done by cutting a veinunder the eye. It was supposed to help the sheep, although I never thought it did any good. (1968,Remembered Trails,19)

THOMAS Starting in the extreme north these drover buyers would buy any cattle they found for sale, mostly store steers ... (1970,Way Up North,55)

drover's dog¶

n.

You could argue that most MPs are only elected because they stand for a viable party: the old "a drover's dog would win Remuera" theory. (May 1, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Labour lost it [sc. the 1990 election] bigtime, and James B was simply the drover's dog. (Apr 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

droving¶

1 n. (Rural) the moving of sheep and other stock on hoof between properties or to railheads, saleyards or wharves.

PLUMMER Towards the end of 1931, after I had been at Puketiti for just on four years, I decided to leave and go droving. (1994,From Drover to Director,43)

Droving's no easy job on East Cape. Long distance droving has certainly changed. (Jul 13, 1995,NZ Farmer,21)

droving party¶

1 n. (Rural) a group of drovers, dogs, horses and their drove.

PASCOE Droving parties used Browning's route to take sheep from Canterbury to Hokitika, an undertaking of more magnitude than could be realised until it was experienced. (1959,Great Days in NZ Exploration,122)

droving team¶

1 n. (Rural) two or more drovers who work together when moving very large mobs of sheep or cattle.

NEWTON Mr and Mrs Swinn claim to be the only man and wife droving team in the country ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,94)

droving trail¶

n.

Ancient trees continue to give shelter, and you can still trace the old droving trail up the adjacent river flat. (May 1996,NZ Historic Places,58/12)

drown the miller¶

phr. to add too much water to liquor, or too much milk or water in tea.

STEWARD ... in mixing my negus I've quite `drowned the miller' ... (1867,Carmina Varia,10)

drowned sailors' purses¶

n. a seaweed (cf. mermaids' beads)

HYDE ... the seaweed known as Drowned Sailors' Purses. (1937,Wednesday's Children,57)

DRSL¶

abbr. Dispute Resolution Services Ltd

Cases are heard by Dispute Resolution Services Ltd - nicknamed Drizzle (DRSL) - when claimants feel they have been unfairly treated. (Nov 17, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A12)

drum¶

n. a rolled swag n1. [(obs. station)]

Got underway, drum and all. (Jan 20, 1898,Otago Witness,62)

ROSS ... Time's up!' is called, thedrum' (the local for swag) hoisted on, and the final ascent begins. (1889,Lakes of Central Otago,44) [NOTES: [Mount Earnslaw Station]]

WRIGHT For the strange gipsy fancy came on me - I longed for the mountain and plain;/ My passport the drum of the whaler, and the old savage freedom again. (1897,Station Ballads,24) [NOTES: `The Hard Case'[Mount Earnslaw Station]]

McKEE WRIGHT I longed for the mountain and plain;/ My passport the drum of the whaler, and the old savage freedom again. (1900,Wisps of Tussock,51)

PICARD You may look down on a man who gives his swag, drum, knot, or parcel of bags a shove round the land ... (1906,Some Ups and Downs in NZ&A,7)

The drummer,' starting from the man who carried a drum, became the man who carried a swag and (then or thereafter) the loaded man (as a commercial traveller loaded with samples). Tocarry the load' is another synonym; and the essential point throughout the symbolry was evidently the load. (Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/14/2)

drum n. a bundle of clothes, etc., wrapped in a blanket; a swag. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

Drum. Swag, obviously from the shape. Hence drummer. (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

BEATTIE 2. And when passing Jimmy Holland's,/ I felt a wee bit queer;/ I thought I'd throw the old drum down/ And have a pint of beer./ ... (1956,Pioneer Recollections,55) [NOTES: 1947-1948 Beattie Pioneer Recollections (1956) 55]

drum n. (Coll.) swag;hump a drum, carry a swag. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

n. a (bawdy) house.

MacKENZIE drum house, lodgings. Also information (1980,While We Have Prisons,96)

Rossini had been fined for keeping a `drum' in Auckland. (Sep 8, 1906,NZ Truth,64/4/7)

n. usu. the drum, correct (esp. horseracing) information; the oil. Also give the drum. Also attrib.

McCALLUM [The race-course tout] says, ... wait till I get the drum.' I say,What's this drum business?' He says: `It's the same as the oil, the griffin, and the low down.' (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,23)

SYDER & HODGETTS To explain or describe. .in 4;`If you haven't operated a winch before, just ask Harry.He's an an old hand at it, he'll give you the drum. (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],408) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 408]

MacKENZIE drum house, lodgings. Also information (1980,While We Have Prisons,96)

NEWBOLD Taylor gave me the usual drum on the rules of the block ... (1982,Big Huey, The,61)

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] Drum 1518 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

v. to give (misleading) information to. [(obs.)]

The unsuspecting lad fell in and drummed everybody that the horse was ?oomey. (Apr 18, 1908,NZ Truth,148/2/6)

As to sheep, some of the mob have drummed me they'll bite if they're disturbed during nesting season, don't have it on your mind that I'm afraid of being bitten by a savage sheep when taking the housemaid out for a walk on Sunday afternoons. (May 6, 1911,NZ Truth,306/4/6)

v. of kakapos, to make their peculiar noise..

HALL-JONES On one occasion the noise of the kakapos drumming on the northern side of the Sound was so loud that he had to put in at Cooper Island for the night. (1968,Early Fiordland,126)

v. steal from a dwelling [criminals' Cf drum n3.]

drum (v.) steal from a dwelling (1980,While We Have Prisons,96)

drum fish¶

n. (See ?drummer 3)

PARKINSON All the coves of this bay teem with fish of various kinds, such as cuttle-fish, large breams, ... small grey breams, small and large barracootas, flying gurnards, horse-mackarel, dog-fish, soles, dabs, mullets, drums, scorpenas or rock-fish, cole-fish, the beautiful fish called chimera, and shags. [In the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C.hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] FlyingGurnards, a flying fish, of a remarkable fine Gold Colour. [double dagger] Chimeras, a fish of Silver Colour - [triple dagger] Drum fish, so call'd from the noise they make, - ' (Jan 15, 1770,Journal,114)

drummer¶

n.

KYPHOSUS SYDNEYANUS Gunther. Drummer. ... Distribution: North Island coasts. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,IV/16)

PARROTT THE DRUMMER Kyphosus sydneyanus< (Gunther) (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,101)

GRAHAM Drummer Segutilum sydneyanum (Gunther) (Syn. Pachymetopon and Pimelepterus drewii Hector) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,407) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 407]

WILSON DRUMMER Inhabitant of more northern, rocky waters down to about 100 feet (30.48 metres) the Drummer, or Silver Drummer as he is sometimes known, is characterised by his stout shape and small mouth and head. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,60)

MORELAND DRUMMER [Kyphosus sydneyanus<] ... Silver drummer is an alternative name. (1967,Marine Fishes,42)

DOOGUE & MORELAND DRUMMER ... Other names: Kyphosus sydneyanus; silver drummer. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,240)

NATUSCH Family KYPHOSIDAE. We have just one kyphosid, the oval drummer, Kyphosus sydneyanus..., a small-mouthed fish with small soft scales covering head, body and fins; it has an outer row of cutting teeth and fine teeth on the jaws and roof of the mouth (vomer). About thirty inches long, ... (1967,Animals of NZ, The,221)

drummer ... NZ & Austral. ... NZ greyish-green oval fish. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,231) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] drummer 1505-14 DRUMMERS 1491-1523 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n. the slowest (often the learner) shearer in a gang [(station)]

The drummer,' starting from the man who carried a drum, became the man who carried a swag and (then or thereafter) the loaded man (as a commercial traveller loaded with samples). Tocarry the load' is another synonym; and the essential point throughout the symbolry was evidently the load. ... and a drummer' is the man with the lowest tally - perhaps because he is likeliest to take and keep the track with hisload.' The general applications of these fresh significations may be doubted. (Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker,18/14/2)

Drummer.-The slowest shearer in a shed. (Jan 20, 1934,Press, The,15)

NEWTON Hewett, the learner, and `' of the gang with seventeen to his credit had also shown an improvement. (1949,High Country Days,55)

PARTRIDGE Drummer. 8. Slowest shearer in a shed: New Zealand shearers': since ca. 1890. Niall Alexander letter of Oct. 22, 1939. Perhaps ex sense 1. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1037)

RINGER. The fastest shearer in the gang. Fast men are also known as guns,' and the slowest man in the shed as thedrummer.' (1949,High Country Days,197,1950 ed.)

ACLAND Drummer: The slowest shearer in a shed. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,366)

MEEK DRUMMER: The shearer with the lowest aggregate tally of shorn sheep. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

BOWEN DRUMMER. The slowest shearer on the board. He shears at the bottom of the board, the furthest away from the wool table. (1956,Wool Away!,156)

MASTERS ... I was only the drummer (slowest shearer) of that particular gang, ... [1925 - North Canterbury] (1960,Back-Country Tales,255)

Drummer: Slowest shearer on the board who shears at the bottom of the board furthest away from the wool table. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,54)

RICHARDS Fred, being the ganger, was on No. 1 stand. Mick was No. 2, Thornton No. 3, and I, being a learner, was on the traditional `drummer's' stand, at the far end of the board. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,73)

drummer: The name given to the shearer with the lowest daily tally. He is not necessarily a bad or lazy shearer, but simply slower than the rest, and in a group of good shearers he could be quite competent, but not as good as the others. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/24) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. a swagger [(rare in NZ)]

Drum. Swag, obviously from the shape. Hence drummer. (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

McGILL drummer swagman or tramp. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40)

n. (Rural) a swagger.

LOUGHNAN drummer: a swagger. This obviously comes from the shape of his swag-roll. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,29)

1 n. (Rural) a slowest, most novice shearer in a gang.

MEEK drummer - the shearer with the lowest aggregate tally of shorn sheep. (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,110)

MILLS ET AL Jack O'Rourke, the ringer, quietly and grimly ordered the drummer to leave the boy alone. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,122)

LOUGHNAN drummer: the slowest shearer in the shed. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,29)

GORDON Right down the other end of the board, sweating and grunting is the "drummer", the youngest and slowest member of the gang. Still learning the game and strengthening his wrists, the drummer's not the sort of bloke that goes in for a 'catch.' (1983,Other Side of Farming, The,ii 1)

GORDON Despite the popularity of the faster machines blade shearing is still taught at special wool board shearing courses and in the last half of each year gangs are still hard at it in the Southern high country - chasing the ringer, ripping bootlaces, going for a catch and shoving an extra cobbler into the drummer's pen. (1983,Other Side of Farming, The,2)

2 n.

AYLING BLUEFISH (Blue drummer, korokoropounamu) Girella cyanea ... As the name suggests their body colour is a uniform bright blue and all the fins are a similar colour. (1982,Collins Guide,229,1984 ed.)

2 n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] drummer, oval 1505 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

drunk as a skunk/drunk as a wheelbarrow¶

phr. very drunk

Drunk as a skunk, with his whiskers skewed,/ (Mar 1953,Here & Now,14) [NOTES: (A.Vogt)]

There's old timers we knew, and some who shot through A hard case, drag the chain, done a bunk, As busy as a blow fly, and bugalugs - from the boo-ai The rouseabout, as drunk as a skunk. (Dec 2004,NZ Memories,p18)

CRUMP Drunk as a skunk he was. b. drunk as a wheelbarrow. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,182)

SANSOM Further up the creek beyond the site of the old still a pretty waterfall tumbles through the native bush. Adam's ale is the only tipple on tap there today. No one will get as drunk as a wheelbarrow on that. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,41)

drunk as chooks¶

phr.

"This lot were as drunk as chooks, " Mr Georgantis said. (Nov 9, 1998,Dominion,3)

HUGHES Pissed as proverbial chooks, they had got stuck into the top shelf early at their own party and now they roared into the car park shrieking and howling like weasels on speed. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,214)

drunk's express¶

n. a common term in NZ cities in days of 6 o'clock closing for a tram, bus or train which left the terminal shortly after the hotel-bars closed at 6.00 pm. [ca1920 p.c. Prof. P.S. Ardern Auckland: a 6 o'clock tram, then bus. ca1950 Wellington, the trains leaving soon after 6 p.m. for the Hutt or Paekakariki.] (See shicker express)

drunkie¶

n. a drunk (person).

BALLANTYNE Near by [sic] a drunkie fell over and hit his head but got up painfully and wobbled on. (1948,Cunninghams, The,68,1976 ed.)

dry¶

adj. of a claim or workings, removed from water; occas., not liable to flooding or seepage. See also dry diggings.

The account of the Gully which he gives is, that fair prospects have been found there, and his opinion is that a party can make an ounce a man, as the sinking is very shallow, and the working dry. (Sep 20, 1861,NZ Goldfields,13) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 20 in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 13]

adj. (with respect to alcohol) [Jim Cameron writes: NSOD gives the general sense, but the words (dry area) and several compounds have considerable historic significance in NZ from the 1890s almost up to the the present. DNZE does not record these - wet/dry area, district, vote; go wet, stay dry. NZPOD has no entry for wet in this sense but does for dry.]

[Caption] In the early days of its history the Corbans winery was located in a 'dry' electorate; the small white building in the background, situated across the railway lines in a 'wet' area was used for many years as the company's sale depot. (Jun 1991,Cuisine,83)

Mr Halford remembers when there was a post office, six churches, three hotels, three garages, two grocers, two tearooms, blacksmiths and wheelwrights, a bakery, bank, drapery, hardware, watchmaker and a town hall, where the ladies smuggled in liquor to the dances under their wide skirts in the days when the district was "dry". (Jan 5, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,1)

This is a "dry" town with no licensed hotels. (Mar 3, 1938,NZ Observer,7)

John says they considered turning it into a restaurant because it is so far up the hill it is just outside the Tawa boundary - and therefore out of the "dry" liquor area. Tawa was a dry area until it went wet following the election. (Jan 13, 2000,Evening Post,11)

The hotel was closed when the district went "dry" in 1906, the bar reopening for business in 1998. (Jun 2004,NZ Memories,No. 48/41)

Paeroa is "dry". (Sep 20, 1913,NZ Observer,4)

From that date [1906] the town was legally "dry". (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(17) : 3)

HUTT The east coast remained 'dry' until 1922 when special enabling legislation made a second poll possible. (1999,Maori & Alcohol,67)

Prior to the last general election Tawa was one of the only three dry suburbs in New Zealand. (Oct 4, 2000,Capital Times,17)

In 1864 came the proclamation that made the first part of the King Country - the Te Kuiti, Otorohanga and Kawhia districts - "dry". (Sep 23, 1953,NZ Observer,6)

The Horouta district went "dry" in 1911. (Dec 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,23)

It is said.. that in some "dry" places they will get up a smoke concert to celebrate a fellow having got over a severe stomach ache. (Jan 8, 1910,NZ Truth,4)

v.

[Hdg] When to "Dry" Cows. (May 7, 1892,Auckland Weekly News,34)

adj. (of cows) not producing milk [in ODE]

There is a difference of opinion in regard to the time cows should become dry before calving. (May 7, 1892,Auckland Weekly News,34)

As soon as the cows are nearly dry, I am going for my holidays. (Mar 11, 1924,Otago Witness,64)

1 n. (Rural) a female animal that has not produced offspring after mating, either through non-conception or miscarriage, or a castrated male animal.

And while about 3% dries was the norm, this year it is up to 12%. 'We normally sell our dries but we've kept the better condition ones to help eliminate a cashflow problem later on when we would have to buy in ewes.' [drystock] (Aug 12, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,15)

2 adj. of sheep, not too wet to prevent shearing [[Get cits from discards.]]

2 adj. [1971 Boxing Day Kendrick Smithyman loquat: It was so dry there that even the rabbits were taking cut lunches.]

dry as a sack of gum dust¶

phr.

SATCHELL But Andersen seemed neither drunk nor mad as he entered the store ... Then he approached the storekeeper and whispered something in his ear. Not a taste,' said the latter aloud.Dry as a sack of gum dust, I give you my word.' (1895,Toll of the Bush,154)

dry as a wooden god¶

phr.

... I went to sleep with the light on and woke up at one-thirty in the morning dry as a wooden god. (Mar 3, 1950,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9) [NOTES: (P. Llewellyn)]

SLATTER ` ... let's get crackin on our own tank-up. Over to the bar at the high port. I'm dry as a wooden god.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,181)

McGILL dry as a wooden god very dry or thirsty; popular NZ Navy WWII. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40)

dry as the rim of a lime-burner's hat¶

phr. of a person, very dry, thirsty (prob. an occas. use during WW1 from Eng dial of EDD dry as a lime-burner's clog. (Cumb); nf W3).

I'm as dry as the rim of a lime-burner's hat. (Jun 7, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,205)

dry blow¶

v. of gold

dry country sheep¶

1 n. (Rural) a breed of sheep e.g. Corriedale that flourishes on dry pasture where it is not prone to footrot.

GORDON The biggest thing is that they can stand this climate a lot better than the Romneys. They're a dry country sheep. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,58)

dry cow¶

1 v. (Rural) to use dry-cow therapy for mastitis. (See dry-cow therapy)

We do not dry cow and have not had to use antibiotics to treat a cow since we started using homeopathics. (Mar 13, 2001,Fencepost.com,Homeopathic.)

dry diggings¶

n.

HOCHSTETTER The conglomerates accumulated on the slopes of the mountains are the proper field for the "dry diggings", while from the gravel and sand streams the gold is obtained by "wet diggings". (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),104)

HOCHSTETTER & PETERMAN By the gradual wearing away of these rocks ... large masses of debris have been formed, and nature itself has executed an operation of gold-washing, by collecting the heavier particles and depositing them in the gullies of streams, or in the conglomerates covering the slopes of the hills. There are, therefore, two principal descriptions of diggings; either river diggings', in the beds of streams, ordry diggings', in the conglomerate and gravel accumulated on the slopes of the mountains. (1864,Geology NZ,88)

dry dry¶

1 n. (Rural) a barren ewe or one that has not conceived a lamb in a season.

.. increasing lambing percentage by using recommended teachniques such as culling dry-dry and wet-dry ewes and shearing two-tooth before tupping. (Dec 1964,NZ Journal of Agriculture,463)

Dry dry ewes amounted to about four per cent, which is nothing much. (Dec 9, 1976,NZ Farmer,45)

Last season they recorded 7.2% ewe deaths over winter and lambing, wet dries were 7.8% dry dry 1.7% and 15% lamb deaths. (Jun 1, 1994,NZ Farmer,22)

KERR 'Get the dry dries, the wet dries and the late wets' .. When Nimmo came by me, I asked him to translate. The first were fat barren ewes destined for harder territory, the second were those who lost their lambs destined for harder territory, and then he too was gone, but I figured 'late wets' were late lambers who'd want a wee spell before their lambs were docked. (2000,High Times in the High Country)

dry ewe¶

1 n. (Rural) a ewe that is barren or has lost her lamb.

MCKENNY Another good plan is to shear all wethers, hoggets, and dry ewes first and to defer, somewhat, the shearing of the wet ewes. (1927,Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.,14)

BLAKISTON The dry shearing (hoggets, rams, wethers, and dry ewes) was done in November, and the wet ewes were shorn after weaning in February. (1952,My Yesteryears,23)

SALISBURY October arrived and so did the shearing gang to do the dry shearing as it was called, or in other words, the hoggets and any wethers that may have been run through, and the dry ewes. (1994,I Was So Lucky,24)

dry hash¶

n. a baked (highly seasoned) dish made out of leftovers or oddments of meat, vegetable, breadcrumbs, without the addition of water; a dry kind of `shepherd's pie'. [DNZE says also dried hash, but no cit.]

WALKER ... moist and `dry' hashes. (1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,57)

[Miss Wilson] accomplished the impossible by abolishing Tuesday's abomination called Dry Hash [at Nelson Boy's College]. (Dec 4, 1983,NZ Times,8) [NOTES: [c1930s]]

There was a pretty hubbub in a toney Wellington hash-house last week ... the bachelors in these dry-hash establishments ... (Oct 7, 1905,NZ Truth,16/4/7)

HYDE `Dry hash, corned beef, then again the stew, ... (1934,Journalese,209)

HYDE `'Ere, take this. Not much, it ain't. Dry 'ash.' ... Dry hash, sailor. (1936,Passport to Hell,223)

dry horrors¶

n. the D.T's.

There's hoodlums, hoodackys and hoodunnits Funny money, down the dunny, join the club The guy with dry horrors - drowning his sorrows little Johnny, Little horror, the Little grub. (Dec 2004,NZ Memories,p18)

Dry horrors.-State of a shepherd when back from a bust in town. (Jan 20, 1934,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

Dry Horrors: State of a shepherd when back from a bust in town. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,366) [NOTES: Glossary]

dry off¶

v. (Rural) [used elsewhere but first recorded in New Zealand] to cease the milking of dairy cows to prepare for calving.

Some practical dairymen have found that to resort to rather violent measures to dry off a cow that is a very persistent milker, lessens the cow's performance the next year. (Dec 22, 1888,Egmont Star,12)

What is the best method to use when drying off cows? (Jun 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,381)

The milk sugar should be got rid of as quickly as possible when time came for drying the cow off and this was best accomplished by completing the drying-off in the minimum time. Treating the subject at length, Mr Wood said that a cow should not be 'dried off' as was commonly understood and practised, but should be left alone and allowed to do so naturally. (Aug 9, 1924,Hawera Star,10)

TINSLEY As in most other companies [dairy companies] the milk supply had all but stopped as cows were dried off for the winter months. (1985,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,163)

Drying off cows early does not prevent this season's production target being achieved. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,10)

TINSLEY If the trend reveals the cows are losing condition rapidly, dry-off thinner cows or take other remedial action. [dry-off] (1993,Cheese Punchers' Ball, The,68)

The cows were nearly all dried off. (Jun 1951,Landfall,5(2) 18 : 112)

ANTHONY The cows were being dried off for the winter, and he was occupying his spare time doing up fences and cleaning out drains. (1936,Follow the Call,144)

It is generally believed that all sorts of devious things happen to a cow which is not "dried off" before being burned out. (Nov 30, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,86)

dry scree community¶

n.

The Torlesse range within its boundaries supports dry scree communities, tussock, mountain beech and totara. (Jul 16, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

dry shearing¶

n. the shearing of dry (rather than lambing) sheep

BLAKISTON The dry shearing (hoggets, rams, wethers and dry ewes) was done in November, and the wet ewes were shorn after weaning in February. (1952,My Yesteryears,20) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

1 n. (Rural) the shearing of wethers, hoggets and dry ewes.

Dry shearing progressed as the weather permitted. (Dec 20, 1951,NZ Farmer,6)

BLAKISTON The dry shearing (hoggets, rams, wethers, and dry ewes) was done in November, and the wet ewes were shorn after weaning in February. (1952,My Yesteryears,23)

SALISBURY October arrived and so did the shearing gang to do the dry shearing as it was called, or in other words, the hoggets and any wethers that may have been run through, and the dry ewes. (1994,I Was So Lucky,24)

dry sheep¶

n.

The first round of dry sheep (wethers, hoggets and rams) and second round of wet sheep (ewes and lambs) each require seven days' shearing, ... (1973,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,70)

dry stock¶

1 n. (Rural) dry ewes, wethers or steers or any stock not used for breeding purposes.

The dry stock are rotated around the farm and the paddocks are shut up for winter grown saved grass. (Jan 15, 1953,NZ Journal of Agriculture,4)

CONNELL & HADFIELD When the paddock has been fed off, dry stock are turned in, or the mower used, to clean up any roughage. (1961,Agriculture,305)

It is easy to justify taking drystock off wet paddocks. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,32)

Cheryl's husband, Geoff, mainly farms drystock on their 108 hectares, but he also grazes the odd dairy herd [drystock] (Sep 3, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,5)

dry stock country¶

n.

LEVY Aerial topdressing also makes possible, on relatively clean country, the translation of dry stock country to wet stock country by its promo-[259]tion of richer growth ... (1951,Grasslands of NZ,258,1970 ed.)

dry till¶

n. a situation where the host or organising body of a function is paying for drinks etc. ["When I am invited to a function and told that there will be a dry till, I am never quite certain initially whether it means that I pay or the organisation does but I think the latter." [P.M.MacCallum]]

Dry Valley¶

n.

McPHERSON Transecting the Transantarctic Mountains west of McMurdo Sound are three ice and snow-free valleys collectively called the Dry Valleys. The valleys extend from the 2,750 m Polar Plateau in the west to within a short distance of the sea. Along with some smaller subsidiary valleys the system constitutes the largest ice-free area in Antarctica, a total of approximately 4,000 square km. (1975,Footprints on a Frozen Continent,64,1979 ed.)

McPHERSON The Dry Valley Region is a geologist's paradise because of the excellent exposure of rock, without grass, trees, soil or snow, to hide it. (1975,Footprints on a Frozen Continent,85,1979 ed.)

Throughout the summer Vanda Station proved its value as a staging station for parties operating within the Dry Valley region... Apart from making measurements throughout the year of the climate of this unique "Dry Valley" area and of the "hot" lake near the station, the wintering-over party also carry out upper atmosphere physics and earthquake observations in conjunction with Scott Base. (1969,AJHR,H34 : 65)

KNIGHT Frighteningly, as this book was going to press, newspapers in New Zealand reported a significant rise in Lake Vanda, in the Dry Valley region of the Ross Dependency. (1988,Icebound,113)

There are three main Dry Valleys, the Victoria Valley in the north, the Taylor Valley in the south and the Wright Valley in the west. Together these three valley systems expose 4000 km2 of moraines, sediments and rocks - an oasis on the edge of the ice sheet. (1978,NZ Antarctic Record,1(1) : 15)

The Dry Valleys were originally discovered in 1903 by Scott, Evans and Lashly and since the rediscovery by geologists Peter Webb and Barrie McKelvey in 1957, the work of summer field parties, including geologists, chemists and physicists, led to the decision to winter at Vanda Station. (Mar 1970,Antarctic,5(9) : 371)

dry vote¶

n.

dry vote: See `declare them wet'. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/24) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

dry's-a-bone¶

n. (trademark) an oilskin raincoat [also Drizabone]

The place was stuffed with diners of all stripes, from the suits to the denim brigade to women in polar fleeces accompanied by gents in drizabones and shooting caps. (Sep 2000,North & South,125)

We watched as Ra, in a dry's-a-bone raincoat herded the great unwashed from the door, instructed them to get a bit of tucker on board and fly right before attempting to breast the tape of the pub door. (Apr 14, 2001,Evening Post,2)

Clarke's drizabone delivery is perfect for the task. (May 20, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

The All Blacks even export the colonial Drizabone look. (Nov 20, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

dry, the¶

1 n. (Rural) [used in Aust.] dryness, dry spell or drought.

GASCOIGNE We've had an awful lot of the dry. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,51)

dry-chucker-in¶

n.

BREMNER A description of an unidentified sheepstation in 1881 recorded that a twenty-two man gang ... put through [the sheep-wash] 1250 sheep in a ... day. The yarder-up' kept the pen nearest the wash full of sheep. Twodry-chuckers-in' forced sheep through a swing door where they fell four feet into a 20-foot wooden trough full of hot soapy water. ... The trough was divided into four partitions with a crutcher' at each. Four times each sheep was soaped, its back scrubbed with a crutch. ... At the end of the trough threewet-chuckers-in' hauled frightened sheep out and sent them down three slides to the cold-water rinsing wells. Each well had two spouts of cold water and four hands called `spouters' who tilted the sheep, parting the wool (1985,Woolscours of NZ,15) [NOTES: 1881]

dry-cow therapy¶

1 n. (Rural) a treatment of newly dried off cows with a long term slow acting antibiotic to prevent mastitis.

The objects of dry cow therapy are 1) to eliminate existing infections of the udder 2) to prevent new infections during the dry period. Dry cow therapy helps protect the cow against these new infections because antibiotics are present in the udder for many weeks. (Feb 23, 1978,NZ Farmer,17)

A warning against farmers expecting 100 per cent results from dry cow therapy can be a valuable tool against mastitis. The Wallaceville researchers said that dry cow therapy was unable to eliminate all infections or prevent reinfection or new infection during the dry period. (Apr 29, 1980,NZ Dairy Exporter)

Dairyfarmers should note those cows affected and consider greater use of dry-cow therapy at drying-off. (Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,03)

The way dry-cow therapy is used is critical to success .. Do not milk the cows the last time they are brought to the shed, but give them dry-cow therapy. (Mar 1987,NZ Dairy Exporter,36)

Dry cow therapy should be done immediately after a cow's last milking. (Feb 7, 1990,NZ Farmer,19)

The cell count average is low, all cows will be dry by sale day and will have been dry cow therapy treated. [dry cow therapy] (May 19, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,18)

dry-fleeced¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sheep] sheltered from dew or weather prior to shearing.

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR After tea Bill had to help pack the shed with another cut of dry-fleeced sheep for the morning run. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,49)

dry-goat therapy¶

1 n. (Rural) administration of antibiotics when a dairy goat is dried off. (See dry-cow therapy)

Whole-herd dry-goat therapy is likely to reduce BTSCC more than part-herd ... (2002,Lifestyle Farmer,April/May 10)

dry-off¶

1 n. (Rural) the cessation of milking of dairy cows or goats.

On day of dry-off, draft and do dry-goat treatment ... (2002,Lifestyle Farmer,April/May 10)

dry-skin¶

adj. [Is this merely a descriptive term or is the punct. astray: = a dry skin, itching for growth ...'Write Alpers.]

MANSFIELD All that day the heat was terrible. The wind blew close to the ground - rooted among the tussock grass - slithered along the road, so that the white pumice dust swirled in our faces - settled and sifted over us and was like a dry-skin itching for growth on our bodies. (1912,Stories,109,1984 Alpers ed.)

dryblowing¶

n. a process where a draught of air is used to separate esp. gold particles from attendant rubbish.

BAKER The finding of gold brought ... nuggeting, dryblowing ... (1941,NZ Slang,28)

dry-blowing n. gold-mining term, separating gold by placing pounded material in one dish, pouring it slowly from a height into another, and allowing the wind or a bellows to blow the dross away. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

drying green¶

n. an outdoor paddock fitted so that fibre material can be spread or hung out ro dry or bleach.

CARR A number of stations ... run a scour ... From five to seven men are generally employed ... at the wash, and the balance on the drying green. ... The work on the green [at the port scour] is practically the same as on a sheep station. (1913,Country Work,18)

CARR [The flax fibre] is carted ... to the drying green, generally called the paddock', where it is spread out to dry and bleach. ... It is [then] taken in hand by thescutcher', who feeds it into a revolving drum ... which beats the refuse out. (1913,Country Work,44)

drying house¶

n. a building for drying sealskins. [(sealers')]

McNAB ... drying house [for seal-skins] (1907,Murihiku) [NOTES: 1795 Log of `Endeavour' Capt Brampton in 1907 McNab Murihiku]

drying off¶

n.

While long lactation is an important factor for high production per cow, consulting officers occasionally advise early drying off to build up reserves of feed for the winter. (Feb 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,52)

1 n. (Rural) [dairy cows] the ceasing of lactation to bear calves.

In general the drying off process should be commenced at least two months before calving. (Jun 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,381)

The milk sugar should be got rid of as quickly as possible when time came for drying the cow off and this was best accomplished by completing the drying-off in the minimum time. (Aug 9, 1924,Hawera Star,10)

They always aim to have a paddock or two of grass on the wintering area of the farm closed up and spelled ready for the herd at drying off. (1950,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,18)

Treatment of a dairy herd should be routine at drying-off time as this corresponds well with their greatest danger period from lice. (Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,68)

Could it be that poor cow condition at drying-off had a big part in the spring problem? [drying-off; drying-off time] (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,10)

drying paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a paddock where fibrous flax hemp, straw and wool are dried.

CHINN We had on hand, ready for shipping, sixty bales of dressed hemp, besides a quantity of fibre in the drying paddock. (1963,Packtrack to Highway,121)

KERR Out of the tanks, a machine feeds the retted straw (and it absorbs three times its own weight of water) on to the drying paddocks. (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,292)

BREMNER In front behind the wooden fence is the draining stage from which wool was carried in baskets to the drying paddock. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,38)

JOHNSTON After the fibre had been taken to the drying paddocks, spread on the ground, turned (sometimes twice), and in the wintertime hung on the fences to allow drying to take place ... (1990,Redan, Valley of Farming and Flaxmilling,178)

BRITTAIN .. the wool was cleaned of grease and dirt in steam boilers, rinsed, spun dry and manhandled onto scrim sheets. These were carted in open drays to the drying paddocks. [drying green, drying field] (2000,Lake Coleridge,84)

drying skids¶

n.

HENDERSON DRYING SKIDS: Raised wooden frames for drying sawn timber. (1961,Friends in Chains,186) [NOTES: >c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 186]

drying yard¶

1 n. (Rural) a draining yard, attached to sheep-dips.

BARNS-GRAHAM These two drying yards will each hold two hundred big sheep, which gives the sheep time to dry a little, and to let the dip drain off, before the other yard is full ... (1950,Sheep Station New Zealand,87)

drying-fence¶

1 n. (Rural) a flax farm fence, used to hang and dry flax prior to processing.

He has erected in a good level paddock no less than seven and a half miles of drying-fences and is therefore now in a position to bleach to advantage and with a minimum of loss. (Sep 15, 1911,NZ Journal of Agriculture,246)

dryland¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of farms, land or farmers] located in a low rainfall or drought area.

One of the major problems limiting production on dryland farms in Canterbury is the lack of feed to flush breeding ewes. (Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,54)

It appears that maize greenfeed will play an important role on dryland farms in Canterbury for years to come. (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,55)

It [saltbush] is readily acceptable to stock, provides good shelter, and can be used to produce 'forage banks' on exposed, sunny, erosion-prone faces with other dryland pasture plants growing between bushes. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,59)

While Dr Moot said he was encouraged to see many dryland farmers returning to lucerne as a high-quality feed suitable for drought-prone soils, farmers could soon lose heart with stem nematode attack. (Nov 23, 2000,Press, The,21)

.. if it is a dryland property, destocking in the summer months is a typical strategy. The Corriedale has been bred for a dryland environment ... (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,Aug/Sept 43)

dryland browntop¶

n. (See grass)

drymill¶

n. [timber industry]

Drymill operator opportunity .. We have an employment opportunity for a male or female drymill operator in our Drymill at our Whirnaki [sic] site, north of Napier. (Oct 25, 2003,Hawke's Bay Today,D1)

Drysdale¶

n. a NZ breed of sheep yielding a coarse wool used in carpet manufacture [after Dr F.W.Dry, 1891-1979, agricultural geneticist].

BROOKING Much of the credit for producing the Drysdale breed must go to its original ancestor the Neilson ram lamb named "Pa Neilson", which... had such a hairy coat that Dry had to invent another category which he named the "N"-grade in honour of its owner. (1977,Massey - Its Early Years,87)

He cites the example of the Drysdale sheep, a wool breed developed in the 1950 for the carpet industry, that has now virtually disappeared from New Zealand farms. (Oct 25, 2002,Dominion Post,C6)

The man who developed the Drysdale sheep breed, Dr Francis William Dry has died in Palmerston North. He was [87 years old.] Dr Dye was born in Driffield, Yorkshire, and educated at Bridlington School and Leeds University from which he graduated in 1925 as a Doctor of Science. He came to New Zealand in 1929 to be a lecturer at the newly-founded Massey Agricultural College. Shortly after his arrival Dr Dry discovered a ram lamb in a flock near Palmerston North which had an extremely hairy fleece due to an abundance of halo-hairs. Dr Dry's successful efforts to isolate the gene in Romney led to the development of the Drysdale. Dr Dry devoted nearly 40 years studying the genetic makeup of the fleece of the sheep and published many papers. He retired from Massey University in 1956 as Professor of Animal Genetics but continued his interest in the Drysdale till his death. (Jul 17, 1979,Dominion,5/1)

Drysdale n. NZ breed of sheep developed from Romneys and Cheviots yielding wool which when blended with crossbred wool is suitable for carpet making. [F.W. Dry, agricultural scientist] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,231) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 149]]

Drysdales are brighter, too. That was one of the best of the series, the year they used drysdales. (May 24, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep, developed in the 1960s from a hairy-fibred Romney and Cheviot-cross, esp. for carpet production. [after Dr F W Dry (1891-1979) geneticist and hair biologist]

The Drysdale .. produces the best carpet wool in the world. (Dec 1970,NZ Journal of Agriculture,69)

Drysdales will give an increase in wool weight per sheep per year, and as good or better lambing percentages. (Nov 13, 1975,NZ Farmer,60)

WARMAN The Drysdale is descended from one of nature's genetic freaks that became the subject of pure scientific research. (1991,What Sheep is that?,28)

MEADOWS The Drysdale was developed during the 1960s into a commercial breed, and its medullated wool fibre is now a vital component in New Zealand carpet blends. (1997,Sheep Breeds of New Zealand,48)

drystock farmer¶

1 n. (Rural) a farmer who grazes stock but does not breed them.

One drystock farmer, who has ben rearing calves for a number of years, said his situation had become a nightmare. (Jul 27, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,15)

Many drystock farmers used to deal in dairy grazers when the return was 5 - 8c/kg DM ... (Feb 22, 2002,Fencepost.com,Expert farmer Livestock)

DSIR¶

abbr. (historical) Department of Scientific and Industrial Research.

Gee Neville and I went to Auckland, where I worked for the DSIR again, in limnology as well as mycology. (2005,Blindsight,52)

DSP¶

abbr. deer slaughter premise

YEREX By the end of that year [1980] several deer slaughter premises (DSP's) were under construction and agreement had been reached with the West German market to accept farmed deer slaughtered on licenced [sic] premises as `game' - an important concession. (1982,Farming of Deer,77)

[Hdg] `DUB' ENDS IN DEATH/ ... Philip was being doubled on the bicycle ... (Oct 30, 1966,Sunday Times (NZ),44)

DSW¶

abbr. Department of Social Welfare

The Department of Social Welfare (DSW) used a system which effectively blocked approvals for prospective parents or delayed a decision so long that many gave up. (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Children in DSW care SIR, We applaud the fact that the Department of Social Welfare is taking steps which will enable a genuine bicultural sensitivity to begin to operate, (Sep 5, 1987,Evening Post,6)

DTC¶

abbr. direct-to-consumer

I'm all for direct-to-consumer advertising of prescription medicines... I don't like the inference behind your story that DTC is somehow bad. (Jul 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

DTs¶

abbr. Delirium tremens

abbr. detentions [Detentions. [nf OED2] -->1984 16 M E79 Pakuranga Coll. 23 D TE'S -->1984 16-17 F E7 Pakuranga Coll. 23 D.T. [F7M9] -->1984 15-17 F E51 Pakuranga Coll. 23 D.T.'S, D.T.S. [F19M7]]

dual purpose sheep¶

1 n. (Rural) a sheep from which production has an equal emphasis on wool and meat.

MEADOWS Dual purpose sheep: sheep from which production has an equal emphasis on wool and meat. (1997,Sheep Breeds of New Zealand,89)

dual-purpose¶

adj. of sheep, bred for both wool and meat production. [OMIT covered by OED2 dual 3, of cattle breeds.] [farmers']

BOWEN ... Merinos, run on hard, dry country, are much lighter to handle than `dual purpose', or mutton breeds run on high-producing lands... The Corriedale is a very popular dual- [132] purpose breed, with a good heavy fleece of quality wool, and an excellent carcass, which makes the Corriedale ewe ideal for producing fat lambs. (1955,Wool Away!,131)

dub¶

n. Often pl. Cheap clay marbles, esp. ones put down to be fired at; a marble game or action where marbles are laid down, usu. in a ring, to be fired at. Compare also dub in (marbles). [cf also: [(children's) ca1918-20 Auckland p.c. a male informant 66 years old (c1978) to Professor Graeme Kennedy. A common term in Auckland in the 1920s]

SUTTON-SMITH Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as taw' orshooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; dubs',dates', stakes',dukes', or changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. [175] Here is Little Ring as played in Waitara, Taranaki, in 1899: A team would consist of six to eight boys [order of shooting determined] ... An oval ring was decribed in the earth by means of a stick, and each player woulddub in' one marble ... A line was drawn some six or eight feet away, as the firing line, and the first player sang out `Fire!' as he fired the first shot.] (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

SUTTON-SMITH It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such asRinger, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/770)

SUTTON-SMITH Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (child marble-players') (1981,History of Children's Play,269)

n. a double-decker tramcar [(obs.)]

... so that our next-to-eldest can get away at 7.45 to catch the `8 o'clock dub.' This double-decker tram must have been on the tracks for close on fifty years. (Mar 1954,Parson's Packet,3)

v. [ca1938 Havelock schoolchildren. Also Taranaki (DEH)]

ADSETT No luck tonight, I'll have to dub you home to keep me hands in practice. Never touched the handle-bars once last time. (1963,Magpie Sings, A,177)

dub v.t. (bb.) ... N.Z. colloq. = double-bank. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,231) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 149]]

NICKY: I was dubbing my little brother down the footpath and this van comes out from behind these bushes. (Jul 20, 1987,Evening Post,18)

v. a cockfighting term

SEDDON Cock fighting was a favoured sport on the goldfields and some very gallant birds were bred for this old English pastime. At Marsden, a secluded mining township in the bush some distance from Kumara, many cock fights were fought and a lot of money changed hands over the fate of these fights called `mains.' One of the cockers gave my father a beautiful white cock, his comb dubbed, trimmed and fighting fit. (1986,Seddons, The,16) [NOTES: c1880s in Seddon The Seddons (1968) 16]

n. short for double-bank; horseback ride behind the rider or on the bar of a bicycle [Common usage in 1930s ca1938 Havelock schoolchildren. -->ca1940 Wellington (R. Mason) -->ca1951 Professor A.B. Cochrane (Wellington)]

McGILL doub/dub/dubb short for doubling', in context of giving someone a lift on your bike; Australians preferdouble-bank' or `double-dink'. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,39)

n. (graffiti term)

Leaving the ranks of bored adolescents getting quick thrills from quick tags (toys, as the amateurs are called), she has gone on to the more esteemed throwup or bomb (a tag in fat letters with the outline coloured in), then the dub (a throwup with an outer line and bubbles), and finally the piece, short for masterpiece (a dub with filled in letters and a painted background). (Jan 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

2 n.

SUTTON-SMITH In this [West Coast version of Duckstones] the duckstone belonged to the He. As soon as he put his duckstone on the big stone the game commenced and the others began to fire their own `dubs' at the duckstone. (1972,Folkgames of Children,167)

HISLOP In my hurry into tea [at the hotel] I planted them [the watches] all in a small drawer at the side of the old-fashioned duchesse, ... (1943,Pure Gold,17)

dub fern¶

n.

SHEPHERD The uphill land produces scarcely anything but very dwarf Tea trees dub fern and a great quantity of a plant something like what we call in England Cats tail grass which indicats [sic] the ground to be inclined to wet (Mar 22, 1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Mar 22 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 362]

dub in¶

v. contribute var. of dob in [CHECK], to put in a share of esp.money into a pool. [[But this is surely merely OED2 dub v&sup4. Make a contribution 1823-.] OMIT -->ca1945 Wellington]

It must have been that year that Johnnie and Ginge and I started the grand money-raising scheme, because dubbing-in for Miss Raynor's farewell present, and then the Christmas shopping, left us really hard-up for the rest of the long holidays. (1969,NZ School Journal,4(3): 00)

SUTTON-SMITH Here is Little Ring as played in Waitara, Taranaki, in 1899: A team would consist of six to eightboys [order of shooting determined] ... An oval ring was decribed in the earth by means of a stick, and each player would dub in' one marble ... A line was drawn some six or eight feet away, as the firing line, and the first player sang outFire!' as he fired the first shot. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

dub in vb. (tr.) N.Z. inf. to contribute to the cost of something: we'll all dub in a dollar for the trip. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,343) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 149]]

McGILL dub in to contribute to a kitty or collection; eg Are you dubbing in for her going away present?' Local variant ofdub up', pay up, mid-C19 English slang. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40)

dubber¶

n. [?sense and derivation: ?OED2 dub v1. 6 b. to trim or crop hedges, trees, etc: ? 10 to trim or work level with an adze: ??AND dubboA backblocker from Dubbo, but 1973 earliest: CHECK EDD. ?a misprint, but what of? Are these workers on the main trunk project?]

MYERS On clearings of bush, hundreds of `dubbers,' sturdy, tough pioneers, lived along the [main trunk] line in slab whares and canvas tents. (1941,Valiant Love,9)

dubbing-in¶

n. contribution

It must have been that year that Johnnie and Ginge and I started the grand money-raising scheme, because dubbing-in for Miss Raynor's farewell present, and then the Christmas shopping left us really hard-up for the rest of the long holidays. (1969,NZ School Journal,4(3):)

duchess¶

v. treat like a duchess

Some ... conscious of being "duchessed" by unaccustomed personal star treatment ... were cautious about just how far Clark would go to address urgent issues . . . (Jan 20, 2005,NZ Herald,C1)

duchess(e)¶

n. in NZ duchesse has developed meanings wider than the orig. and now seems applied not only to a dressing table with drawers, but to a low chest of drawers (?lowboy') without a mirror; and occas. (?because the word is now obsolesc. or unfamiliar) to atallboy'. [check HNZD2]

[Advt] Modern Reflex Mirror Duchess, withCabriolet Legs... Now Only GBP4/10/-. (Jan 19, 1938,Grey River Argus,1)

[Advt] Harley and Co., Ltd., will submitto Public Auction.. Oak Bedroom Suitecomprising Duchesse, Wardrobe, Bedsteadand Pedestal. (Apr 1, 1924,Grey River Argus,1)

[Advt] Dingle Bros Reliable Furnishing Emporium. . . Duchess Suites, Combination Chests, Couches in endless variety. (Jan 3, 1900,Taranaki Herald,4)

[Advt] R.M. Corsey. . . Duchess Chests, Duchess Suites (Jan 3, 1900,Taranaki Herald,5)

FRAME The tweezers ... stayed in exactly the same place on the duchesse. (1957,Owls Do Cry,54) [NOTES: [OED2 I xii]]

HASCOMBE Suddenly a woman hisses, `There's borer in the back of this duchess.' ... What is a duchess? What is borer? (1969,Down and Almost Under,35)

LELAND Duchesse: The hereditary New Zealand title for a LOW CHEST OF DRAWERS WITH A MIRROR on it so it can double as a dressing table. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,35)

ELDRED-GRIGG After we was born we was put in a drawer in a duchesse (1987,Oracles and Miracles,3)

Duchesse Chests.. from 42s to GBP10. (Dec 20, 1907,Dominion,11)

[Advt] 14 Days Sale. Furniture,Consisting of Duchess Chests,Washstands.. Chairs. (May 23, 1918,Greymouth Evening Star,1)
