n.

[Advt] Duchesse Pair, Latest Design,Bevel Mirror, Brackets, Tile BackWashstand. (Jan 14, 1905,NZ Herald,6)

duck¶

n. [[Check ca1899 1957 Pascoe MED 235/7 [Birds South Westland] See also parera, putangitangi, whio]

Sea and water fowles of all sorts are however in no great plenty, those known in Europe are Ducks, Shags, Gannets and gulls all of which were eat(?) by us and found exceeding good, ... (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/276,1955 ed.)

FORSTER Ducks, shags, black oyster-catchers, and some sorts of plovers were very numerous here [at Dusky Bay]. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/133)

BELL The Best kinds were Ducks, Curlews, a bird very much resembling a Wood Cock & Sea Pies; - Shags, Wood Hens, & Parrots were in great abundance ... the Wood Hen very much resembles the Common Barn door Fowl in England (Nov 1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham',50)

PARKER `There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus Nesonetta) and the Blue Mountain Duck (Hymenolaemus). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (Casarca variegata), the Brown Duck (Anas chlorotis), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (Rhynchaspis variegata), and the Scaup or Black Teal (Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae).'] (1889,Catalogue NZ Exhibition,117) [NOTES: [Morris]]

2 n. Early, of various native spp.; now, also introduced spp., ?esp. the mallard gen sp

FORSTER In this fine place, we found a number of wild fowl, and particularly wild ducks ... from whence we gave it the name of Duck Cove. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/137)

MARSDEN ... we dined off a wild duck and potatoes, as also some provisions we had brought with us. The duck Shunghee shot at the lake. (1815,Letters & Journals,99,1932 ed.)

CRAIK Among them are many sorts of wild ducks, large wood-pigeons, sea gulls, rails, parrots, and parroquets. (1830,New Zealanders, The,187)

The River `Wiiaw' is very spacious in places, ... and abounds in fish, eels and wild-ducks of 3 or 4 different kinds. (1835,Boultbee Journal,74,1986 ed.)

I found [round Wellington] Teal, common Wild Duck, the paradise Duck, a variety of the Grebe, a kind of Water Hen the proper name of which I do not know. (Jun 1840,Boultbee Journal,230,1966 ed.)

We scarcely took a step that did not delight us; the soil good, the banks of the [Waipa] river high, interspersed with woods of kahikatea. ... Here the banks of the river were covered with wild-ducks. (1842,GBPP,(No.569) 98) [NOTES: 1841 Jan 4 Report of George Clarke, Protector of Aborigines in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 98]

WAKEFIELD These (wild ducks of different sorts) are principally the black, the grey, the blue-winged, and the paradise duck, or `pa tangi tangi', as it is called by the natives. The last is nearly as large as a goose, and of beautiful plumage (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/57)

Wild ducks, called `Paradise Ducks', nearly as large as a Goose, splendid eating. (1848,Otago Journal,3/47) [NOTES: (R. Donaldson)]

POWER A few curlews, whale-birds, sand-pipers, and wild ducks frequent the coast and river swamps, but are generally fishy, and unfit for the table. (1849,Sketches in NZ,72)

1/80 [The Waikato] runs through ... deep fern fringed with raupo (a bullrush) ...[sic] and the magnificent toi-toi, a gigantic grass whose flower stalk is from 8 to 12 feet and has an exquisite feather of two feet long playing in every air. This grass is ... with the phormium tenax the most remarkable of the open country vegetable products. ... You see many nativedwellings & many canoes for they are a most locomotive people, few as ignorant of all but their own kainga as our British Hodge. There are troops of wild ducks & shags, some hawks of large size, bitterns & smaller waterfowl unknown to me. (Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

BARKER I don't think a minute passed without a brace of wild ducks flying past, - grey, blue, and Paradise. (1867,Station Life in NZ,1870,181 ed.)

THOMSON Several kinds of birds are indigenous to the woods and waters; among them the oyster-catcher, bittern, kingfisher, cormorant, quail, wild-duck, mocking or [16] parson bird, parrots, parroquets, woodhen, pigeon, etc. (the [sic] gigantic Moa bird is believed to be now quite extinct). (1867,Twelve Years in Canterbury,15)

HAR T At the back ... was a large raupo swamp, which was a rare resort for wild ducks and pukaki. (1886,Stray Leaves,13)

HOCHSTETTER The Sultan-hen of brilliant plumage (Porphyris melanotus) [sic], or the Pukeko of the natives; the New Zealand bittern or Matuku (Botaurus melanotus), and the wild-duck Parena [sic] (Spatula rhynchotis). (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),293fn)

duck fart¶

n. The noise of a small stone plopping into water; occas. the stone itself. [(schoolboys') ca1938 Havelock schoolboys. ca1940 Palmerston North p.c. Rodney Simonsen.]

SLATTER The hurling of stones straight up in the air so they would fall into the back-water with that satisfying plup known as a duck fart. (1968,Pagan Game, The,51)

duck itch¶

n.

LELAND Duck itch: a RASH that develops as a result of contact with a waterborne parasite that infests some of New Zealand's southern lakes. It has just left its snail host and is looking for a duck to grow up in. Look for warning signs. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,35)

duck shoot¶

n. [[Cf also duck-shooting season. nf OED2: duckshooter in OED]]

MARSHALL Used to be real live-wires when we were first married,' said Mrs Foden philosophically.Never missed a tin-kettling or first-footing; euchre evenings, sales, duck shoots, dances, send-offs, fires. We always went. ...' (1979,Supper Waltz Wilson,47)

duck shover¶

n. someone who passes on blame

[Hdg] Blood on hands of duck shovers. (Oct 13, 2004,Northern Courier,3)

duck shoving¶

n. (historical) touting for passengers in the street instead of wating one's turn on the rank. [(cabmen's obs.)]

The case was one of a series of cases of what was technically known as `duck shoving', a process of getting passengers which operated unfairly against the cabmen who stayed on the licensed stand and obeyed the by-law. (Jan 25, 1896,Otago Daily Times,3) [NOTES: [Morris]]

2 n. undecisiveness; passing the buck [[AND b. 1942.]]

The Government's Proposals for Resource Management Law Reform: a True Reform or a Case of Duck Shoving? (Jun 1989,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,84/52)

They were fed up with 'duck-shoving'. (Dec 13, 1990,Evening Post,5)

No duck shufflin', yer cow. (Nov 23, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,96)

We have been the perfect vehicle for duck-shoving from one department to another. We have been shunted from the Health Department to the Social Welfare Department to the Education Department. Each in turn has declined responsibility for us. (Oct 20, 1972,Press, The,1/3)

SHERWOOD The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. AQueen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. (1985,Botanist at Bay,26)

duck's breakfast¶

n. a drink of water and nothing to eat (cf. Irishman's dinner, dog's breakfast).

PARTRIDGE He absolutely dropped his bundle, and, to make matters worse, I had started off with a duck'sbreakfast, but I saw a cookhouse and decided to give it a pop for a binder. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

PARTRIDGE Duck's breakfast. A drink of water with nothing to eat: esp. New Zealanders': C. 20. Cf. Irishman's dinner. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,246)

... ducks' breakfast,'to float up to,' to blow up to,'to sleep in the Star Hotel' need no explanation. (Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

McGILL duck's breakfast or dinner a drink of water to WWI soldiers. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40)

duck's disease¶

n.

I have been teased for the way I stand - it's called duck's disease... Now that I have left school and I stand up for myself and no-one has anything to say about duck's disease, I am getting on with my life. (Aug 2000,Tearaway,5)

I have been teased for the way I stand - it's called duck's disease... Now that I have left school and I stand up for myself and on-one has anything to say about duck's disease, I am getting on with my life. (Aug 2000,Tearaway,5)

duck's egg¶

n. ?bankruptcy; a severe loss. [a duck's egg is zero]

I sounded Hirst & found him ... impracticable ...[sic] Cutfield's aid would scarcely have saved him from a duck's egg. The whole affair put the Ministry in a very ungracefull position. (May 10, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/396,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

duck-scarer¶

n. frilled shag, Phalacrocorax melanolencus, Vieill. [(Kenepuru Sound, Marlborough: obs.)]

The frilled shag is, owing to its cautious habits, called the `duck-scarer' by the sportsmen living in the above-mentioned sound [Kenepuru]. (1896,TrNZI,28/367)

duck-shooting season¶

n.

It was a week or so before the opening of the duck-shooting season. (Dec 1, 1928,NZ Free Lance,17)

The duckshooting season started on Saturday and all over the country the active hunters stalked their prey while the others sat patiently in their maimais. (May 10, 2000,Capital Times,17)

duck-shove¶

v. to avoid blame or responsibility

Mr Dunne is strongly critical of all the national and local politicians, roading agencies and other planning bodies "who constantly dither, duck shove and otherwise prevaricate" while motorists continue to die needlessly on the notorious Centennial Highway. (Oct 13, 2004,Northern Courier,3)

As the leader of the [New Zealand] Opposition complained, the Government has `dodged and duckshoved' the issue. (Nov 4, 1960,Spectator (London),677) [NOTES: [OED2]]

duck-shove NZ & Austral. sl.. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,232) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 149]]

duckshove to cheat or pass responsibility on to someone else, perceived as a typical bureaucratic trick; eg `The public is always complaining of duckshoving in that department.' Originally cabbies jumping the queue in mid-C19 Melbourne cab ranks. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,McGILL,40 ed.)

And then there was the bit where she duck-shoved in Parliament about whether she had ever seen, let alone written the letter of apology. (Jun 21, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

duckboard¶

n. A spec. use of duckboard - a slatted timber path laid down in the trenches.]

McARA Duckboards: Boards with transverse cleats laid between the rails; used in wet places to facilitate trucking. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),320)

duckie¶

n. [(child marble-players')]

(1972,Folkgames of Children,SUTTON-SMITH,174 ed.)

ducking-stick¶

n. a device to make wild horses duck their heads into a noose-trap. [nf dicts] [(spec use)]

CRUMP When you get [the noose-snare] set up lay a ducking-stick across the track at the top of your noose so the horse will duck his head under it and through the rope. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,55)

ducks and geese¶

n. police [(prison rhyming sl.)]

Her pot and pan had smacked it for a blue with the ducks and geese, but was out on ginger ale. ducks and geese ... police (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

ducks on the pond¶

exclam.

McGILL ducks on the pond warning of a woman in a male environment; shearing term. [Keith Sinclair] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,40)

duckshooter¶

n. a person who shoots ducks for sport

Fergus Staynes was smitten, sick with desire, in a world where a duckshooter fires and the duck falls from the sky into his face knocking him unconscious to drown in 10 centimetres of water. (Jan 14, 1991,BLANK ENTRY,20)

duckstone¶

n. [(children's) Often pl.]

THOMSON Others wanted [to play] Prisoners' Base' orChivvy', Brewer',Egg-in-the hat', Duck-stone',Red Rover', or `Kingy-seeny'. (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,84)

SUTTON-SMITH Duckstones and Tops were the throwing games of greatest historical importance. Others were Pegknife, Ducks and Drakes, Snowballing, stone and ball throwing. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/739)

SUTTON-SMITH At school, however, there was little place for Duck Stones, with its dangerous stone-throwing. (1981,History of Children's Play,217)

HEINZ Some of the simple games played by the [West Coast] children were rounders, shinty, duckstone, tiggy touchwood, kiss in the ring, ... cockfighting, marbles, fly the garter and leapfrog. (1974,Bright Fine Gold,38) [NOTES: [c1870s] 1953 Patrick Magee (aged 86) Growing Up at the Diggings in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 38]

2 n.

SUTTON-SMITH A game that was based directly upon children's interest in throwing stones was Duckstones (K-16). ... In the simplest form, the players put one stone on top of a larger stone and then attempted to knock the top one off by throwing other stones at it. The player who knocked off the most stones won. ... (South Clutha, 1875; Stillwater, Nelson, 1885; Wakefield, Nelson, 1875). Ibid. 167 In this [West Coast version of Duckstones] the duckstone belonged to the He. As soon as he put his duckstone on the big stone the game commenced and the others began to fire their own `dubs' at the duckstone. (1972,Folkgames of Children,166)

duckweed¶

n. any of a variety of New Zealand aquatic plants.

(And) L. minor (1907,AJHR,C-8) [NOTES: Report on Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (]

COCKAYNE (And) L. minor (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest in AJHR]

(And) (1916,Dunedin Field Club Plant Catalogues)

duckweed [s] Lemna sp. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)

DIEFFENBACH From having formerly been the principal abode of the Rotu-rua natives, ... it was always well cultivated, and ... plantain, duckweed, and others, which in such cases generally spring up, vary agreeably the usually brown tint of the lower native vegetation. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/393)

HOOKER Lemna ... A very curious genus, known as Duckweed in England, and found in most parts of the temperate world. ... Lemna (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 238-239)

Duckweed. Lemna a. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),764)

Duck weed. Lemna minor, Linn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

THOMSON (And) L. minor (1906,Introductory Classbook of Botany)

CHEESEMAN L[Lemna] minor, Linn. ... Duckweed. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,745)

2 n. Nertera depressa

COCKAYNE (And) Nertera depressa (1908,AJHR,C-14) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest]

3 n. Anacharis canadensis (Elodea canadensis). . [ca1954 Wairarapa (R. Mason) `Apparently well established in the district. The plant is nothing like the true duckweeds (Lemna spp)]

4 n. starwort, also called purple-backed duckweed. [(R. Mason) In North Auckland]

HILGENDORF STARWORT (Callitriche verna [spp.]), sometimes called drain weed or even duckweed, is not uncommon in still and slow-running water. ... [It is native to New Zealand.] (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,129,1967 ed.)

duckweed [=] purple-backed duckweed: starwort: watermeal [s] ... duckweed, purple-backed [s] Spirodela oligorrhiza Kurz. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)

dud¶

v. swindle, cheat (out of money)

Some of that vitriol came from Australian fund managers who got dudded in the Lion Nathan deal, but rarely invest in New Zealand companies anyway because the playing field is tilted in favour of the locals. (May 7, 1998,Evening Post,10)

The Pacifika concept may be dead but the feeling that Cullen Sports tried to dud the Warriors and the New Zealand Rugby League and the fans won't fade quite so fast. (Nov 20, 2005,Sunday Star Times,B14)

"Shoddy dropping" and "dudding" are lawful occupations at present. (Sep 23, 1953,NZ Observer,7)

Dudded: It is what some absolutely useless bastard does to you when they get their claws on your shekels. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,277)

dud up¶

v. to fabricate evidence to secure a conviction

NEWBOLD Dud up. (v) Fabricate evidence to secure a conviction (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

dudapper¶

n.

While presenting a programme on Radio Sport recently, I asked listeners what a "dudapper" was... Eventually, one caller came up with the correct answer : a dudapper was once the term used to describe a delivery that bounced twice before reaching the batsman. Shortly after, an elderly gentleman rang in to say that when he was a youngster playing school cricket in England, a team-mate by the name of Nipper Dingle made a specialty of such a delivery. I distinctly remember," said the caller, " our master taking us for practices and saying, 'I've never seen a boy who could bowl a dudapper like you, Nipper Dingle.'" (Mar 18, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

dudeen¶

n. a (clay) pipe. (The word as doodee /du|di:/ was occas. used by old people in Havelock in my childhood for pipe':he won't go anywhere without his old doodee.')

ROCHFORT We no sooner brought up [at Lyttelton] than ... our little craft was crowded with persons, eager for news, smoking their short dudees. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,12)

MONEY ... we were roused by a roaring in our ears, and had only time, the one to snatch his pocket-book ..., the other his black dudheen ... before the hut was a raging furnace. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,95)

KENNAWAY [The Irishman] smoked a short dodeen pipe. (1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,32)

SENIOR [He] knocks the ashes out of his dudheen. (1880,Trout and Travel,100)

A TRAMP The boss of [the Cathedral] is Bishop Julius ... who smokes a `dudeen' and reads shilling shockers. (1891,Casual Ramblings,141)

duds¶

n. a woman's breasts [(pl.) ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream]

SLATTER Telling her he hadn't seen such lovely duds outside a garage calendar. (1968,Pagan Game, The,165)

duff¶

n. boiled or steamed suet pudding, often with dried fruit in it; a plum pudding. [(mainly early outdoor and farming usage)]

"Got a duff?"... "Oh, yes. I made two,filled ours with thrums and sent one tomother." (Apr 2, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,71)

KENNAWAY ... our delicate ... stomachs received the most racy and highly esteemed dainties peculiar to the cuddy table, and which when you all come out you will soon discover, such as `Duff & Treacle', Boiled Pudding, Plum Duff, ... and bread in particular. (1851,Biscuit and Butter,78,1973 ed.)

PHILLIPS I. left at home with strict injunctions to make a duff - (Sep 8, 1867,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,115)

HODDER I chopped suet and plums to make a `duff' for dinner. (1862,Memories of NZ Life,10)

We had a plum duff boiling. (1959,Early Travellers,393) [NOTES: 1864 Barrington West Coast Prosp Party in 1959 Taylor Early Travelles 393]

BAKER ... `duff' - that's colonial for pudding, ma'am. (1872,Xmas Cake in Four Quarters, A,Chap III)

TONKIN On Christmas Day ... if they [Dunedin gaol prisoners] do not absolutely have plum pudding they have a plain of [sic] `duff', with a few currants in it, which to them is doubtless as acceptable as the richest of plum puddings (1980,Dunedin Gaol,15) [NOTES: >c1875 Otago Guardian in 1980 Tonkin Dunedin Gaol 15]

DUNCAN If we drew their attentions to ... the inevitable currant pudding on Sunday, their only answer was Take the whole bloomingduff.' (1888,Wakatipians,28)

BROOKES The largest duff I have ever seen ... (1892,Frontier Life,111)

CARR Anyone who can bake, make a decent `brownie' (as the plain cake is called) and a plum duff is fit for a shearers' cook. (1913,Country Work,17)

Duff: A very plain plum pudding, which was the invariable second course at Sunday dinner on stations. (G.P.W.) [A Northern English variant of,`dough' not recorded before the nine-teeth century.--A.W.] (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

HYDE The duff boiled for three hours, and the rattle of tin plates was a newly invented song of the flax-cutters. (1936,Passport to Hell,48)

HENDERSON Take P.O.W. for example. Everyone had bashed up a duff for himself at one stage or another. (1945,Gunner Inglorious,140)

NEWTON Duff - `steamed pudding' (1947,Wayleggo) [NOTES: Gloss]

NEWTON (1949,High Country Days,195,1950 ed.) [NOTES: (Gloss.)]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Duff. A plain boiled pudding that was standard fare for shearers in the early days. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,96)

FRANCIS The [station] midday meal was more often a cut lunch eaten on the job. The main meal, `tea', was basically mutton, potatoes, onions, ... and, for afters, stewed dried fruit, plum duff or riceand prunes. (1983,Wildlife Ranger,2)

Who will race to Divvy Base and fetch a Christmas duff? (Dec 22, 1941,NZEF Times,I/26 : 17)

1 n. (Rural) a steamed pudding renowned of station cooks and packies.

MONEY The duff was made, the potatoes were boiled .. with plenty of sow thistles or Maori cabbage to give it a flavour ... (1871,Knocking About in NZ,68)

WILLIAMS This is Sunday, a fact I'm made strongly to feel, By the presence of duff at our middle-day meal. (1889,Colonial Couplets,9)

The soil appears fairly good but here and there a few stones are visible, not very many, but scattered all through like the plums in some station duffs. (1894,NZ Farmer,52)

The packer, who is in charge of the packhorses, acts as camp cook. In the evening there is a huge meal, with a 'duff' if the packer has had time to build one. (Aug 1, 1936,NZ Dairy Exporter,69)

A good 'duff' is good indeed and a slice kept for lunch next day is a very sustaining food on the hill but a bad duff is terrible. (Oct 27, 1938,NZ Farmer,10)

MCLEOD .. the packie gets to work on a full-scale dinner of mutton, spuds, vegetables and duff ... (1951,NZ High Country,32)

HILL Jack [the station cook] was soaking his feet in the dish that he mixed the duffs in! (1990,Between the Rivers,192)

ANDERSON Jack was a wonderful cook and made the best station duff. [station duff] (1966,Over the River,204)

duff (up)¶

v. to make pregnant

MORRIESON He duffed one of the maids up at his old man's house and she died having an abortion, ... (1974,Predicament,72,1981 ed.)

MAUGHAM Still he had changed all that, moving into practice and duffing Elizabeth. (1975,Good and Faithful Servants,7)

JOHNSTON When Ma-Mac finds out I've duffed her daughter there'll be a bloody massacre in the village! (1981,Fish Factory,65)

McGILL duff to make pregnant, developed from British phrase up the duff', to be pregnant; egYou know why he married her, don't you? Because he duffed her, of course.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,41)

duffer¶

adj. . [goldmining]

WAITE Those first disappointed arrivals chose to call the expedition a duffer rush. (1869,Discovery West Coast Goldfields,15)

... more than ordinarily rich the last six months seems to have been in `duffer rushes.' (1870,AJHR,D-40-4) [NOTES: Report Goldfields West Coast and Auckland]

WHITWORTH ... you remember the duffer rush at Bruce Bay ... (1875,Cobb's Box,8)

MAY Duffer rushes collapsed so quickly that storekeepers could find themselves in the back-of-beyond with a fully-stocked shanty and no sales to pay for the cost of packing-in and packing-out. (1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,281,1967 ed.)

PFAFF He was among the earliest at Hokitika, Grey, ... Jackson's Bay (a duffer's rush), etc. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,151)

n.

If the cows are themselves duffers, and are mated to a mongrel bull, the heifer calves cannot turn our very good ... (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,28)

The following tables very well illustrate the value of culling out those cows that the system of testing reveals to be `duffers.' (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,382)

POWDRELL Practical farmers sometimes put two calves on to one duffer cow, or to a run cow for five or six weeks ... Ibid. 45 ... first he must weed out the `duffers' ... (1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,42)

n.

MAY Another duffer of a different kind took place in July. Vague reports that the Commercial Banking Company and the New Zealand Banking Corporation had suspended payments caused a run on the unsuspecting Bank of New Zealand at Okarito township, and also at the Ross. (1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,186,1967 ed.)

n. [goldmining]

PFAFF I sunk a shaft on the Larrikin's Terrace there, but it proved a duffer. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,56)

All hands.. are gone or going to theCreek.. which has often been pronounced"a duffer". Here.. a party got into a"pot-hole" and had got for two days' worksixteen ounces of gold. (Mar 4, 1869,Westport Times,2)

New rushes are spoken of every day, and the township which has sprung up is full of life and excitement caused by the crowds of diggers, packers, and storekeepers, all anxiously awaiting the latest intelligence to be off for "pastures new" on the Golden Grey. Affairs will not take their usual course if we do not have numbers coming back to the Hokitika, loudly declaring the whole thing a "duffer"and a "sell." (Aug 3, 1865,Evening Post,2)

They turned out a lot of "duffers". (May 3, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

I think I should have preferred the old claim at the Thames, duffer as it was. (Jan 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

The verdict of the miners ... regarding the Taieri rush is this, that it is, as a gold-diggings, essentially aduffer.' (1864,Saturday Review,50)

MONEY ... our claim proved a duffer'. No less than fifteen shafts did we sink ..., but found a prospect of nothing sufficient to encourage us in working it. <i>Ibid.</i> 121 [Prospective diggers] had only arrived to find the whole thing what is called in digging parlance aduffer' - i.e., that there was comparatively `nothing' to repay them for even the trouble of digging a single hole. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,99)

WRIGHT He was working like a nigger, sinking duffers here and there. (1897,Station Ballads,19) [NOTES: [`Prospector']]

VON HAAST This visit was commemorated by miners who took up Hochstetter' andHaast' claims, which, as we have seen, unlike their namesakes, proved `duffers'. (1948,Julius Von Haast,26 fn)

duffer 1. Useless or stupid person. 2. In Australia and New Zealand, a worked-out orunprofitable mine. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),133,8th ed.)

MAY DUFFER: applied to a rush, a shaft, or a claim generally. A failure. Synonyms were shicer',stringer' or, in the case of a false rush, store-keepers' rush'. A claim which was exhausted was said to beduffered out'. At Ross in 1866 putting down a duffer shaft was termed `sinking for the Queen'. Duffers (Creek) is a common West Coast place-name. (1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1967 ed.)

HAY A duffer: No gold. ...CLAIMS Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known aswages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as pilers'; the richest of all were known asHome-ward-bounders.' (1974,Bright Fine Gold,200) [NOTES: (Glossary of Mining Terms)]

NOLAN Duffer: a mine, claim or gold-rush which proves worthless. (1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,112) [NOTES: (gloss)]

duffer ... 3. Austral. sl. a. a mine that proves unproductive. b. a person who steals cattle. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,344) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 232]]

... the place was rushed' by about 500 men, who speedily deserted it, and declared the Waitahuna to be aduffer.' (1863,AJHR,D6-3) [NOTES: also in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 5]

HOPEFUL If a man isn't up to the mark' he is calleda regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, andhe therefore abandons his hole, it is called a shicer' - that is, the ground was called ashicer' or duffer, thus the origin. (1887,Taken In,135)

BLAIR He puddled and cradled, and digged all he knew / When the claim proved a regular duffer. (1889,Lay of the Old Identities, The,48)

It was soon found to be a "duffer" rush. (Nov 11, 1924,Otago Witness,66)

2 v. a washout

... declaring the whole thing a duffer' and asell.' (1865,Evening Post,1/152/2)

duffer out¶

v.

v. of a mine, claim, to prove a failure; to become unproductive, peter out. [goldmining]

DIGGER'S FAREWELL... tells of 1874 whengold was "duffering out" on the coast,and hundreds of disheartened diggers weremaking their way back from the Grey Riverto the Palmer River in Australia. (1955,Shanties by the Way) [NOTES: Sleeve notes]

O'REGAN Your claim to duffered out at last. (1894,Diggers' Story, The,15)

WRIGHT A good bit of ground duffers out. (1897,Station Ballads,59)

... since the house had been abandoned many years ago when the Owen reefs duffered out. (1907,TrNZI,39/395) [NOTES: (Townson)]

MAY While the energetic army of Waimea sluicers washed the terraces through the boxes and into the gully-beds, the Auckland Lead on the beach was all but duffered out. (1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,198,1967 ed.)

duffer/duffer cow¶

1 n. (Rural) a dry or unthrifty cow.

Possibly the reason why we have so many duffer cows in our herds is partly to be found in our lack of opportunity to think. (Jun 1910,NZ Farmer,556)

The following tables very well illustrate the value of culling out those cows that the system of testing reveals to be "duffers." (May 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,382)

It was necessary to warn the inexperienced buyer who, guided by the limitations of his pocket, might secure what on present values, was a medium or low-priced animal, and finding that he had bought a 'duffer' would drop the breed. (Jul 3, 1920,Hawera Star,7)

duffered¶

adj. exhausted; ended.

O'REGAN Life's claim is almost duffered. (1894,Voices of Wave and Tree,10)

duffered out¶

adj.

HEINZ Duffered out: All the gold has been mined. (1947,Bright Fine Gold,200)

MAY DUFFER: applied to a rush, a shaft, or a claim generally. A failure. Synonyms were shicer',stringer' or, in the case of a false rush, store-keepers' rush'. A claim which was exhausted was said to beduffered out'. At Ross in 1866 putting down a duffer shaft was termed `sinking for the Queen'. Duffers (Creek) is a common West Coast place-name. (1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,526,1967 ed.)

duffing¶

adj. of a claim, find etc., proving unproductive. [goldmining] (See also duffer aj)

'H' Then came the thought of how the boys would chaff him about this duffing claim.' ... There is no crime so great as to make aduffing find' intentionally. (1898,Grain of Gold, The,39)

duffing find¶

n. (See duffing)

"H" There is no crime so great as to make a "duffing find" intentionally. (1898,Grain of Gold, The,39)

dug-out¶

n.

PAYTON As they are all what is known as "dugouts", or of one solid trunk of "totara", it may be imagined that the weight is very considerable. (1888,Round about NZ,245)

HOCHSTETTER I counted not less than twenty-four of us ... the dug-out' had to carry. [fn]Dug-out' is the name of these canoes among the backwoodsmen of North America. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),293)

duggles¶

n. the marbles you put in the centre of the ring, =dingles. Compare dubs. [nf dicts] [?is this supposed to be diggles or dingles?: [(marble players') ca1957-63 Horowhenua p.c. ?]

duke¶

n. [(child marble-players')]

SUTTON-SMITH Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as taw' orshooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; dubs',dates', stakes',dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

Duke of Yorks¶

n. (Rural) makeshift socks or boot-liners [used mainly by bachelors and bushmen in the 1800s]. [cf. Prince Alberts, Prince Edwards]

WILSON They [bushmen] did not wear socks: they cut an old tent into squares and pushed their feet, with the squares around them, into boots - they called these 'Duke of Yorks' and said that changing them daily they protected the feet better than socks. (1955,Land of My Children,6)

dum¶

v. to face [(criminals')]

NEWBOLD DUM (v) (?) Face. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

dumar¶

v.

Two of us dumared out together and every time one of us moved upwards the rope would start to move up and down for the other. (Jun 18, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

dumfarthing¶

n.

He was told he could not own a farm ... he closed it ... And who benefited? Not a soul. But the regulations were carried out to the uttermost dumfarthing. (Nov 1978,Public Service Journal,Vol 65/No.10 14/1)

dummied¶

adj. (Rural) [of land ] owned in the name of one person but farmed by another. [or (in citation below) passive of verb dummy?]

CHANDLER No doubt many of these areas shortly became 'dummied' by a more successful neighbour getting possession of the area of a less successful one; the latter becoming an employee of the former, though ostensibly working his own block. (1996,Land of the Mountain and the Flood,42)

dummy¶

n. solitary confinement [Compare boob, cooler, digger. ca1941 Prison slang: Riverside Community]

Down below.. is the solitary block. This is the dreaded "dummy" where the prison J.P. sends recalcitrants for a spell on bread and water. (Jan 15, 1947,NZ Observer,9)

He [sc. Paddy Webb] described the punishment known as "dummy" - solitary confinement in a dark cell on hard rations. He had seen men go into "dummy" in fairly good health and come out physical wrecks. In "dummy" they got three small blankets, and had to sleep on the floor. (Jul 31, 1917,Press, The,8)

Mr Webb added that if he had been found out in this dishonest behaviour, he would have been put in the 'dummy' - solitary confinement. (Aug 14, 1917,Wanganui Herald,4)

The young prisoner [in the Terrace Gaol] got so bad with boils that he was unable to work, and was placed in The Dummy,' a building which the prisoner described toTruth' as an old chicken house. Whilst in `The Dummy' he received no attention whatever, except that his meals were brought to him. (Jun 5, 1909,NZ Truth,206/5/5)

HYDE He was taken before the Governor and sentenced to three days in the Dummy. It is always dusk in the Dummy, which lies underground. ... At six in the morning the door is unlocked, and the prisoner gets his clothes, all except boots. (1936,Passport to Hell,62)

BURTON The aggressor in this case was promptly led off and incarcerated in the dummy' [for attacking a warder]. <i>Ibid.</i> 109 Someone else had seen a bloodstained towel coming from thedummy'. (1952,In Prison,107)

LEE When one of the prisoners was put in the dummy for misbehaviour, Jim O'Brien ... wanted to bring the jail out on strike. (1965,Rhetoric at the Red Dawn,127)

McKENZIE The punishment block, known as the pound' or thedummy', was a prison within the [Mt Eden] prison. In the basement, through a steel grille and a wooden door, it was a dimly lit and silent annexe leading at its far end to the tiny execution yard. Ibid. 96 dummy punishment block. See pound and back (1980,While We Have Prisons,14)

NEWBOLD Dummy. (n) Detention unit. (1982,Big Huey, The,248)

Though some of the [prison] conditions ... have changed - in that prisons have become more hygienic, bread and water is no longer the basic diet in dummy, nor is the Bible the only punishment book - ... the isolation of solitary confinement still has the whiff of the oubliette. (Oct 13, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

McGILL dummy punishment cell in prison. - practice of taking up land allegedly for yourself, but onbehalf of another, usually a friend or relative acting for a squatter. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,41)

n. [(Mount Eden prison).]

They took him down to the dummy yard where the flogging framework was set up and, Joe said, half the senior staff in The Hill was there. (Nov 1950,Here & Now,15)

n. In NZ from the time land laws were applied, one paid to acquire the title to a parcel of Crown land on behalf of another who was not legally entitled to do so; one who acquires title to land in name only, on behalf of another.

Mr. Browning held the shares in question.. and transferred them to Mr. Martin Sholl, sharebroker, who transferred them to William Lestrange, a well-known "dummy." (Apr 26, 1873,Auckland Weekly News)

TREGEAR He can go and be a Dummy on the Otago runs. (1884,Southern Parables,17)

WRIGHT And yet the talk is evermore, The people want the land!'/ .../ The greedy few will clamour loud and clamour to the end;/ A dummy grabbing what he can is not the people's friend./ And Heaven's curse is on him still in all his schemes for gain;/ ... <i>Ibid.</i> 58 It's the pig-shooting dummy I'veset',/ And I'm willing to say it again. (1897,Southern Parables,44) [NOTES: (`Arlinton')]

Dummy, n. in the early days of settlement, a person who put in a claim for land for the use ofanother. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,4)

Dummy: A man who takes a run in his name for the benefit of another; hence to dummy and dummyism. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

Dummy. 5. In Australia and New Zealand, a man who selects land on behalf of another. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),133,8th ed.)

dummy n. third person or medium at a sale of Crown land, who, swearing he is selecting land for himself, buys it, and, when the deal is completed drops out, allowing the second party to aquire the land for a fee. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

McCASKILL It would appear that a syndicate of directors and senior officials of the Farmers' Coop Association were the prime movers in the purchase [in 1917] and that the Lockheads were [114] really `dummies' whose initial contributions towards the purchase [of the station] were soon lost. (1969,Molesworth,113)

n. (Rural) a dog-training device consisting of a sheepskin draped over a wire netting frame on a pulley line.

WHYTE a dummy is a sheepskin draped over a wire netting frame on a pulley line. (1927,Sheep-Dog, The,13)

HARTLEY A form of dummy sheep, constructed from a 'benzine box' upon which pram wheels and a sheepskin are attached - shaping it like a sheep. (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,40)

n. (Rural) a partition separating two cows in the double bail of a milking shed.

All that is required is a water-tap fitted in front of the 'dummy' with rubber tubing attached long enough to reach to the cow's udder. (Jun 20, 1938,NZ Journal of Agriculture,452)

A modification of the dummy and race has come into favour in certain districts during recent years. (Jun 15, 1939,NZ Journal of Agriculture,489)

The use of galvanised iron piping or iron piping for erection of internal dummies and partitions. (Apr 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,378)

The bails and dummies in this shed are all clear of the floor, suspended from the ceiling. (Apr 26, 1951,NZ Farmer,6)

The McGoughans have mounted these units in pairs within the bale [sic] dummies. Small canvas curtains slightly forward of the units are interesting additions. (Nov 13, 1975,NZ Farmer,15)

I recall the early sheds with only head bales [sic] and the walk-through with the dummy bale [sic] between cows. [dummy bail] (Aug 10, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,Supp 14)

v. to select Crown land as a dummy. [Hist.]

REEVES The attempts often ingeniously made to evade these [land] restrictions by getting the land in the name of relatives, servants, or agents are called dummyism', and may be punished by imprisonment - never inflicted - by fines, and by forfeiture of the landdummied.' (1898,Long White Cloud, The,356)

Dummy: A man who takes a run in his name for the benefit of another; hence to dummy and dummyism. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: (Acland Gloss.)]

n.

378/3 The use of galvanised iron piping or iron piping for erection of internal dummies and partitions. (Apr 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

(caption) A small dairy with suspended dummy and bucket milking machine for one cow. (May 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,479)

n. fishing rig [(?game fishermen's)]

GREY The place looked fishy, and here the boatmen began trolling with hand-lines for bait. They used a small gig, dark in color, shaped like a canoe, which they called a dummy. I rigged up a light tackle and put over a spoon, ... (1926,Angler's Eldorado,33)

1 v. (Rural) to purchase land in name only for another to use, in order that a holding can be legally extended.

The Dummying Question. At the dummyism inquiry today ... (Jun 8, 1883,Hawera Star,2)

If two or three of a family select adjoining blocks a ring fence can be run around the whole allotment. One of the first and most obvious objectives is that the system would afford an easy method of dummyism. Members of a family might be used to "dummy" for their rich relatives. (Aug 6, 1900,Hawera Star,2)

Like all liberal provisions, however, they soon opened the way to land sharks who simply dummied the sections until they could find a purchaser at a greatly advanced price, and then applied for a transfer. (Dec 1904,NZ Farmer,1006)

1 n. (Rural) a land purchaser who buys land for the convenience of another to accumulate.

Dummies were employed to occupy the land for a few years, and as they were permitted to transfer their leases after a three years' residence ... (Jun 16, 1880,Hawera Star,2)

MCKEE WRIGHT The greedy few will clamour land and clamour to the end; A dummy grabbing what he can is not the people's friend. (1898,Station Ballads,46)

MCKEE WRIGHT Dummy - an individual masquerading as the owner of land usually in the interest of a large run-holder. (1898,Station Ballads,63)

In the latter [Hatuma situation] it is well-known that at least a dozen holders are dummies for a particular company but in their case they are holding on to the land and working it (Dec 1904,NZ Farmer,1006)

2 n.

HAMILTON He'd think nothing of snooping into the cell of a man doing his dummy ... Ibid. 159Sometimes, during the strain of that long dummy I'd burst out in a stream of curses at a screw ... (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,57)

dummy cell¶

n. see dummy 2

HAMILTON But the screws weren't taking any chances. When a three-striper came down they locked Barney up in a dummy cell and carted Alec up to the hospital. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,112)

dummy cow¶

1 n. (Rural) a high-consuming, low-producing dairy cow.

If you cannot afford to replace your dummy cows you can at least feed your good cows better by getting rid of cows that are losing you money every day. (Nov 27, 1920,Hawera Star,9)

dummying¶

n. (historical)

PINNEY The upper Ahuriri and the hills ... were now legally tenanted. Any suggestion of dummying is no more (1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,65)

dummyism¶

n. the action or process of dummying [Hist. See cit.dummy v.]

I accused the honourable member of dummyism; I really mean't gridironing. (Aug 21, 1890,Otago Witness,13)

I accused the honourable gentleman of dummyism; I really meant gridironing. (1890,NZ Parliamentary Debates,68/411)

He said that he had not meant "dummyism," and that he had made a mistake, for he intended "gridironing," and wished that word in its place. (1890,NZ Parliamentary Debates,68/413)

[Hdg] The Alleged Dummyism Cases at Macraes. (Jun 12, 1890,Otago Witness,19)

BAGNALL I had no idea that the word dummyism was to be connected with my name., The reporter for the Evening Post hurrying up the stairs past me and asking whether the "Dummyism" enquiry had begun was the first intimation I received of the serious nature of this business. (1976,Wairarapa : An Historical Excursion,286) [NOTES: Quote from about 1890]

REEVES The Kakanui area was not entirely a stranger to a third practice of the large landholder, dummyism, that is land acquisition under cover of different names. It was ... nowhere in New Zealand practised with the same effrontery as in Australia. (1898,Long White Cloud, The,356)

SCOTTER The Kakanui area was not entirely a stranger to a third practice of the large landholder, dummyism, that is land acquisition under cover of different names. It was ... nowhere in New Zealand practised with the same effrontery as in Australia. (1984,Run, Estate and Farm,14)

SINCLAIR Where leaseholders were not permitted to select' land, or where conditions of residence were enforced (?),dummyism' was rife-that is, a leaseholder would pay some `swaggie' to act as the ostensible selector and fufil the requirements for him. (1959,History of New Zealand,156)

McLINTOCK ... as a member of the Otago Wastelands Board from 1878, he opposed `Dummyism' and similar abuses. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/235)

dummyism n. the practice of acquiring land through a dummy, by misrepresentation. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

The Committee on Alleged Dummyism have brought up their report. (Sep 3, 1883,Illustrated NZ News,10)

The first case of alleged dummyism was ventilated at the Land Board on Wednesday. (Dec 12, 1890,NZ Mail,24)

1 n. (Rural) the use of others to buy land for oneself. [an unofficial situation of the 1800s and early 1900s where farmers used other purchasers to help them acquire land.]

The Otago Daily Times suggests that a Royal Commission should be appointed to investigate charges of dummyism in respect to land recently leased. (Mar 9, 1883,Hawera Star,9)

At the dummyism inquiry today, one man, named Kenneth Williamson, a shepherd in the employ of Messrs Gellibrand and Smith, and who was a purchaser at the land sale, said he had been "sounded" as to becoming a purchaser, and had been given to understand that unless he took up a particular section he must shift elsewhere. (Jun 8, 1883,Hawera Star,2)

A gross case of dummyism is said to exist in Hawke's Bay and steps will probably be taken to bring it before the public. (Dec 1892,NZ Farmer,493)

If two or three families select adjoining blocks, a ring fence can be run around the whole allotment. One of the first and most obvious objectives is that the system would afford an easy method of dummyism. Members of a family might be used to "dummy" for their rich relatives. (Aug 6, 1900,Hawera Star,2)

When they saw 420 applicants for one section, a new aspect of dummyism was coming into vogue. (Mar 13, 1907,Hawera Star,5)

The Otago Land Board has been inquiring into a case of alleged dummyism in respect of a run in the Tiger Hill district. (Apr 1908,NZ Farmer,328)

Dummy - a man who takes a run in his name for the benefit of another; hence to d[ummy] and dummyism. (Oct 14, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

dump¶

n. the rubbish tip

RENeE Usually on Sunday afternoons we're filling the car and its boot with garden rubbish because we're going to the dump, or we're actually going to the dump, or we're gardening because next weekend we are planning to go to the dump. (1998,Yin & Tonic,10)

CRANNA There are only four roads in and out of Puapiro - five if you include the road to the dump. (1989,Visitors,107)

Earlier this year we touched briefly on rubbish tips, with reference to a Board of Health survey into their usefulness... Correspondent John Ormond of Stratford unhesitatingly nominates Pahiatua's tip as the mnost scenically sited in the country. (Dec 3, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),144)

n. fecal excretion [?US]

I should point out that ralph' is an onomatopoeia on vomiting, while a 'dump' refers to fecal excretion. ANgauruhoe special' is apparently a particularly eruptive dump' which is typically associated with drinking Australian beer. <i>(1985,Sites,11/15</i>) [NOTES: (HodgesDrinking Vernacular')]

v. [Sunday Times letter suggests these are NZ uses of the word]

According to our TV newsreaders, snow no longer falls, it dumps and Jenny Shipley wasn't replaced by Bill English, she was dumped and the Bangladesh cricket team weren't beaten by the Black Caps - they were dumped. (Jan 13, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A8)

n. a double-dumped bale of wool

DAVIS Below, our wharf gang was busy attaching the short ropes called snotters to a score of dumps that had just been tipped off the back of a truck. Ibid. 105 On wool, when three men work elbow to elbow on seven-hundred-pound dumps and one slip means a hook through your mate's hand... (1964,Watersiders,42)

v. (Rural) to press two normal bales of wool into the size of one.

Practically all wool is dumped prior to shipping, that is, the putting together of two bales into one and securing them by three strong hoop-iron bands. (1919,Wool in NZ,32)

MCCASKILL The cleanest and best wool was dumped in the grease on the station and taken to Blenheim for shipment to London. (1969,Molesworth,103)

SALISBURY This press I was told was quite capable of dumping, i.e. pressing two normal bales of wool into the size of one. (1994,I Was So Lucky,17)

1 n. (Rural) a wool bin in a woolshed.

GASCOIGNE Manu and I looked at each other simultaneously from the depths of two dumps of loose wool- those most luxurious of armchairs in which we had been sprawled with only our legs and the tops of our hats showing. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,50)

dump press¶

n. a powerful hydraulic press used for dumping wool-bales. [also dumping press (woolstore) ca1949 Levin and Co.'s Wellington woolstore. The press was called a dumping press, hydraulically driven, and powered by a gas engine.] (See also dumping press)

It was customary, as at Waipiro Bay ..., to have a wool store and a dump press near the beach. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,10)

1 n. (Rural) a wool press, usually communal, situated near a coastal port.

It appears that in New Zealand a 10 to 20 per cent increase in density of single dumped bales .. could be obtained using existing dump presses with no more than one extra wire. (Dec 1964,NZ Journal of Agriculture,466)

WHEELER It was customary, as at Waipiro Bay, Pourere, Burnview, Akitio, Castlepoint and White Rock to have a wool store and a dump press near the beach. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,10)

dumped¶

adj.

WHEELER The dumped wool was taken by bullock wagon into the surf, transferred to surfboats, and rowed out to the ... steamer lying offshore. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,10)

1 adj. (Rural) [of fleecewool] compressed and wrapped with wire.

MCCASKILL The waggoners slept on the dumped wool under the waggon cover and there was very little room. Each wagon carried about thirty bales dumped. (1969,Man of England Now,104)

WHEELER The dumped wool was taken by bullock wagon into the surf ... (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,10)

dumper¶

n. wool-shed or wool-store hand who dumps wool. [(woolstore) ca1949 Used in Levin and Co.'s Wellington woolstore.]

[?-modn dump; or dump v1] A number of shearers and dumpers having secured a fiddler and fifer, paraded the town with green ribbon round their hats. (Jan 18, 1868,Marlborough Express,3)

n. [[Not recorded in NZ.]]

n. racecourse detective [(criminals')]

I recognise this bloke as a dumper, so I take it on the toe out the gate and up the frog and toad. dumper ... racecourse detective (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

dumping¶

n. [1955 citation is of verb to dump]

LYON When shearers are striving for a tally, or a big output of shorn sheep, dumping is the act of pushing the lamb's head downward when seated on the boards, in such a way that the lamb'slungs are pushed down on his diaphragm causing great agony and often fatal injury ... . The idea is that by dumping the sides of the lamb are flattened and permit a larger flat surface of fleece to be exposed to the shears. (1952,Faring South,194)

BOWEN There are several known styles of shearing. They range from the old blade method of stretching the sheep and shearing more round and round, to the modern method of dumping or crimping the sheep and following the blows right through more along the body of the sheep; ... (1955,Wool Away!,5)

n. the process of compressing two bales of wool into the size of one. [1885 citation is of verb to dump?]

The Wanganui Wool Dumpers Partnership hadconcluded its first financial year ofoperations... The stockpile of unsoldwools in store will contribute to thedumping trade as it is sold. (1991,Ann. Rep. Farmers' Co-op,5)

[Hdg] The Wool-Dumping Charges... That the present charge for dumping wool be reduced at once from 2s to 1s 9d per bale. (Nov 28, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

McCASKILL The dry wool was pressed at the scour and the bales taken to the woolshed for dumping ready for shipment. (1969,Molesworth,103) [NOTES: c1907-1914 Mowat diary in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 103]

PERRY It is a mistake to think that seed (hatiwai[sic] or bidi-bidi) in wool is crushed to dust in the dumping, ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,138)

A powerful hydraulic press forces two bales into the space formerly occupied by one, and they are bound with steel bands, or wires. (This process is called double dumping' ordumping'.) (1974,NZ Agriculture,67)

dumping press¶

n. (Rural) a wool press, usually communal, situated near a port.

The Harbour Board has an up-to-date wool-dumping press and hydraulic pumps. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,42)

dumping shed¶

n.

Wool waggons are daily to be seen onalmost every road bringing down wool fromthe various farms and station to thedumping sheds.. and from thence to thewool ships which roll at anchor in theBay. (Dec 28, 1899,NZ Times,2)

1 n. (Rural) a store for wool [often containing a dump press.]

TAIT The wool dumping shed at Waipiro Bay. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,8)

TAIT The wool dumping shed. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,51)

NEWTON The big "dumping" shed - some 3,000 square feet - which overlooks the beach a mile or so below the mouth of the river is still standing ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,88)

MCGREGOR There was a dumping shed on the beach from where wool was loaded on the wagons and then taken out to the schooner ... (1973,Petticoat Pioneers,I 213)

FEARON A wool dump shed was built on the foreshore at Flat Point for the bales to be stored awaiting for the arrival of a steamer. (1980,Te Wharau,13)

SALISBURY We had twelve pack saddles which belonged to Hore Hore and also used Wrey's and mine so with fourteen horses we set out to pack the wool out to the dumping shed. [dump shed] (1994,I Was So Lucky,150)

dumping-plant¶

n. [(wool)]

A dumping-plant has been erected by the Harbour Board; and last year (1893) 5,703 bales of wool ... were shipped. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,494)

dumpter¶

n.

Pay rise for drivers of dumpters [Headline] The Government Railways Industrial Tribunal hasgranted a rise of 1 1/2d and hour, bringing the rate to 8/5 1/2, for dumpter drivers employed by the New Zealand Railways. The award was made in a reserved decision on a claim by the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants for dumpter operators to be included with plant operators (employees with approved certificates) and paid at the rate of 8/8 1/2 and hour. Dumpter operators have been paid as lorry drivers at 8/4 per hour. (wool) (Nov 10, 1965,Dominion,3)

dumpy¶

n. [OBS.]

The game of Dumpy `was played on a space about the size of a tennis court and divided into three sections. There were six (often more) players, two on each section. Each player had a whipand each pair had to stick to its own section. When the top was whipped over the back line, that gave a point to that team' Taranaki, 1880). (1972,Folkgames of Children,166)

n. an outdoor privy

ANDERSON ... a flush toilet that would not have disgraced any suburban home. Thank heaven for that,' I said.I had visions of tramping some lonely path to an old dumpty, perched over a big hole full of spiders and wiggly things. (1981,Both Sides of the River,101)

FRAME The lavatory, or `dumpy' as we called it, was the usual enclosure about a deep hole, with a railway-red seat. (1982,To the Is-Land,29)

dune tauhinu [s] Cassinia retorta A. Cunn. ex DC. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)
