Dunedin Sound¶

n. A characteristic musical sound emphasising jangly guitar sounds, said to distinguish Dunedin pop groups from other New Zealand bands.

The Dunedin Sound. For many who made the music, it has been enough already for some time now. (Oct 7, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

But the "Dunedin Sound" as such didn't really exist. That was a convenient tag that made it easy for people to lump us atogether and pretend there was a common sound, but right from the start the bands were different. (Apr 1998,North & South,80)

Some of the most memorable are TheChills, whose frosty guitar jangle summedup the label's "Dunedin Sound". (Mar 25, 1996,Salient,30)

[Hdg] Venerable New Zealand label Flying Nun has grown a new wing. The label which brought us the Dunedin sound has unveiled two new signings from... Auckland. (Sep 30, 1999,Evening Post,23)

The book is a personal reminiscence from the inside of "Sneaky Feelings and the Dunedin Sound." as it says in its subtitle. (Oct 24, 1999,Sunday Star Times,F2)

Matthew Bannister was in a band called Sneaky Feelings, formed in the early 80s and part of the so-called "Dunedin Sound." (Dec 10, 1999,Dominion,5)

Then the music of the Dunedin Sounds bands leaked south. (Feb 5, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62) [NOTES: check whether "Sound" or "Sounds"]

The so-called "Dunedin sound: was deliberately glamourless, but Carter was the closest it came to producing a star, a pin-up, a ... teen idol. (Mar 31, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

"Do you consider that there is such a thing as a distinctive "New Zealand" sound?"... No, but I think there's a "Dunedin Sound"." (Dec 15, 1981,In Touch (Wellington),6)

"I spent about two hours.. discussing.. the Dunedin sound and Hunters and Collectors, things like that." (Aug 1981,Rip It Up (Auckland),96/12)

On musical terms, 'Dunedin Sound on 45' was a good idea which could have been done better or worse. (Aug 1981,Rip It Up (Auckland),98/32) [NOTES: Note apparent date anomaly wwith previous citation, needs checking]

I'm worried that the "Dunedin Sound" will begin to parody itself very soon. (May 17, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),68)

DIX Four Dunedin bands - the Chills, Sneaky feelings, Stones and Verlaines - contributed three songs each... The development of these four groups was the yardstick by which outsiders would follow the growth of the 'Dunedin Sound'. (1988,Stranded in Paradise,287)

Empty white-sand beaches, the very good university and the famous "Dunedin Sound" pub music attract people too. (Nov 1991,North & South,74)

Cited by many as the headlining band of a "new Dunedin Sound", Hellzapoppin' has entered the national chart at no 24. (Apr 13, 1992,Salient,12)

Dunedin Sounders¶

n. (See Dunedin Sound)

Which would be more camps than the Dunedin Sounders had when they confronted the industry nearly 20 years ago. (Aug 12, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36)

Dunedinite¶

n. one born or resident in Dunedin

W.T.SMITH ... the 11 of All-England and the 22 of Otago, and as a matter of course the Dunedinites were beat. (Feb 9, 1864,Diary) [NOTES: 1864 Feb 9 W.T.Smith's Diary (South Otago) Hocken Library MS (Griffiths Collection)]

INGLIS The Dunedinites ... have rather arrogated to themselves the reputation of being preternaturally knowing, ... (1887,Our NZ Cousins,224)

DAVIDSON It was sometime in the sixties, when young Dunedinites were full of blood and deviltry ... (1889,Stories of NZ Life,11)

BATHGATE I have wandered some way from the amusements of the Dunedinites in the 'sixties. (1925,Random Recollections,18)

LYON In early Dunedin large shoals of barracouta were easily caught and sold at sixpence or less for a fish ... No wonder the old Dunedinite of a former generation referred to them, those wide-jawed and projecting toothed long fish, as `Old Identities'. (1952,Faring South,131)

REED They found the evening a little chilly, and even the Dunedinite found the warm glow acceptable (1961,North Cape to Bluff)

BAXTER I see him as a Dunedinite. (1985,Horse,122) [NOTES: 1967 Baxter The Man on the Horse in 1985 Horse 122]

MITCHELL Dunedinites think of Auckland as another country. Aucklanders advise South-bound trippers to take enough overcoats ... for the South Pole. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,33)

McGILL I didn't ask the Dunedinites if they knew what was playing at the Court in Christchurch. (1985,G'day Country,173)

SLIGO Each brick ... was dense with the thickness of the Dunedinites' lives. (1987,Final Things,172)

A Dunedinite, Michael Abbott, is pitting himself against the worst that the wilds can throw at him ... (Feb 14, 1989,Press, The,6)

BATHGATE There is nothing, however, in the natural situation or general aspect of the townitself which recalls the "Modern Athens," although a Dunedinite might well exclaimwith Scott " mine own romantic town." (1874,Colonial Experiences,13)

There is a modicum of truth in the Dunedinite's facetiousness. (Mar 20, 1926,NZ Observer,2)

The Dunedinites were supposed to attack at daylight, which was 5 a.m., but they didn't turn up till 5.30 a.m. (Dec 1916,Roll Call,30)

Flying Nun'ophiles and Dunedinites can rattle on at you for hours about how wonderful The Puddle are. (Feb 27, 1993,Evening Post,25)

An enraged Dunedinite is a fearsome creature to behold and is capable of inflicting severe damage. Over 100,000 of these beasts in a stampede would strike a chill into the bravest heart. (Aug 13, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

You Dunedinites are well off; you can go on every day and see it [sc. the Exhibition]. (Feb 27, 1890,Otago Witness,42)

The four Dunedinites arrived just when the fish had gone off the feed. (Dec 21, 1920,Otago Witness,41)

The tact of the Dunedinite was not on a par with that of the world's most famous diplomats. (May 21, 1910,NZ Truth,3)

[Hdg] Dunedinite in Wales. (May 4, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,69)

The Dunedinites are gearing up to see Otago thump North Harbour. (Sep 27, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,3)

Dunedinitis¶

n.

The Scottish settlement's contribution is"Fergy Forester", and he never let's usforget that fact. He suffering"Dunedinitis". (Oct 16, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/4 : 83)

dung-duster¶

n. a topdressing pilot

GREEN "Chris" Christoffells, the engineer at Rotorua, painted a typically English pub sign, The Dung Duster's Arms", and this hung in a prominent place behind the bar. Ibid 315 In the days when topdressing meant tiger moths many farmers were critical of how the fertiliser spread on the ground. They saw the superphosphate dust fall from the aircraft but it quickly settled on the grass and vanished from sight. A few pilots were astute enough to see the sprinkling of superphosphate on the cow dung in the paddocks. The farmers were called over to admire the dusting. So naturally topdressing pilots became "dung busters." (1983,Topdressers, The,141)

1 n. (Rural) an aerial top-dressing pilot.

GEELEN After each long and dusty day the James topdressing pilots returned to Rotorua aerodrome and quenched their thirst at the old Geyser Hotel, Whakarewarewa. "Chris" Christoffels, the engineer at Rotorua, painted a typically English pub sign, The Dung Duster's Arms, and this hung in a prominent place behind the bar. (1983,Topdressers, The,141)

GEELEN Dung Dusters Delight, with the compliments of James Aviation Limited. [miniature bottle of whisky presented to special customers] (1983,Topdressers, The,309)

GEELEN A few pilots were astute enough to see the sprinkling of superphosphate on the cow dung in the paddocks. The farmers were called over to admire the dusting. So naturally topdressing pilots became "dung dusters." (1983,Topdressers, The,315)

dung-dusting¶

n. (informal) aerial topdressing

BOOTH They started [aerial work] with just this top-dressing - dung-dusting, the boys call it - ... (1961,Long Night,109)

dung-out¶

2 n. a clearance or clear-out

More intriguingly, this dungout suggests panic on the part of the producers - though about what, who could say? (Dec 2, 2000,Dominion,25)

Well, her famous dung-out speech, in which she urged tired old hands to make way for new talent, was code for a leadership spill if anyone was game. (Oct 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

This [party] list is not a wholesaledungout, but rather a subtle revolution. (Jun 16, 1996,Sunday Star Times,C2)

Have a dungout of your advisers in a furtive way, issuing euphemistic explanations for getting rid of people, like 'disestablishing the position' and 'restructuring'. (Dec 9, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Even the historic dungout of centre-right councillors from the Auckland City Council is being read in two totally contradictory ways. (Oct 23, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

We gave the house a real good dung out, but the children were still waking up. (Nov 3, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,4)

This means that, given half a chance, other ministers will have wholesale dung-outs of their least popular portfolio responsibilities. (Aug 9, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

The Treaty of Waitangi is one of the biggest such barrels, with the slowest-moving fish - as evenMaori Affairs Minister Parekura Horomia seemed ready to concede yesterday, as Parliament considered his dung-out of the Waitangi Fisheries Commission. (Aug 24, 2000,Dominion,2)

He'd look a big meanie, if he had an honest dung-out. (Jan 26, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Mr Lange is far from being alone inwishing for a dungout of those who aremore "centre" than "left". (Jun 25, 1995,Sunday Star Times,C2)

dung-staining¶

1 n. (Rural) [pen-staining] the marking of wool by dags and dung prior to shearing.

HENDERSON Dung-staining of wool can be kept to a minimum by ordinary good management. Dung-staining of wool during yarding and penning for shearing is all too common. (1968,Growing Better Wool,94)

dunger¶

n. [usually old dunger, aka dunga. This headword buildings, but see also dunger vehicles and machines]

She says memories born in the Ohariu house will remain including spending her first six months in what she describes as a "dunga", heavily pregnant up a ladder working on their "small house in a paddock". (Mar 24, 2003,Norwester,2)

Jarvis remembers the days when the local real estate agents would pop in for a drink after work and they'd crow, "I sold another old dunga today. My shout!"... Some of the old dungas must have been virtually afloat. (Oct 29, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

Richard Long That would have added to the simmering resentment about his other Christchurch home truths: that it was "blindingly obvious" that some parts of the city were unrepairable and that some of the "old dunger" buildings needed to be demolished so the city centre could be rebuilt. There are some Cantabrians who, irrespective of cost and long-term safety standards, would painstakingly rebuild the old dungers brick by brick. (Jun 28, 2011,Dominion Post,B4)

"Quite frankly, people have died in the last earthquake trying to save old buildings. We're not going to do that any more. My absolutely strong position is that the old dungas, no matter what their connection, are going under the hammer." (Mar 1, 2011,Dominion Post,A2) [NOTES: Gerry Brownlee re Chch earthquake]

Newtown, Berhampore and Island Bay are the worst spots for old "dungers". (Nov 18, 1992,Contact (Wgtn),1)

n. something old or unreliable, esp. an old car; something worn out or not of the first class; often collocated old dunger. [aka dunga; this headword vehicles and machines; see also old dunger buildings]

Judge P.J. Bate said Rawhiti might have made an initial mistake in purchasing a car which in common parlance might be called a `dunger', but he had gone about things in the wrong way. (Mar 24, 1982,Evening Post,8)

And Crump has written another book, using his old dunger' of a typewriter which he describes asa real antique' ... (Nov 30, 1983,NZ Truth,23)

`Those cars, doesn't matter whether its a brand new Mercedes, or an old dunger, are all somebody's pride and joy. (Apr 7, 1983,Dominion,7)

D. HILDRETH Very surprised at your not having heard the word dunger', which has been familiar to me since secondary school - 15odd' years [sc. since 1968]. In my experience it's usually used of a car which is old, battered and, I think importantly, noisy. (Oct 1983,Personal Communication)

dunger: an old bicycle (pron. as in dung er); a common South Island term, almost of endearment, for one's bicycle (1981,Rangiora High School 1884-1984) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

McGILL dunga, dunger trrouble, in phr. in the dunga; perhaps extension of the word dung'. - dilapidated object, such as house, car or contraption, from engine goingdunga, dunga, dunga', the word serving to indicate the object is useless. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,41)

There would be a few "old dungers" parked at stations around New Zealand, he said. (Oct 17, 2003,Dominion Post,A5)

What we learnt was: people often want to sell their car, and usually it's because they want the money; sometimes they don't sell it straight away and often they don't get as much money as they want; and sometimes you buy an old dunga cheaply and do it up. (May 5, 1999,Capital Times,00) [NOTES: Check page]

The judge then asked about the 18 "dunger" vehicles registered in Gray's name. (May 2, 2003,Dominion Post,A6)

It's not quite the Orient Express but the Tranzalpine is up-market by New Zealand Railway standards. Quite a change after some of the old, outdated dungers that New Zealanders put up with when they travelled by rail. (Feb 1989,North & South,18)

"I didn't want it to look like a dunga," he says. (Oct 12, 1999,Independent Herald (Wellington),7)

You were either one of us -caring, leftwing types who drove old dungers - or you were one of them... (Jan 29, 2006,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),20)

Held just before Christmas the lads prepare for demolition day finessing their beaten up dungers into race-ready machines by taking chainsaws to the tyres to get traction, and getting the whole family to apply the appropriate war paint to the chariot. (Oct 28, 2005,Dominion Post,B5)

Mr Dewes has purchased "an old dunger" tractor, a rotary hoe and a potato digger from his own funds, but says the return on his investment has been more than achieved. (May 2005,Kokiri Paetae,16)

He is seen driving a dunger of a girl's car instead of the flash rental he showed off on the way to visit Boogie. (Jun 5, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

The reason, quite patently, is that Tranz Rail always buys big dunger ferries that carry trains to span its main trunk line. (Jun 21, 2003,Dominion Post,C2)

The All Black machine - and we're talking the off-field money-making one here, not the on-field dunger that has clearly misfired in recent times - is churning out the money like a printing press. (Nov 3, 2000,Evening Post,32)

She gingerly climbed on to the back of a sulky - if you could call it that. It was a real "dunger", made from rusty pipe and borrowed, like her ropey old harness. (Nov 12, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B16)

We had to take out a commercial motor vehicle policy on our old dunger of a station wagon because we used it to carry all the boys' equipment. (May 1980,In Touch (Wellington),7)

2 n. (informal) a (big old) surfboard

In hindsight, the two boards I owned - the first an oversized "goat boat" or "dunger" in surfer-speak - seem secondary to the real, standard surfer equipment: the roof-racks. (Feb 29, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),4)

He learnt to swim at Te Mahia school and his Dad taught him to surf on "a big old dunger of a board". (Aug 15, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,11)

dungery¶

adj.

There was much underdog-style rejoicing when the government decided to fatten up the Army, after its years of short-sheeted service overseas with dungery old utes and pre-war radios. (Sep 8, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

dungy¶

adj. covered or spattered with dung

So the fingers plucking at the sub-standard wool are high speed, precision instruments flashing in on some fluffy leg wool here or a piece of dungy crutching there and flicking it off to the appropriate bin. (Jun 1996,Mana,No.13: 60)

dunite¶

n. a mineral from Mt Dun in Nelson; a NZ mineral, a kind of olivine [See cit. 1883. [chk Hochstetter] (geologists' ca1946 p.c. Prof. R. Clarke (Victoria University) Probably the most well-known of NZ-named minerals.']

HOCHSTETTER [Dun Mountain, Nelson] consists of a very peculiar kind of rock, of a yellowish-green colour when recently broken, but turning rusty-brown on the surface when decomposing. The mass of the rock is olivine ...; it is distinguished from serpentine for which it was formerly taken, especially by its greater hardness, and its crystalline structure. I have called it Dunite. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),474)

HECTOR Chrome ore. This ore, which is a mixture of chromic iron and alumina, is chiefly associated with magnesian rock, resembling olivine in composition, named Dunite by Dr. Hochstetter.' (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,56)

This mineral is a massive variety of olivine through which grains of chromite are scattered. A specimen from the Dun Mountain, Nelson, was first described by Dr V. Hochstetter (New Zealand), 1863, Eng ed, p475) ... (1883,TrNZI,15/392) [NOTES: (S.H. Cox)]

MORRIS Dunite ... an ore in New Zealand, so called from Dun mountain, near Nelson. (1898,Austral English,132)

The less important [is] ... near the celebrated Milford Sound, in Fiordland. This locality is remarkable owing to the presence with the platinum of that peculiar nickel-iron mineral awaruite. In appearance it is not unlike platinum, and was mistaken by the miners for that mineral. ... Both the metal and the awaruite occur in a district composed ... of serpentine and dunite. (1911,TrNZI,43/451)

McLINTOCK His [Dr. Ferdinand R. Von Hockstetter's] name `dunite' for the olivine rock of Dun Mountain is firmly established. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/92)

dunite n. N.Z. iron ore. [from Dun Mountains, near Nelson N.Z.]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),8)

A large Sydney firm is at present interesting itself in the deposits of dunite, a mineral containing copper, on Dun Mountain in the Nelson district. (May 19, 1939,Taranaki Herald,4)

CHAPPLE Above Nelson in 1851 the Austrian geologist Ferdinand Hochstetter held a piece of heavy red rock in his hand and named it dunite. (2002,Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail,1,71 ed.)

They described their finds and gave them names based on the local geography - dunite from Dun Mountain, and the semi-precious Rodingite from the Roding River. (1990,Tramping in South Island Forest Parks,16)

Dunk and Davey¶

n. a children's game

SUTTON-SMITH There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. West Coast: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; Ibid. 264 Other games are Humpty Dumpty (known as Dunk and Davey in the 1920s), Kick the Tin, and Hot Rice. (1981,History of Children's Play,231)

dunnekin¶

n. [also dunnican]

They soon came out saying that the water was pouring in forward through the Dunnekin and that everything was afloat; we were pitching heavily, the water came in through the hawse holes, and then through the hatch in the Dunnekin. (Oct 23, 1837,Journal of Ensign Best,142,1966 ed.) [NOTES: [Voyage Out]]

TURNER Thus, to go beyond the several examples already given in the book, cack and dunnekin survive in New Zealand as well as Pitcairnese (though in New Zealand, as in Australia, the shorter dunny is much commoner than dunnekin now), but presumably these are independent survivals. (1968,Anglia,86/359)

LYNN ... we built a little dunnican out in the paddock with a three by two rail, so there was not much more we could wish for. (1982,Under the Lynnwood Tree,75)

It wasn't an ignominious defeat (although they would have been out for a row of dunny cans under FPP). (Dec 11, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

Dunners¶

n. (informal) Dunedin [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

Such is my introduction to the university town known as Dunners, where grilled cheese with onion is considered a delicacy and one of the big events on the calender is the annual nude rugby match. (Jul 6, 2011,Dominion Post,Travel 15) [NOTES: Keep in spite of original Sydney source]

Don't try Dunners, theyre just as dry down there, just ask someone from dunedin, they may have one good hookup, but theyre lucky ones. (Apr 6, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.norml.org.nz/postt136.html]

dunnock¶

n. Hedge sparrow Prunella modularis

FALLA et al. HEDGE SPARROW Prunella modularis Local names: Dunnock, Hedgie. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,215)

dunny¶

n. lavatory, toilet, loo [ca1910 at least W.H.B. Orsman vide the `Old King Cole' rhyme extant when he was a schoolboy. A version of the rhyme had been applied earlier to one Blackburn, the Havelock nightcartman. Old King Cole was a merry old soul/ And a merry old soul was he;/ He called for a light in the middle of the night/ To go to the W.C./ The wind blew round the dunny door,/ The candle took a fit,/ Old King Cole fell down the hole/ And came up covered in shit.]

GEE I wrote a poem about him squatting on the dunny ceiling watching us shit. (1992,Going West,153)

CURNOW How small/ Are the terrible doors; how sad the dunny/ And the things you drew on the wall. (1962,Small Room with Large Windows, A,4) [NOTES: 1941 Curnow `Country School' in 1962 A Small Room with Large Windows 4]

The outside dunny, coarse grass and our chance to sleep in the tent. (Dec 1996,North & South,104)

IRELAND In the 1930s there were still outside dunnies in many suburbs of Auckland, some with weekly nightsoil collections, and indoor lavatories were just beginning to replace them (1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,58)

Hosking, machine-gun voiced, calls adunny a dunny. (May 11, 1996,Evening Post,13)

Admittedly, he had suffered under an era of editors who said things such as, "When Muldoon goes to the dunny, I want you down there, looking up!" (Nov 21, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

You can't avoid having a working relationship with the wildlife, whether it's frogs down the dunny, geckos in the rafters,.. or green ants visiting in the night. (Jan 9, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

If the dunnies at parliament could only talk, what tales they'd tell - of those who never wash their hands; forget to flush; of the furtive puffing of leafy substances. (Mar 19, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A11)

At least they could hold forth for hours at a time on the subject of the things they went without, the first fridge they ever saw, when dunnies went indoors, ingenious ways with left-over bottle tops and that lovely Lord Cobham, the former governor-general whose speeches they so adored. (Jul 7, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A11)

While other airlines are dropping from fortune's skies like bluebottles in a sprayed dunny, Qantas alone is flying high. (Oct 20, 2001,Evening Post,18)

I said 'Follow your nose,' and of course he ended up in the dunnies didn't he. (Jun 23, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

Loose forwards and other crafty bastards will ensure they are in the dunny when the money is collected and miraculously re-appear when the beer arrives. (Sep 10, 2003,Capital Times,17)

Who, by then, will be able to tell whether TVNZ was heading down the dunny anyway? (Feb 26, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

The great mystery is how they persuade these people to go on national television and have their most intimate business outside the dunny and the bedroom so ruthlessly exposed. (May 27, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

HILLIARD She delighted in giving cheek to the boys and taking refuge in the girls' dunny. (1960,Maori Girl,iii 19)

Three models contemplating the rigours of life on the road while posed against the wall of a public dunny in 1963 is another classic. (Mar 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

The name is apt enough, for the decayed little kainga sits near the tip of a long flat stretching out southward from the peninsula; ... (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 23)

Hide went to the dunny, at the same time as a union official and, according to Hide, the official asked - presumably because the urinal was extremely small - whether Hide minded if he followed him in. (Mar 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

HENDERSON Dragons, yellow scaly ones, from an old black-covered Whitcombe and Tombs book, lurked to devour small boys at the lavatory or "codge". Why codge instead of dunny I have never known. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,11)

The country's most disgusting long drops, most beautiful dunnies and the people who use them are to feature in a new television documentary. (Oct 2, 2000,Evening Post,16)

...the thought of Jeanette Fitzsimmons involved in a climactic consummation doesn't bear thinking about, does it? Such an act might shake the self-composting Coromandel dunny to its very foundations. (Aug 17, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

HENDERSON Please don't burn our dunny down / Father has promised to pay... / If you burn our dunny down / We'll all have to read in the yard. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,197) [NOTES: c 1936]

Helen Wilson plays dunny patron one. (Aug 4, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F7)

HENDERSON There were the sad little dunnies with bracken growing high around them. (1969,Open Country Calling,273)

[Hdg] Men & Gentlemen. An Investigation into the Condition of the Auckland Public Dunny. (Oct 1982,Metro,99)

New Zealand is still the land of the milk-can dunny. (Sep 28, 1992,Salient,32)

Number eight (4mm thick) wire formed kitchen implements, latched a million dunny doors, and dried the nation's laundry. (Aug 28, 1992,Dominion,23)

HAWES I always scrub the dunny after I've been, that's why the seat's always up. (2000,Dream of Nikau Jam, The,103)

A trestle or two across the road; an outdoor dunny as a sentry box; and vigilant Whangamomonian guards demanding $2 for the passport they're about to issue me with. (Nov 20, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Poor Nats. For five years it's been their boast that only they could give New Zealand high-level access to Washington, that only Bolger would get to use the White House dunny. (Mar 26, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

On the Beehive's seventh floor, province of senior Cabinet ministers. the toilets have been declared "MPs only", forcing staff to use dunnies on lower floors. (Apr 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

But is the party really down the dunny, or just lurking in the S-bend ready to spring back? (May 23, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

ADSETT As they passed the old dunny again, one of the men gave it a playful shake and said something about Westminster Abbey. Dunny, a mildly impolite word for a privy, ... In New Zealand, it is mainly a playground word, especially among the smaller children. among the smaller children. [?Has this def. got separated from its dateline??] (1963,Magpie Sings, A,102)

CASEY Weatherboard getting dingy as a dunny, corrugated iron rusting round the nails. (1963,As Short a Spring,154)

TURNER Thus, to go beyond the several examples already given in the book, cack and dunnekin survive in New Zealand as well as Pitcairnese (though in New Zealand, as in Australia, the shorter dunny is much commoner than dunnekin now), but presumably these are independent survivals. (1968,Anglia,86/359)

SLATTER Hiding in the dunny when the headmaster wanted him. (1968,Pagan Game, The,230)

DUGGAN He has his job to do. Yes. Slushing in the dunny. (1970,O'Leary's Orchard,161) [NOTES: (Riley's Handbook)]

BAXTER Dark as a dunny the under-runner/ The green flax plaited for whiplashes/ (1979,Collected Poems,122,1952 ed.)

SUTHERLAND The dunny was a small house over a hole in the ground. (1978,Elver, The,33)

WILLIAMS You remind me of old Ma Palmer, mate, when I was replacing a few weatherboards on her dunny. (1979,Skin Deep,30)

LELAND Dunny. (see: TOILET) (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,35)

dunny: toilet (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

dunny: loo (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

HENDERSON From veneration inside, the catalogue in time passed outside, to hang from a nail in the dunny, now but a grey gaunt skeleton a little further up the hillside but still commanding the same commendable view. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,35)

LYNN One local builder ... gave instructions to one of his old carpenters to build the dunney for a job, ... The old Privy ... WC ... Lavatory ... Dunney ... Netty ... (1982,Under the Lynnwood Tree,125)

LANGDALE-HUNT There were no flush toilets, only the `Old Dunny' in the backyard, both in town and country with the only difference that a vehicle called a night cart called in town in latter years, ... (1985,Last Entail Male,65)

RICHARDS The dunny was still in the same place, ... but was now hidden ... by a prolific banana-passionfruit bearing vine. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,140)

dunny n. NZ & Austral. sl. lavatory; an outside earth closet. [abbr. of Eng. cant dunnakin] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,233) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 346; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 150]]

SLIGO She heard the door to the [outside] dunny open and shut. (1987,Final Things,179)

HARTLEY For a different visual encounter we had only to visit the lavatory (our family called it the `lav', others preferred the terms dunny or outhouse) outside ... (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,43)

McGILL dunny toilet, a shortened form of English wotrd dunnyken', a night cart, fromdanna', shit. Among many calls upon the word in c/ps: - swings like a dunny door cricket term for a free-swinging and perhaps inept batsman. ANZ. Refer `bangs like a dunny door'. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,41)

dunny (outside toilet) Ibid. 6 I hated it there. My first time I hid in the dunny for about an hour. But she usually gave me a good feed - savs or snarlers, and sometimes a whole chip of strawberries. And fizzy drink instead of cordial. (1988,University Entrance English,3)

Dunny N.Z outdoor toilet (1989,Chosen Place,104)

TAYLOR What're dunny holes?' ...Dunny holes are loos. They used to have them in the olden days,' ... (1986,Shooting Through,42)

GEE When she caught me hiding in the hedge by the dunny where he was trumpeting away like a Salvation Army band she slapped my face. (1972,In My Father's Den,19)

dunny box¶

n. the housing for an outdoor privy

JOHNSTON `Dunny box for a new long drop,' Hec grunted and continued with his work. (1981,Fish Factory,175)

dunny brush¶

n.

MARSHALL Arty couldn't meet our eyes as the car pulled away. `What a dunneybrush he turned out to be,' said Mathew [sic], and we laughed. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,62)

Chatterton passed a hand over his own stiff, grey hair. A dunny brush, he'd heard it called. (Jul 25, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49) [NOTES: (Marshall A Day With Yestermen)Also in 1989 Marshall Divided World 12]

dunny budgie¶

n. (humorous) a fly

Now, on to an even more basic subjectthan love or jealousy: flies - or dunnybudgies as a friend with a colourfulgrasp of the language calls them. (Mar 1, 1995,Capital Times,8)

dunny paper¶

n. toilet paper

SLIGO Their cavalcade passed by, streaming with pink dunny paper ... (1987,Final Things,88)

There is no shortage of power, water, dunny paper or anything vital - except rugby tickets. (Jun 15, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

Most of us would be hard-pressed to think of a private beach, aside from the perennial topic of dunny-paper magnate John Spencer's pile. (Aug 30, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

HAWES 'We're int6o dunny paper territory.'... Ibid. 17 'The dunny paper's stopped.' (2000,Dream of Nikau Jam, The,12)

dunny rat¶

n. cf. shithouse rat

HULME ... Joe tells her, adding with a laugh that Simon has the luck of a proverbial dunny rat. (1983,Bone People, The,220)

dunny rose¶

n. a trailing rose grown to hide or beautify an outdoor dunny.

FRAME They had a nice trellis-work too, with dunny roses growing up it. (1951,Lagoon, The,55,1961 ed.) [NOTES: [My Cousin's]]

FRAME I drew aside the curtains by `Dad's seat' and looked out along the path to the cypress tree and the old dunny with its dunny roses spilling in a mass of white buds over the corrugated tin-hat roof. (1985,Envoy from Mirror City,167)

Let alone the joy when it's your go at last and you can "swing high as the dunny roses"... (Sep 17, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),108)

Dunny rose, / Macrocarpa hedge, / and the orchards / where my girl-mother / picked apples / through hot summers / have gone. (Feb 7, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65)

FRAME Along the path from the lean-to, the 'dunny' beside the cypress tree and soon known as 'the cypress', was covered with the small fragrant roses known to us as 'dunny roses', and was without a door, while the dunny seat, long and wide like a beach dunny, was set over a deep hole half-filled with old 'kiki' (our word for faeces) in varying shades of brown, topped with faded pieces of newspaper, the Oamaru Mail and the Otago Daily Times. (1984,Angel at My Table, An,51)

dunnyhouse¶

n. (See dunny)

... its window revealing a red-painted dunnyhouse under the macrocarpas. (1983,Landfall,147/124)

durbrain¶

n. a silly or useless person; a fool [?related to smoking derbs and supposed effect on brain]. [1984 17 F E59 Pakuranga Coll. 1 DURBRAIN [a silly person] white buds over the corrugated tin-hat roof. Cf also dunny b. attrib.]

durry¶

v. to smoke (illicitly) [(schoolboys') 1960 18C M B11 Nelson Boys C. 21 DURRY [TO SMOKE A CYGARETTE]]

n. a roll-your-own cigarette [1987 Dr C. Corne p.c. Shakespeare Tavern, Auckland a rolled cigarette, a derb 1984 16 F E30 Pakuranga Coll. 33 DURREY [CIGARETTE] -->1984 16 M E81 Pakuranga Coll. 33 DURRY [M3] -->1984 17 M E112Pakuranga Coll. 33 DURRY [SMOKING] -->1984 17 F E54 Pakuranga Coll. 33 DURRY: HAVE A DURRY [M2] -->1984 17 M E107Pakuranga Coll. 33 DURRY: HAVE A DURREE -->1984 17 M E115Pakuranga Coll. 33 DURRYING [F2M1]]

McGILL He had worked out of Christchurch ... he said as he [120] carefully rolled a durry. (1985,G'day Country,119)

McGILL durry cigarette, usually roll-your-own, the making often called durries, perhaps associated with Bull Durham brand tobacco. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,41)

MARRINER 'Keep the durries; I reckon you'll be needing them more than me.' (2001,Stonedogs,332)

There was I, watching King of the Hill, blowing smoke rings and feeling lower than a snake's belly on account of recently falling prey to the durry again, and there on the screen were Hank and wide Peggy, admonishing son Bobby who'd just been caught smoking his first cigarette. (Oct 24, 1998,Evening Post,21)

Simple rules for survival: no pimping (telling tales), no stealing another's durries (smokes), no chatting up another guy's girlfriend, and no pooftahs. (Apr 2000,North & South,130)

His brother George VI was a decent enough stick who, with the aid of a strong wife (the centenarian Queen mother), and several packs of durries a day, got us safely through World War 2. (May 9, 2001,Capital Times,2)

"Got a durry?" (Aug 14, 2000,Salient,No. 17 : 19)

dusky¶

n. short for dusky dolphin q.v.

[I] am suddenly the focus of attention for three of the little duskys who are swimming aroundand under me... At one stage we see a group of four duskys mating. (Jan 17, 1994,Evening Post,11)

dusky beech¶

n. Nothofagus fusca

LAING & BLACKWELL Nothofagus fusca Dusky beech (1906,Plants of NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

dusky dolphin¶

n. Lagenorhynchus obscurus

The inquisitive dusky dolphins would come to investigate the divers and play with them. (Jul 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 58/33)

Without searching, we were surrounded by hundreds of dusky dolphins. (Jul 11, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,10)

The dusky dolphin (Lagenorhynchus obscurus) is perhaps as plentiful round the coast of New Zealand as the common porpoise. It can be distinguished from it by the falcate dorsal fin and the more pointed snout. It is black above and white below, with an oblique white band on the flanks. (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/140) [NOTES: (Oliver)]

DOOGUE & MORELAND DUSKY DOLPHIN ... Other names: Lagenorhynchus obscurus. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,304)

To the south and further out are the larger and more acrobatic Dusky dolphins. (Feb 1982,North & South,10)

dusky plover¶

n. (Charadrius obscurus) New Zealand dotterel, tuturuwaka

COLENSO Here ... the Dusky Plover (Charadrius obscurus) and the Southern Godwit ... were in large flocks. The natives call the former, Tuturuwaka [check ?-wata]. [1959 ed fn] Dusky Plover or New Zealand Dotterel ... (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excurs Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 44]

  1. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [si], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

dusky shearwater¶

n. = sooty shearwater? (Puffinus griseus, the muttonbird)

BIRDS' EGGS WANTED .. Dusky Shearwater ... (Sep 20, 1905,Otago Witness,88)

dust¶

n. the dust, miners' phthisis or silicosis.

McARA Dust: Quartz dust was a major menace to the health of miners. It blocked up the microscopic air-sacs in the lungs, producing hardening of the tissues and impairing the function of the lungs. Eventually, sometimes after many years, death resulted. The disease miners' phthisis was commonly called `the dust.' It gradually came to an end after the indroduction of axial-water-feed drills. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),320)

n. gunpowder [(whalers' ?technical jargon)]

WAKEFIELD Dust `gunpowder' (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/318)

2 n. gold-dust

The gold is in dust and nuggets. ... The implement most effectual in economising labour is the `Long Tom', or trough strainer, cradles are but of little comparative service. (Dec 10, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/30/183) [NOTES: (Heaphy's Report)]

SWAINSON The dust consisted of flaky gold, of a pale lemon colour, largely intermixed with auriferous quartz, the separation having been effected only by washing in the simplest manner. Ibid. 109 These parties also brought up from the same spot various other specimens; one parcel of which, consisting of large rich dust and flakes, and exceedingly auriferous quartz (perhaps as rich, gaudy specimens as have yet been seen), was sold by auction by the undersigned yesterday. (1853,Auckland,106) [NOTES: 1852 Dec 13 Gold Circular in 1853 Swainson Auckland 106]

HYDE Hadn't so much as a pick, he hadn't, and when he came down again he was carrying his dust in a sugar-sack on his back. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,54)

3 n. a kauri-gum grade, gum-dust

The chief factor influencing sales and prices of kauri-gum in recent years has been the rquest for the poorer qualities, called chips' anddust'. (Aug 1916,Chambers Edinburgh Journal,542/1) [NOTES: [OED2 chip]]

STALLWORTHY At one time the dust, and scrapings, of the gum were not saleable ... Since then there has always been a price of some sort for all dust and scrapings. (1916,Early Northern Wairoa,54)

... it is no doubt also responsible for the dark coloured varnishes produced from the chip grades. [fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, orchalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content. (1936,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,17/371)

McLINTOCK An increasing demand for poorer grades of gum [after 1900], used in making linoleum, made it profitable to search for smaller gum: nuts',chips', seeds', anddust'. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/207)

REED The [1920 Kauri Gum Industry] report stated that during the preceding few years the proportion of low-grade gum, chips and dust (scrapings) had increased in volume ... to about two-thirds of the total gum exports. (1972,Gumdiggers, The,82)

MALCOLM The scrapings [sc. of gum] were kept and sold as 'dust', the bigger pieces were known as 'nuts' and the biggest as 'bold'. (1982,Where it all Began,110)

In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,41) [NOTES: check whether "nuts" or "nubs"]

dusted¶

adj. suffering from silicosis [miners']

RICHARDS The greatest occupational hazard of mining was the dust. ... Drilling was all done dry in those days. The air was laden with particles of flint and quartz, ground to the consistency of flour. ... Once a man was `dusted', there was no cure. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,5)

duster¶

n. a thief

Then they started their series of thefts. ...I notice that there has been a lot of `dusters' working over there recently, but these men are the first we have got of them. (Nov 2, 1912,NZ Truth,384/6/2)

n. an aerial topdresser

Country Calendar Bruce has been a duster for years. (May 5, 1982,TV1)

n. a blackboard eraser

LELAND Duster. When you were a kid did your teacher ever give you the job of taking the BLACKBOARD ERASERS outside and beating them together creating great interesting clouds of chalk dust? Things are no different in New Zealand, except they are called dusters. This term is also used for dustcloths. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,36)

dustie¶

n. rubbish collector, dustman

As far as he was concerned the waterside workers were less than the dusties; they were damaging the country. (Jul 10, 1972,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16/5)

Ferocious dogs, dangerous sliver of glass ... are obstacles faced every day by men of the Wellington rubbish carts. But anyone who thinks these rubbish men (or dustmen or `dusties' as they're sometimes called) don't earn their money, should spend a morning with a crew. (May 17, 1975,Evening Post,93)

DUSTIES SEEK SUPPORT. Wellington City Council refuse collectors are petitioning the public ... (Feb 2, 1982,Dominion,3)

Wellington dusties returned to work yesterday morning after reaching agreement with the city council on a dispute that stopped rubbish collections for two days. (Jul 9, 1986,Dominion,4)

Excuse me,' Susan broke in,would somebody mind telling me what a garbo is?' `Sorry Susie. What they say in Oz. A dustie,' Nicholas explained. (1987,Islands,38/133) [NOTES: (Beveridge)]

I'd seen you all at the pub I had taken to frequenting, the local Maori crim, bus drivers', dusties' pub. (1987,Metro Fiction,6) [NOTES: (Keogh, Chiaroscuro)]

No one told me that the dusties collectedthe rubbish around the back. Early. Andno one told the dusties that a whiterobed flailer was not a kehua, a ghost. (Jun 8, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

Dusties will stop collecting rubbish from the back door of the house from 1 October. (Jul 8, 1993,City Voice,1)

[Hdg] Former dustie switches to sales... After a brief spell studying mechanical engineering at night school, then driving trucks.. [he] looked round for something more challenging. (Sep 7, 2000,Evening Post,Real Estate Suppl. 21)

Everyone left their full cans at the edge of the footpath for the men we called the 'dusties'. (Aug 2005,NZ Memories,55 / 29)

Dustpan¶

n. [(Boer War spec or local)]

HALL The column moved on through Barberspan and Leeuwpan. [fn] The New Zealanders soon had good reason to name this unpleasant locality `Dustpan.' (1950,New Zealanders in South Africa,50)

dusty miller¶

n. Senecio cineraria [Wild, exotic but fully naturalised as per nzflora.landcareresearch.co.nz]

BOSWELL He laughed when he saw her gathering up the pretty, furry `dusty millers' as they scurried across the path and placing them on Mother's flowers ... (1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,50)

dusty miller [s] Senecio cineraria L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)

[he] first met "dusty millers", as they were commonly known, when he was an apprentice in Invercargill. (Feb 11, 2006,Dominion Post,Indulgence, p21)

Dutch oven¶

n. a camp oven

BARRY A `Dutch oven' has been erected for the purpose of burning the saw-dust and shavings, which are drawn through pipes by means of a powerful suction blast into the furnace. (1966,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,147) [NOTES: 1926 Prospectus of the Waitane Saw-milling and Afforestation Ltd in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 147]

BURTON A refinement of open roasting was the Dutch or camp oven, a 38-centimetre round iron pot with legs and a handle so that it could either stand or hang. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,23)

Dutch shout¶

n. a Dutch treat (See also Parnell shout,Yankee shout)

Dutchie¶

n. A Dutchman, also a German or other middle European [as DNZE, but in SOED (Dutchy) so not a NZism]

SLATTER And in peace the civilians must have something to hate too. The Dutchies or the Pommies or the Doolins or somebody. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,60)

MASTERS Mr. Jock Anderson, ..[116]. , arranged to met [sic] a new-Dutchman, ... As he came onto a small bluff he called out. The Dutchie responded ... (1960,Back-Country Tales,115)

Dutchman¶

n. In early NZ applied as elsewhere to any North European, esp. to a sailor. Also as an appellation or nickname (Dutch Charlie, Dutch Harry, etc.). Compare Scandy.

Many expressed regret when the blasted Dutchman' succeeded in clearing his name. The tendency to call every foreignera Dutchman' is well known and amazing. (May 29, 1909,NZ Truth,205/5/2)

BEATTIE Take `Dutch Harry' for instance. His name was Henry Wickson (or Wixon), and it was said he was an Austrian and came from Memel. ... To the whalers any foreigner was Dutch so that is how he got his nickname.] (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,47)

EADDY Quite a number of the trading scows were manned wholly with Scandinavians. They were very clannish, these people, and should a Dutchman' as they were always dubbed, be appointed master of any scow, generally speaking, that vessel would eventually be manned entirely byDutchmen.' (1939,Neath Swaying Spars,26)

Duvaucel's gecko¶

n. (Environment) NZ's largest remaining gecko, now limited to island populations. Long-lived, sometimes exceeding 40 years. [Hoplodactylus duvaucelii]

[Caption] Among the 14 or so species of reptile on Little Barrier are Duvaucel's gecko (at up to 25 cm, including the tail, one of the largest geckos in the world), the very rare chevron skink (found only on Little and Great Barrier Islands), and the Pacific gecko... (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/13)

Conservator Rob McCallum said the extermination of rats would lead to a dramatic return of some wildlife, including tuatara. lizards, insects, giant wet and Duvaucel's gecko, and a threatened burrowing seabird, the Cook's petrel. (Jun 11, 2004,Dominion Post,A7)

Jenny Jones Named after an early French naturalist in 1836, Duvaucel's gecko is a brown gecko. It is the largest New Zealand species. (2002,Lizards,28)

Indeed, rare species such as Pycroft's petrel, Duvaucel's gecko and the New Zealand native cucumber are all showing signs of regaining their foothold on these islands. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,10)

dwang¶

n.

SALMOND dwang a short piece of framing timber fixed tightly between studs, to which lining materials are fixed (1986,Glossary of Building Terminology,232)

In the night its beams, joists and dwangs emit loud cracks. (Apr 23, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

The interior walls of farm garages revealjoists, braces and dwangs in full workingorder. (Jan 30, 1993,Dominion,10)

dwarf¶

adj. as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants, see astelia, bedstraw, cabbage palm, cabbage tree, carmichaelia; fern, comb-fern; gorse, grass, mountain bent; grass, ring; heath, kowhai, mallow, mazuz, mistletoe, montia, musk; nettle, nightshade, pine, poa, polypody, tainui.

dwarf astelia¶

n. Astelia linearis

COCKAYNE Astelia linearis Dwarf astelia (1909,AJHR,C-12 (And)) [NOTES: Botanical Survey Stewart Island]

dwarf beard¶

n. cavers' technical term for a limestone waterfall

The walls around us bristle with stalactites and stalagmites. Some are fragile, like spun glass, others solid Greek columns. Sometimes they join together to form intricate chandeliers, curtains and "dwarf beards" - waterfalls of white rock frozen in mid-air. (Apr 1997,NZ Geographic,No. 34/34)

dwarf cabbage tree¶

n. Cordyline pumilio.

COCKAYNE (And) Cordyline pumilio. dwarf cabbage tree (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

COCKAYNE (And) Cordyline pumilio. dwarf cabbage tree (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

(And) Cordyline pumilio. dwarf cabbage tree (1925,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

BURTON There is now little doubt that the primary migration to New Zealand ... brought the Maori food plants from an eastern Polynesian homeland, ... These plants were the island yam (Dioscorea esculenta), the bottle gourd, the taro, a dwarf type of cabbage tree and the kumara. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,3)

dwarf false musk¶

n. Mazus pumilio

COCKAYNE Mazus pumilio dwarf false musk (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

dwarf kowhai¶

n.

COCKAYNE (And). Sophora prostrata (1915,AJHR,C-6) [NOTES: Plant Covering Kennedy's Bush (Canterbury)]

dwarf kowhai [=] prostrate kowhai [s] Ibid. 42 kowhai, dwarf [=] prostrate kowhai [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)

dwarf mistletoe¶

2 n. (Environment) one of three dwarf or leafless semi-parasitic indigenous mistletoes Korthalsella salicornioides, Korthalsella lindsayi, or Korthalsella clavata . (See all entries for mistletoe,Maori mistletoe,white mistletoe,etc)

The dwarf mistletoes also choose a range of hosts although Korthalsella salicornioides favours mainly kanuka and manuka. (Jul 2005,Open Space,No 64)

WILSON Korthalsella salicornioides DWARF MISTLETOE ... Tiny green to yellow-green, jointed leafless parasite forming tufts or bunches on twigs of manuka. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,62)

Dwarf mistletoes are found mostly on coprosma, kanuka and manuka. They often go unnoticed because they are so small, but they are distributed throughout the country. (Sep 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 59/60) [NOTES: Check ref.]

dwarf montia¶

n. Montia verna

dwarf montia [s] Montia verna Necker 50 montia, dwarf [s] Montia verna Necker (1967,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)

TAYLOR DWARF MONTIA (Montia fontana spp. chondrosperma). This European plant is widespread in New Zealand, and present in many pastures, ... (1980,Weeds of Crops,40)

dwarf pine¶

n. [aka dwarf-pine, pygmy pine; Lepidothamnus laxifolius previously Dacryidium laxifolius]

COCKAYNE The Dwarf-pine (Dacrydium laxifolium), which on the dry pumice soil has assumed the cushion-form. (1910,NZ Plants,104)

DWB¶

abbr. driving while black [ORIGIN: acronym] (See driving while black)

Some reported being frequently pulled over by police for no particular reason, dubbed the "DWB" or "driving while black" phenomenon, the students found. (Oct 8, 2005,Dominion Post,A10)

dwell time¶

n.

Capacity on the same piece of port land varies depending on how high containers are stacked and how long each container "dwells" or stays at a port. It inceases if containers are stacked higher or if dwell time is shorter. (Oct 24, 2005,Dominion Post,C3)

When Ms Elton joined CentrePort the average dwell time (time on the wharf) for a container was 15 days. (Aug 20, 2001,NZ Infotech Weekly,15)

dwelling dancer¶

n. [Compare stairdancer.]

PARTIDGE A burglar, esp. a transient lodger that pillages boarding-houses:Australian: since ca. 1910. Baker 1945. Cf. dancer, 6,of which it is prob. an elaboration - and an alteration insense. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,218)

DWF¶

abbr. Distribution Workers Federation

Particular ensitivity surrounds this case (the second to be brought within the first month of the new industrial relations legislation) because of the position of the Distribution Workers Federation (DWF). (Aug 26, 1987,National Business Review,1)

dwindles¶

n.

Speaking of Norman Kirk, Bob Tizard said "At times he was perfectly lucid [in Cabinet]; at other times he would wander off into a fit of the dwindles". (Aug 31, 1999,Radio NZ / National Radio,Kim Hill Show)

dyer's eyebright¶

n. (See eyebright)

dyer's weed¶

n. mignonette

HILGENDORF MIGNONETTE (Reseda luteola) is called wild mignonette, scentless mignonette, giant mignonette and dyer's weed. It is not uncommon in fields and waste places in both islands. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,96,1967 ed.)

dyer's weed, [=] wild mignonette [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,23)

dyke¶

n. [goldmining; aka dike]

SWAINSON In the detritus on the sides of the mountains, and in the beds of the stream, quartz occurs in detached blocks of various sizes, mixed with fragments of slate, granite and trap; but regulardykes of quartz are not generally met with, although they are reported to exist. (1853,Auckland,91)

DYKE.- A wall-like intrusion of igneous rock into a fissure. (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,54)

Near Carricktown, however, several dyke-like outcrops were found, locally known to the miners as `dykes'. They are not dykes, but outcrops of hard, bluish-grey, flinty or horny quartz, often much slickensided on one wall. (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.5 (NS) 29) [NOTES: (Park, Cromwell)]

One vertical dyke of solid whitish stone of moderate hardness, cuts the line of the tunnel at an oblique angle, and I have seen some indications of a second intersecting dyke. (Mar 9, 1859,Lyttelton Times,3)

Another feature analogous to this coal-field is, that in this hill is a dyke, apparently descending vertically through the strata, of a beautiful conglomerate of slate and quartz, and which I have never before seen at this elevation. (Apr 10, 1863,Colonist, The)

n. a privy [aka dike]

A john' means a cop, not a toilet, and the [38] latter is sometimes called (between men only) adyke' or `house of parliament'. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,37)

HILLIARD But the dyke's in the bathroom. (1960,Maori Girl,74)

TURNER I have heard it suggested that ... the vulgar dyke for `urinal' is used in Ireland, ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,11)

HILLIARD Everything from a light bulb to the wringer to the ball-cock in the dyke. (1978,Glory and the Dream, The,196)

BAXTER The new guitar of sex I kept on twanging/ Inside the iron virgin/ Of the little smelly dyke, ... (1979,Collected Poems,250,1962 ed.) [NOTES: (1962) 1979 Baxter Collected Poems 250]

They make you put your head in a tuck locker. Or go in the Drying Room ... If you stay on the dike you can not [sic] be tested. (1972,Islands,1/14) [NOTES: Henderson (Freedom's Ramparts)]

A corrupt man can sit on a dike and watch [27] a tree beginning to blossom in the yard ... (1972,Islands,1/26) [NOTES: Baxter (Elegy for Boyle Crescent)]

dynamite pill¶

n. Cascara sagrada (three-grain) tablet takento ease constipation, Compare depth-charge. [ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream. ca1941 Trentham Military camp.]

dyno¶

n. dynamite

dyno: dynamite (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection)]
